I am sent to bring comfort to the mourners in Zion, and to give them a crown instead of ashes, the oil of joy instead of mourning, and a garment of praise instead of a spirit of heaviness and despair. They will then be called mighty oaks of righteousness, a planting of the Lord for His own glory.

(Isaiah 61:4) 
They will rebuild the ancient ruins that have been desolate for ages. They will restore the cities that were laid waste and scattered throughout many generations.

(Isaiah 61:5) 
And foreigners will stand ready to tend your flocks. The children of strangers will be your farmers and your vinedressers, helping you with your labor.

(Isaiah 61:6) 
But you, the redeemed people, will be called priests of the Lord. You will be named ministers of our God, serving Him in His holy temple. You will feed on the strength and wealth of the nations, and you will glory in their splendor.

(Isaiah 61:7) 
Instead of the double shame and disgrace you have endured, your people will praise their portion. Because of this, they will possess double in their own land, and everlasting joy will be theirs.

(Isaiah 61:8) 
For I, the Lord, love justice and hate robbery and injustice, even when offered as a burnt offering to me. Therefore, I will truly give them their reward, and I will make an everlasting covenant with them.

(Isaiah 61:9) 
Their offspring will be known among the nations, and their descendants among the peoples. All who see them will recognize them, that they are the offspring whom the Lord has blessed.

(Isaiah 61:10) 
I will greatly rejoice in the Lord. My soul will exult and triumph in my God, for He has clothed me with the garments of salvation and wrapped me in the robe of righteousness. He has adorned me like a bridegroom with a garland, and like a bride bedecked with her jewels.

(Isaiah 61:11) 
For just as the earth brings forth its sprouts, and just as a garden causes its seeds to grow, so the Lord God will cause righteousness and praise to spring forth before all the nations.

(Isaiah 62:1) 
For the sake of the City of God, I will not be silent. For the sake of the people of Jerusalem, I will not rest, until her righteousness shines forth like brilliant light, and her salvation burns brightly like a lamp.

(Isaiah 62:2) 
Then the nations will see your righteousness, and all kings will behold your glory. You will be called by a new name, a name that the mouth of the Lord Himself will declare.

(Isaiah 62:3) 
You will be a crown of splendor in the hand of the Lord, a royal diadem in the right hand of your God.

(Isaiah 62:4) 
You will no longer be called 'Forsaken', and your land will no longer be called 'Desolate'. Instead, you will be called 'My Delight is in Her' (which means God takes pleasure in you), and your land 'Inhabited'. For the Lord Himself takes delight in you, and your land will be settled with people.

(Isaiah 62:5) 
For just as a young man settles down with a virgin, so your sons will settle and live within you. And just as a bridegroom rejoices over his bride, so your God will rejoice over you.

(Isaiah 62:6) 
Upon your walls, O Jerusalem, I have placed watchmen. All day and all night, they will never be silent. You who bring the Lord to remembrance, never be silent.

(Isaiah 62:7) 
And do not give Him any rest, until He establishes Jerusalem and makes her a city praised throughout the earth.

(Isaiah 62:8) 
The Lord has sworn by His right hand and by His mighty arm: 'I will no longer give your grain as food for your enemies. Foreigners will no longer drink the wine for which you have toiled.'

(Isaiah 62:9) 
Instead, those who harvest the grain will eat it and praise the Lord. And those who gather the wine will drink it in the courtyards of My holy sanctuary.

(Isaiah 62:10) 
Go out, go out through the gates! Prepare the way for the people! Make the highway level, clear away the stones! Raise a banner for all the nations!

(Isaiah 62:11) 
Behold, the Lord has made a proclamation to the furthest ends of the earth! Say to the Daughter of Zion: 'Behold, your Savior comes! His reward is with Him, and His just recompense is before Him.'

(Isaiah 62:12) 
And they will be called 'The Holy People', 'The Redeemed of the Lord'. And you, O Jerusalem, will be called 'Sought Out' and 'A City Never Forsaken'.

(Isaiah 63:1) 
Who is this one coming from the land of Edom, his garments stained crimson from the city of Bozrah? Who is this one, so glorious in his robe, marching forth in the fullness of his power? He answers, “I am the one who proclaims righteousness, and I am a mighty defender to save.”

(Isaiah 63:2) 
So why then are your garments red, and your robes like those of someone treading grapes in a winepress?

(Isaiah 63:3) 
I alone have trodden the winepress, and of all the nations, there was no one with me to help. I trampled them down in my burning fury, and I crushed them in my hot wrath. Their lifeblood splattered upon my garments, and I have stained all my clothing with it.

(Isaiah 63:4) 
For the day of vengeance was determined in my heart, and the year for my people’s deliverance and retribution upon their enemies has now come.

(Isaiah 63:5) 
I looked all around, but there was no helper; I sought, but there was no one to assist. So my own mighty arm brought me victory, and my fierce indignation sustained me and gave me strength.

(Isaiah 63:6) 
And I trampled down entire nations in my fury, and I overwhelmed them with my indignation as if they were drunk. And I brought their power crashing down to the earth.

(Isaiah 63:7) 
I will recount the manifold mercies of the Lord; I will sing praises to the Lord for all He has bestowed upon us. I will recall the abundance of good things He has given to the house of Israel, which He bestowed upon them according to the greatness of His compassion and the multitude of His tender mercies.

(Isaiah 63:8) 
And He said: “Surely they are My people, My children who will not prove false to Me.” And so, He became their Savior.

(Isaiah 63:9) 
In all their affliction, He Himself was not afflicted, for the angel of His presence saved them. In His boundless love and His tender compassion, He personally redeemed them. He carried them and lifted them up throughout all the days of the ages.

(Isaiah 63:10) 
But they, in turn, rebelled and grieved His Holy Spirit. So He turned against them as an enemy, and He Himself fought against them.

(Isaiah 63:11) 
Then He remembered the days of old, the days of Moses and His people. The Lord asked, “Where is He who brought out from the sea the shepherds of His flock? Where is He who placed His Holy Spirit within them?”

(Isaiah 63:12) 
It was He who led Moses by his right hand, by His glorious majestic arm. He divided the waters of the sea before them to make for Himself an everlasting name for all time.

(Isaiah 63:13) 
He led them through the deep waters as easily as a horse walks through the desert without stumbling.

(Isaiah 63:14) 
Just like cattle returning to their pasture, the Spirit of the Lord was their guide. In this way, You led Your people, to make for Yourself a glorious name.

(Isaiah 63:15) 
Look down, O Lord, from the highest heavens, and behold us from Your holy and glorious dwelling place. Where is Your zealous care and Your mighty power? Where are the multitude of Your tender mercies and Your deep compassion? Are they now withheld from me?

(Isaiah 63:16) 
For You alone are our Father. Even if Abraham did not know us, and Jacob did not acknowledge us, You, O Lord, are our Father, our Redeemer! From all eternity, this is Your name.

(Isaiah 63:17) 
Why, O Lord, have You allowed us to wander from Your ways? Why have You hardened our hearts so that we no longer revere You? Turn back, we pray, for the sake of Your servants, the tribes of Your own inheritance.

(Isaiah 63:18) 
Why have You momentarily brought low Your holy people? Our enemies have now taken possession of Your holy sanctuary.

(Isaiah 63:19) 
We have become as though we were from the very beginning, when You had not yet ruled over us, and Your name was not yet invoked upon us.

(Isaiah 64:1) 
If only you would tear open the sky and come down to us, the mountains would melt away at your presence and power!

(Isaiah 64:2) 
Just as a fire burns away brushwood, and as a roaring fire makes water boil, so too would these mountains vanish and be utterly consumed. Do this so that you might make your power known to your enemies, and the nations would be terrified at your presence.

(Isaiah 64:3) 
When you have performed awesome, terrible deeds, we have waited for your appearance. You have descended in the past, and the mountains melted away at your presence and power.

(Isaiah 64:4) 
Since the beginning of time, no one has heard, no ear has perceived, no eye has seen, O God, any other god but you who has prepared such wonders for those who wait for you.

(Isaiah 64:5) 
You come to meet those who rejoice in doing what is right and just. They will remember you as they walk in your paths. But truly, you were angry, and we sinned against you. We have remained in our sins and have been living in them constantly. Yet, even so, we trust that we shall be saved!

(Isaiah 64:6) 
Indeed, all of us have become like something ritually unclean, and all our supposed good deeds are like a soiled, discarded cloth. We have all withered and fallen away like a leaf, and our sins, like a strong wind, have swept us away into darkness.

(Isaiah 64:7) 
There is no one among us who truly calls upon your name, no one who truly rises up to seek and take hold of you. You have hidden your presence from us, and you have crushed us and delivered us into the power of our own sins.

(Isaiah 64:8) 
And yet now, O Lord, you are still our Father. We are merely the clay, and you are our divine Potter. All of us are the complete work of your own hands.

(Isaiah 64:9) 
Do not be angry beyond measure, O Lord, and please do not remember our sins forever! Look upon us, we beg you—we are all your own people.

(Isaiah 64:10) 
Your holy city has become a desolate wasteland. Zion itself has become a barren wilderness. Jerusalem is utterly destroyed.

(Isaiah 64:11) 
The very Temple, the house of our holiness and our glory, where our fathers praised you, has been utterly consumed by fire. And all our precious, desirable things have been reduced to rubble and ruin.

(Isaiah 64:12) 
Despite all these things, O Lord, will you continue to hold yourself back? Will you remain silent and afflict us so severely, allowing us to be utterly destroyed?

(Isaiah 65:65:1) 
Those who had not previously asked Me, searched for Me. Those who had not sought Me, found Me. I said, 'Here I am! Here I am!' to a nation—meaning the Gentiles—that never called upon My name.

(Isaiah 65:65:2) 
I continually extended My hands all day long to a disobedient people—My chosen nation, Israel—who walked in a path that was not good, choosing to follow their own rebellious thoughts.

(Isaiah 65:65:3) 
This is a people who constantly provoke My anger right before My face. They offer sacrifices in pagan gardens and burn incense on altars made of bricks, instead of honoring Me according to My law.

(Isaiah 65:65:4) 
These are people who dwell in tombs and sleep in pagan shrines, seeking to consult the dead. They eat the flesh of swine and have the broth of unclean things in their vessels—all of which are an abomination to Me.

(Isaiah 65:65:5) 
These are the ones who say, 'Keep away from me, do not come near me, for I am holier than you, and you would make me unclean!' Such people will be like smoke, consumed by My fiery anger, a fire that burns continuously throughout the day.

(Isaiah 65:65:6) 
Behold, it is written before Me: I will not remain silent, but I will surely repay. I will give them the full measure of their just retribution into their very laps.

(Isaiah 65:65:7) 
Your wickedness, along with the wickedness of your fathers together, says the Lord, who offered pagan sacrifices upon the mountains and publicly insulted Me upon the hills—I will repay the full measure of all their past sins into their laps.

(Isaiah 65:65:8) 
This is what the Lord says: 'Just as when a cluster of grapes is found to have one good grape, people say, 'Do not destroy it, for there is a blessing within it,' so also will I do for the sake of My faithful servants, so that I will not utterly destroy all of My people.

(Isaiah 65:65:9) 
And I will bring forth a remnant from Jacob, and from Judah will come those who inherit My holy mountains. My chosen ones will possess this land as their inheritance, and My faithful servants will live there securely.

(Isaiah 65:65:10) 
And the plains will become lush pastures for flocks of sheep, and the Valley of Achor—once a place of trouble—will become a peaceful resting place for herds of cattle. This will be for My people who have faithfully sought Me.

(Isaiah 65:65:11) 
But as for you who have abandoned the Lord, you who have forgotten My holy mountain of Zion, you who set a table in honor of the pagan god of Fortune, and who prepare wine offerings for the pagan goddess of Destiny—

(Isaiah 65:65:12) 
I will count you out for the sword, and all of you will fall in a great slaughter. This is because when I called, you did not answer; when I spoke, you did not listen. Instead, you did what was evil in My sight and deliberately chose what greatly displeased Me.

(Isaiah 65:65:13) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord God says: 'Behold, My faithful servants will eat and be satisfied, but you who rebelled will hunger. Behold, My servants will drink and be refreshed, but you will thirst. Behold, My servants will rejoice with gladness, but you will be put to utter shame.

(Isaiah 65:65:14) 
Behold, My servants will sing praises with overflowing joy from their hearts, but you will cry out with bitter sorrow in your hearts, and you will wail from the crushing despair of your spirit.

(Isaiah 65:65:15) 
And you who rebelled will leave your names as a curse and an oath for My chosen ones—meaning, 'May God do to me what He did to them.' The Lord God will put you to death, but He will call His faithful servants by a new name, signifying their new identity in Him.

(Isaiah 65:65:16) 
So that whoever is blessed upon the earth will be blessed in the God of Truth, and whoever takes an oath on earth will swear by the God of Truth. This will happen because the former troubles and sorrows are completely forgotten and hidden from My eyes forever.

(Isaiah 65:65:17) 
For behold, I am about to create new heavens and a new earth—a completely renewed creation. The former things, filled with sorrow and sin, will not even be remembered, nor will they ever come to mind.

(Isaiah 65:65:18) 
Instead, you will rejoice and be utterly exultant forever in the things that I am creating. For behold, I am creating Jerusalem to be a source of great rejoicing, and her people to be a source of profound joy.

(Isaiah 65:65:19) 
And I Myself will exult in Jerusalem and rejoice in My people. In that renewed city and among My people, the sound of weeping and the sound of distressful crying will never be heard again.

(Isaiah 65:65:20) 
In that time, there will no longer be an infant who lives only a few days, nor an old person who fails to complete the full measure of their years. For the one who dies at a hundred years old will be considered a mere child; but the sinner who lives a hundred years will still be cursed and face judgment.

(Isaiah 65:65:21) 
They will build houses and live in them securely. They will plant vineyards and enjoy their fruit.

(Isaiah 65:65:22) 
They will not build a house for someone else to live in; they will not plant a vineyard for someone else to eat its fruit. For the days of My people will be like the days of the Tree of Life itself, and they will fully enjoy the work of their hands.

(Isaiah 65:65:23) 
They will not labor in vain, nor will they bear children destined for trouble or calamity. For they and their descendants are the blessed offspring of the Lord, and their grandchildren will remain with them.

(Isaiah 65:65:24) 
And it will be that even before they call out to Me, I will hear them. While they are still speaking their prayers, I Myself will immediately answer them.

(Isaiah 65:65:25) 
The wolf and the lamb will feed together in peace, and the lion will eat straw like the ox—its predatory nature transformed. As for the young serpents, dust will remain their food, signaling the final triumph over evil. There will be no harm or destruction anywhere on My holy mountain of creation, says the Lord.

(Isaiah 66:1) 
The Lord says these things: "The entire universe is My throne, and the earth is where I rest My feet. What kind of house could you possibly build for Me? And what kind of place could be My resting place?"

(Isaiah 66:2) 
"My hand made all these things, and all of them came into being," declares the Lord. "But who am I going to look upon with favor? Only those who are humble in spirit, those who have a contrite spirit, and those who tremble at My words."

(Isaiah 66:3) 
"Whoever sacrifices an ox, yet has no true devotion, is like someone who murders a man. Whoever sacrifices a lamb, yet has no true devotion, is like someone who sacrifices a dog's brain, which is an abomination. Whoever offers a grain offering, yet has no true devotion, is like someone who offers pig's blood, which is unclean. Whoever burns incense as a memorial, yet has no true devotion, is like someone who blesses an idol. All of these are things they have chosen according to their own corrupted ways, and their souls have delighted in their abominable practices."

(Isaiah 66:4) 
"Therefore, I will also choose their vexations, and I will bring upon them the very things they feared. This is because I called out to them, and there was no one who responded. I spoke, and they did not listen. Instead, they did evil in My sight, and they chose what I did not desire."

(Isaiah 66:5) 
"Listen to the word of the Lord, you who tremble at His word. Your brethren, who hate you and cast you out because of My name, have said, 'Go far from us, for the Lord is honored!' But the Lord will appear in your joy, and those who persecuted you will be put to shame."

(Isaiah 66:6) 
There is a voice of a people crying out from the city. There is a voice crying out from the Temple. It is the voice of the Lord, rendering retribution to His enemies.

(Isaiah 66:7) 
Before she was in labor, she gave birth. Before her pains came, she bore a male child.

(Isaiah 66:8) 
Who has ever heard such a thing? And who has seen things like this? Will a land give birth to an entire nation in one day? Or will a whole people be born all at once? For Zion has travailed and given birth to her children.

(Isaiah 66:9) 
"Will I, who brings to the point of birth, then close the womb and not let her give birth?" declares the Lord. "Or will I, who forms all things, then shut the womb and prevent new life?" says your God.

(Isaiah 66:10) 
Rejoice with Jerusalem, and exult in her, all you who love her. Rejoice with her with joy, all you who mourn over her.

(Isaiah 66:11) 
so that you may nurse and be filled from the breast of her consolation. So that you may draw milk and overflow with delights from her abundant glory.

(Isaiah 66:12) 
For the Lord says these things: "Behold, I will extend peace to Jerusalem like a flowing river, and like an overflowing torrent, the glory and wealth of the nations will come to you, which you will draw from. You will be carried on her sides, and on her knees, you will be tenderly cared for."

(Isaiah 66:13) 
"Just as a mother comforts her child, so will I comfort you. And in Jerusalem, you will find consolation."

(Isaiah 66:14) 
"You will see it, and your heart will rejoice, and your bones will flourish like fresh grass, full of new life. And the hand of the Lord will be known to His servants, but He will show His wrath to His enemies."

(Isaiah 66:15) 
For behold, the Lord will come in fire, and His chariots will be like a whirlwind, to render His fury in indignation and His rebuke in a flame of fire.

(Isaiah 66:16) 
For the Lord will judge with fire and by His sword He will judge all flesh, and many will be slain by the Lord.

(Isaiah 66:17) 
"Those who sanctify themselves and purify themselves in the gardens, following one among them in secret rituals, those who eat swine's flesh, and abominable things, and even mice—they will all be consumed together," declares the Lord.

(Isaiah 66:18) 
"For I know their works and their thoughts. I am coming to gather all nations and tongues. And they will come and see My glory."

(Isaiah 66:19) 
"And I will set a sign among them. And from those who are saved among them, I will send them to the nations by the sea: to Africa and Lydia, nations known for their skilled archers; to Italy and Greece; to distant islands, to those who have not heard of Me and have not seen My glory. And they will declare My glory among the nations."

(Isaiah 66:20) 
"And they will bring all your brethren from all nations as an offering to the Lord, conveyed on horses, in chariots, in litters, on mules, and in wagons, to My holy mountain Jerusalem," declares the Lord. "This will be just as the sons of Israel bring their offering in clean vessels into the house of the Lord."

(Isaiah 66:21) 
"And I will also choose some of them, even from the Gentiles, to serve as priests and as Levites," declares the Lord.

(Isaiah 66:22) 
"For just as the new heavens and the new earth, which I am making, will stand firm before Me," declares the Lord, "so also will your offspring and your name stand firm forever."

(Isaiah 66:23) 
"And it will be that from one new moon to the next new moon, and from one Sabbath to the next Sabbath, all flesh will come to worship before My face," declares the Lord.

(Isaiah 66:24) 
"And they will go out and see the corpses of the men who transgressed against Me. Their worm will not die, and their fire will not be extinguished. And they will be a terrifying spectacle to all flesh, a perpetual warning against sin."

(Jeremiah 1:1) 
These are the prophetic words of Jeremiah, son of Hilkiah, who was one of the priests from the town of Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin.

(Jeremiah 1:2) 
The Word of the Lord first came to him in the thirteenth year of the reign of Josiah, son of Amon, king of Judah.

(Jeremiah 1:3) 
It continued through the reign of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah, and lasted until the eleventh year of Zedekiah, son of Josiah, king of Judah, when Jerusalem was carried away into exile during the fifth month — this was the full duration of his prophetic ministry.

(Jeremiah 1:4) 
Then the Word of the Lord came directly to me, saying:

(Jeremiah 1:5) 
“Before I created your physical form in your mother’s womb, I knew you. And before you were born, I consecrated you to My service, appointing you as a prophet to all the nations.”

(Jeremiah 1:6) 
But I said: “Oh, Lord God! I cannot speak for You, for I am but a youth and I don’t know what to say.”

(Jeremiah 1:7) 
But the Lord said to me: “Do not say, ‘I am a youth.’ For wherever I send you, you shall go, and everything I command you to say, you shall speak.

(Jeremiah 1:8) 
Do not be afraid of anyone’s presence, because I Myself am with you to deliver you,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 1:9) 
Then the Lord stretched out His hand and touched my mouth — an act of divine commissioning and empowerment. And the Lord said to me: “Behold, I have now put My very own words in your mouth.

(Jeremiah 1:10) 
Look! Today I have given you authority over nations and over kingdoms. You are to uproot nations, tear them down, destroy them, and overthrow them through your prophecies. And you are also to build up and to plant new beginnings through your prophecies.”

(Jeremiah 1:11) 
Then the Word of the Lord came to me again, saying: “Jeremiah, what do you see?” And I answered: “I see an almond branch” — the first tree to wake and blossom in spring, symbolizing God’s watchful readiness.

(Jeremiah 1:12) 
And the Lord said to me: “You have seen well! For I Myself will be watchful over My word to ensure that I perform it.”

(Jeremiah 1:13) 
The Word of the Lord came to me a second time, saying: “What do you see now?” And I said: “I see a boiling pot, and its mouth is tilted from the north,” indicating the direction from which the judgment will come.

(Jeremiah 1:14) 
Then the Lord said to me: “Calamity and evil will be unleashed from the north upon all the inhabitants of this land.

(Jeremiah 1:15) 
For behold, I am summoning all the families of the kingdoms of the north,” declares the Lord. “And they will come, and each one will set his royal throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem. They will also attack all its surrounding walls and all the cities of Judah.”

(Jeremiah 1:16) 
I will then pronounce My judgments against them for all their wickedness. They abandoned Me, offered libations to foreign gods, and worshipped the idols made by their own hands.

(Jeremiah 1:17) 
Therefore, you, Jeremiah, must prepare yourself for action. Arise and speak to them everything that I command you. Do not be afraid of their presence or dread their faces,

(Jeremiah 1:18) 
“—for behold, I have made you today like a fortified city, an iron pillar, and a bronze wall against the entire land — against the kings of Judah, its princes, its priests, and the people of the land.

(Jeremiah 1:19) 
They will fight against you, but they will not prevail over you, because I am with you,” declares the Lord, “to deliver you from them.”

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:1) 
And the word of the Lord came to me, saying:

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:2) 
Go and proclaim to Jerusalem, saying: The Lord declares: "I remember your devotion from when you were young, and the great love you had for Me when we were first espoused. You followed Me through the wilderness, through land that was not cultivated."

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:3) 
Israel was consecrated to the Lord, the very firstfruits of His harvest. Anyone who tried to destroy Israel was found guilty and brought disaster upon themselves, the Lord declares.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:4) 
Listen to the word of the Lord, O house of Jacob, and all the families within the house of Israel:

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:5) 
The Lord declares: "What injustice did your ancestors find in Me that made them abandon Me? They pursued empty idols and became empty themselves."

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:6) 
They did not ask: "Where is the Lord who brought us up from the land of Egypt? Where is the One who led us through the wilderness—through a desolate and impassable land, through a land of drought and the shadow of death, a land where no one journeyed and no human dwelled?"

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:7) 
I brought you into a fertile land—a garden paradise—to enjoy its fruits and its goodness. But when you entered, you defiled My land and made My inheritance an abomination.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:8) 
Even the priests did not ask: "Where is the Lord?" Those who were supposed to teach the Law did not truly know Me. The leaders of the people rebelled against Me. The prophets spoke in the name of Baal and pursued worthless idols.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:9) 
Therefore, I will again bring a charge against you, declares the Lord. I will contend with your children's children, and they will answer for your sins.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:10) 
Cross over to the coasts of the Cypriots and observe! Send messengers to Kedar and carefully consider if anything like this has ever happened!

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:11) 
Has any nation ever changed its gods, even though those gods are not real? Yet My people have exchanged their true glory—Me—for an idol that brings no benefit.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:12) 
Be utterly shocked, O universe, at this! Look with horror and be completely devastated, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:13) 
For My people have committed two great evils: they have abandoned Me, the very spring of life-giving water, and they have dug for themselves cracked cisterns that cannot hold water.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:14) 
Is Israel a slave? Or was he born into slavery? Why then has he become prey to his enemies?

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:15) 
Lions have roared over him; they have raised their voices in triumph. They have made his land a desolate wasteland. His cities have been burned to ashes, and no one lives in them.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:16) 
Even the people of Memphis and Tahpanhes—the Egyptians—have utterly disgraced you. They have shaved your head bare, taking away your dignity.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:17) 
Did this not happen to you because you abandoned the Lord your God, at the very time He was leading you on your path?

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:18) 
And now, what do you want for yourself on the way to Egypt, that you may drink the muddy waters of the Shihor? And what good will it do you on the way to Assyria, that you may drink the waters of the Nile?

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:19) 
Your own wickedness will punish you, and your turning away will condemn you. Know and see that it is evil and bitter for you to abandon the Lord your God, and that you have no reverent fear of Me, declares the Lord God of all creation.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:20) 
Long ago, you broke My yoke and tore off My bonds, declaring: "I will not serve You!" Indeed, on every high hill and under every leafy tree, you prostrated yourself like a prostitute.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:21) 
I Myself planted you as a choice vine, an entirely true seed. How then have you turned into a degenerate, wild vine in My sight?

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:22) 
Even if you wash yourself with soda and use much lye soap, the stain of your guilt remains before Me, declares the Lord God.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:23) 
How can you say: "I am not defiled; I have not run after the Baals"? Look at your ways in the valley, understand what you have done! You are like a swift, restive young camel, running aimlessly.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:24) 
You are like a wild ass, accustomed to the wilderness, snorting for passion in her desire. Who can turn her away from her lust? All who seek her will find her when she is in heat.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:25) 
You try to hold your foot back from running bare, and your throat from thirst. But you said: "It's hopeless! No, I have loved foreign gods, and after them I will go!"

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:26) 
Just as a thief is put to shame when he is caught, so the house of Israel will be put to shame—they, their kings, their princes, their priests, and their prophets.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:27) 
They say to a wooden idol: "You are my father," and to a stone idol: "You gave birth to me." They have turned their backs to Me, not their faces. But in the time of their affliction, they will say: "Arise and deliver us!"

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:28) 
Where are your gods that you made for yourselves? Let them rise up and deliver you in your time of affliction! For you have as many gods, O Judah, as you have cities.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:29) 
Why do you want to bring a charge against Me? You have all abandoned Me, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:30) 
In vain I struck your children; they did not accept correction. Your own sword devoured your prophets, like a devastating lion.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:31) 
O generation, consider the word of the Lord! Have I been a wilderness to Israel? Or a land that yields nothing? Why then do My people say: "We have broken free; we will not come to You any more"?

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:32) 
Can a virgin forget her jewelry, or a bride her wedding dress? Yet My people have forgotten Me for countless days.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:33) 
How skillfully you prepare your path to pursue your lovers! So much so that you have taught even the wicked women your evil ways.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:34) 
Even on your clothes, the blood of innocent, poor people is found. You did not catch them breaking into your house; their blood was openly shed for all to see.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:35) 
Yet you say: "I am innocent; surely His anger has turned away from me." Behold, I will bring a charge against you because you insist: "I have not sinned."

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:36) 
How contemptible you have made yourself, so readily changing your paths! You will be disappointed by Egypt, just as you were disappointed by Assyria.

(Jeremiah 2:Jeremiah 2:37) 
Even from there you will go forth with your hands on your head in shame, for the Lord has rejected those you trusted, and you will find no help from them.

(Jeremiah 3:1) 
They have a saying: 'If a man divorces his wife, and that divorced woman marries another man, will she ever return to him? Wouldn't that woman be defiled and stained forever?' Yet you, O Israel, have committed spiritual adultery with many false lovers; nevertheless, return to Me, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 3:2) 
Look up to the barren heights and see where you have not prostituted yourself. You sat by the roadsides, waiting for your lovers, like a highwayman ambushing in the desert, and the land has been defiled by your spiritual adultery and your wickedness.

(Jeremiah 3:3) 
Because of this, the early rains were withheld, and there was no spring rain. You have taken on the shameless face of a harlot; you refused to be ashamed of your sins.

(Jeremiah 3:4) 
Even now you call out to Me, saying: 'My Father, You were the guide of my youth, the One who led me in purity.'

(Jeremiah 3:5) 
Will God be angry forever? Will His wrath endure to the very end? This is what you say, but you continued to do all the evil things you possibly could.

(Jeremiah 3:6) 
Then the Lord spoke to me, saying: 'Have you seen what unfaithful Israel has done? She has gone up to every high mountain and under every green tree, practicing spiritual prostitution there.'

(Jeremiah 3:7) 
And I thought: 'After she has done all these things, she will surely return to Me.' But she did not return to Me. And her treacherous sister, Judah, saw all this.

(Jeremiah 3:8) 
I saw that because unfaithful Israel had committed spiritual adultery, I had divorced her and given her a certificate of divorce. Yet her treacherous sister Judah was not afraid to do the same, but she too went and acted like a prostitute.

(Jeremiah 3:9) 
And with utter disregard, she committed her spiritual adultery. She defiled the land by committing adultery with idols of stone and wood.

(Jeremiah 3:10) 
And in spite of all these warnings, treacherous Judah did not return to Me with her whole heart, but only pretended to repent, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 3:11) 
Then the Lord said to me: 'Apostate Israel has proven herself more righteous than treacherous Judah by comparison.'

(Jeremiah 3:12) 
Go and proclaim these words toward the north, and say: 'Return, apostate Israel!' declares the Lord. 'I will not look on you with anger, for I am merciful,' declares the Lord, 'and I will not remain angry forever.'

(Jeremiah 3:13) 
'Only acknowledge your guilt—that you have rebelled against the Lord your God, and have given your love to foreign gods under every green tree, and have not obeyed My voice,' declares the Lord your God.

(Jeremiah 3:14) 
Return, O wayward children!' declares the Lord, 'for I am your true husband. I will take you, one from a city and two from a family, and bring you to My holy mountain, Zion.'

(Jeremiah 3:15) 
And I will give you shepherds who follow My heart, and they will nourish you with true knowledge and sound teaching.

(Jeremiah 3:16) 
And in those days, when you have multiplied and become fruitful in the land,' declares the Lord, 'people will no longer speak of the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord. It will not come to mind, nor will they remember it or miss it; no new one will be made.'

(Jeremiah 3:17) 
At that time, Jerusalem will be called 'The Throne of the Lord.' And all nations will gather there, to Jerusalem, in the name of the Lord, and they will no longer follow the stubborn evil of their hearts.

(Jeremiah 3:18) 
In those days, the house of Judah will unite with the house of Israel, and they will come together from the land of the north to the land that I gave to your fathers as an inheritance and a place of rest.

(Jeremiah 3:19) 
But I myself said, 'How will I adopt you as My children and give you a desirable land, a glorious heritage among the nations?' And I said, 'You will call Me 'My Father' and will not turn away from following Me.'

(Jeremiah 3:20) 
But just as a wife proves faithless to her husband, so have you, O house of Israel, been unfaithful to Me,' declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 3:21) 
A sound is heard on the barren heights—the weeping and cries for mercy of the children of Israel, because they have corrupted their ways and forgotten the Lord their God.

(Jeremiah 3:22) 
'Return, you wayward children, and I will heal your waywardness.' And they answer: 'Here we are! We come to You, for You are the Lord our God!'

(Jeremiah 3:23) 
Surely, the worship on the multitude of hills and the clamor on the mountains were deceptive and vain. Truly, in the Lord our God alone is the salvation of Israel.

(Jeremiah 3:24) 
And shame has covered what we worshipped on the mountains since our youth: their names, their silver, their gold, their wood, and their stones—all the idols we made.

(Jeremiah 3:25) 
We must lie down in our shame, and our disgrace will cover us. For we have sinned against the Lord our God, both we and our fathers, from our youth even to this very day, and we have not listened to the voice of the Lord our God.

(Jeremiah 4:4:1) 
“If you truly return, O Israel,” says the Lord, “you must turn back to Me completely. And if you remove all your idols from My sight, then you will not be disturbed or cast away.

(Jeremiah 4:4:2) 
Then you will solemnly swear: ‘As the Lord lives!’ and you will do so truthfully, justly, and righteously. And then, the nations who observe this will bless Him, and find their own praise and honor in Him.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:3) 
For this is what the Lord says to the people of Judah and to Jerusalem: “Break up your uncultivated land. Prepare your hearts for a new beginning. Do not sow among thorns, which will choke out any good seed.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:4) 
Circumcise yourselves spiritually for the Lord. Remove the foreskins of your hearts, O men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem. Do this lest My righteous indignation go forth like a fire and burn so fiercely that no one can extinguish it, all because of the evil practices and pursuits you continue.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:5) 
“Announce this throughout Judah and make it heard in Jerusalem! Speak up! Blow the trumpet in the land! Shout urgently and declare: ‘Gather together! Let us retreat into the fortified cities for protection!’”

(Jeremiah 4:4:6) 
“Raise a warning flag in Zion! Brace yourselves! Do not stand still or hesitate, because I am bringing disaster from the north, a great and terrible destruction.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:7) 
A lion has come up from his lair—a destructive enemy, the plunderer of nations, has been stirred up. He has left his place to make your land a wasteland. Your cities will be devastated, and no one will live in them.

(Jeremiah 4:4:8) 
Because of this coming disaster, put on sackcloth. Mourn deeply and wail aloud, for the Lord’s fierce anger has indeed turned against us.

(Jeremiah 4:4:9) 
“And it will happen on that day,” says the Lord, “that the king’s courage will fail, and the princes’ resolve will collapse. The priests will be utterly astonished, and the prophets will be amazed and confounded.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:10) 
Then I, Jeremiah, said: “Alas, alas, alas, O Lord God! Have You then deceived this people and Jerusalem, by saying: ‘Peace will be for you’? Yet now, behold, the sword of war has reached even to our very souls, bringing death and despair.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:11) 
In that appointed time, it will be said to this people and to Jerusalem: “A scorching wind comes from the desert road, O daughter of My people. It is not a gentle wind to cool you or to cleanse you.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:12) 
A mighty, destructive wind will come to Me from those northern lands. Now indeed, I will speak My judgments and execute them against My people.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:13) 
Behold, the enemy will advance like storm clouds, and his chariots will rush forward like a tempest. His horses are swifter than eagles. Woe to us! For we are utterly devastated!

(Jeremiah 4:4:14) 
Wash your heart clean from wickedness, O Jerusalem, so that you may be saved! How long will these harmful and sinful thoughts dwell within you?

(Jeremiah 4:4:15) 
For a voice is now announcing the approaching danger from Dan, the northernmost tribe. And it is making known the idol-worship from Mount Ephraim, which is the cause of this coming judgment.

(Jeremiah 4:4:16) 
Announce to the nations! Behold, Jerusalem has heard the news through her watchmen: a siege is coming from a distant land! The enemy has raised its battle cry against the cities of Judah.

(Jeremiah 4:4:17) 
Like watchmen guarding fields, they—the invaders—have encircled Jerusalem, because she despised Me, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 4:4:18) 
Your own ways and your evil practices have brought these things upon you. This is your wickedness, because it is bitter in its fruits, and because it has penetrated deep into your very heart.

(Jeremiah 4:4:19) 
My inner being, my inner being is in pain, and my heart aches with anguish! My very core is disturbed within me; I cannot be silent. For my soul has heard the sound of the trumpet, the dreadful sound of the battle cry!

(Jeremiah 4:4:20) 
Destruction upon destruction is announced! All the land is being laid waste. Suddenly my dwelling places are destroyed; in an instant, my tents are in ruins.

(Jeremiah 4:4:21) 
How long must I witness the people fleeing, and hear the terrifying sound of the trumpet?

(Jeremiah 4:4:22) 
“Because My people are foolish, they have not truly known Me. They are senseless children, lacking understanding and wisdom. They are skilled and wise only in doing evil, but they have not learned how to do good.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:23) 
I looked at the earth, and behold, it was desolate and utterly void, like the primordial chaos. And I looked at the skies, and there was no light in them.

(Jeremiah 4:4:24) 
I saw the mountains, and behold, they were trembling. All the hills were disturbed and shaking.

(Jeremiah 4:4:25) 
I looked, and behold, there was no human being. Every bird of the sky had fled away.

(Jeremiah 4:4:26) 
I saw, and behold, the fertile land of Carmel was a desert. Every city belonging to it was demolished before the face of the Lord, and before the terrible wrath of His fury.

(Jeremiah 4:4:27) 
For this is what the Lord says: “All the land will be a desolation. However, I will not make a complete end of it, so that some remnant will remain.”

(Jeremiah 4:4:28) 
Because of this, the earth will mourn, and the skies above will darken in sorrow. This is because I have spoken, I have intended it, and I have not repented of My decision, nor have I turned away from My decree.

(Jeremiah 4:4:29) 
From the sound of the cavalry and the archers, the people fled. They ran into the forests and climbed upon the rocks for refuge. All the cities were abandoned, and no human being remained living in them.

(Jeremiah 4:4:30) 
And you, O ravaged Jerusalem, what will you do now? Though you clothe yourself in scarlet, and adorn yourself with golden jewelry, and paint your eyes with dark kohl, you will adorn yourself in vain. Your former allies and lovers have despised you; they will seek to take your very life.

(Jeremiah 4:4:31) 
For I have heard a voice like that of a woman in labor, the deep distress like one giving birth for the first time. It is the voice of the daughter of Zion, gasping for breath and dying in agony, stretching out her hands in despair. Woe is me! For my soul fails within me because of all those who are slain!”

(Jeremiah 5:5:1) 
Go through the streets of Jerusalem and look, observe, and search in its public places. See if you can find even one person who practices justice and lives faithfully before God. If you can, I will spare the entire city.

(Jeremiah 5:5:2) 
And even when they swear, saying, 'As the Lord lives,' they are swearing falsely in their hearts.

(Jeremiah 5:5:3) 
O Lord, your eyes look for faithfulness in people. You struck them, but they felt no sorrow for their sins. You crushed them with your judgments, but they refused to accept discipline. They have made their faces harder than rock itself and refused to turn back to You.

(Jeremiah 5:5:4) 
But I, Jeremiah, thought: 'Perhaps these are only the poor and foolish people, those who do not know the Lord’s way or the justice required by their God.'

(Jeremiah 5:5:5) 
So I will go to the prominent leaders and speak with them, for they certainly know the Lord’s way and the justice demanded by their God. But look, they too have together broken the yoke of God’s law and have burst His bonds.

(Jeremiah 5:5:6) 
Therefore, a lion from the forest has struck them down. A wolf of the evening has laid waste to them. A leopard watches continually over their cities. Everyone who ventures out from within them will be seized and torn apart. This is because their transgressions have become exceedingly numerous, and their apostasies against God have grown strong.

(Jeremiah 5:5:7) 
Considering all these things, how can I possibly show you mercy, O Judah? Your children have abandoned Me and have sworn their oaths by those who are not gods at all. I filled them with abundance, yet they committed adultery, and they indulged themselves in the houses of prostitutes.

(Jeremiah 5:5:8) 
Every one of them has become like a lustful, neighing horse. Each man whinnies after his neighbor's wife with unbridled desire.

(Jeremiah 5:5:9) 
Shall I not bring judgment for these things, declares the Lord? Or shall My very soul not take vengeance on such a nation as this?

(Jeremiah 5:5:10) 
Go up onto her walls and tear them down, but do not utterly destroy everything. Cut off her branches, for they do not belong to the Lord.

(Jeremiah 5:5:11) 
For the house of Israel and the house of Judah have dealt with Me with extreme treachery, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 5:5:12) 
They have denied the very existence and power of the Lord, saying, 'He is nothing! Evil will not come upon us, nor will we ever see war or famine.'

(Jeremiah 5:5:13) 
The prophets also speak mere wind; there is no divine message from God in their words. Therefore, these judgments will indeed happen to them instead.

(Jeremiah 5:5:14) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord, the God of the armies of heaven, says: 'Because you, O false prophets and people, have spoken this word of denial and falsehood, behold, I am putting My true words, spoken through Jeremiah, into your mouth as a raging fire, and this people will be like wood, and My words will consume them entirely.'

(Jeremiah 5:5:15) 
Behold, O house of Israel, I am bringing upon you a nation from far away, declares the Lord. It is a strong nation, an ancient nation, a nation whose language you will not understand, nor will you be able to comprehend what they say.

(Jeremiah 5:5:16) 
Their quiver is like an open tomb, for all their warriors are mighty.

(Jeremiah 5:5:17) 
And they will consume your harvests and your bread. They will devour your sons and your daughters. They will consume your flocks and your herds. They will devour your vines and your fig trees. And with the sword, they will destroy your fortified cities, in which you place your trust.

(Jeremiah 5:5:18) 
Nevertheless, even in those dreadful days, declares the Lord, I will not make a complete end of you.

(Jeremiah 5:5:19) 
And when you ask, 'Why has the Lord our God done all these things to us?' you shall say to them: 'Just as you abandoned Me and served foreign gods in your own land, so too will you be forced to serve strangers in a land that is not your own.'

(Jeremiah 5:5:20) 
Declare this message to the house of Jacob, and make it heard in Judah, saying:

(Jeremiah 5:5:21) 
Hear this, O foolish and senseless people! You have eyes, but you refuse to see; you have ears, but you choose not to hear.

(Jeremiah 5:5:22) 
Do you not fear Me, declares the Lord? Will you not tremble before My presence? It is I who set the sand as the sea’s boundary, an eternal decree it cannot pass. Though its waves surge and roar, they cannot prevail, and though they swell, they cannot cross over it.

(Jeremiah 5:5:23) 
But this people has developed a stubborn and rebellious heart. They have turned away from Me and have departed from My ways.

(Jeremiah 5:5:24) 
They do not say in their hearts, 'Let us fear the Lord our God, who gives us the seasonal rains, both the autumn and spring showers at their proper time, and who preserves for us the full bounty of the annual harvest.'

(Jeremiah 5:5:25) 
Your iniquities have caused all this abundance to be withheld, and your sins have turned away every good thing from you.

(Jeremiah 5:5:26) 
For among My people, wicked men are found. They lie in wait, just like bird catchers setting snares and traps to capture other people.

(Jeremiah 5:5:27) 
Just as a cage is full of birds, so their houses are full of deceit. And by means of this deception, they have become great and have grown rich.

(Jeremiah 5:5:28) 
They have become well-fed and sleek. They have wickedly ignored My words. They have not judged the cause of the widow, nor have they taken up the case of the orphan, and they have failed to uphold the rights of the poor.

(Jeremiah 5:5:29) 
Shall I not bring judgment for these things, declares the Lord? Or shall My very soul not take vengeance on such a nation as this?

(Jeremiah 5:5:30) 
A dreadful and astonishing thing has taken place in this land.

(Jeremiah 5:5:31) 
The prophets spoke false prophecies, and the priests ruled in agreement with them. And My people loved to have it so! But what will you do then, when the end comes for all of this?

(Jeremiah 6:1) 
Prepare yourselves, O children of Benjamin, and flee from the midst of Jerusalem! Sound the trumpet in Tekoa, and raise a signal over Beth-Haccerem! For a great evil is being seen coming from the north, and a mighty destruction is approaching.

(Jeremiah 6:2) 
I have compared the daughter of Zion—the city of Jerusalem—to a beautiful and delicate woman.

(Jeremiah 6:3) 
Against her will come shepherds and their flocks—these are the invading armies. They will pitch their tents all around her, and each one will graze their flocks in her fields, taking possession of her land.

(Jeremiah 6:4) 
The invaders cry out, 'Prepare for war against her! Rise up, let us attack her at noon!' Then they lament, 'Woe to us, for the day is declining! The evening shadows are growing long!'

(Jeremiah 6:5) 
So they determine, 'Rise up, let us attack by night, and let us destroy her palaces!'

(Jeremiah 6:6) 
For this is what the Lord of hosts says: 'Cut down her trees, and cast up a siege mound all around Jerusalem. This is the city marked for punishment, for all manner of oppression is found within her.'

(Jeremiah 6:7) 
Just as a cistern keeps its water fresh, so she—Jerusalem—has kept her wickedness fresh and flowing. Nothing but violence and ruin will be heard within her walls.

(Jeremiah 6:8) 
Receive instruction, O Jerusalem! Be warned, lest My soul finally depart from you, lest I make you a desolate land, utterly uninhabitable.

(Jeremiah 6:9) 
This is what the Lord of hosts says: 'They will thoroughly glean the remnant of Israel, like grapes in a vineyard, down to the last cluster. Return, you invaders, like a grape-gatherer to his basket, and glean again!'

(Jeremiah 6:10) 
To whom shall I speak? Whom shall I warn so that they might listen? Behold, their ears are spiritually uncircumcised and closed; they cannot hear. Behold, the Word of the Lord has become an object of scorn to them, and they do not accept it.

(Jeremiah 6:11) 
Therefore, I am full of the Lord's wrath; I am weary of holding it in. I must pour it out upon the children in the street, and upon the assembly of young men together. Indeed, I will pour it out upon man and woman alike, upon the old man and the one full of days—even the very aged.

(Jeremiah 6:12) 
Their houses will pass to others, their fields and their wives will be taken together. For I will stretch out My punishing hand upon the inhabitants of this land, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 6:13) 
For from the least of them to the greatest, everyone is given over to greed and covetousness. From the prophets to the priests, all practice deceit.

(Jeremiah 6:14) 
They tried to heal the brokenness of the daughter of My people—Israel—with superficial and shameful words, saying, 'Peace, peace!' when there was no peace at all.

(Jeremiah 6:15) 
They will certainly be put to shame because they committed such abominations. But instead of being ashamed, they were not at all confused by their own wickedness and did not know how to blush. Therefore, they shall fall among those who are falling; in the time of their visitation—their punishment—they shall stumble, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 6:16) 
This is what the Lord says: 'Stand by the ways and look, and ask for the ancient paths. Ask which is the good way, and walk in it, and you will find rest for your souls.' But they—the people—replied, 'We will not walk in it.'

(Jeremiah 6:17) 
And I set watchmen over you, saying, 'Listen to the sound of the trumpet!' But they replied, 'We will not listen!'

(Jeremiah 6:18) 
Therefore, hear, O you nations, and know, O assembly of peoples, how great the judgments are that I will bring upon them!

(Jeremiah 6:19) 
Hear, O earth! Behold, I am bringing calamity upon this people—it is the fruit of their own evil thoughts and plans. For they have not listened to My words, and they have rejected My law.

(Jeremiah 6:20) 
To what purpose do you bring Me frankincense from Sheba, and sweet-smelling cane from a distant land? Your burnt offerings are not accepted by Me, and your sacrifices have not pleased Me.

(Jeremiah 6:21) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord says: 'Behold, I will set stumbling blocks before this people; upon them, fathers and sons shall stumble together. Neighbor and friend shall perish together.'

(Jeremiah 6:22) 
This is what the Lord says: 'Behold, a people is coming from the land of the north, and a great nation shall rise up from the farthest reaches of the earth.'

(Jeremiah 6:23) 
They will grasp bow and shield; they are cruel and will show no mercy. Their voice will roar like the surging sea, and they will ride upon horses, arrayed as a warrior prepared for battle against you, O daughter of Zion—Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 6:24) 
We have heard the report of them, and our hands are paralyzed with fear. Anguish has seized us, and pains like those of a woman in childbirth.

(Jeremiah 6:25) 
Do not go out into the fields, and do not walk on the roads, for the sword of the enemy brings terror and destruction all around.

(Jeremiah 6:26) 
O daughter of My people, gird yourself with sackcloth and sprinkle yourself with ashes! Mourn as for an only son, and make a bitter lament, for suddenly the destroyer will come upon us.

(Jeremiah 6:27) 
I have made you, Jeremiah, an assayer among My people, a strong one. You are to know and test their way—their conduct.

(Jeremiah 6:28) 
All of them are rebellious princes, walking deceitfully. They are like bronze and iron—hardened and thoroughly corrupt.

(Jeremiah 6:29) 
The bellows have blown out, and the lead is consumed by the fire. The refiner has melted the ore in vain, for their wickedness is not consumed or purged away.

(Jeremiah 6:30) 
Call them rejected silver, for the Lord has cast them away as worthless.

(Jeremiah 7:7,1) 
The Lord spoke to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 7:7,2) 
“Stand at the gate of the Lord’s Temple and proclaim this message there. Say, ‘Listen to the word of the Lord, all of you people of Judah, who come through these gates to worship the Lord!’”

(Jeremiah 7:7,3) 
“This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: ‘Amend your ways of living and your daily actions. If you do, I will continue to let you dwell in this place.

(Jeremiah 7:7,4) 
Do not trust in the lies being told when people say, “This is the Temple of the Lord! The Temple of the Lord! The Temple of the Lord!” —as if the building itself will save you.

(Jeremiah 7:7,5) 
For only if you truly amend your ways of living and your daily actions, and if you truly act justly with one another,

(Jeremiah 7:7,6) 
and if you do not oppress the foreigner, the orphan, or the widow, and if you do not shed innocent blood in this place, and if you do not follow after other gods—which would only bring evil upon yourselves—

(Jeremiah 7:7,7) 
only then will I allow you to dwell in this place, in the land which I gave to your ancestors to keep forever.

(Jeremiah 7:7,8) 
But now, look, you are trusting in deceitful words that cannot help you.

(Jeremiah 7:7,9) 
You steal, murder, commit adultery, swear falsely by God’s name, offer sacrifices to the pagan god Baalim, and then go after other foreign gods whom you have no true knowledge of.

(Jeremiah 7:7,10) 
And after all this, you come and stand before Me in this Temple, where My name is invoked, and you say, “We are safe now!” simply because you have committed all these abominations.

(Jeremiah 7:7,11) 
Has this Temple, where My name is invoked by you, become nothing more than a hideout for robbers in your eyes? Yes, I Myself have seen this, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 7:7,12) 
Go now to My former dwelling place in Shiloh, where My name first dwelled among you, and see what I did to it because of the wickedness of My people, Israel.

(Jeremiah 7:7,13) 
And now, because you have done all these wicked deeds, declares the Lord—even though I spoke to you persistently, rising early to speak, but you did not listen; and I called to you, but you did not answer—

(Jeremiah 7:7,14) 
I will do to this Temple, where My name is invoked and in which you place your trust, and to this land that I gave to you and your ancestors, exactly what I did to Shiloh.

(Jeremiah 7:7,15) 
I will cast you out of My sight, just as I cast out all your kinsmen, all the descendants of Ephraim—the northern kingdom of Israel.

(Jeremiah 7:7,16) 
Therefore, you, Jeremiah, do not pray for these people. Do not offer up any praise or prayer on their behalf. Do not plead with Me, because I will not listen to you.

(Jeremiah 7:7,17) 
Do you not see what they are doing in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?

(Jeremiah 7:7,18) 
The children gather wood, the fathers light the fire, and the women knead the dough to make ritual cakes for the “Queen of Heaven” —a pagan goddess. They pour out drink offerings to other foreign gods, all of which provokes My wrath.

(Jeremiah 7:7,19) 
Is it really Me they are provoking? declares the Lord. No, they are only provoking themselves, bringing shame and disgrace upon their own faces.

(Jeremiah 7:7,20) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord God says: “Behold, My fury and My indignation will be poured out upon this place—upon the people, upon the animals, upon the trees of the region, and upon the produce of the earth. It will ignite, and it will not be quenched.”

(Jeremiah 7:7,21) 
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: “Go ahead and add your burnt offerings to your other sacrifices and eat all the meat yourselves—I have no desire for them.

(Jeremiah 7:7,22) 
For when I brought your ancestors out of the land of Egypt, I did not speak to them or command them primarily about burnt offerings and other sacrifices.

(Jeremiah 7:7,23) 
Instead, this is the command I gave them: ‘Listen to My voice, and I will be your God, and you will be My people. Walk in all the ways that I command you, so that it may go well with you.’

(Jeremiah 7:7,24) 
But they did not listen, nor did they pay any attention. Instead, they walked according to their own desires and the stubborn wickedness of their evil hearts. They turned their backs on Me and did not move forward.

(Jeremiah 7:7,25) 
From the day your ancestors departed from the land of Egypt until this very day, I have sent all My servants the prophets to you, tirelessly sending them day after day, rising early to send them.

(Jeremiah 7:7,26) 
Yet they did not listen to Me, nor did they pay any attention. Instead, they stubbornly stiffened their necks and behaved even worse than their ancestors.

(Jeremiah 7:7,27) 
You will speak all these words to them, but they will not listen to you. You will call to them, but they will not answer you.

(Jeremiah 7:7,28) 
Then you are to say to them: ‘This is the nation that has not listened to the voice of the Lord their God, nor has it accepted correction. Faithfulness has perished, and it is no longer found in their mouths.

(Jeremiah 7:7,29) 
Cut off your hair and throw it away, and then raise a lamentation on the bare heights—a public mourning ritual. For the Lord has rejected and abandoned the generation that has aroused His wrath.

(Jeremiah 7:7,30) 
“For the people of Judah have done evil in My sight, declares the Lord. They have placed their detestable idols in the Temple where My name is invoked, thereby defiling it.

(Jeremiah 7:7,31) 
They have also built the high places of Topheth, which is in the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, to burn their sons and daughters in the fire—a horrifying act which I never commanded, nor did it ever enter My mind.

(Jeremiah 7:7,32) 
Therefore, behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when this place will no longer be called Topheth, or the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, but instead, ‘The Valley of Slaughter.’ People will be forced to bury the dead in Topheth because there will be no other space left.

(Jeremiah 7:7,33) 
The dead bodies of these people will become food for the birds of the sky and for the wild animals of the earth, and there will be no one to frighten them away.

(Jeremiah 7:7,34) 
I will silence the sounds of joy and gladness, the voices of the bridegroom and the bride, in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem, for the entire land will be utterly devastated and uninhabited.”

(Jeremiah 8:1) 
“At that time,” the Lord declares, “they will dig up the bones of the kings of Judah, the bones of its princes, the bones of the priests, the bones of the prophets, and the bones of the inhabitants of Jerusalem from their graves.

(Jeremiah 8:2) 
They will then spread those bones out before the sun, the moon, and all the celestial bodies—which they loved, which they served, which they followed, which they sought out, and which they worshipped. The bones will not be gathered or buried; instead, they will lie like refuse on the surface of the earth,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 8:3) 
And all the survivors from this evil lineage, those who remain in all the places where I have driven them, will prefer death over life,” declares the Lord of Armies.

(Jeremiah 8:4) 
Then you are to say to them: “This is what the Lord says: 'When someone falls, do they not get up? When someone turns away, do they not come back?'

(Jeremiah 8:5) 
Why then has this people of Jerusalem turned away with such stubborn defiance? They cling to lies and refuse to return to Me.

(Jeremiah 8:6) 
I have listened and heard: no one speaks what is good, no one repents of their wickedness, saying, 'What have I done?' Everyone rushes headlong into their chosen path, like a horse charging wildly into battle.

(Jeremiah 8:7) 
Even the kite in the sky knows its appointed seasons; the turtle-dove, the swallow, and the stork observe the time of their migration. But My people do not know the judgment of the Lord.

(Jeremiah 8:8) 
How can you say, 'We are wise, and the Law of the Lord is with us'? Indeed, the lying pen of the scribes has turned it into a falsehood. Their interpretation is a lie.

(Jeremiah 8:9) 
The wise are put to shame; they are terrified and trapped. For they have rejected the word of the Lord, so what wisdom is left in them?

(Jeremiah 8:10) 
Therefore, I will give their wives to strangers and their fields to new inheritors. For from the least of them to the greatest, all are greedy for dishonest gain; from prophet to priest, everyone practices deceit.

(Jeremiah 8:11) 
They treat the brokenness of My people superficially, saying, 'Peace, peace,' when there is no true peace.

(Jeremiah 8:12) 
They ought to be ashamed because they have committed such abominations. Yet, they are not at all ashamed; they do not even know how to blush. Therefore, they will fall among those who are falling; at the time of their punishment, they will collapse,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 8:13) 
“I will surely gather them for destruction,” declares the Lord. “There are no grapes on the vine, and no figs on the fig tree, and even the leaf has withered. What I had given them has passed away from them.”

(Jeremiah 8:14) 
“Why do we sit here idly? Gather together, and let us enter the fortified cities and be silent there, for the Lord our God has made us silent and given us bitter, poisonous water to drink, because we have sinned against the Lord.

(Jeremiah 8:15) 
We waited for peace, but no good came; for a time of healing, but behold, there was only turmoil.

(Jeremiah 8:16) 
The snorting of their horses is heard from Dan; at the sound of the neighing of their mighty steeds, the whole land trembles. They have come and devoured the land and everything in it—the city and its inhabitants.

(Jeremiah 8:17) 
For behold, I am sending among you venomous serpents—vipers whose bites cannot be charmed away. And they will bite you,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 8:18) 
My sorrow is beyond sorrow; my heart is mournful within me.

(Jeremiah 8:19) 
Listen! The cry of my people is heard from a distant land: 'Is the Lord not in Zion? Is her King not there?' 'Why then have they provoked Me to anger with their carved idols and with their worthless foreign gods?'

(Jeremiah 8:20) 
The harvest is over, the summer has ended, and we are not saved.

(Jeremiah 8:21) 
For the brokenness of my people, I am crushed; I am grieved, and despair has overwhelmed me.

(Jeremiah 8:22) 
Is there no balm in Gilead? Is there no physician there? Why then has the wound of my people not been healed?

(Jeremiah 9:1) 
If only my head were a fountain of water, and my eyes an endless spring of tears! Then I could cry day and night for all the people of my nation who have been violently killed.

(Jeremiah 9:2) 
Oh, if only I had a traveler's lodging place far away in the desert! Then I would abandon my own people and run away from them. For they are all spiritually unfaithful to God, acting like adulterers, and their whole assembly is full of those who rebel against God's laws.

(Jeremiah 9:3) 
They make their tongues like a taut bow, ready to shoot out lies instead of truth. They have grown strong in their evil ways in the land, constantly progressing from one sin to another. 'They have not truly known Me,' says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 9:4) 
Let everyone be on guard against their neighbor, and do not trust any brother. For every brother will try to trip you up with deceit, and every friend will walk about spreading slanders and lies.

(Jeremiah 9:5) 
People will mock their own brother, and they will refuse to speak the truth. For they have specifically trained their tongues to speak only lies. They have behaved wickedly, and they refuse to turn away from their sins and repent.

(Jeremiah 9:6) 
Your dwelling place is entirely surrounded by treachery. They continue to act in deceit, and because of this, they have not truly known Me,' says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 9:7) 
Therefore, the Lord of heavenly armies says this: 'Behold, I will refine them through suffering, and I will test their hearts like metal. For what else can I possibly do with the behavior of My people?'

(Jeremiah 9:8) 
Their tongue is a deadly, wounding arrow, always speaking deceit. With their mouth, they speak words of peace to their neighbor, but secretly, they set traps and snares for them.

(Jeremiah 9:9) 
Because of all these sins, 'Shall I not visit them with My judgment?' says the Lord. 'And for a nation behaving in this manner, shall My very soul not take vengeance?'

(Jeremiah 9:10) 
I will take up a lament and mourning over the mountains, and a dirge over the beautiful pastures of the wilderness. For they have been so utterly burned and laid waste that no one can even pass through them. No sound of human or animal is heard, for even the birds of the sky and the cattle have fled away and are gone.

(Jeremiah 9:11) 
I will turn Jerusalem into heaps of rubble, a den for wild jackals. And I will make the cities of Judah utterly desolate, with no one left to live in them.

(Jeremiah 9:12) 
Who is truly wise enough to understand this? To whom has the Lord spoken clearly enough to explain it? Why has the land perished? Why has it become desolate like a wilderness, with no one left to even pass through it?

(Jeremiah 9:13) 
And the Lord Himself answered, saying: 'This has happened because they abandoned My law, which I gave to them. They did not listen to My voice, and they refused to live according to My commands.'

(Jeremiah 9:14) 
Instead, they followed the stubborn wickedness of their own hearts and pursued the Baals—the false gods that their fathers had taught them to worship.

(Jeremiah 9:15) 
Therefore, the Lord of heavenly armies, the God of Israel, says this: 'Behold, I will feed this people with a bitter herb, like wormwood, and I will give them poisonous water to drink, like gall.'

(Jeremiah 9:16) 
I will scatter them among nations that neither they nor their ancestors have ever known. And I will send the sword of war after them, until they are completely consumed and destroyed.

(Jeremiah 9:17) 
The Lord of heavenly armies says this: 'Pay close attention! Call for the professional mourning women to come; send for those who are skilled in lamentation, and tell them to hurry!'

(Jeremiah 9:18) 
Let them hurry and begin a lament over us, so that our eyes may stream with tears, and our eyelids pour out floods of water.

(Jeremiah 9:19) 
For a voice of lamentation is heard coming from Zion: 'How utterly destroyed we are! How profoundly we are shamed! For we have been forced to abandon our land, and our homes have been torn down and ruined!'

(Jeremiah 9:20) 
Therefore, women, listen to the word of the Lord! Let your ears receive the solemn words that come from His mouth. Teach your daughters how to lament, and let each woman teach her neighbor a mournful dirge.

(Jeremiah 9:21) 
For death has climbed through our windows; it has entered our very homes. It has come to kill the little children playing outside and the young men gathered in the public squares.

(Jeremiah 9:22) 
Speak this message: 'Thus says the Lord: The corpses of men will fall like dung upon the surface of the land, and they will be like grain bundles left behind the reaper, with no one left to gather them for burial.'

(Jeremiah 9:23) 
The Lord says this: 'Let no wise person boast in their own wisdom, and let no strong person boast in their own strength, and let no rich person boast in their own riches.'

(Jeremiah 9:24) 
But if anyone desires to boast, let them boast in this: that they truly know and understand Me—that I am the Lord who demonstrates steadfast mercy, unwavering justice, and righteousness throughout the earth. For these are the things that please Me,' says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 9:25) 
'Behold, the days are coming,' says the Lord, 'when I will bring judgment upon everyone who is circumcised physically but still holds an uncircumcised heart—meaning, they are outwardly religious but inwardly rebellious.'

(Jeremiah 9:26) 
This judgment will come upon Egypt, and upon Judah, and upon Edom, and upon the Ammonites, and upon Moab, and upon all those desert dwellers who shave the hair at the corners of their temples as a pagan practice. For while all these other nations are physically uncircumcised, the entire house of Israel is, in a more profound way, uncircumcised in their heart, showing no true devotion to God.

(Jeremiah 10:1) 
Pay attention to the message of the Lord that He has spoken to you, O house of Israel.

(Jeremiah 10:2) 
The Lord says this: Do not learn to live according to the ways of the gentile nations, and do not be afraid of the signs in the sky, which those pagan nations fear.

(Jeremiah 10:3) 
Because the customs of other peoples are empty and meaningless. It is a tree cut from the forest, an object crafted by the hands of a carpenter with an axe.

(Jeremiah 10:4) 
They make it beautiful with silver and gold. Then they fasten it with nails and hammers so that it will not fall over or move.

(Jeremiah 10:5) 
They are like a scarecrow standing in a cucumber field; they cannot speak. They must be carried because they cannot walk on their own. Therefore, do not fear them, because they cannot do any evil, nor can they do any good.

(Jeremiah 10:6) 
There is no one like you, O Lord. You are truly great, and your name is mighty in strength.

(Jeremiah 10:7) 
Who would not fear you, King of all nations? Indeed, honor is properly due to you. Among all the wise people of the nations, and in all their kingdoms, there is no one who is like you.

(Jeremiah 10:8) 
All of them will equally prove to be foolish and stupid. The teaching of their worthless idols is nothing more than wood.

(Jeremiah 10:9) 
Beaten silver is brought from Tarshish, and gold from Ophir. It is the work of a craftsman and the hands of a goldsmith. Blue and purple cloth form their clothing. All these idols are simply the work of human artisans.

(Jeremiah 10:10) 
But the Lord is the true God. He is the living God, and the eternal King. The earth trembles at His indignation, and the nations cannot endure His threats.

(Jeremiah 10:11) 
Therefore, you shall say to them: "The gods that did not make the universe and the earth will utterly perish from the earth, and from all that is under the universe."

(Jeremiah 10:12) 
He Himself made the earth by His own power. He established the world by His own wisdom, and by His own understanding, He stretched out the celestial bodies of the universe.

(Jeremiah 10:13) 
At the sound of His voice, He brings abundant waters into the sky, and He raises clouds from the ends of the earth. He makes lightning flash during the turns of the rain, and He brings forth the wind from His storehouses.

(Jeremiah 10:14) 
Every human being has become foolish by their own supposed knowledge. Every artisan is put to shame by his carved idol, because his molten image is a lie, and there is no spirit of life within them.

(Jeremiah 10:15) 
They are worthless, and their work is worthy of ridicule. In the time of their judgment, they will utterly perish.

(Jeremiah 10:16) 
The portion of Jacob is not like these idols. For He who formed all things is the true God, and Israel is the tribe of His inheritance. The Lord of Hosts is His name.

(Jeremiah 10:17) 
Gather up your goods from the land, you who live under siege.

(Jeremiah 10:18) 
For this is what the Lord says: "Behold, this time I will hurl out the inhabitants of the land far away, and I will distress them so severely that their wickedness will be revealed."

(Jeremiah 10:19) 
Woe is me because of my brokenness. My wound is becoming severe. And I said, "Truly, I am crushed by this sickness."

(Jeremiah 10:20) 
My tent has been destroyed. All my ropes are broken. My children have gone out from me, and they are no more. There is no one left to spread out my tent or set up my tent coverings.

(Jeremiah 10:21) 
Because the shepherds have acted foolishly. They have not sought the Lord. Therefore, they have not acted wisely, and all their flock is scattered.

(Jeremiah 10:22) 
Listen! A sound of a rumor is coming. A great commotion approaches from the land of the north. Its purpose is to make the cities of Judah a desolate wilderness and a lair for jackals.

(Jeremiah 10:23) 
I know, O Lord, that a human being's way is not his own path to choose. Nor is it for a man to walk and direct his own steps.

(Jeremiah 10:24) 
Correct me, O Lord, but do so with just judgment. Do not correct me in your furious anger, lest you reduce me to nothing.

(Jeremiah 10:25) 
Pour out your wrath upon the nations that have not known you, and upon the regions that have not called upon your name. For they have consumed Jacob, and they have devoured and utterly destroyed him. They have laid waste to his homeland and its beauty.

(Jeremiah 11:1) 
This is the message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord.

(Jeremiah 11:2) 
"Listen to the terms of this covenant," the Lord commanded, "and speak them to the men of Judah and to all who live in Jerusalem."

(Jeremiah 11:3) 
Then you must tell them: "This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: 'Cursed is anyone who does not listen to the terms of this covenant, and does not obey them.'"

(Jeremiah 11:4) 
"These are the terms I commanded your fathers when I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of that blazing iron furnace of slavery. I told them: 'Listen to My voice, and do everything I command you. If you do, you will be My people, and I will be your God.'"

(Jeremiah 11:5) 
"I made this covenant so that I would keep the oath I swore to your fathers—that I would give them a land flowing with milk and honey, just as it is this very day." Then I, Jeremiah, answered, saying, "Amen, O Lord!"

(Jeremiah 11:6) 
And the Lord said to me: "Proclaim all these words in the cities of Judah and in the open places of Jerusalem, saying: 'Listen to the words of this covenant, and obey them.'"

(Jeremiah 11:7) 
"For I solemnly warned your fathers from the day I brought them out of the land of Egypt until this very day. I rose early and repeatedly warned them, saying: 'Listen to My voice!'"

(Jeremiah 11:8) 
"But they would not listen, nor would they pay attention. Instead, each one stubbornly followed the evil desires of their own heart. So, I brought upon them all the curses of this covenant—the very words I commanded them to obey, but which they refused to do."

(Jeremiah 11:9) 
And the Lord said to me: "A conspiracy has been discovered among the men of Judah and among the inhabitants of Jerusalem."

(Jeremiah 11:10) 
"They have turned back to the wickedness of their ancestors, who refused to listen to My words. And these people have gone after foreign gods to serve them. The people of Israel and the people of Judah have broken My covenant, the one I made with their fathers."

(Jeremiah 11:11) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord says: "Behold, I am bringing upon them such evils and calamities that they will not be able to escape. When they cry out to Me, I will not listen to them."

(Jeremiah 11:12) 
"Then the cities of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem will go and cry out to the false gods to whom they offer their libations, but those gods will not be able to save them in their time of affliction."

(Jeremiah 11:13) 
"For you, O Judah, have as many gods as you have cities! And according to the number of the streets of Jerusalem, you have set up altars of shame, altars to offer sacrifices to the Baals."

(Jeremiah 11:14) 
"Therefore, Jeremiah, do not pray for this people, nor offer up any praise or prayer on their behalf. For I will not listen when they cry out to Me in their time of affliction."

(Jeremiah 11:15) 
"Why has My beloved nation committed so many wicked deeds right in My own house, the Temple? Will the holy sacrifices you offer cleanse you of your evil deeds? Can these rituals truly turn you away from your sins?"

(Jeremiah 11:16)
