"The Lord once called you a leafy olive tree, beautiful, fruitful, and pleasing. But now, at the sound of a great, roaring storm, He has set its wood on fire, and its branches are burned."

(Jeremiah 11:17) 
"And the Lord of hosts, who first planted you like an olive tree, has declared that disaster will come upon you because of the evils that the people of Israel and the people of Judah brought upon themselves. They provoked Me to wrath by offering sacrifices to the Baals."

(Jeremiah 11:18) 
But You, O Lord, have shown me what is happening, and I have come to know it. You then revealed to me their wicked schemes.

(Jeremiah 11:19) 
I was like a gentle lamb led to the slaughter, completely unaware that they had devised plots against me. They were saying: "Let us put wood into his bread"—meaning, "Let us destroy him by cutting off his sustenance and strength"—"and let us cut him off from the land of the living, so that his name will no longer be remembered."

(Jeremiah 11:20) 
But You, O Lord of hosts, who judge justly and examine the innermost thoughts and hearts of all, let me see Your vengeance upon them. For I have laid my entire case before You.

(Jeremiah 11:21) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord says concerning the men of Anathoth who seek your very life and say, "You must not prophesy in the name of the Lord, or you will die by our hands."

(Jeremiah 11:22) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord of hosts says: "Behold, I will punish them! Their young men will die by the sword, and their sons and their daughters will die by famine."

(Jeremiah 11:23) 
"And there will be no remnant of them left alive. For I will bring calamity upon the men of Anathoth in the very year of their reckoning and punishment."

(Jeremiah 12:12:1) 
You are righteous, Lord, if I were to contend with You. Yet, I will speak with You concerning justice. Why does the path of the wicked prosper? Why is it well for all who deal treacherously and act wickedly?

(Jeremiah 12:12:2) 
You planted them, and they have taken root; they grow and bear fruit. You are near to their mouths, but You are far from their inner hearts and consciences.

(Jeremiah 12:12:3) 
But You, Lord, know me; You have seen me and tested my heart concerning You. Gather them together like sheep ready for sacrifice, and set them apart for the day of their slaughter and destruction.

(Jeremiah 12:12:4) 
How long will the earth mourn, and the grass of every field wither, because of the wickedness of its inhabitants? The beasts and the birds have perished, because the wicked have said, 'God will not see what becomes of us in the end.'

(Jeremiah 12:12:5) 
If you have struggled running with footmen, how then will you be able to contend with horses? And if you have felt secure in a land of peace, what will you do when the Jordan overflows its banks?

(Jeremiah 12:12:6) 
For even your brothers and your father’s household, even they have fought against you, and they have cried out loudly after you. Do not believe them, even when they speak pleasant words to you.

(Jeremiah 12:12:7) 
I have forsaken My house, My temple, and My people. I have abandoned My heritage, Israel. I have given My dearly beloved people into the hand of their enemies.

(Jeremiah 12:12:8) 
My heritage has become to Me like a roaring lion in the forest. She has raised her voice against Me, so I have treated her as an enemy.

(Jeremiah 12:12:9) 
Is My heritage to Me like a bird of various colors? Or have dyed birds—foreign invaders—surrounded Me? Come, gather together, all you beasts of the field, hurry to devour her!

(Jeremiah 12:12:10) 
Many shepherds—foreign invaders and their rulers—have destroyed My vineyard. They have trampled My treasured portion of land. They have turned My desirable portion into a desolate wilderness.

(Jeremiah 12:12:11) 
They have laid it utterly waste. The entire land mourns before Me, because there is no one who takes these things to heart or repents.

(Jeremiah 12:12:12) 
Over all the barren pathways, the destroyers have come. For the sword of the Lord will devour from one end of the land to the other. There is no peace for anyone.

(Jeremiah 12:12:13) 
They have sown wheat, but they have reaped thorns. They will inherit only toil, and it will not profit them. You will be put to shame by your harvest, because of the burning anger of the Lord.

(Jeremiah 12:12:14) 
Thus says the Lord concerning all My evil neighbors who have touched My inheritance—the land which I distributed to My people Israel: Behold, I will uproot them from their own land. And I will pull out the roots of Judah from the midst of those nations.

(Jeremiah 12:12:15) 
And it shall be, after I have uprooted them, I will turn and have compassion on them. I will bring them back, each person to his own inheritance, and each one to his own land.

(Jeremiah 12:12:16) 
And it shall be, if they diligently learn the ways of My people, so that they swear by My Name, saying, 'As the Lord lives'—just as they taught My people to swear by Baal—then they will be built up in the midst of My people.

(Jeremiah 12:12:17) 
But if they do not listen and obey, then I will utterly uproot and destroy that nation, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 13:1) 
The Lord told me this: "Go get yourself a linen loincloth, and put it on your body around your waist. Don't ever wash it in water."

(Jeremiah 13:2) 
So I got the loincloth, just as the Lord had commanded. And I put it on.

(Jeremiah 13:3) 
Then the Lord spoke to me again, a second time, saying this:

(Jeremiah 13:4) 
"Take the loincloth you just got, the one you are wearing. Go to the Euphrates River, and hide it there in a crack in the rock."

(Jeremiah 13:5) 
So I went and hid it, just as the Lord had commanded me.

(Jeremiah 13:6) 
After many days passed, the Lord told me: "Go now. Go back to the Euphrates River and get the loincloth, the one I told you to hide there."

(Jeremiah 13:7) 
So I went to the Euphrates. I dug it up and took the loincloth from where I had hidden it. But behold, the loincloth was completely rotted and ruined. It was useless.

(Jeremiah 13:8) 
Then the Lord spoke to me again, saying:

(Jeremiah 13:9) 
"The Lord says this: Just like this loincloth, I will cause the pride of Judah to rot away. And I will cause the great pride of Jerusalem to rot away."

(Jeremiah 13:10) 
"This wicked people, who refuse to listen to My words, and who follow the stubbornness of their own hearts, who have gone after other gods to serve them and worship them—they will become like this loincloth: good for nothing."

(Jeremiah 13:11) 
"Just as a loincloth clings closely to a man's body, so I had bound to Myself all the house of Israel and all the house of Judah," says the Lord. "My intention was for them to be My people, a source of fame, praise, and glory to Me. But they did not listen."

(Jeremiah 13:12) 
"So you shall speak this proverb to them: 'The Lord God of Israel says this: "Every wine jar will be filled with wine." And they will say to you, 'Of course, we know that every wine jar will be filled with wine! What's the point?'"

(Jeremiah 13:13) 
"Then you shall say to them: 'The Lord says this: "Behold, I will fill all the inhabitants of this land with a staggering drunkenness. This includes the kings who sit on David's throne, the priests, and the prophets, and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem."'"

(Jeremiah 13:14) 
"I will scatter them, separating each person from their brother, fathers and sons alike," says the Lord. "I will show no mercy, no pity, and no forgiveness; I will simply destroy them completely."

(Jeremiah 13:15) 
Listen and pay close attention with your ears. Do not be so proud, because the Lord has spoken this warning.

(Jeremiah 13:16) 
Give honor to the Lord your God now, before He causes your feet to stumble on the dark mountains. Before the shadowy mountains darken fully, you will look for light, but behold, it will be the shadow of death instead. And everything will turn into deep gloom.

(Jeremiah 13:17) 
But if you refuse to listen to this warning, my soul will weep in secret over your pride. It will weep bitterly, and my eyes will shed many tears, because the Lord's flock has been led away into captivity.

(Jeremiah 13:18) 
Tell the king and the queen mother: "Humble yourselves and sit in the dust!" "Because your glorious crown has fallen from your heads."

(Jeremiah 13:19) 
The cities of the Negeb, the southern region of Judah, are shut up. No one can get in or out. All of Judah has been exiled, carried away completely.

(Jeremiah 13:20) 
Lift up your eyes and look at those coming from the north. Where is the flock that was entrusted to you? Where are your glorious sheep?

(Jeremiah 13:21) 
What will you say when God punishes you? For you yourself have taught them to be against you, and you have appointed them as rulers over you, like princes over your head. Won't pains seize you, like a woman giving birth?

(Jeremiah 13:22) 
If you say in your heart, 'Why have these terrible things happened to me?' It is because of your many sins that your shameful parts have been exposed. Your garment has been stripped off, and your body left bare.

(Jeremiah 13:23) 
Can an Ethiopian change the color of his skin? Or can a leopard change its spots? Then you, who have become so accustomed to doing evil, can also do good.

(Jeremiah 13:24) 
Therefore, I will scatter them like straw, which is blown away by the wind across the desert.

(Jeremiah 13:25) 
"This is your fate, the portion I have allotted to you," says the Lord. "Because you have forgotten Me and have trusted in lies."

(Jeremiah 13:26) 
That is why I Myself have pulled up your skirt to expose your face. And all your public shame has been revealed.

(Jeremiah 13:27) 
"Your spiritual adulteries, the lustful neighing of your horses, the wickedness of your fornication—I have seen your abominations on the hills. Woe to you, Jerusalem! You will not be cleansed. How much longer will you persist in this?"

(Jeremiah 14:1) 
This is the message of the Lord which came to Jeremiah the prophet about the severe drought conditions.

(Jeremiah 14:2) 
Judah mourned and her city gates collapsed in despair. The people sat on the ground, grieving, and the desperate cries of Jerusalem rose up.

(Jeremiah 14:3) 
The leaders sent their servants to fetch water. They went to draw it, but they found no water. They returned with their empty vessels, feeling ashamed and distressed, covering their heads in despair.

(Jeremiah 14:4) 
Because the land was so desolate, and because no rain fell upon the ground, the farmers were utterly ashamed. They too covered their heads in deep despair.

(Jeremiah 14:5) 
Even the wild deer in the field gave birth and then abandoned its young, because there was no grass for it to feed on.

(Jeremiah 14:6) 
And the wild donkeys stood on the bare rocks, gasping for air like desert beasts. Their eyes grew dim and faint, because there was no grass to be found anywhere.

(Jeremiah 14:7) 
Lord, if our many sins are testifying against us, then for the sake of your holy name, please act! For we have turned away from you so many times, and we have truly sinned against you.

(Jeremiah 14:8) 
You are the true hope of Israel, its only Savior in times of deep distress. Why do you act as if you are a mere stranger in our land, or like a traveler who just stops for the night to rest, with no intention of staying?

(Jeremiah 14:9) 
Why do you seem like a bewildered man, or like a mighty warrior who is powerless to save us? But Lord, you are truly among us, and your holy name has been called upon us. Do not abandon us!

(Jeremiah 14:10) 
This is what the Lord says to this people, who loved to wander away and never settled in His ways. The Lord was not pleased with them. Now, He will remember their many sins, and He will punish their evil deeds.

(Jeremiah 14:11) 
Then the Lord said to me: "Do not pray for this people's well-being."

(Jeremiah 14:12) 
"Even when they fast, I will not listen to their prayers. And if they offer burnt offerings and sacrifices, I will not accept them. For I will utterly consume them with the sword, with famine, and with pestilence."

(Jeremiah 14:13) 
And I said, "Oh, oh, oh, Lord God! The prophets themselves are telling them, 'You will not see a sword, nor will there be famine among you. Instead, He will give you true peace in this very place!'"

(Jeremiah 14:14) 
Then the Lord said to me: "The prophets are speaking lies in My name! I did not send them, nor did I command them, nor did I speak to them. They are prophesying to you a deceitful vision, empty divination, every vile thing, and the deceptions that come from their own hearts."

(Jeremiah 14:15) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord says concerning those prophets who are prophesying in My name, whom I did not send, and who insist: 'There will be no sword or famine in this land!' Those very prophets will be consumed by the sword and by famine.

(Jeremiah 14:16) 
And the people to whom these prophets lie will be cast out into the streets of Jerusalem because of famine and the sword. There will be no one left to bury them—neither the people themselves, nor their wives, nor their sons, nor their daughters. Indeed, I will pour out the full consequence of their own evil upon them.

(Jeremiah 14:17) 
And you, Jeremiah, shall say this word to them: "Let my eyes stream with tears day and night without ceasing, because the virgin daughter of my people has been utterly crushed with a great breaking, a very dreadful and grievous wound."

(Jeremiah 14:18) 
"If I go out to the fields, behold, there are those slain by the sword. And if I enter the city, behold, there are those wasted away by famine. Even the prophet and the priest have been led into exile, to a land they do not know."

(Jeremiah 14:19) 
"Have you completely rejected Judah? Has your soul truly abhorred Zion? Why then have you struck us so severely that we cannot be healed? We looked for peace, but no good came; we hoped for a time of healing, but behold, there is only terror!"

(Jeremiah 14:20) 
"We acknowledge our wickedness, O Lord, and the iniquity of our fathers, for we have truly sinned against you."

(Jeremiah 14:21) 
"Do not give us over to public disgrace for the sake of your holy name. Do not dishonor the glorious throne of your majesty. Remember your covenant with us; do not annul it!"

(Jeremiah 14:22) 
"Can any of the idols of the nations bring rain? Or can the skies themselves give showers? Are you not the Lord our God, the only one we have waited for? For you alone are the one who has made all these things."

(Jeremiah 15:1) 
And the Lord said to me: "Even if Moses and Samuel stood before Me interceding, My favor would not be with this people. Send them away from My presence, and let them depart for their judgment."

(Jeremiah 15:2) 
And when they ask you, 'Where shall we go out to?' you shall tell them: 'Thus says the Lord: Those appointed to death, to death they shall go. And those appointed to the sword, to the sword they shall go. And those appointed to famine, to famine they shall go. And those appointed to captivity, to captivity they shall go.'

(Jeremiah 15:3) 
And I will appoint over them four kinds of destroyers, says the Lord: the sword to kill, dogs to tear, the birds of the sky and the beasts of the earth to devour and destroy their corpses.

(Jeremiah 15:4) 
And I will make them an object of horror and shaking to all the kingdoms of the earth, because of Manasseh, the son of Hezekiah, king of Judah, for all the detestable things he did in Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 15:5) 
For who will have pity on you, Jerusalem? Or who will mourn for you? Or who will go to pray for your peace and well-being?

(Jeremiah 15:6) 
You have forsaken Me, says the Lord; you have turned your back. So I will stretch out My hand against you and destroy you. I am weary of relenting from judgment.

(Jeremiah 15:7) 
And I will scatter them with a winnowing fork to the very ends of the earth. I will make My people childless and destroy them, for they have not turned back from their wicked ways.

(Jeremiah 15:8) 
Their widows have become more numerous to Me than the sand of the sea. I have brought upon them, even upon the mother of young men, a destroyer at noonday, striking unexpectedly. Suddenly I have brought anguish and terrors upon her, even upon her cities.

(Jeremiah 15:9) 
She who bore seven children has grown weak; she has gasped her last breath. Her sun has set while it was still day, signifying a sudden and premature end to her prosperity. She has been shamed and disgraced. And their remaining ones I will deliver to the sword in the sight of their enemies, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 15:10) 
Woe is me, my mother! Why did you give birth to me, a man of strife, a man of contention to the whole land? I have neither lent money at interest nor borrowed it, so I have no financial disputes. Yet everyone curses me.

(Jeremiah 15:11) 
The Lord said: "Surely I will release you for your own good. Surely I will intercede for you in the time of affliction and in the time of tribulation against your enemy."

(Jeremiah 15:12) 
Can common iron be broken by iron from the north, or common metal by steel? (Meaning, Judah cannot withstand the northern invader).

(Jeremiah 15:13) 
Your wealth and your treasures I will give as plunder without payment, because of all your sins and throughout all your borders.

(Jeremiah 15:14) 
And I will make you serve your enemies in a land you do not know. For a fire has been kindled in My wrath, and it will burn to the lowest depths, even to the underworld.

(Jeremiah 15:15) 
You know, O Lord, remember me, and come to my aid, and deliver me from my persecutors. Do not, in Your enduring patience, allow me to be consumed. Know that for Your sake I have suffered scorn and humiliation.

(Jeremiah 15:16) 
Your words were found, and I consumed them. And Your word became to me a joy and the delight of my heart, for I am called by Your name, O Lord, God of hosts.

(Jeremiah 15:17) 
I did not sit with the assembly of those who mock or make merry, nor did I rejoice in the presence of Your powerful hand upon me. Instead, I sat alone, for You had filled me with Your stern warning of judgment.

(Jeremiah 15:18) 
Why has my pain become perpetual, and my wound incurable and refusing to heal? Have You become to me like a deceitful stream, like waters that fail when most needed and are therefore unfaithful?

(Jeremiah 15:19) 
Therefore, thus says the Lord: "If you return to Me, I will restore you, and you shall stand before My face. And if you separate the precious from the worthless in your message, you shall be as My mouth. Let them turn to you and your message, but you must not turn to them and their ways."

(Jeremiah 15:20) 
And I will make you to this people a strong bronze wall. They will fight against you, but they will not prevail, because I am with you to save you and to deliver you, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 15:21) 
And I will deliver you from the hand of evil men, and I will redeem you from the hand of the powerful.

(Jeremiah 16:1) 
And then the word of the Lord came to me, saying:

(Jeremiah 16:2) 
"You shall not take a wife for yourself, and you shall have no sons or daughters in this place."

(Jeremiah 16:3) 
"For this is what the Lord says about the sons and daughters who are born in this place, and about their mothers who bore them, and about their fathers who fathered them in this land:"

(Jeremiah 16:4) 
"They will die of terrible diseases; they will not be mourned, nor will they be buried. Their bodies will become like dung spread upon the face of the earth. They will be consumed by sword and by famine. And their corpses will be food for the birds of the sky and the beasts of the earth."

(Jeremiah 16:5) 
"For this is what the Lord says: 'Do not enter a house of feasting, nor go to mourn, nor offer them comfort. For I have taken my peace from all these people,' declares the Lord, 'along with my mercy and my compassion.'"

(Jeremiah 16:6) 
"Both great and small will die in this land. They will not be buried, nor will they be mourned. No one will cut themselves or shave their heads for them as a sign of grief."

(Jeremiah 16:7) 
"And no one will break bread for them in mourning to comfort them over the dead. No cup of consolation will be given to them for their father or their mother."

(Jeremiah 16:8) 
"You shall not enter a house of feasting to eat and drink with them either."

(Jeremiah 16:9) 
"For this is what the Lord of armies, the God of Israel, says: 'Behold, I will remove from this place, before your very eyes and during your lifetime, the voice of joy and the voice of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride.'"

(Jeremiah 16:10) 
"And when you announce all these words to these people, and they say to you: 'Why has the Lord spoken all this great evil against us? What is our iniquity? And what is our sin that we have sinned against the Lord our God?'"

(Jeremiah 16:11) 
"Then you shall say to them: 'Because your fathers abandoned me,' declares the Lord, 'and went after other gods, and served them, and worshiped them. They abandoned me and did not keep my law.'"

(Jeremiah 16:12) 
"But you have acted even worse than your fathers! For behold, each one of you walks according to the stubbornness of your own evil heart, refusing to listen to me."

(Jeremiah 16:13) 
"And I will cast you out from this land into a land which neither you nor your fathers have known. There you will serve other gods day and night, gods who will give you no rest."

(Jeremiah 16:14) 
"Therefore, behold, the days are coming,' declares the Lord, 'when it will no longer be said: "As the Lord lives, who brought the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt!"'"

(Jeremiah 16:15) 
"But instead: 'As the Lord lives, who brought the children of Israel out of the land of the north and out of all the lands where I had cast them!' For I will bring them back into their own land, which I gave to their fathers."

(Jeremiah 16:16) 
"Behold, I will send for many fishermen,' declares the Lord, 'and they will fish them out. And after that, I will send for many hunters, and they will hunt them down from every mountain and every hill, and out of the crevices of the rocks.'"

(Jeremiah 16:17) 
"For my eyes are upon all their ways. Nothing is hidden from my face, nor is their iniquity concealed from my sight."

(Jeremiah 16:18) 
"And I will first repay them double for their iniquities and their sins, because they have defiled my land with the carcasses of their idols, and with their abominations they have filled my inheritance."

(Jeremiah 16:19) 
"O Lord, my strength and my fortress, my refuge in the day of tribulation! To you, the nations will come from the farthest ends of the earth and say: 'Truly, our fathers inherited lies, worthless things that brought them no benefit.'"

(Jeremiah 16:20) 
"Can a man make gods for himself, when they are not truly gods?"

(Jeremiah 16:21) 
"Therefore, behold, I will make them know this time. I will show them my hand and my power, and they will know that my name is the Lord."

(Jeremiah 17:1) 
The sin of Judah has been etched into their very being with an iron stylus and a diamond point. It is engraved upon the tablet of their hearts, and upon the horns of the altars where they offer their sacrifices—a permanent sign of their idolatry.

(Jeremiah 17:2) 
Their own children will remember their altars of false worship and their sacred groves under every green tree, on every high hill where they committed these sins.

(Jeremiah 17:3) 
Your mountains—which are like a wilderness—and your strength, all your treasures, I will give them over to plunder. Your high places, where you committed idolatry, will be given over because of your sins in all your territories.

(Jeremiah 17:4) 
You will be forced to let go of your own inheritance, the land I gave you. I will make you serve your enemies in a land you do not know, because you have ignited a fire of My anger, and it will burn on and on, unceasingly.

(Jeremiah 17:5) 
The Lord says this: Cursed is the man who trusts in man, who makes his own human strength his confidence, and whose heart turns away from the Lord.

(Jeremiah 17:6) 
For such a man will be like a desert broom bush in the arid wasteland; he will not even perceive when good things come. Instead, he will live in the parched places of the wilderness, in a salt land that is completely uninhabited and barren.

(Jeremiah 17:7) 
Blessed is the man who places his trust in the Lord, and whose total confidence is the Lord Himself.

(Jeremiah 17:8) 
And he will be like a tree that has been planted by flowing waters, sending out its roots by the stream. It will not fear when the summer's intense heat arrives, for its leaves will remain green. In a year of drought, it will not be anxious, nor will it stop producing its fruit.

(Jeremiah 17:9) 
The heart of man is twisted and perverse, and it is inscrutable—who can truly understand or know it fully?

(Jeremiah 17:10) 
I am the Lord, the One who deeply searches the heart and tests the innermost desires and intentions. I give to each person according to the way they live their life, and according to the fruit of their actions.

(Jeremiah 17:11) 
Just like a partridge that hatches eggs it did not lay, so is the person who gathers riches unjustly, not by righteous means. In the middle of his life, he will be forced to abandon them, and in the end, he will be exposed as a fool.

(Jeremiah 17:12) 
Your glorious throne, exalted from the very beginning of time, is the place where we are made holy by Your presence.

(Jeremiah 17:13) 
O Lord, You are the very hope of Israel! All who abandon You will be put to shame. Those who turn away from You will have their names written in the dust, forgotten and without hope, for they have abandoned the Lord, the true fountain of life-giving waters.

(Jeremiah 17:14) 
Heal me, O Lord, and then I will truly be healed. Save me, and then I will truly be saved, because You are the one I praise.

(Jeremiah 17:15) 
Look! These people say to me, "Where is the word of the Lord you speak of? Let it come to pass, if it is real!"

(Jeremiah 17:16) 
But I have not fled from being a shepherd, following You. I have not desired the day of human calamity, as You well know. What came out of my lips was always spoken correctly and truthfully in Your sight.

(Jeremiah 17:17) 
Do not become a terror to me; You are my strength in the day when I face affliction.

(Jeremiah 17:18) 
Let those who persecute me be put to shame, but let me not be shamed. Let them be terrified, but let me not be terrified. Bring upon them a day of calamity, and crush them with a double, overwhelming destruction.

(Jeremiah 18:1) 
The Lord spoke to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 18:2) 
"Go down to the potter’s house, and there you will hear My words."

(Jeremiah 18:3) 
So I went down to the potter’s house, and I saw him working on his wheel.

(Jeremiah 18:4) 
But the vessel that the potter was shaping from clay with his hands was ruined. So he changed his mind and made another vessel, just as it seemed good to him, the potter, to do.

(Jeremiah 18:5) 
Then the Lord spoke to me, saying:

(Jeremiah 18:6) 
"Can I not deal with you, O house of Israel, as this potter deals with his clay?" says the Lord. "Behold, just as the clay is entirely in the hand of the potter, so are you entirely in My hand, O house of Israel."

(Jeremiah 18:7) 
"If I pronounce a judgment against a nation or against a kingdom—meaning I will uproot it, pull it down, and destroy it—"

(Jeremiah 18:8) 
"—if that nation, concerning which I have spoken, turns away from its evil, then I will change My mind concerning the evil I had planned to bring upon it."

(Jeremiah 18:9) 
"And if I pronounce a blessing upon a nation or upon a kingdom—meaning I will build it up and plant it—"

(Jeremiah 18:10) 
"—and that nation does evil in My sight, refusing to obey My voice, then I will change My mind concerning the good I had promised to do for it."

(Jeremiah 18:11) 
Now then, speak to the men of Judah and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, saying: "Thus says the Lord: Behold, I am now forming a disaster against you and devising a plan to bring it upon you. Therefore, let each one of you turn away from your evil path, and correct your ways and your actions."

(Jeremiah 18:12) 
But they replied: "That is hopeless! We will go our own way, and each of us will act according to the stubborn wickedness of his own heart."

(Jeremiah 18:13) 
Therefore, the Lord says this: "Ask the other nations: who has ever heard of such a horrifying thing—this betrayal that the virgin Israel, My once-pure people, has committed?"

(Jeremiah 18:14) 
"Does the snow on the rocks of Lebanon ever melt away completely? Do the cold, gushing waters that flow from the mountains ever dry up?"

(Jeremiah 18:15) 
"Yet My people have forgotten Me; they offer sacrifices to worthless idols. They have stumbled in their ways, straying from the ancient paths that lead to life, choosing instead to walk on unpaved byways—a path that is not meant for public, righteous use—"

(Jeremiah 18:16) 
"—resulting in their land becoming a desolation, a perpetual object of scorn and horror. Everyone who passes by it will be utterly appalled and will shake their head in disbelief."

(Jeremiah 18:17) 
"Like a scorching desert wind, I will scatter them before their enemy. I will show them My back and not My face—meaning I will abandon them and not help them—on the day of their destruction."

(Jeremiah 18:18) 
Then they said: "Come, let us devise plots against Jeremiah. For we have our own priests who teach the Law, our own wise men who give counsel, and our own prophets who speak the word of God—we don't need *him*. Come, let us attack him with our tongues through false accusations and slander, and let us ignore everything he says."

(Jeremiah 18:19) 
Lord, pay attention to me, and hear the voice of my adversaries.

(Jeremiah 18:20) 
Is evil to be repaid for good? For they have dug a pit to trap me and take my life. Remember how I stood before You to intercede for them, to speak good on their behalf, and to turn Your indignation away from them.

(Jeremiah 18:21) 
Therefore, hand their children over to famine, and deliver them to the power of the sword. Let their wives become childless and widows. Let their men be slain by death, and their young men be run through by the sword in battle.

(Jeremiah 18:22) 
Let a cry be heard from their houses, when You suddenly bring a band of marauders upon them. For they have dug a pit to capture me and have hidden snares for my feet.

(Jeremiah 18:23) 
But You, O Lord, know all of their plots against me, even those meant to bring about my death. Do not forgive their iniquity, and let not their sin be blotted out from Your sight. Let them be cast down before You; in the time of Your wrath, let them be struck down.

(Jeremiah 19:1) 
The Lord says this: "Go and buy yourself an earthenware flask from a potter. Then take some of the elders of the people and some of the elder priests with you,

(Jeremiah 19:2) 
and go out to the Valley of Ben-Hinnom, which is near the entrance of the Potsherd Gate. There you will proclaim the words that I will speak to you.

(Jeremiah 19:3) 
And you shall say: 'Hear the word of the Lord, kings of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem! The Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, says this: Behold, I am bringing such a disaster upon this place that everyone who hears of it will have their ears ring with horror and shock.

(Jeremiah 19:4) 
This is because they have abandoned Me and have made this sacred place foreign and profane by sacrificing in it to foreign gods—gods unknown to them, their fathers, or the kings of Judah. They have also filled this place with the blood of innocent people.

(Jeremiah 19:5) 
They have built high places for Baal to burn their sons with fire as offerings to Baal—a practice I never commanded, never spoke of, and one that never even entered My mind.

(Jeremiah 19:6) 
Therefore, behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, when this place will no longer be called Topheth or the Valley of Ben-Hinnom, but instead, the Valley of Slaughter.

(Jeremiah 19:7) 
In this very place, I will shatter the plans of Judah and Jerusalem. I will make them fall by the sword before their enemies and by the hands of those who seek to take their lives. I will also make their dead bodies food for the birds of the sky and the wild beasts of the earth.

(Jeremiah 19:8) 
I will make this city a desolate waste and an object of scornful whistling. Everyone who passes by it will be astonished and will whistle in derision at all its wounds and devastation.

(Jeremiah 19:9) 
I will make them eat the flesh of their own sons and the flesh of their own daughters. Each person will eat the flesh of their neighbor during the siege and in the desperate distress with which their enemies and those who seek their lives will confine them.

(Jeremiah 19:10) 
Then you shall break the flask in the sight of the men who have gone with you.

(Jeremiah 19:11) 
And you shall say to them: 'The Lord of hosts says this: Just so will I shatter this people and this city, like a potter's vessel that is broken beyond repair. They will be buried in Topheth because there will be no other place left to bury them.'

(Jeremiah 19:12) 
So will I do to this place, says the Lord, and to its inhabitants. I will make this city like Topheth itself.

(Jeremiah 19:13) 
The houses of Jerusalem and the houses of the kings of Judah will become as unclean as the place of Topheth. This is because in all the houses, on whose rooftops they sacrificed to all the host of heaven—the astral deities—and poured out drink offerings to foreign gods, they have been defiled.

(Jeremiah 19:14) 
Then Jeremiah came back from Topheth, where the Lord had sent him to prophesy. He stood in the courtyard of the house of the Lord and spoke to all the people.

(Jeremiah 19:15) 
The Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, says this: 'Behold, I am bringing upon this city and upon all its towns every disaster that I have spoken against it. This is because they have stubbornly hardened their necks, refusing to listen to My words.'

(Jeremiah 20:1) 
Pashhur, the son of Immer, a priest who was appointed as the chief officer in the Temple of the Lord, heard Jeremiah speaking these prophetic words.

(Jeremiah 20:2) 
So Pashhur struck Jeremiah the prophet and then put him in stocks, which were located at the Upper Benjamin Gate in the Temple of the Lord.

(Jeremiah 20:3) 
The next day, Pashhur released Jeremiah from the stocks. Jeremiah then said to him, "The Lord will no longer call you Pashhur; instead, He will call you Magor-Missabib"—meaning 'Terror on Every Side.'

(Jeremiah 20:4) 
For thus says the Lord: 'Behold, I will make you a terror to yourself and to all your friends. They will fall by the sword of their enemies, and you will witness it with your own eyes. I will also give all of Judah into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will carry them off to Babylon and strike them down with the sword.'

(Jeremiah 20:5) 
'And I will give all the wealth of this city, all its resources, all its precious things, and all the treasures of the kings of Judah into the hands of their enemies. They will plunder them, take them away, and carry them off to Babylon.'

(Jeremiah 20:6) 
'And you, Pashhur, and all who live in your house, will go into captivity. You will go to Babylon, and there you will die, and there you will be buried—you and all your friends, to whom you prophesied lies.'

(Jeremiah 20:7) 
Jeremiah then spoke to the Lord, saying, "You drew me in, O Lord, and I was drawn in to serve You. You are stronger than I, and You have prevailed over me. I have become a laughingstock all day long; everyone mocks me."

(Jeremiah 20:8) 
"For whenever I speak, I must cry out about violence and devastation; I announce it continually. So the word of the Lord has become a constant source of reproach and mockery for me, all day long."

(Jeremiah 20:9) 
"But if I say, 'I will not remember Him, nor speak anymore in His Name,' then His word becomes in my heart like a burning fire, shut up in my bones. I become weary of holding it in, and I cannot endure it."

(Jeremiah 20:10) 
"For I hear the whisperings of many, and terror is on every side. They say, 'Denounce him! Let's denounce him!' All my former friends, who once watched my side, now wait for me to be deceived so they can catch me and take revenge."

(Jeremiah 20:11) 
"But the Lord is with me like a powerful warrior. Therefore, those who persecute me will stumble and will not prevail. They will be greatly ashamed, for they have failed to act wisely. Their disgrace will be eternal; it will never be forgotten."

(Jeremiah 20:12) 
"O Lord of hosts, You are the one who tests the righteous and sees into the depths of their minds and hearts. I beg You, let me see Your vengeance upon them, for I have entrusted my cause to You alone."

(Jeremiah 20:13) 
"Sing to the Lord! Praise the Lord! For He has delivered the life of the poor and oppressed from the hand of the wicked and malicious."

(Jeremiah 20:14) 
"Cursed be the day on which I was born! May the day my mother bore me never be blessed!"

(Jeremiah 20:15) 
"Cursed be the man who brought the news to my father, saying, 'A male child is born to you!'—and thereby filled him with great joy."

(Jeremiah 20:16) 
"May that man become like the cities that the Lord overthrew without remorse or a change of heart! May he hear screams in the morning and wailing at noon!"

(Jeremiah 20:17) 
"Why did he not kill me while still in the womb, so that my mother's womb might have been my grave, and her womb an eternal conception?"

(Jeremiah 20:18) 
"Why did I come out of the womb at all, only to see trouble and sorrow, and to have my days consumed in confusion and shame?"

(Jeremiah 21:1) 
The Lord sent a message to Jeremiah when King Zedekiah sent Pashhur, son of Malchiah, and Zephaniah, son of Maaseiah the priest, to him, with a question for the prophet.

(Jeremiah 21:2) 
"Please ask the Lord for us, because Nebuchadnezzar, the King of Babylon, is fighting a war against us. We hope that the Lord might perform all His miracles as He has in the past, and make Nebuchadnezzar retreat from us."

(Jeremiah 21:3) 
And Jeremiah said to them, "You will tell King Zedekiah this:

(Jeremiah 21:4) 
'The Lord, the God of Israel, says this: "Listen, I am going to turn against you the very weapons of war that are in your hands—the weapons you are using to fight the King of Babylon and the Chaldeans who are besieging you outside your city walls. I will then gather these besieging forces into the very heart of this city.

(Jeremiah 21:5) 
I myself will fight against you with an outstretched hand and a mighty arm. I will fight with righteous anger, with indignation, and with great fury.

(Jeremiah 21:6) 
I will strike down the inhabitants of this city—both people and their animals—and they will die from a terrible plague.

(Jeremiah 21:7) 
'After these things,' says the Lord, 'I will give Zedekiah, the King of Judah, along with his servants and his people—including anyone in this city who survives the plague, famine, and the sword—into the hands of Nebuchadnezzar, the King of Babylon. I will deliver them into the hands of their enemies, those who seek to take their lives. Nebuchadnezzar will strike them down without mercy, without sparing anyone, and without ceasing.'"

(Jeremiah 21:8) 
And to this people you are to say: 'The Lord says this: "Listen, I am now setting before you the path to life and the path to death.

(Jeremiah 21:9) 
Anyone who stays inside this city will die by the sword, by famine, and by plague. But anyone who goes out and deserts to the Chaldeans who are besieging you will live. His life will be snatched away from danger, a bare escape, but he will live."

(Jeremiah 21:10) 
For I have set My face against this city for its destruction, not for its well-being,' says the Lord. 'It will be handed over to the King of Babylon, and he will burn it down with fire.'"

(Jeremiah 21:11) 
And regarding the house of the King of Judah, hear the word of the Lord:

(Jeremiah 21:12) 
'O house of David,' the Lord says this: 'Administer justice diligently and rescue the one who is oppressed from the hand of his accuser. Do this quickly, lest My indignation burst out like fire, consuming everything, and there be no one to extinguish it, because of the wickedness of your actions.

(Jeremiah 21:13) 
Listen, I am coming against you, O inhabitant of the valley—you who call yourself 'the rock of the plain,'” says the Lord. "You who say, 'Who can strike us down? Who can enter into our fortified homes?'"

(Jeremiah 21:14) 
'But I will punish you according to the consequences of your deeds,' says the Lord. 'And I will set fire to its dense forest—referring to the city and its inhabitants—and it will consume everything all around it.'"

(Jeremiah 22:1) 
The Lord God says this: 'Go down to the royal palace of the king of Judah, and speak this message there:''

(Jeremiah 22:2) 
'Say: "Listen to the message from the Lord God, O King of Judah, you who sit on the throne of King David, you and your royal officials, and all your people who come through these city gates."

(Jeremiah 22:3) 
The Lord God says: 'Do what is right and just. Rescue those who are robbed or unjustly oppressed from the power of their oppressors. Do not harm or oppress the foreigner, the orphan, or the widow. And do not shed innocent blood in this place.'

(Jeremiah 22:4) 
For if you faithfully carry out this command, then kings from the royal line of David will continue to enter through the gates of this palace. They will sit on David's throne, riding in chariots and on horses, along with their royal officials and all their people.

(Jeremiah 22:5) 
But if you do not listen to these words, the Lord God says: 'I have sworn by Myself that this royal palace will become a heap of ruins, utterly deserted.'

(Jeremiah 22:6) 
For the Lord God says this concerning the royal palace of the king of Judah: 'Even though you are as glorious to Me as the forested heights of Gilead or the majestic cedars of Lebanon—regions known for their splendor—I solemnly declare that I will turn you into a desolate wasteland, with cities left uninhabited.'

(Jeremiah 22:7) 
I will consecrate destroyers against you—each man with his weapons. They will cut down your choicest cedar timbers, and they will throw them into the fire.

(Jeremiah 22:8) 
Many foreign nations will pass by this city, and each one will ask his neighbor: 'Why has the Lord God done this to such a magnificent city?'

(Jeremiah 22:9) 
And the answer will be: 'Because they abandoned the covenant of the Lord their God. They worshipped other foreign gods and served them instead of God.'

(Jeremiah 22:10) 
Do not weep for King Josiah, who has died naturally, nor mourn him too excessively. Instead, weep for King Shallum (Jehoahaz), who is being led away into exile. For he will never return to this land, nor will he ever see the land of his birth again.

(Jeremiah 22:11) 
For the Lord God says this concerning Shallum (also called Jehoahaz), the son of Josiah, King of Judah—he who reigned in place of his father Josiah, and who has departed from this place: 'He will never return here again.'

(Jeremiah 22:12) 
Instead, in the very place to which they have taken him captive, there he will die, and he will never see the land of his birth again.

(Jeremiah 22:13) 
Woe to the king who builds his royal palace through injustice, and his luxurious upper rooms without any regard for justice! He forces his neighbors to work for him for nothing, and he does not pay them for their labor.

(Jeremiah 22:14) 
Woe to the king who says: 'I will build myself a grand and spacious palace, with vast upper rooms!' He then makes its windows wide, and panels its ceilings with expensive cedar wood, and paints it with bright, lavish colors.

(Jeremiah 22:15) 
Do you truly believe you are a king merely because you outdo others in building with cedar? Did not your father, Josiah, eat and drink and enjoy life? Yet he also practiced justice and righteousness, and because of this, everything went well for him.

(Jeremiah 22:16) 
He defended the cause of the poor and the needy, ensuring they received justice, as if it were his own cause. Is this not truly what it means to know Me? declares the Lord God.

(Jeremiah 22:17) 
But your eyes and your heart are set on nothing but your own greed, on shedding innocent blood, on practicing oppression, and on committing constant injustice.

(Jeremiah 22:18) 
Therefore, the Lord God says this concerning Jehoiakim, the son of Josiah, king of Judah: 'No one will mourn him by saying, "Alas, my brother! Alas, my sister!" No one will lament for him by crying, "Alas, my lord! Alas, his majesty!"'

(Jeremiah 22:19) 
He will be buried with the disgraceful burial of a donkey—his corpse will be dragged and cast out beyond the gates of Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 22:20) 
O Jerusalem, go up to Lebanon and cry out! Raise your voice in Bashan! Call out from the heights of Abarim! For all your political allies have been shattered and destroyed.

(Jeremiah 22:21) 
I spoke to you when you were prosperous, but you defiantly said, 'I will not listen.' This has been your persistent way from your earliest youth, because you have never listened to My voice.

(Jeremiah 22:22) 
All your leaders will be swept away by the wind, scattered and destroyed. And your allies will be led into captivity. Then you will be shamed and utterly disgraced because of all your wickedness.

(Jeremiah 22:23) 
You who live in your cedar-paneled palaces, as if nesting securely among the majestic cedars of Lebanon—how terribly you will groan when the pains of judgment come upon you, pains like those of a woman in childbirth!

(Jeremiah 22:24) 
As surely as I live, declares the Lord God, even if Coniah (also called Jehoiachin), the son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, were a cherished signet ring on My right hand, I would still tear you from it.

(Jeremiah 22:25) 
I will give you into the power of those who seek to kill you, into the power of those whose faces you dread: into the power of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and into the power of the Chaldeans.

(Jeremiah 22:26) 
I will hurl you and your mother who bore you into a foreign land, a land where neither of you were born, and there you will both die.

(Jeremiah 22:27) 
And to the land to which they so deeply long to return, they will never come back.

(Jeremiah 22:28) 
Is this man Coniah just a despised and broken clay pot? Is he a vessel no longer fit for any use? Why are he and his offspring cast out and thrown into a land they have never known?

(Jeremiah 22:29) 
O land, O land, O land—listen closely to the message of the Lord God!

(Jeremiah 22:30) 
The Lord God says this: 'Record this man Coniah as childless, meaning he will have no royal heir. He is a man who will not prosper in his lifetime. For none of his descendants will ever sit on the throne of David, nor will any ever again rule with authority in Judah.'

(Jeremiah 23:1) 
“Woe to the shepherds who scatter and tear apart the flock of My pasture!” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 23:2) 
“Therefore, this is what the Lord God of Israel says to the shepherds who are supposed to feed My people: ‘You have scattered My flock, driven them away, and you have failed to care for them properly. So now, behold, I Myself will punish you for the evil of your actions and intentions,’ declares the Lord.”

(Jeremiah 23:3) 
“And I Myself will gather the remnant of My flock from all the lands to which I have driven them away; and I will bring them back to their own pastures, and they will become fruitful and multiply.”

(Jeremiah 23:4) 
“And I will raise up new, good shepherds over them, and these shepherds will truly feed them. My flock will no longer be afraid or terrified, and not one of them will be missing from their number,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 23:5) 
“Behold, the days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when I will raise up for David a righteous Branch—this will be a King who will reign, and He will be wise. He will execute justice and righteousness throughout the entire land.”

(Jeremiah 23:6) 
“In those days, Judah will be saved, and Israel will dwell in security. And this is the name by which they will call Him: ‘The Lord Our Righteousness.’”

(Jeremiah 23:7) 
“Therefore, behold, the days are coming,” declares the Lord, “when people will no longer swear by saying, ‘As the Lord lives, who brought the children of Israel up from the land of Egypt!’”

(Jeremiah 23:8) 
“...but rather, they will say, ‘As the Lord lives, who brought up and brought in the descendants of the house of Israel from the land of the north, and from all the other lands to which I had driven them!’ And they shall dwell securely in their own land.”

(Jeremiah 23:9) 
Regarding the false prophets, Jeremiah laments: “My heart is broken within me; all my bones tremble. I am like a drunken man, like a man completely overcome by wine, because of the Lord and the sheer weight of His holy words.”

(Jeremiah 23:10) 
“For the land is filled with adulterers—those unfaithful to God. Because of God’s curse, the land mourns, and the pastures of the wilderness are dried up. The course of their actions has become evil, and the strength of their deeds is not righteous.”

(Jeremiah 23:11) 
“For both prophet and priest have become defiled. Even in My own Temple, I have found their wickedness,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 23:12) 
“Therefore, their path will be like slippery ground in the deep darkness. They will be driven on and stumble headlong into it. For I will bring disaster upon them in the year of their punishment and reckoning,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 23:13) 
“Among the prophets of Samaria, I saw something truly disgusting: they prophesied by the pagan god Baal and led My people Israel astray.”

(Jeremiah 23:14) 
“But among the prophets of Jerusalem, I have seen an even more shocking and appalling thing: they commit adultery and walk in lies. They strengthen the hands of evildoers, so that no one turns from their wickedness. To Me, all of them have become like Sodom, and its inhabitants like Gomorrah.”

(Jeremiah 23:15) 
“Therefore, this is what the Lord of armies says concerning these prophets: ‘Behold, I will feed them bitter wormwood and give them poisoned water to drink. For from the prophets of Jerusalem, a defilement has spread throughout the entire land.’”

(Jeremiah 23:16) 
“This is what the Lord of armies says: ‘Do not listen to the words of the prophets who are prophesying to you and deceiving you. They speak only the vision of their own deceitful hearts, and not a single word from the mouth of the Lord Himself.’”

(Jeremiah 23:17) 
“They say to those who blaspheme Me, ‘The Lord has spoken: “Peace will be to you.”’ And to everyone who walks in the stubbornness of their own heart, they have falsely declared, ‘No evil will come upon you.’”

(Jeremiah 23:18) 
“For who among them has truly stood in the private council of the Lord, so that he has genuinely seen and heard His word? Who has truly paid attention to His word and heard it?”

(Jeremiah 23:19) 
“Behold, the whirlwind of the Lord! His fury has gone forth like a powerful tempest, and it has fallen directly upon the heads of the wicked!”

(Jeremiah 23:20) 
“The fury of the Lord will not turn back until He has fully executed and completely accomplished the plans of His heart. In the final days, you will understand His purpose clearly.”

(Jeremiah 23:21) 
“I did not send these false prophets, yet they ran on their own initiative. I did not speak to them, yet they still prophesied.”

(Jeremiah 23:22) 
“If they had truly stood in My divine council, they would have certainly heard My words, and then they would have turned My people from their evil ways and from the wickedness of their deeds.”

(Jeremiah 23:23) 
“‘Am I a God who is only near at hand?’ declares the Lord. ‘And not a God who is also far off?’”

(Jeremiah 23:24) 
“‘If a man hides himself in secret places, will I not see him?’ declares the Lord. ‘Do I not fill the entire universe and the earth?’ declares the Lord.”

(Jeremiah 23:25) 
“I have heard what these prophets say, prophesying lies in My name and constantly declaring, ‘I had a dream! I had a dream!’”

(Jeremiah 23:26) 
“How long will this persist in the hearts of these prophets who prophesy lies—these prophets who speak only the deceptions of their own hearts?”

(Jeremiah 23:27) 
“These are the prophets who intend to make My people forget My name through the false dreams that each one tells to his neighbor, just as their fathers forgot My name because of the pagan god Baal.”

(Jeremiah 23:28) 
“Let the prophet who has a dream tell his dream for what it truly is. But let him who has My true word speak My word faithfully and truthfully! What does worthless chaff have in common with nourishing wheat?” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 23:29) 
“‘Is not My word like a consuming fire?’ declares the Lord. ‘And like a mighty hammer that shatters rock?’”

(Jeremiah 23:30) 
“Therefore, behold, I am against these prophets,” declares the Lord, “who steal My words, each one from his neighbor, claiming them as their own!”

(Jeremiah 23:31) 
“Behold, I am against these prophets,” declares the Lord, “who use their own tongues to speak and then falsely declare, ‘Thus says the Lord!’”

(Jeremiah 23:32) 
“Behold, I am against these prophets of lying dreams,” declares the Lord, “who have recounted them and have deceived My people with their lies and with their empty, baseless claims. I did not send them, nor did I command them, and they are of absolutely no benefit to this people,” declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 23:33) 
“Therefore, if this people, or a prophet, or a priest, asks you, saying, ‘What is the “burden” of the Lord?’—that is, the prophetic word or oracle—then you shall say to them: ‘You yourselves are the burden! And I will cast you off completely,’ declares the Lord.”

(Jeremiah 23:34) 
“And as for the prophet, or priest, or anyone among the people who still mockingly says, ‘The burden of the Lord,’ I will severely punish that person and his household.”

(Jeremiah 23:35) 
“Instead, this is what you should say, each one to his neighbor and to his brother: ‘What answer has the Lord given?’ and ‘What has the Lord truly spoken?’”

(Jeremiah 23:36) 
“And the phrase ‘the burden of the Lord’ you shall mention no more, because each man’s own careless words will become his actual burden. For you are perverting the true words of the living God, the Lord of armies, our God!”

(Jeremiah 23:37) 
“This is what you should say to the prophet: ‘What answer has the Lord given you?’ and ‘What has the Lord truly spoken?’”

(Jeremiah 23:38) 
“But if you persist in saying, ‘The burden of the Lord,’ because you have said this very phrase—‘The burden of the Lord’—even after I specifically commanded you, saying, ‘You shall not say, “The burden of the Lord!”’—”

(Jeremiah 23:39) 
“Therefore, behold, I Myself will surely take you up and throw you away—remove you entirely from My presence—along with the city that I gave to you and to your fathers.”

(Jeremiah 23:40) 
“And I will inflict upon you an everlasting reproach and an everlasting disgrace, which will never be erased from memory.”

(Jeremiah 24:1) 
The Lord showed me a vision: and behold, there were two baskets of figs placed directly before the Lord's temple. This vision came after Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, had already carried away Jeconiah, the son of Jehoiakim, who was the king of Judah, along with his princes, the craftsmen, and the smiths from Jerusalem, bringing them as captives to Babylon.

(Jeremiah 24:2) 
One basket contained figs that were exceedingly good, like the very first figs to ripen in the season. The other basket contained figs that were exceedingly bad, so rotten they could not possibly be eaten.

(Jeremiah 24:3) 
Then the Lord spoke to me, saying, "What do you see, Jeremiah?" And I answered, "I see figs: the good figs are very, very good; and the bad figs are very, very bad, so rotten that they cannot be eaten."

(Jeremiah 24:4) 
Then the word of the Lord came to me, saying:

(Jeremiah 24:5) 
"Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Just as these good figs represent something positive, so I will look with favor upon the exiles of Judah whom I have sent from this place—from their homeland, into the land of the Chaldeans—for their ultimate good."

(Jeremiah 24:6) 
"And I will fix My gaze upon them for their well-being and favor, and I will bring them back to this land of Judah. I will build them up, and I will not tear them down; I will plant them firmly, and I will not uproot them."

(Jeremiah 24:7) 
"And I will give them a transformed heart, a spiritual capacity to know Me truly—to understand that I am the Lord. Then they will truly be My people, and I will be their God, because they will turn back to Me with a single, undivided heart."

(Jeremiah 24:8) 
"And as for the very bad figs, the ones so rotten that they cannot be eaten—thus says the Lord: So will I treat Zedekiah, the king of Judah, and his princes, and the rest of the people of Jerusalem who remained in this land, and those who chose to live in the land of Egypt instead of going into exile."

(Jeremiah 24:9) 
"I will make them a source of trouble and distress for all the kingdoms of the earth. They will become a scandal and a byword, a proverb and a curse in all the places to which I will drive them away."

(Jeremiah 24:10) 
"And I will send upon them the sword, and famine, and plague, until they are completely consumed and swept away from the land that I gave to them and their ancestors."

(Jeremiah 25:1) 
This is the message that came to Jeremiah concerning all the people of Judah in the fourth year of Jehoiakim, the son of Josiah, king of Judah—that was the first year of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon.

(Jeremiah 25:2) 
The prophet Jeremiah spoke this message to all the people of Judah and to all the residents of Jerusalem, saying:

(Jeremiah 25:3) 
From the thirteenth year of Josiah, the son of Amon, king of Judah, until this very day—which is now the twenty-third year—the word of the Lord has come to me. I have spoken to you persistently, rising early each morning to speak, but you have not listened.

(Jeremiah 25:4) 
Furthermore, the Lord has sent all His servants, the prophets, to you, rising early and sending them repeatedly. Yet, you have not listened, nor have you inclined your ear to hear them.

(Jeremiah 25:5) 
Their message was always: 'Turn back, each one of you, from your evil way and from your wicked thoughts. Then you will live in the land that I have given to you and to your fathers, for all generations, forever.'

(Jeremiah 25:6) 
They also said: 'Do not follow other gods to serve them or worship them. Do not provoke Me to wrath with the works of your hands, and then I will not afflict you.'

(Jeremiah 25:7) 
But you did not listen to Me, says the Lord. Instead, you provoked Me to wrath with the works of your hands, bringing harm upon yourselves.

(Jeremiah 25:8) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord of Hosts says: 'Because you have not listened to My words—'

(Jeremiah 25:9) 
Behold, I will send for and gather all the tribes from the north,' says the Lord. 'I will send for Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, My servant, and I will bring them against this land and against its inhabitants, and against all the nations that surround it. I will utterly destroy them and make them an object of horror, a hissing, and an everlasting desolation.'

(Jeremiah 25:10) 
'I will take away from them the sound of joy and the sound of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, the sound of the millstone grinding grain, and the light of the lamp that shines.'

(Jeremiah 25:11) 
'And all this land will become a desolation and an object of horror. These nations will serve the king of Babylon for seventy years.'

(Jeremiah 25:12) 
'When the seventy years are completed, I will punish the king of Babylon and that nation,' says the Lord, 'for their iniquity. I will also punish the land of the Chaldeans, and I will make it an everlasting desolation.'

(Jeremiah 25:13) 
'I will bring upon that land all My words that I have spoken against it—everything that is written in this book, which Jeremiah has prophesied against all the nations.'

(Jeremiah 25:14) 
'For many nations and great kings have subjugated them. I will repay them according to their deeds and according to the works of their own hands.'

(Jeremiah 25:15) 
For this is what the Lord of Hosts, the God of Israel, says: 'Take this cup of the wine of My wrath from My hand and make all the nations, to whom I send you, drink from it.'

(Jeremiah 25:16) 
'They will drink and stagger and act madly because of the sword that I will send among them.'

(Jeremiah 25:17) 
So I took the cup from the hand of the Lord and made all the nations to whom the Lord sent me drink it.

(Jeremiah 25:18) 
This included Jerusalem and the cities of Judah, its kings and its princes, to make them a desolation, an object of horror, a hissing, and a curse, as it is this day.

(Jeremiah 25:19) 
I also made Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, his servants, his princes, and all his people drink.

(Jeremiah 25:20) 
And all the mixed peoples, and all the kings of the land of Uz, and all the kings of the land of the Philistines—including Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and the remnant of Ashdod—all drank.

(Jeremiah 25:21) 
Edom, Moab, and the children of Ammon also drank.

(Jeremiah 25:22) 
All the kings of Tyre, all the kings of Sidon, and the kings of the islands across the sea also drank.

(Jeremiah 25:23) 
Dedan, Tema, and Buz, and all who shave the corners of their hair, drank too.

(Jeremiah 25:24) 
All the kings of Arabia and all the kings of the mixed peoples who live in the desert also drank.

(Jeremiah 25:25) 
All the kings of Zimri, all the kings of Elam, and all the kings of Media also drank.

(Jeremiah 25:26) 
All the kings of the north, near and far, one against another, and all the kingdoms of the earth that are on the face of the universe drank. And the king of Sheshach—that is, Babylon—will drink after them all.

(Jeremiah 25:27) 
Then you will say to them: 'This is what the Lord of Hosts, the God of Israel, says: Drink, get drunk, vomit, fall, and do not rise again because of the sword that I will send among you.'

(Jeremiah 25:28) 
If they refuse to take the cup from your hand to drink, then you will say to them: 'This is what the Lord of Hosts says: You shall surely drink!'

(Jeremiah 25:29) 
'For behold, I am beginning to bring affliction on the city where My Name is invoked—Jerusalem. And do you think you, as if innocent, will be delivered from misfortune? No, you will not be delivered! For I am calling for a sword against all the inhabitants of the earth,' says the Lord of Hosts.

(Jeremiah 25:30) 
Therefore, you are to prophesy all these words to them and say to them: 'The Lord will roar from on high; He will utter His voice from His holy dwelling. He will roar mightily over His habitation. With a shout like those treading the winepress, He will cry out against all the inhabitants of the earth.'

(Jeremiah 25:31) 
'The sound will reach to the ends of the earth, for the Lord has a controversy with the nations. He has a case against all flesh. He will deliver the wicked to the sword,' says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 25:32) 
This is what the Lord of Hosts says: 'Behold, disaster will go forth from nation to nation, and a great storm will arise from the farthest ends of the earth.'

(Jeremiah 25:33) 
'And those slain by the Lord on that day will be from one end of the earth to the other. They will not be lamented, nor gathered, nor buried; they will lie as dung on the surface of the earth.'

(Jeremiah 25:34) 
Wail, you shepherds, and cry out! Roll in the dust, you chiefs of the flock! For your days are fulfilled for you to be slaughtered, and I will scatter you, and you will fall like precious vessels broken into pieces.

(Jeremiah 25:35) 
Escape will perish from the shepherds, and salvation from the chiefs of the flock.

(Jeremiah 25:36) 
A sound of crying from the shepherds, and a howling from the chiefs of the flock, because the Lord has devastated their pastures.

(Jeremiah 25:37) 
The fields of peace have been silenced because of the fierce anger of the Lord.

(Jeremiah 25:38) 
He has left His lair like a lion. Indeed, their land has become a desolation because of the fierceness of the oppressor's wrath, and because of the fierceness of His burning anger.

(Jeremiah 26:26:1) 
In the early days of the reign of Jehoiakim, the son of Josiah, King of Judah, this message came from the Lord, saying:

(Jeremiah 26:26:2) 
Thus says the Lord: Stand in the courtyard of the Lord’s house and speak to all the cities of Judah who come to worship in the Lord’s house. Tell them all the words that I have commanded you to speak to them, and do not hold back a single word.

(Jeremiah 26:26:3) 
Perhaps they will listen to my words and turn back, each person from their wicked way of life. If they do, then I will relent and not bring the disaster I intend for them, which I planned because of the evil of their deeds.

(Jeremiah 26:26:4) 
You shall say to them: Thus says the Lord: If you do not listen to Me and walk in My law which I have given to you—

(Jeremiah 26:26:5) 
and if you do not listen to the words of My servants the prophets, whom I have sent to you repeatedly, rising up early to send them, but you have not heeded them—

(Jeremiah 26:26:6) 
then I will make this house (the Temple) like Shiloh (a place of past destruction), and I will make this city a curse to all the nations of the earth.

(Jeremiah 26:26:7) 
The priests, the prophets, and all the people heard Jeremiah speaking these words in the Lord’s house.

(Jeremiah 26:26:8) 
When Jeremiah had finished speaking everything the Lord had commanded him to speak to all the people, the priests, the prophets, and all the people seized him, shouting, “You must surely die!”

(Jeremiah 26:26:9) 
They demanded, “Why have you prophesied in the name of the Lord, saying that this house (the Temple) will become like Shiloh, and that this city will be made desolate, without an inhabitant?” And all the people gathered together against Jeremiah in the Lord’s house.

(Jeremiah 26:26:10) 
When the princes of Judah heard these words, they came up from the king’s house to the Lord’s house and sat down at the entrance of the New Gate of the Lord’s house to hear the matter.

(Jeremiah 26:26:11) 
And the priests and the prophets spoke to the princes and to all the people, declaring, “This man deserves a sentence of death! For he has prophesied against this city, just as you have heard with your own ears.”

(Jeremiah 26:26:12) 
Then Jeremiah spoke to all the princes and to all the people, saying, “The Lord sent me on a mission to prophesy against this house and against this city all the words that you have heard.”

(Jeremiah 26:26:13) 
Now therefore, make your ways good and amend your deeds. Obey the voice of the Lord your God, and the Lord will relent from the disaster that He has spoken against you.

(Jeremiah 26:26:14) 
But as for me, behold, I am in your hands. Do with me whatever seems good and right in your eyes.

(Jeremiah 26:26:15) 
Nevertheless, know and understand this: if you put me to death, you will bring innocent blood upon yourselves, upon this city, and upon its inhabitants. For truly, the Lord has sent me to you to speak all these words in your hearing.

(Jeremiah 26:26:16) 
Then the princes and all the people said to the priests and to the prophets, “This man does not deserve the sentence of death, for he has spoken to us in the name of the Lord our God.”

(Jeremiah 26:26:17) 
And some of the elders of the land rose up and spoke to all the assembly of the people, saying:

(Jeremiah 26:26:18) 
“Micah the Morasthite was a prophet in the days of Hezekiah, king of Judah. He said to all the people of Judah, ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts: Zion shall be plowed like a field; Jerusalem shall become a heap of ruins, and the mountain of the Temple shall be like the wooded high places.’

(Jeremiah 26:26:19) 
Did Hezekiah, king of Judah, and all Judah put him to death for this prophecy? No! Instead, he feared the Lord and entreated the favor of the Lord, and the Lord relented from the disaster which He had spoken against them. And we ourselves are about to do great harm to our own souls by seeking to kill this prophet.”

(Jeremiah 26:26:20) 
There was also a man who prophesied in the name of the Lord, Uriah the son of Shemaiah from Kiriath-jearim. He prophesied against this city and against this land, according to all the words of Jeremiah.

(Jeremiah 26:26:21) 
But when King Jehoiakim, and all his mighty men, and all the princes heard these words, the king sought to put him to death. When Uriah heard it, he was afraid, and he fled and went into Egypt.

(Jeremiah 26:26:22) 
Then King Jehoiakim sent men into Egypt: Elnathan the son of Achbor, and other men with him into Egypt.

(Jeremiah 26:26:23) 
And they brought Uriah out of Egypt and brought him to King Jehoiakim. The king then struck him down with a sword and cast his dead body into the burial ground of the common people.

(Jeremiah 26:26:24) 
Nevertheless, the hand of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, was with Jeremiah, so that he was not delivered into the hands of the people to be put to death. Ahikam’s influence protected Jeremiah.

(Jeremiah 27:1) 
It was in the beginning of the reign of Joakim, the son of Josiah, who was the king of Judah, that this message from the Lord came to Jeremiah.

(Jeremiah 27:2) 
The Lord said to me: "Make yourself literal chains and a wooden yoke, and then put them on your own neck." This was to be a visible sign of a coming servitude.

(Jeremiah 27:3) 
Then send these chains and this yoke to the kings of Edom, and Moab, and the sons of Ammon, and Tyre, and Sidon. Send them through the hand of the messengers who are coming to Jerusalem, to King Zedekiah of Judah, probably for a council of alliance.

(Jeremiah 27:4) 
You shall command these messengers to say to their rulers: "This is what the Lord of all creation, the God of Israel, says. This is what you must tell your own rulers:"

(Jeremiah 27:5) 
"It was I who made the earth, and its people, and all the animals on the face of the earth, by my great strength and with my powerful outstretched arm. And I have given this earth to whomever I choose to give it to, to rule over."

(Jeremiah 27:6) 
"And now, I have given all these lands into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, who is my appointed servant. Moreover, I have also given him the wild animals of the field, so that they too will serve him."

(Jeremiah 27:7) 
"All nations will serve him, and his son, and his grandson. They will serve him until the appointed time comes for his own land and for himself. Many nations and great kings will serve him."

(Jeremiah 27:8) 
"But any nation or kingdom that will not serve this Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and that will not put its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon, I will punish that nation. I will visit them with the sword, and with famine, and with plague,' says the Lord, 'until I have completely destroyed them by his hand.'"

(Jeremiah 27:9) 
"Therefore, do not listen to your false prophets, nor your diviners, nor your dreamers, nor your soothsayers, nor your sorcerers, who speak to you saying: 'You will not serve the king of Babylon!'"

(Jeremiah 27:10) 
"For they are prophesying a lie to you. Their goal is to make you be removed far from your own land, so that I may cast you out, and you may utterly perish."

(Jeremiah 27:11) 
"However, the nation that *does* put its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon and serves him—I will leave that nation in its own land,' says the Lord, 'and its people will be able to cultivate it and live in it peacefully.'"

(Jeremiah 27:12) 
I also spoke to King Zedekiah of Judah according to all these same words, saying: "Put your necks under the yoke of the king of Babylon. Serve him and his people, and you will live."

(Jeremiah 27:13) 
Why should you and your people die by the sword, and by famine, and by plague, just as the Lord has spoken against any nation that refuses to serve the king of Babylon? Do not bring this destruction upon yourselves.

(Jeremiah 27:14) 
Do not listen to the words of the prophets who are telling you: 'You will not serve the king of Babylon,' because they are speaking a complete lie to you.

(Jeremiah 27:15) 
"For I have not sent them," says the Lord. "And they are prophesying falsely in my name, so that I may cast you out, and both you and your prophets who prophesy to you may perish."

(Jeremiah 27:16) 
I also spoke to the priests and to this people, saying: "This is what the Lord says: 'Do not listen to the words of the prophets who are prophesying to you, saying: "Behold, the sacred vessels of the Lord will quickly be brought back from Babylon now!" because they are prophesying a lie to you.'"

(Jeremiah 27:17) 
"Do not listen to them! Instead, serve the king of Babylon, and you will live. For why should this city become a desolate ruin?"

(Jeremiah 27:18) 
"But if they truly are prophets, and if the word of the Lord is truly in them, then let them now make supplication to the Lord of all creation! Let them pray that the vessels which are still left in the House of the Lord, and in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem, may not also be carried off to Babylon."

(Jeremiah 27:19) 
For this is what the Lord of all creation says concerning the great pillars, and concerning the large bronze basin called 'the Sea,' and concerning the bases that supported the lavers, and concerning the rest of the vessels that still remain in this city.

(Jeremiah 27:20) 
These are the items that Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, did not take when he carried away Jeconiah, the son of Joakim, who was the king of Judah, from Jerusalem to Babylon, along with all the nobles of Judah and Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 27:21) 
Indeed, this is what the Lord of all creation, the God of Israel, says concerning those vessels that are still left in the House of the Lord, and in the house of the king of Judah, and in Jerusalem:

(Jeremiah 27:22) 
"They will be carried to Babylon, and there they will remain until the day I intervene and visit them," says the Lord. "Then I will cause them to be brought back from Babylon and fully restored to this holy place."

(Jeremiah 28:1) 
It came to pass in that year, at the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah, specifically in the fourth year, in the fifth month, that Hananiah, the son of Azur, a prophet from Gibeon, came to me, Jeremiah, in the Temple of the Lord, speaking before the priests and all the people.

(Jeremiah 28:2) 
Hananiah said: “Thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: I have broken the yoke of the king of Babylon!

(Jeremiah 28:3) 
Within two full years, I will cause all the sacred vessels of the Temple of the Lord, which Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, took from this very place and carried away to Babylon, to be brought back to this place.

(Jeremiah 28:4) 
And King Jeconiah, the son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, along with all the people of Judah who were carried into captivity in Babylon—I will bring them back to this place,” says the Lord. “For I will shatter the yoke of the king of Babylon.”

(Jeremiah 28:5) 
Then Jeremiah the prophet spoke to Hananiah the prophet, in the presence of the priests and all the people who were standing in the Temple of the Lord.

(Jeremiah 28:6) 
Jeremiah the prophet said: “So be it! May the Lord do as you have said! May the Lord fulfill your words which you have prophesied, that He may bring back the sacred vessels to the Temple of the Lord, and all the exiles from Babylon to this very place.

(Jeremiah 28:7) 
Nevertheless, hear this word that I speak in your hearing and in the hearing of all the people.

(Jeremiah 28:8) 
The prophets who were before me and before you, from ancient times, prophesied concerning many lands and great kingdoms about war, disaster, and famine.

(Jeremiah 28:9) 
But the prophet who prophesies peace—when his word comes to pass and what he has prophesied is fulfilled, then it will be known if the Lord truly sent that prophet.”

(Jeremiah 28:10) 
Then Hananiah the prophet took the yoke from the neck of Jeremiah the prophet and broke it.

(Jeremiah 28:11) 
And he said in the presence of all the people: “Thus says the Lord: So will I break the yoke of Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, from the necks of all the nations within two full years.” After this declaration, the people were encouraged to trust Hananiah's words.

(Jeremiah 28:12) 
And Jeremiah the prophet went on his way.

(Jeremiah 28:13) 
Then the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah after Hananiah the prophet had broken the yoke from the neck of Jeremiah the prophet, saying:

(Jeremiah 28:14) 
“Go and say to Hananiah: ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: You have broken a wooden yoke, but in its place, you will have a yoke of iron.

(Jeremiah 28:15) 
For thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: I have placed an iron yoke upon the neck of all these nations, so that they must serve Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, and they will serve him. Moreover, I have also given him the wild animals of the field.’”

(Jeremiah 28:16) 
And Jeremiah the prophet said to Hananiah the prophet: “Listen, Hananiah! The Lord has not sent you, and by your lies, you have made this people put their trust in a falsehood.

(Jeremiah 28:17) 
Therefore, thus says the Lord: ‘Behold, I will remove you from the face of the earth. This very year you shall die, because you have spoken words of rebellion against the Lord.’”

(Jeremiah 28:18) 
And Hananiah the prophet died that same year, in the seventh month, just as Jeremiah had prophesied.

(Jeremiah 29:1) 
These are the words from the book that Jeremiah the prophet sent from Jerusalem. It was addressed to the remaining elders who had been taken into exile, as well as to the priests, the prophets, and all the people whom Nebuchadnezzar had led from Jerusalem into Babylon.

(Jeremiah 29:2) 
This message was sent after King Jeconiah, the queen mother, the court officials, the princes of Judah and Jerusalem, and the craftsmen and skilled workers had all been taken from Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 29:3) 
The letter was carried by Elasah, the son of Shaphan, and Gemariah, the son of Hilkiah. These men had been sent by King Zedekiah of Judah to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, in Babylon. The letter said:

(Jeremiah 29:4) 
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says to all the exiles, all of whom I caused to be taken into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon:

(Jeremiah 29:5) 
Build houses and live in them. Plant gardens and eat the fruit they produce.

(Jeremiah 29:6) 
Take wives and have sons and daughters. Give your sons wives, and give your daughters to husbands, so that they may bear sons and daughters. Multiply there in Babylon, and do not let your numbers diminish.

(Jeremiah 29:7) 
Also, seek the peace and prosperity of the city where I have caused you to be taken into exile. Pray to the Lord for that city, because your own peace will depend on its peace.

(Jeremiah 29:8)
