For this is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Do not let your own prophets who are among you, or your diviners, deceive you. Do not listen to the dreams you cause to have or interpret for yourselves.

(Jeremiah 29:9) 
For they prophesy lies to you in My name. I have not sent them, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 29:10) 
For this is what the Lord says: When Babylon's seventy years begin to be completed, I will visit you. I will bring about My good promise to you, that I will bring you back to this place.

(Jeremiah 29:11) 
For I know My plans, which I plan for you, says the Lord. They are plans of peace and not of affliction, to give you a hopeful future and an expected end.

(Jeremiah 29:12) 
Then you will call upon Me, and you will come and pray to Me, and I will hear you.

(Jeremiah 29:13) 
You will seek Me and find Me when you seek Me with all your heart.

(Jeremiah 29:14) 
And I will be found by you, says the Lord. I will restore you from your captivity and gather you from all the nations and from all the places to which I have driven you out, says the Lord. I will bring you back from the place to which I caused you to go into exile.

(Jeremiah 29:15) 
You say, 'The Lord has raised up for us prophets in Babylon!'

(Jeremiah 29:16) 
But this is what the Lord says concerning the king who sits on David's throne, and concerning all the people who dwell in this city—your brethren who did not go out with you into exile:

(Jeremiah 29:17) 
This is what the Lord of Armies says: Behold, I will send upon them the sword, and famine, and pestilence. I will make them like vile figs, which cannot be eaten because they are so bad.

(Jeremiah 29:18) 
I will pursue them with the sword, with famine, and with pestilence. I will make them a terror to all the kingdoms of the earth, a curse, an astonishment, a hiss, and a reproach among all the nations to which I have driven them out.

(Jeremiah 29:19) 
This will happen because they have not listened to My words, says the Lord. They did not hear the messages I sent to them by My servants the prophets, though I was diligent in sending them. And you yourselves did not listen, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 29:20) 
Therefore, hear the word of the Lord, all you exiles, all whom I have sent from Jerusalem into Babylon.

(Jeremiah 29:21) 
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says concerning Ahab, the son of Kolaiah, and concerning Zedekiah, the son of Maaseiah, who prophesy lies to you in My name: Behold, I will deliver them into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar, King of Babylon, and he will strike them down before your very eyes.

(Jeremiah 29:22) 
And from them will be taken a curse by all the exiles of Judah who are in Babylon. They will say, 'May the Lord make you like Zedekiah and like Ahab, whom the King of Babylon burned in the fire!'

(Jeremiah 29:23) 
This will happen because they have committed foolishness in Israel. They have committed adultery with their neighbors' wives and have spoken a word falsely in My name, which I did not command them. I am the Judge and the Witness, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 29:24) 
And to Shemaiah the Nehelamite you shall say:

(Jeremiah 29:25) 
This is what the Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says: Because you have sent letters in your own name to all the people who are in Jerusalem, and to Zephaniah, the son of Maaseiah, the priest, and to all the other priests, saying:

(Jeremiah 29:26) 
'The Lord has appointed you as priest in place of Jehoiada the priest, so that you should be an officer over every madman and prophet, and should put him in the stocks and in prison!'

(Jeremiah 29:27) 
'So now, why have you not rebuked Jeremiah of Anathoth, who prophesies to you?'

(Jeremiah 29:28) 
Shemaiah's letter continued: 'Because for this very reason he sent to us in Babylon, saying: 'It is a long time; build houses and live in them; and plant gardens and eat their produce.''

(Jeremiah 29:29) 
Then Zephaniah the priest read this letter in the hearing of Jeremiah the prophet.

(Jeremiah 29:30) 
And the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 29:31) 
Send a message to all the exiles, saying: 'This is what the Lord says concerning Shemaiah the Nehelamite: Because Shemaiah has prophesied to you, though I did not send him, and has caused you to trust in a lie,'

(Jeremiah 29:32) 
'therefore this is what the Lord says: Behold, I will punish Shemaiah the Nehelamite and his descendants. He shall not have a man to dwell among this people, nor shall he see the good that I will do for My people, says the Lord, because he has spoken rebellion against the Lord.'

(Jeremiah 30:1) 
This is the prophetic message that came to Jeremiah from the Lord, saying:

(Jeremiah 30:2) 
This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: 'Write down all the words I have spoken to you in a scroll, for future generations.'

(Jeremiah 30:3) 
For behold, days are surely coming, declares the Lord, when I will reverse the captivity and restore My people, both Israel and Judah, declares the Lord. I will bring them back to the very land that I gave to their ancestors, and they will possess it once again, in lasting peace.

(Jeremiah 30:4) 
These, then, are the specific words that the Lord has spoken concerning both the northern kingdom of Israel and the southern kingdom of Judah.

(Jeremiah 30:5) 
For this is what the Lord says: 'We have heard a terrifying cry, a sound of utter dread and not of peace.'

(Jeremiah 30:6) 
Ask now, and observe: can a man give birth? Why then do I see every man with his hands on his loins, like a woman in labor, and every face turned pale with bitter anguish, as if in the throes of death?

(Jeremiah 30:7) 
Alas! For that day is great and terrible; there is no other like it. It is a time of extreme distress for Jacob—a period of unparalleled tribulation for God's chosen people—yet, in the end, he will be saved out of it.

(Jeremiah 30:8) 
And it will come to pass in that day, declares the Lord of hosts, that I will break the yoke of foreign oppression from your neck and tear off your bonds. Strangers will no longer make you their slaves or rule over you.

(Jeremiah 30:9) 
Instead, they will serve the Lord their God and David their king—the Messiah, the true King from David's line—whom I will raise up for them to rule eternally.

(Jeremiah 30:10) 
Therefore, do not fear, My servant Jacob, declares the Lord, nor be dismayed, O Israel; for behold, I will save you from a distant land of exile, and your offspring from the land of their captivity. Jacob will return, find rest and security, and thrive, and no one will make him afraid or cause him terror.

(Jeremiah 30:11) 
For I am with you, declares the Lord, to save you. I will bring to a complete and utter end all the nations among whom I have scattered you. But I will not bring you to an utter end; rather, I will discipline you with precise justice, and I will by no means spare you as if you were innocent of sin.

(Jeremiah 30:12) 
For this is what the Lord says: 'Your brokenness seems incurable; your wound is a most grievous affliction.'

(Jeremiah 30:13) 
There is no one to plead your case or to bring about your healing; among all those who once claimed to love you, no one has truly cared for your recovery.

(Jeremiah 30:14) 
All your former allies and lovers have forgotten you; they do not seek you out now in your distress. For I myself have struck you with the blow of an enemy, with cruel chastisement, because of the multitude of your iniquities and the severity of your hardened sins.

(Jeremiah 30:15) 
Why do you cry out over your crushing blow? Your pain seems incurable. Because of the multitude of your iniquities and your severe sins, I have done these things to you; this is the consequence of your actions.

(Jeremiah 30:16) 
Therefore, all who devour you will themselves be devoured; and all your adversaries, every single one of your enemies, will be led away into captivity. Those who plundered you will become plunder, and all who ravaged you I will give over to utter desolation and ruination.

(Jeremiah 30:17) 
For I will restore health to you and heal you of your deep wounds, declares the Lord, because they have called you 'Outcast Zion,' saying, 'This is Zion, and there is no one who cares for her or seeks her welfare.'

(Jeremiah 30:18) 
Thus says the Lord: 'Behold, I will reverse the captivity of Jacob's dwellings and have compassion on his tents, restoring them to their former glory. The city will be rebuilt on its ancient mound, and the Holy Temple will be established according to its proper design and divine order.'

(Jeremiah 30:19) 
From them will emanate songs of thanksgiving and the joyful sound of those who celebrate. I will multiply their numbers, and they will not decrease; I will bring them glory, and they will not be diminished or brought low.

(Jeremiah 30:20) 
And their children will be as they were in days of old, and their community will be established and secure before My presence. I will then visit My judgment upon all who oppress them and cause them tribulation.

(Jeremiah 30:21) 
Their ruler will be one of their own, a native, and their sovereign will come forth from their midst. I will bring him near, and he will approach Me directly. For who is this, declares the Lord, who would dare to risk his very life and dedicate his heart to draw near to Me as an intermediary?

(Jeremiah 30:22) 
And you will once again be My people, and I will truly be your God, in a renewed covenant.

(Jeremiah 30:23) 
Behold, the whirlwind of the Lord, His fierce wrath bursting forth, a continuing storm, will come crashing down upon the heads of the wicked.

(Jeremiah 30:24) 
The fierce anger of the Lord will not turn back until He has accomplished and completely carried out the intentions and purposes of His heart. In the last days, you will understand these things clearly and fully.

(Jeremiah 31:1) 
In that time, the Lord declares, I will be the God of all the tribes of Israel, and they will be My people.

(Jeremiah 31:2) 
This is what the Lord says: The people who survived the sword found grace and favor in the desert. Israel will journey to its place of rest.

(Jeremiah 31:3) 
The Lord appeared to them from far away. He said, 'I have loved you, My people, with an everlasting love, a love that continues forever. That is why I have drawn you to Myself with steadfast mercy.'

(Jeremiah 31:4) 
And I will build you up again, and you will be built up, O virgin Israel, a nation restored to purity. You will again adorn yourself with your tambourines, and you will go forth in the joyful dance of those celebrating.

(Jeremiah 31:5) 
You will again plant vineyards on the mountains of Samaria. Those who plant them will enjoy their fruits, and they will cultivate them securely, free from fear.

(Jeremiah 31:6) 
For there will be a day when the watchmen on the mountain of Ephraim will call out, saying: 'Arise! Let us go up to Zion, to the Lord our God!'

(Jeremiah 31:7) 
For this is what the Lord says: Sing with great joy over Jacob, and shout among the chief nations. Proclaim, praise, and say: 'Save, O Lord, Your people, the remnant of Israel!'

(Jeremiah 31:8) 
Behold, I will bring them from the land of the north, and gather them from the farthest ends of the earth. Among them will be the blind and the lame, the pregnant woman and the one giving birth, all together—a great assembly of those returning here.

(Jeremiah 31:9) 
They will come with weeping for their past sins, but I will lead them with comfort. I will guide them by streams of water on a straight path where they will not stumble. For I have become a Father to Israel, and Ephraim is My firstborn son, treated with special favor.

(Jeremiah 31:10) 
Hear the word of the Lord, O nations, and declare it in the distant islands, and say: 'He who scattered Israel will gather him, and He will guard him like a shepherd guards his flock.'

(Jeremiah 31:11) 
For the Lord has redeemed Jacob and has set him free from the hand of one stronger than himself.

(Jeremiah 31:12) 
And they will come and sing praises on Mount Zion. They will stream together to receive the good things from the Lord: abundant grain, new wine, and oil, and the young of flocks and herds. Their souls will be like a well-watered garden, and they will hunger no more, neither physically nor spiritually.

(Jeremiah 31:13) 
Then the virgin nation will rejoice in the dance, and young men and old men will celebrate together. For I will turn their mourning into joy. I will comfort them and make them glad instead of sad.

(Jeremiah 31:14) 
And I will satisfy the souls of the priests with rich abundance, and My people will be filled with My good things, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 31:15) 
This is what the Lord says: A voice is heard in Ramah, a sound of bitter lamentation, weeping, and deep sorrow. Rachel is weeping for her children and refuses to be comforted for them, because they are no longer present.

(Jeremiah 31:16) 
This is what the Lord says: Restrain your voice from weeping and your eyes from tears. For there is a reward for your labor and suffering, declares the Lord. Your children will return from the land of the enemy.

(Jeremiah 31:17) 
And there is hope for your future, declares the Lord. Your children will return to their own territory and borders.

(Jeremiah 31:18) 
I have clearly heard Ephraim lamenting: 'You have disciplined me, and I have learned my lesson like an untamed young bull that must be broken. Turn me back to You, and I will be restored, for You are the Lord my God.'

(Jeremiah 31:19) 
Indeed, after You turned me back, I repented. And after You showed me my errors, I struck my thigh in deep regret and sorrow. I was ashamed and disgraced, for I bore the reproach and consequences of my youthful rebellion.

(Jeremiah 31:20) 
Is not Ephraim My precious son? Is he not a delightful child to Me? For as often as I speak concerning him, I still remember him with love and tenderness. Because of this, My innermost being yearns for him; I will surely have abundant mercy on him, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 31:21) 
Set up signposts for yourself, place markers for guidance to the way back. Direct your heart toward the straight path, the way in which you once walked obediently. Return, O virgin Israel, return to your cities.

(Jeremiah 31:22) 
How long will you waver and wander aimlessly in your desires, O faithless daughter? For the Lord has created a new thing on the earth: A woman will encompass a man. This signifies a unique and unprecedented new order established by God, often understood as a spiritual reversal or a prophecy pointing towards the Incarnation of Christ.

(Jeremiah 31:23) 
This is what the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, says: Again they will speak this word in the land of Judah and in its cities, when I restore their captivity: 'May the Lord bless you, O dwelling place of righteousness, O holy mountain of Zion!'

(Jeremiah 31:24) 
And Judah and all its cities will dwell there together, both farmers and those who lead flocks.

(Jeremiah 31:25) 
For I have satisfied the thirsty soul, and I have filled every hungry soul with good things.

(Jeremiah 31:26) 
At this, I awoke, as if from a deep vision or a blessed sleep, and I looked around. My sleep had been sweet and refreshing to me.

(Jeremiah 31:27) 
Behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will sow the house of Israel and the house of Judah with the seed of men and the seed of animals, causing them to multiply abundantly.

(Jeremiah 31:28) 
And just as I watched over them with vigilance to pluck up, to tear down, to demolish, to destroy, and to afflict, so will I watch over them to build and to plant, declares the Lord. My active hand will be for their good.

(Jeremiah 31:29) 
In those days, they will no longer say the proverb: 'The fathers ate sour grapes, and the children's teeth were set on edge,' blaming past generations for their own suffering.

(Jeremiah 31:30) 
Instead, each one will die for his own iniquity. Every person who eats sour grapes—his own teeth will be set on edge, for he will bear the consequences of his own actions.

(Jeremiah 31:31) 
Behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah.

(Jeremiah 31:32) 
This new covenant will not be like the covenant I made with their fathers on the day I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt—that covenant which they broke and rendered void, even though I was their Lord and Master, declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 31:33) 
But this will be the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, declares the Lord: I will put My law within their inner being, and I will write it on their hearts, making it an internal spiritual guide. And I will be their God, and they will be My people.

(Jeremiah 31:34) 
And no longer will each man need to teach his neighbor, or each man teach his brother, saying: 'Know the Lord!' For they will all know Me intimately, from the least of them to the greatest, declares the Lord. For I will forgive their iniquity, and I will remember their sin no more at all.

(Jeremiah 31:35) 
This is what the Lord says, who gives the sun for the light of day, and the moon and stars for the light of night; who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—the Lord of hosts is His name, indicating His power over all creation.

(Jeremiah 31:36) 
If these fixed laws of nature for the sun, moon, and stars should cease from before Me, declares the Lord, then also the offspring of Israel will cease from being a nation before Me for all days. This is a promise of Israel's eternal existence as a people.

(Jeremiah 31:37) 
This is what the Lord says: If the universe above can be measured, and the foundations of the earth below can be explored, then I would also cast away all the offspring of Israel because of all they have done, declares the Lord. As the former is impossible, so is the latter.

(Jeremiah 31:38) 
Behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when the city of Jerusalem will be rebuilt for the Lord, extending from the Tower of Hananeel all the way to the Corner Gate.

(Jeremiah 31:39) 
And the measuring line will go out further, beyond the normal boundary, encompassing all the hill of Gareb and encircling Goath.

(Jeremiah 31:40) 
And the entire valley of dead bodies and ashes, a place once of waste and defilement, and all the region of Hammeel up to the Kidron Valley, and as far as the corner of the Horse Gate toward the east, will be holy to the Lord. It will not be uprooted or destroyed again, ever.

(Jeremiah 32:1) 
The word of the Lord came to Jeremiah in the tenth year of King Zedekiah of Judah—which was also the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar’s reign.

(Jeremiah 32:2) 
At that time, the Babylonian king's army was besieging Jerusalem. Jeremiah the prophet was imprisoned in the courtyard of the guard, which was located at the king of Judah’s palace.

(Jeremiah 32:3) 
King Zedekiah of Judah had locked Jeremiah up, asking, 'Why do you prophesy, saying: ‘This is what the Lord says: I am about to hand this city over to the king of Babylon, and he will capture it’?'

(Jeremiah 32:4) 
‘And King Zedekiah of Judah will not escape from the Chaldeans; instead, he will certainly be handed over to the king of Babylon. He will speak with him face to face, and see him eye to eye.’

(Jeremiah 32:5) 
‘He will lead Zedekiah away to Babylon, and Zedekiah will remain there until I pay him attention,’ declares the Lord. ‘If you fight against the Chaldeans, you will have no success at all.’

(Jeremiah 32:6) 
Then Jeremiah said: 'The word of the Lord came to me, saying:'

(Jeremiah 32:7) 
‘Listen, Hanamel, the son of your uncle Shallum, is coming to you with an offer. He will tell you to buy his field, which is in Anathoth, because you have the right to redeem it by your family connection.’

(Jeremiah 32:8) 
Then my cousin Hanamel came to me in the courtyard of the guard, just as the Lord had foretold. He said to me, ‘Buy my field that is in Anathoth, in the land of Benjamin. You have the right to inherit it and to buy it. So take possession of it!’ And I understood that this was indeed the word from the Lord.

(Jeremiah 32:9) 
So I bought the field from my cousin Hanamel, which was in Anathoth. I weighed out the silver for him—seven shekels and ten pieces of silver.

(Jeremiah 32:10) 
I wrote the details in a deed, sealed it, and had witnesses sign. Then I weighed out the money on the scales.

(Jeremiah 32:11) 
Then I took the deed of purchase—both the sealed copy and the unsealed copy—in accordance with the customs and legal requirements.

(Jeremiah 32:12) 
I handed the deed of purchase to Baruch, the son of Neri, the son of Maaseiah. This was done in the presence of my cousin Hanamel, in the presence of the witnesses who had signed the purchase deed, and in the presence of all the Judeans who were sitting in the courtyard of the guard.

(Jeremiah 32:13) 
And I instructed Baruch in their presence, saying:

(Jeremiah 32:14) 
‘This is what the Lord of armies, the God of Israel, says: Take these documents—this sealed purchase deed and this unsealed document—and put them in a clay jar so they may last for many days.’

(Jeremiah 32:15) 
‘For this is what the Lord of armies, the God of Israel, says: Houses, fields, and vineyards will again be bought and owned in this land.’

(Jeremiah 32:16) 
After I had given the deed of purchase to Baruch, the son of Neri, I prayed to the Lord, saying:

(Jeremiah 32:17) 
‘Ah, Sovereign Lord, God! Behold, You created the universe and the earth by Your great power and Your outstretched arm. Nothing is too difficult for You.’

(Jeremiah 32:18) 
‘You show loving-kindness to thousands, but also bring the punishment for the iniquity of parents upon their children and their descendants after them. O Great and Mighty God, whose name is the Lord of armies.’

(Jeremiah 32:19) 
‘Great in counsel and incomprehensible in thought! Your eyes observe all the ways of the children of Adam, so that You may give to each one according to their ways and according to the fruit of their deeds.’

(Jeremiah 32:20) 
‘You performed signs and wonders in the land of Egypt and have continued to do so, even to this day, both in Israel and among mankind. You have made a Name for Yourself, which is renowned to this very day.’

(Jeremiah 32:21) 
‘You brought Your people Israel out of the land of Egypt with signs and wonders, with a strong hand and an outstretched arm, and with great terror.’

(Jeremiah 32:22) 
‘You gave them this land, which You had sworn to their fathers to give them—a land flowing with milk and honey.’

(Jeremiah 32:23) 
‘They entered it and took possession, but they did not obey Your voice and did not walk in Your law. They did not do anything You commanded them to do, and so all these calamities have come upon them.’

(Jeremiah 32:24) 
‘See how the siege ramps are built right up to the city walls for its capture! The city has been handed over to the Chaldeans, who are fighting against it, through the sword, famine, and pestilence. Whatever You spoke has now come to pass, and You Yourself see it!’

(Jeremiah 32:25) 
‘Yet You, Sovereign Lord, God, said to me: “Buy the field with money and have witnesses,” even though the city has been given into the hands of the Chaldeans.’

(Jeremiah 32:26) 
Then the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 32:27) 
‘Behold, I am the Lord, the God of all living beings. Is anything too difficult for Me?’

(Jeremiah 32:28) 
‘Therefore, this is what the Lord says: Behold, I am about to hand this city over to the Chaldeans and to King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, and he will capture it.’

(Jeremiah 32:29) 
‘The Chaldeans who are fighting against this city will come in and set it on fire. They will burn it down, along with the houses on whose rooftops they offered sacrifices to Baal and poured out drink offerings to other gods to provoke My anger.’

(Jeremiah 32:30) 
‘For the children of Israel and the children of Judah have continually done evil in My sight from their youth. Indeed, the children of Israel have provoked Me to anger by the work of their hands, declares the Lord.’

(Jeremiah 32:31) 
‘This city has been a constant provocation of My wrath and indignation from the day it was built until this very day, so that it must be removed from My sight.’

(Jeremiah 32:32) 
‘Because of all the evil that the children of Israel and the children of Judah committed—provoking Me to anger by the work of their hands with their wooden and stone idols.’

(Jeremiah 32:33) 
‘They turned their backs to Me, not their faces. Even though I taught them diligently, rising early and instructing them, they refused to listen to My discipline.’

(Jeremiah 32:34) 
‘They set up their detestable idols in the very House where My Name is invoked, to defile it.’

(Jeremiah 32:35) 
‘They built the high places of Baal in the Valley of Ben Hinnom to consecrate their sons and daughters to Molech. I never commanded them to do such an abomination, nor did it ever enter My mind that they would lead Judah into such sin.’

(Jeremiah 32:36) 
‘And now, concerning all these things, this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says about this city, about which you yourselves are saying, “It will be handed over to the king of Babylon by sword, famine, and pestilence.”’

(Jeremiah 32:37) 
‘Behold, I will gather them from all the lands to which I have driven them in My furious anger, My indignation, and My great wrath. I will bring them back to this very place and make them dwell here securely.’

(Jeremiah 32:38) 
‘They will be My people, and I will be their God.’

(Jeremiah 32:39) 
‘I will give them one heart and one way of living, so that they may fear Me always. This will be for their own good and for the good of their children after them.’

(Jeremiah 32:40) 
‘I will make an everlasting covenant with them: I will never stop doing good to them. And I will put My fear in their hearts so that they will not turn away from Me.’

(Jeremiah 32:41) 
‘I will rejoice over them by doing good to them. I will plant them firmly in this land with all My heart and all My soul, truly and permanently.’

(Jeremiah 32:42) 
‘For this is what the Lord says: Just as I brought all this great disaster upon these people, so also will I bring upon them all the good that I promised them.’

(Jeremiah 32:43) 
‘Fields will again be bought and owned in this land, about which you are now saying, “It is desolate, without man or beast, and given into the hands of the Chaldeans.”’

(Jeremiah 32:44) 
‘Fields will be bought for money, deeds will be written, sealed, and signed by witnesses in the land of Benjamin and in the areas around Jerusalem, in the cities of Judah, in the cities of the hill country, in the cities of the western foothills, and in the cities of the Negev. For I will restore their fortunes,’ declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 33:1) 
And the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah a second time, while he was still imprisoned in the court of the prison, saying:

(Jeremiah 33:2) 
Thus says the Lord, who will bring these things about, who will shape them, and who will establish them—the Lord is His name:

(Jeremiah 33:3) 
Call to Me, and I will hear you. I will declare to you great and unshakeable things, which you do not know.

(Jeremiah 33:4) 
For thus says the Lord, the God of Israel, concerning the houses of this city and the houses of the kings of Judah, which have been torn down to build up defenses against the siege towers and the ramparts of the enemy.

(Jeremiah 33:5) 
And concerning those who went out to fight against the Chaldeans: they will fill those houses with the corpses of the men whom I struck down in My wrath and in My indignation, because I hid My face from them on account of all their wickedness.

(Jeremiah 33:6) 
Behold, I will bring them healing and restoration, and I will cure them. I will reveal to them a lasting abundance of peace and truth.

(Jeremiah 33:7) 
I will restore the fortunes of Judah and the fortunes of Israel, and I will rebuild them as they were in the beginning.

(Jeremiah 33:8) 
I will cleanse them from all their iniquity by which they sinned against Me. I will forgive all their iniquities by which they sinned against Me and spurned Me.

(Jeremiah 33:9) 
And Jerusalem will be to Me a name of joy, a praise, and a glory before all the nations of the earth, who will hear of all the good things I do for them. They will be in awe and wonder at all the good things and all the peace that I bring to them.

(Jeremiah 33:10) 
Thus says the Lord: In this place, which you say is a desolate wilderness—where there is neither man nor beast—and in the cities of Judah, and outside Jerusalem, and in its streets which are laid waste, without man, without inhabitant, and without beast, there will still be heard:

(Jeremiah 33:11) 
...the voice of joy and the voice of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, the voice of those saying: 'Give praise to the Lord of hosts, for the Lord is good, for His mercy endures forever!' And the voice of those bringing offerings into the house of the Lord. For I will restore the fortunes of the land as they were in the beginning, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 33:12) 
Thus says the Lord of hosts: In this desolate place, where there is neither man nor beast, and in all its cities, there will again be a dwelling for shepherds, where flocks will lie down in peace.

(Jeremiah 33:13) 
And in the cities of the hill country, in the cities of the plain, and in the cities toward the south, and in the land of Benjamin, and in the areas around Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, flocks will again pass under the hand of the one counting them, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 33:14) 
Behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, when I will raise up a righteous Branch for David. He will execute true judgment and justice in the land.

(Jeremiah 33:15) 
In those days Judah will be saved, and Jerusalem will dwell securely. And this is the name by which they will call Him: 'The Lord is Our Righteousness.'

(Jeremiah 33:16) 
For thus says the Lord: A man from the line of David will never be lacking to sit upon the throne of the house of Israel.

(Jeremiah 33:17) 
And from the priests and Levites, a man will never be lacking before Me who offers burnt offerings, burns grain offerings, and makes sacrifices every single day.

(Jeremiah 33:18) 
And the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 33:19) 
Thus says the Lord: If My covenant with the day and My covenant with the night can be broken, so that day and night do not come at their appointed time,

(Jeremiah 33:20) 
...then My covenant can also be broken with David My servant, so that he will not have a son to reign on his throne, and likewise with the Levites, who are My priestly ministers.

(Jeremiah 33:21) 
...then just as the stars of the heavens cannot be counted, and the sands of the sea cannot be measured, so also will I make the descendants of David My servant, and the Levites My ministers, countless in number.

(Jeremiah 33:22) 
And the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 33:23) 
Have you not seen what this people has said, saying: 'The two families whom the Lord had chosen, Judah and Israel, have now been utterly cast off?' Thus, they have despised My people, considering them no longer a nation before them.

(Jeremiah 33:24) 
Thus says the Lord: If My covenant with day and night can be broken, and if the laws of the universe and the earth can be undone,

(Jeremiah 33:25) 
...then also My covenant will be broken with the descendants of Jacob and David My servant. Then I would no longer choose rulers from their descendants to preside over the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

(Jeremiah 33:26) 
For just as the stars of the universe cannot be counted and the sands of the sea cannot be measured, so also will I make the descendants of David My servant and the Levites My ministers countless in number.

(Jeremiah 34:1) 
This is the message that came from the Lord to Jeremiah at the time when Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, and all of his army, and all the kingdoms of the earth that were under his power, and all the peoples, were fighting against Jerusalem and against all its cities, saying:

(Jeremiah 34:2) 
This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: 'Go and speak to Zedekiah, the king of Judah, and tell him: This is what the Lord says: Behold, I will give this city into the hands of the king of Babylon, and he will burn it with fire.

(Jeremiah 34:3) 
And you will not escape from his hand, but you will be captured and handed over to him. Your eyes will see the eyes of the king of Babylon, and his mouth will speak to your mouth, and you will go to Babylon.

(Jeremiah 34:4) 
Nevertheless, hear the word of the Lord, O Zedekiah, king of Judah: This is what the Lord says to you: 'You will not die by the sword.'

(Jeremiah 34:5) 
You will die in peace. And just as they burned spices for your fathers, the former kings who were before you, so they will perform the funeral burning ceremony for you. And they will mourn for you, saying, 'Alas, O king!' For I myself have spoken this word, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 34:6) 
And Jeremiah the prophet spoke all these words to Zedekiah, the king of Judah, in Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 34:7) 
And the army of the king of Babylon was fighting against Jerusalem and against all the remaining cities of Judah, against Lachish and against Azekah. For these were the only fortified cities of Judah that still remained.

(Jeremiah 34:8) 
This is the word that came to Jeremiah from the Lord, after King Zedekiah had made a covenant with all the people in Jerusalem,

(Jeremiah 34:9) 
that each man should set free his male servant and each man his female servant, whether Hebrew men or Hebrew women, making them free. And that no one should keep them, that is, any Jew, in servitude.

(Jeremiah 34:10) 
So all the officials and all the people, who had entered into the covenant that each man should set free his male servant and each man his female servant so they would no longer keep them in servitude, listened to it. And they obeyed and set them free.

(Jeremiah 34:11) 
But afterwards they turned back. And they took back their male and female servants whom they had set free, and they subjected them to be male and female slaves again.

(Jeremiah 34:12) 
Then the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah from the Lord, saying:

(Jeremiah 34:13) 
This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: 'I made a covenant with your fathers on the day I brought them out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery, saying: '

(Jeremiah 34:14) 
'At the end of seven years, each of you shall set free his Hebrew brother who has been sold to him; and when he has served you for six years, you shall set him free from you.' But your fathers did not listen to Me, nor did they incline their ear to My commands.

(Jeremiah 34:15) 
And you yourselves turned today and did what was right in My eyes, by proclaiming liberty each man to his neighbor. And you made a covenant before Me in the Temple, in the house where My name is invoked.

(Jeremiah 34:16) 
But you turned back and profaned My name. And each of you took back his male servant and each his female servant, whom you had set free to be at liberty. And you subjected them, so that they became your male and female slaves again.

(Jeremiah 34:17) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord says: 'You have not listened to Me, to proclaim liberty each man to his brother and each man to his friend.' Behold, I proclaim liberty to you, says the Lord, a liberty to die by the sword, by pestilence, and by famine. And I will make you a horror to all the kingdoms of the earth.

(Jeremiah 34:18) 
And I will give the men who have transgressed My covenant and have not performed the words of the covenant which they made before Me, when they cut a calf in two and passed between its parts—this was a ritual for making solemn covenants—

(Jeremiah 34:19) 
I will give the officials of Judah and the officials of Jerusalem, the eunuchs, and the priests, and all the people of the land who passed between the parts of the calf.

(Jeremiah 34:20) 
I will give them into the hands of their enemies and into the hands of those who seek their lives. And their dead bodies will be food for the birds of the sky and for the beasts of the earth.

(Jeremiah 34:21) 
And Zedekiah, the king of Judah, and his officials, I will give into the hands of their enemies and into the hands of those who seek their lives, and into the hands of the army of the king of Babylon, who had withdrawn from you.

(Jeremiah 34:22) 
Behold, I will command, says the Lord, and I will bring them back to this city of Jerusalem. And they will fight against it, and capture it, and burn it with fire. And I will make the cities of Judah a desolation, so that there will be no inhabitant.

(Jeremiah 35:1) 
This message came to Jeremiah from the Lord. It happened during the reign of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah. The Lord's message stated:

(Jeremiah 35:2) 
"Go to the family of the Rechabites. Speak to them, and bring them into the Temple of the Lord, into one of its chambers. Then, offer them wine to drink."

(Jeremiah 35:3) 
So I, Jeremiah, brought Jaazaniah, son of Jeremiah, son of Habazziniah, along with his brothers and all the members of the Rechabite family—their sons, their wives, and their entire company.

(Jeremiah 35:4) 
I led them into the Temple of the Lord. We went to the chamber belonging to the sons of Hanan, son of Igdaliah, a man of God. This room was located near the chamber of the princes, and it was above the chamber of Maaseiah, son of Shallum, who was the gatekeeper of the Temple.

(Jeremiah 35:5) 
Then I set before the Rechabite family, there in their chamber, many cups and goblets, all filled with wine. And I said to them, "Drink this wine."

(Jeremiah 35:6) 
They answered me, "We will not drink wine. Our ancestor, Jonadab, son of Rechab, commanded us, saying: 'You and your sons must never drink wine, not for all time.

(Jeremiah 35:7) 
You shall not build houses to live in. You shall not plant any crops. You shall not plant vineyards, nor possess any of your own. Instead, you must live in tents all your days. This way, you will live many days upon the face of the earth where you are dwelling as sojourners —people who live in a place but do not own land or settle permanently.'"

(Jeremiah 35:8) 
Therefore, we have obeyed and done everything that Jonadab, our ancestor, commanded us. We have not drunk wine throughout our entire lives—neither we, nor our wives, nor our sons, nor our daughters.

(Jeremiah 35:9) 
We have not built houses to live in, and we have had no vineyard, no field, and no crops to plant.

(Jeremiah 35:10) 
We have always lived in tents, exactly as our ancestor Jonadab commanded us."

(Jeremiah 35:11) 
"However, when Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, came up and invaded our land, we said, 'Come, let us go into Jerusalem to escape the army of the Chaldeans and the army of Syria.' That is why we are currently staying in Jerusalem."

(Jeremiah 35:12) 
Then the Lord's message came to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 35:13) 
This is what the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, declares: 'Go and tell the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem: Will you not accept My instruction and listen to My words?' says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 35:14) 
The words of Jonadab, son of Rechab, which he commanded his sons—that they should not drink wine—have been strong and effective. They have not drunk wine to this very day, and they have diligently kept the command of their ancestor. But I, the Lord, have spoken to you repeatedly, rising early and speaking diligently, yet you have not obeyed Me.

(Jeremiah 35:15) 
I sent all My servants, the prophets, to you, rising early and sending them persistently. I told them to say: 'Return, each one of you, from your wicked ways, and do good works. Do not follow foreign gods, nor worship them, and then you shall dwell in the land that I have given to you and to your fathers.' But you have not paid attention, nor have you listened to Me.

(Jeremiah 35:16) 
Because the sons of Jonadab, son of Rechab, have kept the command of their ancestor, which he gave them, but this people—the people of Judah—has not obeyed Me:

(Jeremiah 35:17) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord God of hosts, the God of Israel, declares: 'Behold, I am bringing upon Judah and upon all the inhabitants of Jerusalem all the calamity and disaster that I have spoken against them. This is because I spoke to them, but they did not listen; and I called to them, but they did not answer Me.'"

(Jeremiah 35:18) 
Then Jeremiah said to the family of the Rechabites: "This is what the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, declares: 'Because you have obeyed the command of your ancestor Jonadab, and have kept all his statutes, and have done everything he commanded you;

(Jeremiah 35:19) 
therefore, this is what the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, says: "There shall never fail to be a man from the lineage of Jonadab, son of Rechab, who stands in My presence, serving Me, for all time.'"

(Jeremiah 36:1) 
This happened in the fourth year of King Jehoiakim, who was the son of Josiah and king of Judah. This word came from the Lord to Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 36:2) 
“Take a scroll and write on it all the words that I have spoken to you against Israel, and against Judah, and against all the nations. Write everything I have said since I first spoke to you, from the days of Josiah, up until this very day.”

(Jeremiah 36:3) 
“Perhaps the entire house of Judah will listen to all the terrible things that I plan to do to them. If they do, each person might turn away from their wicked path. Then I will be merciful and forgive their evil deeds and their sins.”

(Jeremiah 36:4) 
So Jeremiah called Baruch, the son of Neriah. And Baruch wrote down everything Jeremiah dictated from the mouth of the Lord—all the words the Lord had spoken to Jeremiah—onto a scroll.

(Jeremiah 36:5) 
Then Jeremiah instructed Baruch, saying:

(Jeremiah 36:6) 
“I am confined and cannot go into the Lord’s Temple.”

(Jeremiah 36:7) 
“Therefore, you go in and read from the scroll. On it, you wrote down the words of the Lord at my dictation. Read it aloud to the people in the Lord’s Temple on a day of fasting. Also read it to all the people of Judah who come from their various towns.”

(Jeremiah 36:8) 
So Baruch, the son of Neriah, did everything that Jeremiah the prophet had commanded him. He read the words of the Lord from the scroll inside the Lord’s Temple.

(Jeremiah 36:9) 
It happened in the fifth year of King Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, king of Judah, in the ninth month. All the people in Jerusalem and the entire multitude from the towns of Judah who had gathered together in Jerusalem proclaimed a fast before the Lord.

(Jeremiah 36:10) 
And Baruch read Jeremiah’s words from the scroll in the Lord’s Temple, specifically in the chamber of Gemariah, the son of Shaphan the scribe, which was in the upper court. All the people were listening.

(Jeremiah 36:11) 
Now Micaiah, the son of Gemariah, the son of Shaphan, heard all the words of the Lord as they were read from the scroll.

(Jeremiah 36:12) 
Then Micaiah went down to the king’s palace, to the scribe’s chamber. There, all the officials were sitting: Elishama the scribe, Delaiah son of Shemaiah, Elnathan son of Akbor, Gemariah son of Shaphan, Zedekiah son of Hananiah, and all the other officials.

(Jeremiah 36:13) 
And Micaiah reported to them all the words that he had heard Baruch read from the scroll in the hearing of the people.

(Jeremiah 36:14) 
So all the officials sent Jehudi, the son of Neriah, son of Shelemiah, son of Cushi, to Baruch, saying: “Take the scroll from which you read in the hearing of the people and bring it with you. Come here.” So Baruch, the son of Neriah, took the scroll in his hand and went to them.

(Jeremiah 36:15) 
And they said to him, “Sit down and read these words to us.” So Baruch read them aloud to them.

(Jeremiah 36:16) 
When they had heard all the words, they were astonished, each one looking at his neighbor. And they said to Baruch, “We must report all these words to the king.”

(Jeremiah 36:17) 
And they questioned Baruch, saying, “Tell us, how did you write all these words? Was it at his dictation?”

(Jeremiah 36:18) 
And Baruch answered them, “He dictated all these words to me, as if reading them aloud, and I wrote them down on the scroll with ink.”

(Jeremiah 36:19) 
Then the officials said to Baruch, “Go, hide yourself, both you and Jeremiah. No one should know where you are.”

(Jeremiah 36:20) 
They then went to the king in the courtyard. They reported all the words to the king, after placing the scroll in the chamber of Elishama the scribe.

(Jeremiah 36:21) 
And the king sent Jehudi to bring the scroll. Jehudi took it from the chamber of Elishama the scribe. And Jehudi read it aloud, in the hearing of the king and all the officials who stood around the king.

(Jeremiah 36:22) 
The king was sitting in his winter palace in the ninth month. A fire was burning before him in the brazier.

(Jeremiah 36:23) 
After Jehudi had read just three or four columns of the scroll, the king cut the scroll with a scribe’s knife and threw it into the fire that was in the brazier. He kept throwing pieces until the entire scroll was consumed by the fire in the brazier.

(Jeremiah 36:24) 
Neither the king nor any of his servants who heard all these words showed any fear, nor did they tear their clothes in repentance, which was the custom when hearing a dire prophecy.

(Jeremiah 36:25) 
However, Elnathan, Delaiah, and Gemariah pleaded with the king not to burn the scroll, but he did not listen to them.

(Jeremiah 36:26) 
Then the king commanded Jerahmeel, the king’s son, Seraiah son of Azriel, and Shelemiah son of Abdeel, to seize Baruch the scribe and Jeremiah the prophet. But the Lord hid them, protecting them from capture.

(Jeremiah 36:27) 
After the king had burned the scroll and the words that Baruch had written at Jeremiah’s dictation, the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah again, saying:

(Jeremiah 36:28) 
“Take another scroll again and write on it all the former words that were on the first scroll, which King Jehoiakim of Judah burned.”

(Jeremiah 36:29) 
“And to King Jehoiakim of Judah, you are to say: ‘This is what the Lord says: You burned this scroll, saying, “Why did you write on it that the king of Babylon will surely come and destroy this land, sweeping away both people and animals?”’”

(Jeremiah 36:30) 
“Therefore, this is what the Lord says concerning King Jehoiakim of Judah: ‘He will have no successor to sit on the throne of David. His dead body will be thrown out, exposed to the scorching heat by day and the freezing cold by night, without a proper burial.’”

(Jeremiah 36:31) 
“‘And I will punish him, his descendants, and his servants for their wickedness. I will bring upon them, upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and upon the men of Judah, all the disaster that I have declared against them, because they did not listen.’”

(Jeremiah 36:32) 
Then Jeremiah took another scroll and gave it to Baruch, the son of Neriah, the scribe. And Baruch wrote on it, from Jeremiah’s dictation, all the words of the book that King Jehoiakim of Judah had burned in the fire. In addition, many other similar words were added to it, emphasizing the severity of the prophecies.

(Jeremiah 37:37:1) 
King Zedekiah, Josiah's son, came to power, reigning in place of Jehoiachin, who was the son of Jehoiakim. King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had appointed Zedekiah over the land of Judah.

(Jeremiah 37:37:2) 
But Zedekiah himself, along with his officials and the common people of the land, did not listen to the messages from the Lord that He had spoken through Jeremiah the prophet.

(Jeremiah 37:37:3) 
King Zedekiah sent Jehucal, Shelemiah's son, and Zephaniah, Maaseiah's son who was a priest, to Jeremiah the prophet. The king asked them to say: “Please pray for us to the Lord our God.”

(Jeremiah 37:37:4) 
At this time, Jeremiah was still moving about freely among the people of Jerusalem, for the other prophets had already been imprisoned.

(Jeremiah 37:37:5) 
At that very moment, the Pharaoh’s army had marched out of Egypt to provide aid to Judah. When the Chaldean forces, who were besieging Jerusalem, heard this news, they temporarily withdrew from Jerusalem to meet the Egyptian threat.

(Jeremiah 37:37:6) 
Then a specific message from the Lord came to Jeremiah the prophet, saying:

(Jeremiah 37:37:7) 
“This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says: Tell the king of Judah, who sent you to inquire of Me: ‘Behold, the army of Pharaoh, which came out to help you, will return to its own land of Egypt.'

(Jeremiah 37:37:8) 
And then, after dealing with the Egyptians, the Chaldeans will return. They will fight against this city, capture it, and burn it down completely with fire.”

(Jeremiah 37:37:9) 
“This is what the Lord says: Do not deceive yourselves by thinking, ‘The Chaldeans will surely go away and withdraw from us permanently.’ I tell you, they will not withdraw permanently.

(Jeremiah 37:37:10) 
Even if you were to strike down the entire Chaldean army that is fighting against you, and only a few wounded men remained from them, each one of those men would still rise up from his tent and come to burn this city with fire. Their victory is inevitable.”

(Jeremiah 37:37:11) 
So, when the Chaldean army had indeed withdrawn from Jerusalem because of Pharaoh’s advancing army,

(Jeremiah 37:37:12) 
Jeremiah decided to leave Jerusalem. His purpose was to go to the land of Benjamin to claim his portion of family land and settle a property dispute among his kinsmen.

(Jeremiah 37:37:13) 
But when Jeremiah arrived at the Benjamin Gate of Jerusalem, a guard was stationed there named Irijah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Hananiah. He seized Jeremiah the prophet and accused him, saying: “You are trying to desert to the Chaldeans!”

(Jeremiah 37:37:14) 
Jeremiah immediately responded, saying: “That is false! I am not fleeing to the Chaldeans!” But Irijah would not listen to him. Instead, Irijah seized Jeremiah and brought him before the leading officials of the city.

(Jeremiah 37:37:15) 
The officials were furious with Jeremiah. They ordered him to be beaten severely and then cast him into a prison that had been set up in the house of Jonathan the scribe, because Jonathan’s house had been converted into a temporary jail.

(Jeremiah 37:37:16) 
So Jeremiah was brought down into the cistern, which served as a dungeon, and into the cramped prison cells. Jeremiah remained there for many days.

(Jeremiah 37:37:17) 
However, King Zedekiah later sent for Jeremiah and had him brought to the palace. He questioned him secretly in his own house, asking: “Is there any new message from the Lord?” Jeremiah answered straightforwardly: “There is!” And then Jeremiah added: “You will certainly be handed over to the king of Babylon.”

(Jeremiah 37:37:18) 
Jeremiah then said to King Zedekiah: “What wrong have I done to you, or to your officials, or to your people, that you have thrown me into this house of imprisonment?”

(Jeremiah 37:37:19) 
“Where are your own prophets who prophesied to you,” Jeremiah challenged, “the ones who kept saying, ‘The king of Babylon will not come against you or against this land’?”

(Jeremiah 37:37:20) 
“Now therefore, please listen, my lord king,” Jeremiah pleaded. “Let my urgent appeal come before you, and please do not send me back to the house of Jonathan the scribe, for if I return there, I will surely die.”

(Jeremiah 37:37:21) 
So King Zedekiah gave a command that Jeremiah should be confined in the court of the guardhouse. He also ordered that Jeremiah be given a loaf of bread each day from the bakers’ street, and this continued until all the bread in the city was completely consumed. And so Jeremiah remained in the court of the guardhouse.

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:1) 
Shephatiah the son of Mattan, Gedaliah the son of Pashhur, Jucal the son of Shelemiah, and Pashhur the son of Malchiah heard the words that Jeremiah was speaking to all the people, saying:

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:2) 
The Lord God says this: 'Whoever remains in this city will die by sword, by famine, and by plague. But whoever surrenders to the Chaldeans will live; his life will be spared as if by salvation, though he will be captured.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:3) 
The Lord God says this: 'This city will certainly be handed over into the power of the army of the King of Babylon, and they will capture it.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:4) 
Then the princes said to the king: 'We ask that this man be put to death. Because by saying words like these to them, he is weakening the hands of the soldiers who are left in this city, and also the hands of all the people. For this man is not seeking the peace of these people, but their harm.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:5) 
And King Zedekiah said: 'Look, he is in your hands; for the king can do nothing to oppose you.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:6) 
So they took Jeremiah and threw him into the cistern of Malchiah, the son of Hammelech, which was in the court of the prison. They let Jeremiah down with ropes. Now there was only mud in the cistern, not water, so Jeremiah sank into the mud.

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:7) 
Now Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, a eunuch who was in the king's household, heard that they had thrown Jeremiah into the cistern. (The king was then sitting at the Benjamin Gate).

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:8) 
So Ebedmelech left the king's household and spoke to the king, saying:

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:9) 
'My lord the king, these men have done evil in all that they have done to Jeremiah the prophet, throwing him into the cistern so he might die there from hunger. For there is no more bread left in the city.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:10) 
Then the king commanded Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, saying: 'Take thirty men from here with you, and lift Jeremiah the prophet out of the cistern before he dies.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:11) 
So Ebedmelech took the men with him. He went into the king's house, to the room beneath the treasury, and from there he took old rags and worn-out clothes. And he let them down by ropes to Jeremiah in the cistern.

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:12) 
Then Ebedmelech said to Jeremiah: 'Put these old rags, these worn-out and decayed clothes, under your armpits beneath the ropes.' And Jeremiah did so.

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:13) 
So they pulled Jeremiah up with the ropes and brought him out of the cistern. And Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison.

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:14) 
King Zedekiah then sent for Jeremiah the prophet and had him brought to him at the third entrance, which was in the house of the Lord. And he said to Jeremiah: 'I am going to ask you a question. Do not hide anything from me.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:15) 
Then Jeremiah said to Zedekiah: 'If I tell you, will you not surely put me to death? And if I give you counsel, you will not listen to me.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:16) 
So King Zedekiah swore secretly to Jeremiah, saying: 'As the Lord lives, who created our lives, I will neither put you to death nor hand you over to these men who are seeking your life.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:17) 
Then Jeremiah said to Zedekiah: 'The Lord God of hosts, the God of Israel, says this: If you go out and surrender to the princes of the King of Babylon, your life will be spared, and this city will not be burned with fire; and you and your household will live.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:18) 
'But if you do not go out and surrender to the princes of the King of Babylon, this city will be handed over to the Chaldeans, and they will burn it with fire. And you will not escape from their hand.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:19) 
And King Zedekiah said to Jeremiah: 'I am afraid of the Jewish citizens who have deserted to the Chaldeans; I am afraid that I might be handed over to them, and they would mock me.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:20) 
But Jeremiah said: 'They will not hand you over. Listen, I beg you, to the voice of the Lord that I am speaking to you. Then it will go well with you, and your life will be spared.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:21) 
'But if you refuse to surrender, this is the word that the Lord has shown me:'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:22) 
'Behold, all the women who are left in the house of the King of Judah will be led out to the princes of the King of Babylon. And they themselves will say: “Your trusted friends have deceived you and have overcome you! They have let your feet sink into the mud, and they have led you astray into a slippery place.”'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:23) 
'All your wives and your children will be led out to the Chaldeans. And you yourself will not escape from their hands, but will be captured by the hands of the King of Babylon. And this city will be burned with fire.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:24) 
Then Zedekiah said to Jeremiah: 'Let no one know these words, and you will not die.'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:25) 
'But if the princes hear that I have spoken with you, and they come to you and say to you: “Tell us what you said to the king, and do not hide it from us, and we will not put you to death;”'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:26) 
'Then you shall say to them: “I presented my plea before the king, asking him not to send me back to Jonathan's house, lest I die there.”'

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:27) 
So all the princes came to Jeremiah and questioned him; and he answered them according to all the words that the king had commanded him. So they ceased questioning him, for nothing had been heard about the actual conversation.

(Jeremiah 38:Jeremiah 38:28) 
So Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison until the day Jerusalem was captured. And the word of the Lord came to him.

(Jeremiah 39:1) 
In the ninth year of Zedekiah's reign as King of Judah, during the tenth month, Nebuchadnezzar, the King of Babylon, came with his entire army to Jerusalem and laid siege to the city.

(Jeremiah 39:2) 
Then, in the eleventh year of Zedekiah's reign, in the fourth month, on the fifth day of that month, the city's defenses were breached.

(Jeremiah 39:3) 
All the princes of the King of Babylon entered the city and took their seats in the Middle Gate. These included Nergal-sharezer (the Samgar-nebo), Sarsechim (the Rab-saris), Nergal-sharezer (the Rab-mag), and all the other remaining princes of the King of Babylon.

(Jeremiah 39:4) 
But when King Zedekiah of Judah and all his fighting men saw them, they fled from the city by night. They went through the King’s Garden gate, which was between the two walls, and then escaped toward the desert road.

(Jeremiah 39:5) 
The Chaldean army pursued them and captured Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho. When they had seized him, they brought him to Nebuchadnezzar, the King of Babylon, at Riblah, which is in the land of Hamath, where the king pronounced judgment upon him.

(Jeremiah 39:6) 
The King of Babylon then executed Zedekiah's sons at Riblah, right before his very eyes. Nebuchadnezzar also killed all the nobles of Judah.

(Jeremiah 39:7) 
He also put out Zedekiah's eyes and bound him with bronze chains so that he could be led away to Babylon.

(Jeremiah 39:8) 
The Chaldeans set the king's palace and the people's homes on fire. They also tore down the walls of Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 39:9) 
Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, carried away into exile in Babylon the rest of the people who had remained in the city, along with the deserters who had gone over to him, and all the remaining people.

(Jeremiah 39:10) 
But Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, left some of the poorest people in the land of Judah, those who had absolutely nothing. On that same day, he gave them vineyards and cisterns for their use.

(Jeremiah 39:11) 
Now, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had given specific orders concerning Jeremiah to Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard. He had said:

(Jeremiah 39:12) 
"Take Jeremiah. Watch over him carefully and do not cause him any harm. Instead, treat him exactly as he wishes."

(Jeremiah 39:13) 
So Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, along with Nebushazban (the Rab-saris), and Nergal-sharezer (the Rab-mag), and all the chief officers of the King of Babylon, sent men.

(Jeremiah 39:14) 
They sent for Jeremiah and had him brought out of the court of the prison. Then they entrusted him to Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, so that he could be taken to his home and live among his own people.

(Jeremiah 39:15) 
While Jeremiah was still confined in the court of the prison, the word of the Lord had come to him, saying:

(Jeremiah 39:16) 
"Go and tell Ebed-melech, the Ethiopian: 'Thus says the Lord of Hosts, the God of Israel: "Behold, I am bringing My words of judgment upon this city, for evil and not for good. They will be fulfilled before your very eyes on that day."'

(Jeremiah 39:17) 
"But I will rescue you on that day," declares the Lord, "and you will not be handed over to the men you fear."

(Jeremiah 39:18) 
"For I will certainly deliver you. You will not fall by the sword, but you will save your life because you trusted in Me," declares the Lord.

(Jeremiah 40:1) 
The word from the Lord came to Jeremiah after Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, released him from Ramah. Nebuzaradan had taken Jeremiah, bound in chains, from among all the people who were being exiled from Jerusalem and the land of Judea, as they were being led away to Babylon.

(Jeremiah 40:2) 
So Nebuzaradan, the captain of the guard, took Jeremiah aside and said to him: “The Lord your God has spoken this disaster against this land.”

(Jeremiah 40:3) 
He has brought it about. The Lord has done exactly as He said He would, because you sinned against the Lord and did not listen to His voice. Therefore, this word from God has come to pass upon you.

(Jeremiah 40:4) 
“Now, look, I am releasing you today from the chains that were on your hands. If you wish to come with me to Babylon, then come, and I will personally watch over you and care for you. But if you do not wish to come with me to Babylon, then stay here. See, the whole land is before you; you may go wherever you please, and wherever you want to go, go there.”

(Jeremiah 40:5) 
When Jeremiah remained silent and gave no answer, Nebuzaradan spoke again: “Go back to Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, whom the king of Babylon has appointed as governor over the cities of Judah. You can live with him among the remaining people there, or you can go anywhere else that pleases you.” The captain of the guard also gave Jeremiah provisions and a gift, and then he let him go.

(Jeremiah 40:6) 
So Jeremiah went to Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, in Mizpah. He lived with Gedaliah among the people who were still left in the land of Judah.

(Jeremiah 40:7) 
Now, all the commanders of the armies who had been scattered throughout the surrounding regions—they, along with their men—heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, as governor over the land. The king had entrusted to him the care of the men, women, and children, and the poorest of the land, who had not been taken into exile in Babylon.

(Jeremiah 40:8) 
So these men came to Gedaliah in Mizpah, along with their soldiers: Ishmael, the son of Nethaniah; Johanan and Jonathan, the sons of Kareah; Seraiah, the son of Tanhumeth; the sons of Ephai; and Jezaniah, the son of Maacah.

(Jeremiah 40:9) 
Then Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, made an oath to them and their men, saying: “Do not be afraid to serve the Chaldeans. Stay in the land, serve the king of Babylon, and things will go well for you.”

(Jeremiah 40:10) 
“Look, I myself will reside in Mizpah to stand before the Chaldeans who come to us and to carry out their commands. As for you, go and gather your wine harvest, your grain harvest, and your olive oil. Store these provisions in your vessels, and then settle in the cities you have taken possession of.”

(Jeremiah 40:11) 
And all the Jews who were in Moab, among the Ammonites, in Edom, and in all the other surrounding regions—when they heard that the king of Babylon had allowed a remnant of the Jewish people to remain in the land of Judah, and that he had appointed Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan, over them—

(Jeremiah 40:12) 
—all these Jewish people returned from all the places to which they had fled. They came back to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah in Mizpah, and they gathered a very abundant harvest of wine, grain, and olive oil.

(Jeremiah 40:13) 
Johanan, the son of Kareah, and all the commanders of the armies who had been scattered in the surrounding regions, came to Gedaliah in Mizpah.

(Jeremiah 40:14) 
And they said to him: “Do you not know that Baalis, the king of the Ammonites, has sent Ishmael, the son of Nethaniah, to murder you?” But Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, did not believe what they told him.

(Jeremiah 40:15) 
Then Johanan, the son of Kareah, spoke to Gedaliah privately in Mizpah, saying: “I will go and kill Ishmael, the son of Nethaniah, without anyone else knowing about it. This is so he cannot murder you, which would cause all the Jews who have gathered around you to be scattered again, and the entire remnant of Judah to perish.”

(Jeremiah 40:16) 
But Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, said to Johanan, the son of Kareah: “You must not do this thing, for you are speaking a lie about Ishmael.”

(Jeremiah 41:41:1) 
It happened in the seventh month: Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, who was of royal lineage, came to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, in Mizpah. With Ishmael were officers of the king and ten other men. They ate a meal together there in Mizpah.

(Jeremiah 41:41:2) 
Then Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and the ten men who were with him, stood up. They struck Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, with a sword and killed him. Gedaliah was the one whom the King of Babylon had appointed over the land.

(Jeremiah 41:41:3) 
Ishmael also killed all the Jews who were with Gedaliah in Mizpah. He also killed the Chaldean soldiers who were found there.

(Jeremiah 41:41:4) 
On the second day after he had killed Gedaliah, and before anyone else knew about it,

(Jeremiah 41:41:5) 
eighty men arrived from Shechem, Shiloh, and Samaria. Their beards were shaved, their clothes torn, and their bodies gashed, as a sign of mourning. They were carrying grain offerings and incense to present at the House of the Lord.

(Jeremiah 41:41:6) 
Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, went out from Mizpah to meet them, pretending to weep as he walked. When he met them, he deceptively said to them, 'Come to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam.'

(Jeremiah 41:41:7) 
When they had come into the middle of the city, Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, and the men who were with him, slaughtered them in the middle of the city. Then he threw their bodies into a pit.

(Jeremiah 41:41:8) 
However, ten of those men were found among them. They pleaded with Ishmael, 'Do not kill us! We have hidden stores of barley, wheat, oil, and honey in the fields.' So Ishmael stopped, and he did not kill them along with their companions.

(Jeremiah 41:41:9) 
The pit into which Ishmael threw all the bodies of the men he had killed, in connection with Gedaliah's murder, was the large cistern that King Asa had made long ago, because of King Baasha of Israel. Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, filled it with the slain.

(Jeremiah 41:41:10) 
Ishmael then captured all the rest of the people who were in Mizpah: the king's daughters and everyone else who remained in Mizpah. These were the people whom Nebuzaradan, the commander of the guard, had entrusted to Gedaliah, son of Ahikam. Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, took them and set off to cross over to the Ammonites.

(Jeremiah 41:41:11) 
However, Johanan, son of Kareah, and all the army commanders who were with him, heard about all the evil deeds that Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, had committed.

(Jeremiah 41:41:12) 
So, gathering all their men, they went to fight against Ishmael, son of Nethaniah. They found him by the great waters that are in Gibeon.

(Jeremiah 41:41:13) 
When all the people who had been taken by Ishmael saw Johanan, son of Kareah, and all the army commanders who were with him, they rejoiced greatly.

(Jeremiah 41:41:14) 
All the people whom Ishmael had captured in Mizpah turned around. They returned and went over to Johanan, son of Kareah.

(Jeremiah 41:41:15) 
But Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, escaped with eight of his men from Johanan, son of Kareah, and fled to the Ammonites.

(Jeremiah 41:41:16) 
So Johanan, son of Kareah, and all the army commanders who were with him, gathered together all the remnant of the people whom Ishmael, son of Nethaniah, had taken from Mizpah, after he had murdered Gedaliah, son of Ahikam. These were the strong men of war, the women, the children, and the eunuchs, whom he had brought back from Gibeon.

(Jeremiah 41:41:17) 
They then set out and settled in Geruth Kimham, which is near Bethlehem. Their plan was to flee and go into Egypt.

(Jeremiah 41:41:18) 
They did this because they feared the Chaldeans. They were afraid of retaliation for the murder of Gedaliah, son of Ahikam, whom the King of Babylon had appointed over the land of Judah, by Ishmael, son of Nethaniah.

(Jeremiah 42:1) 
Then all the commanders of the army, including Johanan the son of Kareah, and Jezaniah the son of Hoshaiah, came near with all the people, from the least important to the greatest.

(Jeremiah 42:2) 
And they said to Jeremiah the prophet: 'Let our prayer be heard before you, and pray for us to God Our Lord. Pray for all of this small remnant of people. We have been left behind—only a few of us from the many—just as you yourself can see with your own eyes.'

(Jeremiah 42:3) 
'And let God Our Lord reveal to us the way in which we ought to go, and the message we should follow.'

(Jeremiah 42:4) 
Jeremiah the prophet said to them: 'I have heard you. Behold, I will pray to God Our Lord on your behalf, according to your words. And every single message that He answers me with, I will tell you. I will not hide anything from you.'

(Jeremiah 42:5) 
And they themselves said to Jeremiah: 'May Our Lord be a true and faithful witness between us. We swear that we will do exactly according to every message that God Our Lord sends you to us with.'

(Jeremiah 42:6) 
'Whether the message is good or bad, we will obey the voice of God Our Lord, to Whom we are sending you, so that it may go well with us when we listen to the voice of God Our Lord.'

(Jeremiah 42:7) 
Then, after ten days, the message from Our Lord came to Jeremiah.

(Jeremiah 42:8) 
So Jeremiah called Johanan the son of Kareah, and all the commanders of the army who were with him, and all the people, from the least important to the greatest.

(Jeremiah 42:9) 
And he said to them: 'Thus says God Our Lord, the God of Israel, to Whom you sent me to present your prayers before Him...'

(Jeremiah 42:10) 
'If you remain settled in this land, I will build you up and not tear you down. I will plant you and not pluck you up. For I have now relented from the disaster that I brought upon you.'

(Jeremiah 42:11) 
'Do not fear the king of Babylon, whom you are terrified of. Do not be afraid of him, declares Our Lord. For I am with you to save you and to rescue you from his power.'

(Jeremiah 42:12) 
'And I will show you mercy; I will have compassion on you. I will bring you back to your own land.'

(Jeremiah 42:13) 
'But if you say: 'We do not want to remain in this land,' and if you do not listen to the voice of God Our Lord...'

(Jeremiah 42:14) 
'...saying: 'No, not at all! Instead, we will go into the land of Egypt, where we will not see war, and we will not hear the sound of the trumpet, and we will not suffer from famine!' —and so you intend to live there...'

(Jeremiah 42:15) 
'Because of this, now hear the message of Our Lord, you remnant of Judah! Thus says Our Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: 'If you stubbornly set your faces toward entering Egypt, and if you indeed go there to live...'

(Jeremiah 42:16) 
'...then the very sword that you dread will overtake you there in the land of Egypt. And the famine that you fear will cling to you there in Egypt. And there you will die.'

(Jeremiah 42:17) 
'And all the men who stubbornly set their faces toward entering Egypt to live there will die by the sword, by famine, and by plague. Not one of them will survive or escape from the disaster that I will bring upon them.'

(Jeremiah 42:18) 
'For thus says Our Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: Just as My wrath and My indignation poured out over the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so will My indignation pour out over you if you enter Egypt. You will become an object of cursing, astonishment, malediction, and disgrace, and you will never again see this place.'

(Jeremiah 42:19) 
'Our Lord has spoken this message over you, O remnant of Judah: Do not go into Egypt! Know this for certain, because I have solemnly warned you today.'

(Jeremiah 42:20) 
'For you acted deceptively with your own souls when you said: 'Let us pray to God Our Lord for us. According to everything that God Our Lord tells us, so we will do.' And yet now you have acted deceptively with your own souls.'

(Jeremiah 42:21) 
'And you sent me to God Our Lord, saying: 'Pray for us to God Our Lord, and according to everything that God Our Lord tells you, so announce it to us.''

(Jeremiah 42:22) 
'Therefore, know this for certain now: you will die by the sword, by famine, and by plague in the very place where you desired to go and live.'

(Jeremiah 43:1) 
And so it happened, when Jeremiah had finished speaking to all the people every single word of the Lord their God—those words for which the Lord their God had sent him on a mission to them—all these very words:

(Jeremiah 43:2) 
Then Azariah, the son of Hoshaiah, and Johanan, the son of Kareah, and all the arrogant men spoke, saying to Jeremiah: "You are speaking a lie! The Lord our God has not sent you on a mission, saying: 'Do not go to Egypt to live there.'"

(Jeremiah 43:3) 
"Instead, Baruch, the son of Neriah, is inciting you against us, so that you may hand us over into the power of the Chaldeans, to kill us and to carry us away to Babylon."

(Jeremiah 43:4) 
So Johanan, the son of Kareah, and all the commanders of the soldiers, and all the people, did not listen to the voice of the Lord, so that they might remain in the land of Judah.

(Jeremiah 43:5) 
Instead, Johanan, the son of Kareah, and all the commanders of the soldiers, took all the remaining people of Judah who had returned from all the nations where they had been exiled, so that they might live in the land of Judah.

(Jeremiah 43:6) 
They took the men, and the women, and the children, and the king's daughters, and every living person whom Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, had left behind with Gedaliah, the son of Ahikam, the son of Shaphan. And they also took Jeremiah the prophet and Baruch, the son of Neriah.

(Jeremiah 43:7) 
And so they entered the land of Egypt because they had not obeyed the voice of the Lord, and they came all the way to Tahpanhes.

(Jeremiah 43:8) 
Then the word of the Lord came to Jeremiah in Tahpanhes, saying:

(Jeremiah 43:9) 
"Take large stones in your hand and bury them in the hidden place that is under the brick pavement at the entrance of Pharaoh's house in Tahpanhes, with the men of Judah watching."

(Jeremiah 43:10) 
"And you are to say to them: 'Thus says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel: "Behold, I myself am sending for and bringing Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, my servant. And I will set his throne upon these very stones which you have hidden, and he will pitch his royal tent over them."'

(Jeremiah 43:11) 
"And when he comes, he will strike the land of Egypt. Those destined for death will face death; those destined for captivity will go into captivity; and those destined for the sword will die by the sword."

(Jeremiah 43:12) 
"And he will set fire to the houses of the gods of Egypt; he will burn them and lead their idols into captivity. He will strip the land of Egypt clean, just as a shepherd thoroughly cleans his garment of clinging dirt or parasites. Then he will depart from there in peace."

(Jeremiah 43:13) 
"And he will break to pieces the sacred pillars of Heliopolis, which are in the land of Egypt, and he will burn the temples of the gods of Egypt with fire."

(Jeremiah 44:44:1) 
This is the message that came to Jeremiah concerning all the Jews living in the land of Egypt. These were the Jews dwelling in Migdol, Tahpanhes, Memphis, and in the region of Pathros. The message stated:

(Jeremiah 44:44:2) 
This is what the Lord of heavenly armies, the God of Israel, says: 'You yourselves have seen all the disasters I brought upon Jerusalem and upon all the cities of Judah. Behold, they are desolate ruins today, and no one lives in them anymore.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:3) 
This happened because of the evil deeds they committed, which provoked Me to anger. They did this by going and offering incense to other gods and worshipping them—false gods that neither they, nor you, nor your fathers had ever known.

(Jeremiah 44:44:4) 
Even so, I sent all My servants the prophets to you, again and again, rising early and sending them. I told them to say: 'Do not do this detestable kind of thing that I hate.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:5) 
But they did not listen, nor did they pay any attention. They refused to turn from their evil ways and stop offering incense to other gods.

(Jeremiah 44:44:6) 
So My indignation and My fury were poured out, and they burned in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. These places became a desolate ruin and a waste, just as you see them this very day.

(Jeremiah 44:44:7) 
Now, therefore, this is what the Lord of heavenly armies, the God of Israel, says: 'Why are you doing this great evil against your own lives? You are causing men and women, infants and nursing babies to perish from among you in Judah, ensuring that no remnant remains for you.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:8) 
You provoke Me to anger with the works of your own hands by offering sacrifices to false gods in the land of Egypt, where you have come to live as foreigners. By doing this, you ensure your own destruction, making yourselves a curse and a disgrace among all the nations of the earth.

(Jeremiah 44:44:9) 
Have you forgotten the wickedness of your fathers, and the wickedness of the kings of Judah, and the wickedness of their wives? Have you forgotten your own wickedness, and the wickedness of your wives, which they all committed in the land of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?

(Jeremiah 44:44:10) 
They have not humbled themselves or been cleansed of their sins even to this very day. They have not feared Me, nor have they walked in My law and in My commandments, which I gave to you and to your fathers.

(Jeremiah 44:44:11) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord of heavenly armies, the God of Israel, says: 'Behold, I am setting My face against you with resolve to bring disaster and to destroy all Judah.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:12) 
I will take the remnant of Judah who stubbornly set their minds on going into the land of Egypt to live there as foreigners. They will all perish in the land of Egypt; they will fall by the sword and by famine. From the least important to the most important, they will die by sword and famine.
