They will become a curse, an object of horror, a malediction, and a reproach.

(Jeremiah 44:44:13) 
I will punish those who live in the land of Egypt, just as I punished Jerusalem, with the sword, famine, and pestilence.

(Jeremiah 44:44:14) 
There will be no one who escapes and survives from the remnant of Judah who go into the land of Egypt to live there as foreigners. They will not return to the land of Judah, which they desire with all their souls to inhabit. No, they will not return, except for a very few who manage to flee in haste.

(Jeremiah 44:44:15) 
Then all the men who knew that their wives were regularly offering sacrifices to false gods, along with their wives, and all the large crowd of Jews from the land of Judah who were living in the land of Egypt, in Pathros, answered Jeremiah, saying:

(Jeremiah 44:44:16) 
'The message you have spoken to us in the name of the Lord—we will not listen to it from you!'

(Jeremiah 44:44:17) 
'No, we will certainly do everything we have vowed to do, which comes out of our own mouths. We will continue to offer sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven—that pagan goddess—and pour out drink offerings to her, just as we ourselves, and our fathers, our kings, and our princes did in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem. When we did this, we were filled with bread, and it was well with us; we experienced no misfortune.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:18) 
'But ever since we stopped offering sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pouring out drink offerings to her, we have lacked everything, and we have been consumed by the sword and by famine.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:19) 
'And when we women offer sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pour out drink offerings to her, do you think we make cakes in her image for her worship and pour out drink offerings to her without our husbands knowing about it and consenting?' This implies a rhetorical 'No, we do it with their full knowledge and consent.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:20) 
Then Jeremiah spoke to all the people, to all the men and all the women who had answered him with those words, saying:

(Jeremiah 44:44:21) 
'The sacrifices you offered in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem—you and your fathers, your kings, and your princes, and the people of the land—did the Lord not remember these things? Did these actions not come into His mind?'

(Jeremiah 44:44:22) 
'And the Lord could no longer tolerate it, because of the wickedness of your deeds and because of the detestable things you committed. Therefore, your land became a desolation, a place of horror, and a curse, without an inhabitant, just as you see it this very day.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:23) 
'Because you offered incense and sinned against the Lord, and you did not obey the voice of the Lord, and you did not walk in His law, in His commandments, and in His testimonies, these disasters have come upon you, just as you see them this very day.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:24) 
Jeremiah then said to all the people and to all the women: 'Hear the message of the Lord, all of you from Judah who are in the land of Egypt!'

(Jeremiah 44:44:25) 
'This is what the Lord of heavenly armies, the God of Israel, says: "You and your wives have spoken with your mouths and carried out with your hands, saying: 'We will certainly perform our vows which we made, to offer sacrifices to the Queen of Heaven and pour out drink offerings to her.' You have indeed confirmed your vows and have fulfilled them with your actions."'

(Jeremiah 44:44:26) 
'Therefore, hear the message of the Lord, all of you from Judah who live in the land of Egypt: "Behold, I have sworn by My great name," says the Lord, "that My name will no longer be invoked by the mouth of any man of Judah in all the land of Egypt, no one saying: 'As the Lord God lives!' This means their claim to follow Me will cease."'

(Jeremiah 44:44:27) 
'"Behold, I will watch over them for evil and not for good. All the men of Judah who are in the land of Egypt will be consumed by the sword and by famine until they are utterly destroyed and perish."'

(Jeremiah 44:44:28) 
'And only a very few who escape the sword will return from the land of Egypt to the land of Judah. Then all the remnant of Judah who entered the land of Egypt to live as foreigners there will know whose word stands firm: My word, or their word.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:29) 
'And this will be a sign to you,' says the Lord, 'that I will punish you in this very place, so that you may know that My words will truly be established against you to bring disaster.'

(Jeremiah 44:44:30) 
'This is what the Lord says: "Behold, I will hand over Pharaoh Hophra, the king of Egypt, into the hand of his enemies and into the hand of those who seek his life, just as I handed over Zedekiah, the king of Judah, into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon—his enemy and one who sought his life."'

(Jeremiah 45:Jeremias 45:1) 
This is the message that the prophet Jeremiah spoke to Baruch, son of Neriah. This happened when Baruch was writing these words from Jeremiah's own dictation into a scroll, during the fourth year of Jehoiakim, son of Josiah, as king of Judah. Jeremiah delivered the message to Baruch, saying:

(Jeremiah 45:Jeremias 45:2) 
The Lord God of Israel says this to you, Baruch:

(Jeremiah 45:Jeremias 45:3) 
You said, 'Alas for me, I am miserable! The Lord has added more sorrow to my existing pain. I am exhausted from my constant groaning, and I cannot find any peace or rest.'

(Jeremiah 45:Jeremias 45:4) 
Then Jeremiah will say this to him: The Lord declares, 'Listen! What I have built up, I am now going to tear down. What I have planted, I am now going to uproot. This will happen throughout all the land.'

(Jeremiah 45:Jeremias 45:5) 
And are you seeking great things and personal honors for yourself? Stop seeking them! For behold, the Lord declares, 'I am about to bring disaster upon all of humanity. But I will allow you to keep your life as a spoil of war, and you will be safe wherever you go.'

(Jeremiah 46:1) 
This is the word of the Lord, which came to Jeremiah the prophet, and it was a message against the nations.

(Jeremiah 46:2) 
It was a message concerning Egypt and the army of Pharaoh Neco, the king of Egypt. This army was stationed by the Euphrates River at Carchemish, where Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, defeated them. This battle happened in the fourth year of the reign of Jehoiakim, the son of Josiah, the king of Judah.

(Jeremiah 46:3) 
To the Egyptian army, God says: Prepare your large shield and your small buckler, and go forth to war!

(Jeremiah 46:4) 
Harness your horses, O horsemen, and mount them! Stand ready with your helmets, fitted securely, and sharpen your spears. Put on your breastplates, O warriors!

(Jeremiah 46:5) 
But what is this that I see? I see them utterly terrified, turning their backs and fleeing! Their mighty warriors are cut down and have turned to run away. They have not returned because fear has gripped them from every side, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 46:6) 
The swift soldier will not escape, and the strong warrior will not be saved. By the Euphrates River, in the northern lands, they have stumbled and fallen down completely.

(Jeremiah 46:7) 
Who is this that rises up like the Nile River, and whose waters surge like powerful torrents?

(Jeremiah 46:8) 
It is Egypt, rising up like the Nile, and its waters will surge like torrents. Egypt says: 'I will rise up and cover the whole land! I will destroy its cities and all their inhabitants!'

(Jeremiah 46:9) 
Mount your horses, and rejoice in your chariots, O mighty warriors! Go forth, Ethiopians and Libyans, holding your shields! And you, Lydians, hold and direct your arrows!

(Jeremiah 46:10) 
But that day is the day of the Lord, the God of the heavenly armies—a day of vengeance, when He will take retribution on His enemies. The sword will devour until it is completely satisfied, and it will be drunk with their blood. For this is a sacrifice to the Lord, the God of heavenly armies, in the northern land, by the Euphrates River.

(Jeremiah 46:11) 
Go up to Gilead and gather healing balm, O virgin daughter of Egypt! You multiply your medicines in vain; there will be no healing for you from this wound.

(Jeremiah 46:12) 
The nations have heard of your shame and disgrace, and your wailing has filled the whole earth. For a mighty warrior has stumbled against another mighty warrior, and both of them have fallen together.

(Jeremiah 46:13) 
This is the word that the Lord spoke to Jeremiah the prophet, concerning Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, and his coming to strike the land of Egypt.

(Jeremiah 46:14) 
Announce it in Egypt! Make it heard in Migdol! Let it resound in Memphis and Tahpanhes! Say to them: 'Stand ready and prepare yourselves, for the sword will devour all around you!'

(Jeremiah 46:15) 
Why has your mighty protector fallen? He did not stand, because the Lord Himself overthrew him.

(Jeremiah 46:16) 
Many have fallen, and one man has fallen upon his neighbor. They will say: 'Arise, let us return to our own people and to the land of our birth, away from the face of the sword of the oppressor from the north.'

(Jeremiah 46:17) 
Call the name of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt: 'A mere boast at its appointed time,' or 'A great noise that quickly passes.'

(Jeremiah 46:18) 
'As I live,' says the King, whose name is the Lord of heavenly armies, 'for as Tabor stands majestic among the mountains, and as Carmel rises by the sea, so surely will he come!'

(Jeremiah 46:19) 
Prepare for yourselves your traveling bags for exile, O dwelling daughter of Egypt! For Memphis will become a desolate wasteland, laid waste and completely uninhabited.

(Jeremiah 46:20) 
Egypt is like a most beautiful heifer, but a stinging gadfly, a deadly attack, will come to her from the north.

(Jeremiah 46:21) 
Even her hired soldiers, who were among her like well-fed calves, have turned and fled together; they could not stand their ground. For the day of their slaughter has come upon them, the very time of their divine punishment.

(Jeremiah 46:22) 
Her voice will sound like the hiss of a serpent fleeing, because the enemy will march with an army and come against her with axes, like those who cut down trees in a forest.

(Jeremiah 46:23) 
They have cut down her forest, says the Lord, a forest that cannot be replenished. For the invaders are more numerous than locusts, and there is no numbering them.

(Jeremiah 46:24) 
The daughter of Egypt is utterly put to shame; she is delivered into the hand of the people from the north.

(Jeremiah 46:25) 
Thus says the Lord of heavenly armies, the God of Israel: 'Behold, I am about to punish the mighty pride of Alexandria, and Pharaoh, and Egypt itself, and her gods, and her kings — even Pharaoh and all those who trust in him.'

(Jeremiah 46:26) 
And I will deliver them into the hand of those who seek their lives, and into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, and into the hand of his servants. But after these things, Egypt shall be inhabited again, as in the days of old, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 46:27) 
But as for you, My servant Jacob, do not fear, and do not be terrified, O Israel! For behold, I will save you from distant lands, and your descendants from the land of their captivity. And Jacob shall return and rest and be at peace, and no one shall make him afraid.

(Jeremiah 46:28) 
Therefore, do not fear, O My servant Jacob, says the Lord, for I am with you. For I will utterly destroy all the nations among whom I have scattered you, but I will not utterly destroy you. Instead, I will discipline you with justice, and I will by no means let you go unpunished as if you were innocent.

(Jeremiah 47:1) 
The word of the Lord, which came to Jeremiah the prophet, was a prophecy concerning the Philistines. This prophecy came before Pharaoh attacked the city of Gaza.

(Jeremiah 47:2) 
The Lord declares: "Behold, a great flood of devastation is rising from the north, like an overflowing torrent. It will cover the land and all its inhabitants—the cities and everyone living in them. People will cry out in terror, and all the inhabitants of that land will wail."

(Jeremiah 47:3) 
At the terrifying sound of crashing weapons and the shouts of warring princes, at the loud rumbling of chariot wheels and the furious charge of war chariots, fathers will be too paralyzed by fear and despair to even reach out to save their children. Their hands will be too weak from terror to act.

(Jeremiah 47:4) 
This devastation comes because a destroyer will come against all the Philistines, intending to destroy the cities of Tyre and Sidon, along with all their allied forces. For the Lord will completely annihilate the Philistines, those remaining descendants from the island of Caphtor.

(Jeremiah 47:5) 
Gaza has been stripped bare in mourning and desolation. Ashkelon is utterly silent, and the remaining inhabitants of their coastal plain are likewise silent. The prophet cries out, "How long will you continue to destroy, O razor of the Lord?"

(Jeremiah 47:6) 
"O razor of the Lord, how long will you keep destroying? When will you finally rest? Sheathe yourself! Be still, and be silent!"

(Jeremiah 47:7) 
"How can it possibly rest when the Lord Himself has given it a command? He has directed it against Ashkelon and against all the Philistine coastal regions, and there He has appointed its destructive work."

(Jeremiah 48:1) 
The Lord of Armies, the God of Israel, says this concerning Moab: Woe to Nebo, for it is laid waste and put to shame! Kiriathaim has been captured; her stronghold is disgraced and has trembled.

(Jeremiah 48:2) 
There is no more rejoicing in Moab over Heshbon. An evil plan has been devised: “Come, let us destroy Moab from being a nation.” Therefore, you will be silenced and pursued by the sword.

(Jeremiah 48:3) 
A voice of crying is heard from Horonaim, a great devastation and destruction.

(Jeremiah 48:4) 
Moab has been crushed. Proclaim her fate to her little ones.

(Jeremiah 48:5) 
With bitter weeping, they ascend the road to Luhith. For on the descent to Horonaim, the enemies have raised a cry of destruction.

(Jeremiah 48:6) 
Flee, save your lives, and you will be like a desert bush in the wilderness.

(Jeremiah 48:7) 
Because you trusted in your strongholds and your treasures, you also will be captured. Chemosh (the god of Moab) will go into exile, along with his priests and his princes.

(Jeremiah 48:8) 
A destroyer will come to every city, and no city will be saved. The valleys will perish, and the plains will be laid waste, for the Lord has spoken it.

(Jeremiah 48:9) 
Give wings to Moab, that she may flee swiftly. Her cities will become desolate and uninhabited.

(Jeremiah 48:10) 
Cursed is he who does the Lord's work deceitfully. And cursed is he who keeps his sword from shedding blood.

(Jeremiah 48:11) 
Moab has been at ease from her youth, resting on her dregs like wine undisturbed. She has not been poured from vessel to vessel, nor has she gone into exile. Therefore, her taste remains in her, and her scent has not changed.

(Jeremiah 48:12) 
Therefore, behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, when I will send men to Moab to tip her over and empty her out. They will empty her vessels and smash her jars.

(Jeremiah 48:13) 
Moab will be put to shame by Chemosh (her god), just as the house of Israel was put to shame by Bethel, their false god in whom they trusted.

(Jeremiah 48:14) 
How can you say, “We are mighty, strong men for battle”?

(Jeremiah 48:15) 
Moab is laid waste, and her cities are attacked. Her chosen young men are slaughtered, says the King, whose name is the Lord of Armies.

(Jeremiah 48:16) 
The destruction of Moab is near, and her calamity hastens swiftly.

(Jeremiah 48:17) 
All who surround Moab, and all who know her name, mourn for her. Say, “How has the strong staff, the glorious scepter, been broken?”

(Jeremiah 48:18) 
Descend from your glory and sit in the dust, Daughter of Dibon. For the destroyer of Moab has come against you; he has torn down your strongholds.

(Jeremiah 48:19) 
Stand by the road and look, inhabitant of Aroer. Ask the fleeing one and the one who has escaped, saying, “What has happened?”

(Jeremiah 48:20) 
Moab is disgraced, for she is overcome. Wail and cry out! Proclaim by the Arnon River that Moab is laid waste.

(Jeremiah 48:21) 
And judgment has come upon the land of the plain: upon Holon, and upon Jahzah, and upon Mephaath,

(Jeremiah 48:22) 
And upon Dibon, and upon Nebo, and upon Beth-Diblathaim,

(Jeremiah 48:23) 
And upon Kiriathaim, and upon Beth-Gamul, and upon Beth-Meon,

(Jeremiah 48:24) 
And upon Kerioth, and upon Bozrah, and upon all the cities of the land of Moab, far and near.

(Jeremiah 48:25) 
The horn (symbol of strength) of Moab is cut off, and her arm is broken, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 48:26) 
Make Moab drunk, for she has defied the Lord. Moab will wallow in her own vomit and become a laughingstock.

(Jeremiah 48:27) 
Was not Israel a laughingstock to you, as if you had found him among thieves? Therefore, because of the words you spoke against him, you will be taken captive.

(Jeremiah 48:28) 
Leave the cities and dwell in the rock, inhabitants of Moab. Be like a dove that makes its nest in the highest cleft of a rock.

(Jeremiah 48:29) 
We have heard of Moab's great pride; she is exceedingly proud: her loftiness, her arrogance, her pride, and the haughtiness of her heart.

(Jeremiah 48:30) 
I know her boasting, says the Lord, but her power is not equal to her boast, nor can she accomplish what she claims.

(Jeremiah 48:31) 
Therefore, I will wail over Moab; I will cry out for all of Moab. I will mourn for the men of Kir-Heres (the strong city of Moab).

(Jeremiah 48:32) 
I will weep for you, O vine of Sibmah, with the weeping of Jazer. Your branches spread beyond the sea, reaching even to the Sea of Jazer. But a destroyer has fallen upon your harvest and your vintage.

(Jeremiah 48:33) 
Joy and gladness have been taken away from the fruitful fields and from the land of Moab. I have removed wine from the winepresses. No one will tread the grapes and sing the treader's song.

(Jeremiah 48:34) 
From the cry of Heshbon even to Elealeh and Jahaz, they have raised their voices. From Zoar to Horonaim, they cry like a three-year-old heifer. The waters of Nimrim also will be desolate.

(Jeremiah 48:35) 
And I will put an end to Moab, says the Lord, to anyone who offers sacrifices on the high places and burns incense to her idols.

(Jeremiah 48:36) 
Therefore, my heart will lament for Moab like a flute, and my heart will lament for the men of Kir-Heres like a flute. For the wealth she acquired has perished, even more than she possessed.

(Jeremiah 48:37) 
For every head will be shaved bald, and every beard cut off. On all hands will be gashes, and on every back, sackcloth. These are traditional signs of deep mourning.

(Jeremiah 48:38) 
On all the rooftops of Moab and in her public squares, there will be universal lamentation. For I have crushed Moab like a useless vessel, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 48:39) 
How she is broken! How they wail! How Moab has turned her back in shame! Moab will be an object of scorn and a warning to all around her.

(Jeremiah 48:40) 
Thus says the Lord: Behold, an enemy will swoop down like an eagle and spread his wings over Moab.

(Jeremiah 48:41) 
Kerioth is captured, and the strongholds are taken. The hearts of Moab's warriors on that day will be like the heart of a woman in labor.

(Jeremiah 48:42) 
And Moab will be destroyed from being a nation, because she defied the Lord.

(Jeremiah 48:43) 
Terror, a pit, and a snare are upon you, O inhabitant of Moab, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 48:44) 
Whoever flees from the terror will fall into the pit, and whoever climbs out of the pit will be caught in the snare. For I will bring these things upon Moab in the year of their punishment, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 48:45) 
Those who fled stood helpless in the shadow of Heshbon, because they had no more strength. For fire will come out from Heshbon, and a flame from the midst of Sihon. It will devour the border regions of Moab and the heads of the boastful people.

(Jeremiah 48:46) 
Woe to you, Moab! You have perished, O people of Chemosh. For your sons and your daughters have been taken captive.

(Jeremiah 48:47) 
Yet, in the latter days, I will restore the fortunes of Moab, says the Lord. Thus far is the judgment upon Moab.

(Jeremiah 49:1) 
To the descendants of Ammon. This is what the Lord says: Does Israel not have sons? Does Israel not have an heir? If so, why has the false god Milcom, or the king of Ammon, taken possession of the tribe of Gad's land? And why do his people dwell in its cities?

(Jeremiah 49:2) 
Therefore, behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, when I will cause the sound of battle to be heard against Rabbah, the capital city of the descendants of Ammon. It will become a desolate mound of rubble, and its surrounding villages will be set on fire. Then Israel will truly possess what is its inheritance, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 49:3) 
Cry out, O Heshbon, for the city of Ai is devastated! Wail, O villages of Rabbah! Put on sackcloth, mourn, and wander through the ruins, for Milcom—your false god and king—will be taken into exile, along with his priests and his princes.

(Jeremiah 49:4) 
Why do you boast about your valleys? Your valley is ruined, O pampered daughter of Ammon! You trusted in your treasures and said, 'Who will attack me?'

(Jeremiah 49:5) 
Behold, I am bringing terror upon you from all those around you, says the Lord, the God of heavenly armies! I will scatter you in all directions, and there will be no one to gather the fleeing survivors.

(Jeremiah 49:6) 
But after these things, I will restore the fortunes of the descendants of Ammon, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 49:7) 
Concerning Edom. This is what the Lord of heavenly armies says: Is there no longer wisdom in Teman, a place known for its wise men? Has counsel perished from the sons of Esau? Has their wisdom become useless?

(Jeremiah 49:8) 
Flee, turn back, retreat into the depths, O inhabitants of Dedan, an allied nation! For I will bring the destruction of Esau's descendants (Edom) upon him, the time of his punishment.

(Jeremiah 49:9) 
If grape gatherers came to you, wouldn't they leave some gleanings behind? If thieves came by night, they would only steal enough for themselves.

(Jeremiah 49:10) 
But I myself will strip Esau (Edom) bare; I will uncover his hidden places, and he will not be able to hide. Edom is devastated, along with his children, his relatives, and his neighbors; there will be no one left.

(Jeremiah 49:11) 
O Edom, leave your orphans to Me; I will preserve their lives. And your widows will hope in Me, even amidst your destruction.

(Jeremiah 49:12) 
For this is what the Lord says: Behold, those who were not condemned to drink the cup of My wrath will certainly drink it. So then, will you, who are far from innocent, be left unpunished? No, you will not be left; you will surely drink the cup of My judgment.

(Jeremiah 49:13) 
For I have sworn by Myself, says the Lord, that Bozrah, Edom's capital city, will become a desolate ruin, an object of reproach, a wasteland, and a curse. And all its cities will become everlasting desolations.

(Jeremiah 49:14) 
I have heard a report from the Lord, and an envoy has been sent among the nations: 'Gather yourselves, and come against Edom! Let us rise up for battle!'

(Jeremiah 49:15) 
For behold, I have made you small among the nations, despised among men.

(Jeremiah 49:16) 
Your arrogance has deceived you, and the pride of your heart, you who dwell in the clefts of the rocks, like the city of Petra, trying to seize the heights of the hill. Though you make your nest as high as the eagle's, from there I will bring you down, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 49:17) 
And Edom will become a desolation; everyone who passes by it will be horrified and will hiss in astonishment at its wounds.

(Jeremiah 49:18) 
Just as Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighboring cities were overthrown, says the Lord, no one will live there, and no human being will dwell in it.

(Jeremiah 49:19) 
Behold, one will come up like a lion from the thickets of the Jordan River against the strong pastures. For I will suddenly make him rush upon it. And the one whom I choose, him I will appoint over it. For who is like Me? And who will challenge Me? And what shepherd can stand before My face?

(Jeremiah 49:20) 
Therefore, hear the plan of the Lord that He has formed concerning Edom, and His intentions that He has devised concerning the inhabitants of Teman: Surely, the weakest of the flock will drag them away. Surely, their dwellings will be devastated along with them.

(Jeremiah 49:21) 
At the sound of their fall, the earth will tremble. The cry of their destruction will be heard as far as the Red Sea.

(Jeremiah 49:22) 
Behold, he will ascend like an eagle and fly swiftly, spreading his wings over Bozrah. And on that day, the hearts of Edom's bravest warriors will be like the heart of a woman in labor.

(Jeremiah 49:23) 
Concerning Damascus. Hamath and Arphad are shamed and dismayed, for they have heard terrible news. They are troubled like the restless sea; they cannot be at peace.

(Jeremiah 49:24) 
Damascus is weakened; she has turned to flee. Terror has seized her, and anguish and pains have overcome her, like a woman in labor.

(Jeremiah 49:25) 
How is it that such a praiseworthy city, the city of My joy, has been abandoned?

(Jeremiah 49:26) 
Therefore, her young men will fall in her streets, and all her men of battle will be silenced on that day, says the Lord of heavenly armies.

(Jeremiah 49:27) 
And I will kindle a fire in the wall of Damascus, and it will consume the palaces of Ben-Hadad, a royal title for the kings of Aram-Damascus.

(Jeremiah 49:28) 
Concerning Kedar and the kingdoms of Hazor, which Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, attacked. This is what the Lord says: 'Rise up, go up against Kedar, and lay waste to the people of the East, the desert tribes.'

(Jeremiah 49:29) 
Their tents and their flocks will be captured; their tent coverings, all their vessels, and their camels will be taken away. Terror will be proclaimed against them from every side.

(Jeremiah 49:30) 
Flee, depart quickly, retreat into the depths, O inhabitants of Hazor, says the Lord! For Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, has formed a plan against you, and has devised intentions concerning you.

(Jeremiah 49:31) 
Rise up, and go up against a nation that lives peacefully and securely, says the Lord. They have no gates nor bars; they dwell alone without defenses.

(Jeremiah 49:32) 
Their camels will become plunder, and their great number of livestock will be spoil. And I will scatter them to every wind, those whose hair is trimmed at the temples (a sign of their custom). And from every side, I will bring destruction upon them, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 49:33) 
And Hazor will become a dwelling for jackals, a desolation forever. No one will live there, nor will any human being dwell in it.

(Jeremiah 49:34) 
The word of the Lord that came to Jeremiah the prophet concerning Elam, in the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, king of Judah, saying:

(Jeremiah 49:35) 
This is what the Lord of heavenly armies says: 'Behold, I will break the bow of Elam, which is their chief strength.'

(Jeremiah 49:36) 
And I will bring upon Elam four winds from the four corners of the universe; and I will scatter them to all these winds. There will be no nation to which the refugees of Elam will not go.

(Jeremiah 49:37) 
And I will cause Elam to be terrified before their enemies and before those who seek their lives. I will bring evil upon them, the fierceness of My wrath, says the Lord. And I will send the sword after them until I have consumed them.

(Jeremiah 49:38) 
And I will set My throne in Elam, and there I will destroy its kings and princes, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 49:39) 
But in the last days, I will restore the fortunes of Elam, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 50:1) 
This is the message that the Lord spoke concerning Babylon, and concerning the land of the Chaldeans, given through Jeremiah the prophet.

(Jeremiah 50:2) 
Declare this among the nations; proclaim it loudly and make it known! Set up a signal; preach it openly and do not conceal it! Tell them: 'Babylon has been conquered! Bel, their false god, is shamed! Merodach, their idol, is broken! Her lifeless images are disgraced, their false gods are shattered!'

(Jeremiah 50:3) 
For a nation from the North has marched against Babylon. They will turn her land into a desolate wasteland, and no one will live there, neither people nor animals. Her people will flee and scatter.

(Jeremiah 50:4) 
In those days and at that time, says the Lord, the people of Israel and Judah will come together. They will come weeping, urgently seeking the Lord their God.

(Jeremiah 50:5) 
They will ask the way to Zion, their faces turned towards it with earnest desire. They will come and join themselves to the Lord through an everlasting covenant, one that will never be forgotten or broken.

(Jeremiah 50:6) 
My people have become a lost flock. Their leaders have led them astray, driving them to climb false mountains of sin. They wandered from hill to mountain, forgetting their true resting place and their spiritual home.

(Jeremiah 50:7) 
All who found them devoured them like prey. And their enemies justified themselves, saying: 'We are not guilty, for these people have sinned against the Lord, the very source of justice and glory, and the God whom their ancestors eagerly expected and worshipped.'

(Jeremiah 50:8) 
Flee from Babylon's midst! Get out of the land of the Chaldeans! Lead the way like rams at the head of a flock, guiding others to safety.

(Jeremiah 50:9) 
For behold, I am stirring up and bringing against Babylon a great alliance of nations from the northern lands. They will prepare for battle against her, and from that very direction, Babylon will be captured. Their arrows will be like those of a mighty warrior, striking true and not returning without their kill.

(Jeremiah 50:10) 
And the land of Chaldea will become plunder. All who plunder her will take their fill.

(Jeremiah 50:11) 
Because you rejoiced with shouts of triumph and plundered My chosen inheritance. Because you gamboled like calves in fresh pasture and bellowed like strong bulls in triumph.

(Jeremiah 50:12) 
Your mother—Babylon itself—is utterly shamed, and she who bore you is disgraced. Behold, she will be the lowliest among the nations, a desolate wasteland, without roads, and parched dry.

(Jeremiah 50:13) 
Because of the Lord's burning wrath, Babylon will remain uninhabited and become a complete wasteland. Every person who passes by Babylon will be struck with awe and will hiss in dismay at all her devastating wounds.

(Jeremiah 50:14) 
Form your battle lines all around Babylon, all of you who draw the bow! Fire your arrows at her; do not hold back a single arrow, for she has deeply sinned against the Lord.

(Jeremiah 50:15) 
Shout the battle cry against her from every side! Babylon has surrendered! Her cities are overthrown, her mighty walls are torn down, for this is the Lord's vengeance. Take revenge on her; deal with her exactly as she dealt with others.

(Jeremiah 50:16) 
Cut off the sower in Babylon, and the one wielding the sickle at harvest time, so no future crops will grow. Because of the invaders' sword, everyone will flee back to their own people, and each person will escape to their homeland.

(Jeremiah 50:17) 
Israel is a scattered flock, driven away by ferocious lions. First, the king of Assyria devoured them. Then, this last one, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, crushed their bones.

(Jeremiah 50:18) 
Therefore, this is what the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, declares: 'Behold, I will punish the king of Babylon and his land, just as I punished the king of Assyria.'

(Jeremiah 50:19) 
And I will bring Israel back to their own dwelling place. And they will graze in the fertile lands of Carmel and Bashan, and on Mount Ephraim and Gilead their souls will be fully satisfied.

(Jeremiah 50:20) 
In those days and at that time, says the Lord, the iniquity of Israel will be sought out, but none will be found; the sin of Judah will be sought, but it will not be found. For I will graciously forgive those whom I have preserved.

(Jeremiah 50:21) 
Go up against the land of Merathaim—a land of double rebellion—and against the inhabitants of Pekod—a land of punishment. Completely destroy those who resist, and put to death those who follow them. Devote everything to utter destruction, says the Lord. Do everything I have commanded you.

(Jeremiah 50:22) 
The sound of battle echoes across the land, and the destruction is immense.

(Jeremiah 50:23) 
How completely broken and shattered is the hammer that struck down the whole earth—Babylon! How Babylon has become a wasteland among the nations!

(Jeremiah 50:24) 
I have set a trap for you, Babylon, and you are caught, completely unaware! You are discovered and seized, because you dared to defy the Lord.

(Jeremiah 50:25) 
The Lord has opened His armory and brought forth the weapons of His wrath. For this is the work of the Lord God of hosts in the land of the Chaldeans.

(Jeremiah 50:26) 
Come against her from every border; break open her granaries until her goods lie in heaps. And utterly destroy, leaving no survivors; let nothing remain.

(Jeremiah 50:27) 
Slay all her mighty warriors; let them go down to the slaughter! Woe to them! For their day has come—the time of their destined punishment!

(Jeremiah 50:28) 
Listen! The sound of those who flee and escape from the land of Babylon, they come to declare in Zion the vengeance of the Lord our God—the vengeance for His sacred Temple.

(Jeremiah 50:29) 
Summon many archers against Babylon, all you who draw the bow! Surround her completely; let no one escape! Repay her for her deeds; do to her exactly as she has done to others, because she has acted with arrogant pride against the Lord, against the Holy One of Israel.

(Jeremiah 50:30) 
Therefore, her young warriors will fall in her streets. And all her fighting men will be utterly silenced on that day, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 50:31) 
Behold, I am against you, O arrogant one! says the Lord God of hosts. For your day has come—the time of your deserved punishment.

(Jeremiah 50:32) 
And that arrogant one will stumble and fall, with no one to help her rise again. And I will kindle a fire in Babylon's cities, and it will consume everything around her.

(Jeremiah 50:33) 
This is what the Lord of hosts says: The people of Israel and Judah have both suffered severe oppression. And all who took them captive held them tightly, refusing to release them.

(Jeremiah 50:34) 
Their Redeemer is mighty; the Lord of hosts is His name. He will vigorously defend their cause in judgment, so that He may bring chaos upon the earth and shake the inhabitants of Babylon.

(Jeremiah 50:35) 
A sword of judgment hangs over the Chaldeans! says the Lord. It hangs over the inhabitants of Babylon, over her princes, and over her wise men.

(Jeremiah 50:36) 
A sword upon her diviners, and they will go mad with terror. A sword upon her mighty warriors, and they will be struck with fear.

(Jeremiah 50:37) 
A sword upon her warhorses and upon her chariots, and upon all the foreign mercenaries within her, and they will become as weak as women. A sword upon her treasures, and they will be plundered.

(Jeremiah 50:38) 
A drought upon her rivers and canals, and they will be dried up. Because it is a land full of carved images, and its people are driven to madness by their false gods.

(Jeremiah 50:39) 
Therefore, desert creatures will dwell there with howling animals, and ostriches will make their home in it. It will never again be inhabited, nor will it be rebuilt for all future generations.

(Jeremiah 50:40) 
Just as the Lord overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah and their neighboring cities, says the Lord, no man will live there, and no human being will settle in it.

(Jeremiah 50:41) 
Behold, a people is coming from the North—a great nation, and many kings will rise up from the far ends of the earth.

(Jeremiah 50:42) 
They seize bow and shield for battle. They are cruel and show no mercy. Their battle cries will roar like the surging sea, and they will advance on horses. They are arrayed for battle like a mighty warrior, against you, O daughter Babylon.

(Jeremiah 50:43) 
The king of Babylon has heard reports of them, and his hands have gone limp with fear. Anguish has gripped him, like the pain of a woman giving birth.

(Jeremiah 50:44) 
Behold, like a lion rising from the thickets of the Jordan, he will come against Babylon's strong and beautiful pastures. For I will suddenly make him rush against her. And who is the chosen one whom I will appoint to rule over her? For who is truly like Me? And who can stand against Me? And what shepherd, what ruler, can resist My face?

(Jeremiah 50:45) 
Therefore, listen to the plan of the Lord that He has formed against Babylon, and the intentions He has conceived concerning the land of the Chaldeans. Even the smallest of the flock, the weakest nations, will drag them away captive. Surely, their very dwelling place will be utterly destroyed along with them.

(Jeremiah 50:46) 
At the sound of Babylon's capture, the entire earth will tremble, and her cries will be heard among all the nations.

(Jeremiah 51:51:1) 
The Lord says this: "Pay attention! I am stirring up against Babylon and against its inhabitants—those living deep within its core, whom I have specifically chosen to be at the center of My punitive will—a wind that brings destruction and plague."

(Jeremiah 51:51:2) 
I will send against Babylon destroyers, who will winnow it and clear out its land, much like a farmer separates chaff from grain; because enemies will come against it from every direction on the day of its calamity.

(Jeremiah 51:51:3) 
Let the archer not prepare his bow; let him not rise up in his armor to fight. Do not spare its young men; put to death all its warriors.

(Jeremiah 51:51:4) 
The slain will fall in the land of the Chaldeans, and those wounded to death will lie in its streets.

(Jeremiah 51:51:5) 
For Israel and Judah have not been abandoned by their God, the Lord of armies, even though their own land was filled with sin against the Holy One of Israel.

(Jeremiah 51:51:6) 
Flee from the midst of Babylon, and let each one save his own life! Do not remain silent about her wickedness, because this is the time of the Lord's vengeance; He Himself will repay her what she deserves.

(Jeremiah 51:51:7) 
Babylon was like a golden cup in the Lord's hand, intoxicating the whole earth. The nations drank of her wine, and for this reason, they were driven mad.

(Jeremiah 51:51:8) 
Suddenly Babylon has fallen and is shattered! Wail over her; get balm for her pain, in case she can still be healed.

(Jeremiah 51:51:9) 
"We tried to heal Babylon, but she was not healed. Let us abandon her, and let each one go to his own country; for her judgment has reached even to the skies, and is lifted up even to the clouds."

(Jeremiah 51:51:10) 
The Lord has brought forth our vindication. Come, let us declare in Zion the work of the Lord our God.

(Jeremiah 51:51:11) 
Sharpen your arrows! Fill your quivers! The Lord has stirred up the spirit of the kings of the Medes against Babylon to destroy it, for this is the Lord's vengeance—the vengeance for His Temple.

(Jeremiah 51:51:12) 
Raise a standard against the walls of Babylon! Increase the guard! Set watchmen! Prepare ambushes! For the Lord has planned and has done what He declared against the inhabitants of Babylon.

(Jeremiah 51:51:13) 
O you who dwell by many waters, rich in treasures! Your end has come, the measure of your greed is full.

(Jeremiah 51:51:14) 
The Lord of armies has sworn: "I will surely fill you with men like a swarm of locusts, and a shout of triumph will be raised over you."

(Jeremiah 51:51:15) 
It is He who made the earth by His power, who established the world by His wisdom, and by His understanding He stretched out the skies and the rest of the universe.

(Jeremiah 51:51:16) 
At the sound of His voice, He brings forth the abundance of waters in the sky; He makes the clouds rise from the ends of the earth. He creates lightning with the rain, and He brings forth the wind from His storehouses.

(Jeremiah 51:51:17) 
Every human is proven foolish in their knowledge; every craftsman of idols is put to shame by his carved image; for his idol is a mere empty breath, and there is no true spirit or life within them.

(Jeremiah 51:51:18) 
They are useless, and a work worthy of ridicule. In the time of their judgment, they will perish completely.

(Jeremiah 51:51:19) 
The portion of Jacob is not like these empty idols; for He who formed all things, He is Jacob's God, and Israel is the tribe of His inheritance. The Lord of armies is His name.

(Jeremiah 51:51:20) 
"You, O Babylon, are My hammer and My weapons of war. With you, I will smash nations; with you, I will destroy kingdoms.

(Jeremiah 51:51:21) 
With you, I will smash the horse and its rider; with you, I will smash the chariot and its driver.

(Jeremiah 51:51:22) 
With you, I will smash man and woman; with you, I will smash old and young; with you, I will smash the young man and the virgin.

(Jeremiah 51:51:23) 
With you, I will smash the shepherd and his flock; with you, I will smash the farmer and his team of oxen; with you, I will smash governors and rulers.

(Jeremiah 51:51:24) 
And I will repay Babylon and all the inhabitants of Chaldea for all the evil they inflicted upon Zion. You will see it with your own eyes," says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 51:51:25) 
Behold, I am against you, O destroying mountain—a great power that corrupts the whole earth! declares the Lord. I will stretch out My hand against you, and I will roll you down from the rocks, and I will make you a burnt-out mountain.

(Jeremiah 51:51:26) 
They will not take from you even a stone for a corner, nor a stone for a foundation. Instead, you will be eternal desolation, says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 51:51:27) 
Raise a banner in the land! Blow the trumpet among the nations! Declare the nations holy for war against her! Summon against her the kings of Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz! Appoint a commander over her! Bring up cavalry like a swarm of bristly locusts!

(Jeremiah 51:51:28) 
Prepare the nations against her for war: the kings of Media, their governors, all the rulers of all their lands, and their entire dominion.

(Jeremiah 51:51:29) 
Then the earth will quake and tremble, because the Lord's purpose against Babylon has awakened—to make the land of Babylon desolate and uninhabited.

(Jeremiah 51:51:30) 
The mighty men of Babylon have ceased fighting; they remain in their strongholds. Their strength has withered, and they have become like women. Her dwellings are set on fire, her bars are broken.

(Jeremiah 51:51:31) 
Runner will come to runner, and messenger to messenger, to announce to the king of Babylon that his city has been captured from one end to the other.

(Jeremiah 51:51:32) 
The river crossings have been seized, and the marshes are burned with fire, and the warriors are terrified and in disarray.

(Jeremiah 51:51:33) 
For thus says the Lord of armies, the God of Israel: "The daughter of Babylon is like a threshing floor; the time for her to be trodden down is near. Yet a little while, and the time of her harvest—her destruction—will come."

(Jeremiah 51:51:34) 
"Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, has devoured me, he has crushed me. He has made me like an empty vessel; he has swallowed me like a dragon, filled his belly with my delicacies, and then cast me aside."

(Jeremiah 51:51:35) 
The people of Zion will say: "May the injustice done to me and my flesh be upon Babylon!" And Jerusalem will say: "May my shed blood be upon the inhabitants of Chaldea!"

(Jeremiah 51:51:36) 
Therefore, the Lord says this: "Behold, I will plead your case, and I will take vengeance on your behalf. I will dry up her sea—meaning her power and resources—and make her spring of fresh water run dry."

(Jeremiah 51:51:37) 
And Babylon will become a heap of ruins, a dwelling place for jackals, an object of horror and hissing, because no one will inhabit it.

(Jeremiah 51:51:38) 
They will roar together like lions; they will growl like lion cubs.

(Jeremiah 51:51:39) 
In their heat, I will give them their drinks; I will make them drunk so that they become sluggish and sleep an eternal sleep, and do not awaken," says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 51:51:40) 
I will bring them down like lambs to the slaughter, like rams with goats to be sacrificed.

(Jeremiah 51:51:41) 
How has Sheshach—a symbolic name for Babylon—been captured? How has the renown of the whole earth been seized? How has Babylon become an object of horror among the nations?

(Jeremiah 51:51:42) 
The sea has risen over Babylon; she is covered with the multitude of its waves, symbolizing overwhelming destruction.

(Jeremiah 51:51:43) 
Her cities have become a desolation, a land uninhabitable and deserted; a land where no one dwells, and no human being passes through it.

(Jeremiah 51:51:44) 
And I will punish Bel, the chief idol of Babylon, and I will make him vomit out what he has swallowed from his mouth. Nations will no longer flow to him in worship, and even the wall of Babylon will fall.

(Jeremiah 51:51:45) 
Go out from her midst, My people! Let each one save his own life from the fierce anger of the Lord!

(Jeremiah 51:51:46) 
And lest your heart should faint, and you should be afraid of the rumor that will be heard in the land—when a rumor comes in one year, and after that, in another year, another rumor, bringing injustice in the land, and ruler rising against ruler.

(Jeremiah 51:51:47) 
Therefore, behold, the days are coming when I will punish the carved images of Babylon, and all her land will be put to shame, and all her slain will fall in her midst.

(Jeremiah 51:51:48) 
And the universe and the earth, and all that is in them, will sing for joy over Babylon, because destroyers will come against her from the north," says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 51:51:49) 
Just as Babylon caused the slain to fall in Israel, so too in Babylon will the slain fall throughout all the earth.

(Jeremiah 51:51:50) 
You who have escaped the sword, come, do not stand still! Remember the Lord from afar, and let Jerusalem rise in your hearts.

(Jeremiah 51:51:51) 
"We are ashamed, because we have heard reproach; dishonor has covered our faces, for foreigners have come against the holy places of the Lord's house."

(Jeremiah 51:51:52) 
Therefore, behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, when I will punish her carved images, and throughout all her land, the wounded will groan.

(Jeremiah 51:51:53) 
Even if Babylon should ascend to the very sky, and establish her strength firmly in the heights, from Me will come destroyers against her," says the Lord.

(Jeremiah 51:51:54) 
A sound of a cry comes from Babylon, and great destruction from the land of the Chaldeans!

(Jeremiah 51:51:55) 
For the Lord will devastate Babylon and destroy its great voice—the clamor of its people. Its waves will roar like many waters, giving forth the sound of their tumult.

(Jeremiah 51:51:56) 
Because a destroyer comes upon her, that is, upon Babylon. Her mighty warriors will be captured, and their bows will be shattered; for the Lord is a strong avenger, surely rendering recompense.

(Jeremiah 51:51:57) 
"I will make her princes drunk, along with her wise men, her governors, her rulers, and her mighty warriors. They will sleep an eternal sleep and not awaken," says the King, whose name is the Lord of armies.

(Jeremiah 51:51:58) 
Thus says the Lord of armies: "The wide walls of Babylon will be utterly broken down, and her high gates will be burned with fire. The peoples have toiled in vain, and the nations have wearied themselves only for the fire."

(Jeremiah 51:51:59) 
This is the message that Jeremiah the prophet gave to Seraiah, the son of Neriah, son of Maaseiah, when Seraiah went with Zedekiah, the king of Judah, to Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. Seraiah was the chief officer tasked with delivering prophetic messages.

(Jeremiah 51:51:60) 
Jeremiah wrote in a single scroll all the evil that was to come upon Babylon—all these words that are written against Babylon.

(Jeremiah 51:51:61) 
Jeremiah then said to Seraiah: "When you arrive in Babylon, and you see it, and you have read all these words—

(Jeremiah 51:51:62) 
you are to say: 'O Lord, You Yourself have spoken concerning this place, that You would destroy it, so that there will be no one living in it, neither man nor beast, and it will be an eternal desolation.'

(Jeremiah 51:51:63) 
And when you have finished reading this scroll, you are to tie a stone to it and throw it into the middle of the Euphrates River.

(Jeremiah 51:51:64) 
And you are to say: 'Thus shall Babylon be submerged, and it will not rise from the face of the affliction that I will bring upon it, and it will be utterly broken.' Here ends the words of Jeremiah.

(Jeremiah 52:1) 
Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal, daughter of Jeremiah from Libnah.

(Jeremiah 52:2) 
And he did evil in the sight of the Lord, just as Jehoiakim had done everything.

(Jeremiah 52:3) 
Because of the Lord's anger, these events happened to Jerusalem and Judah, until He cast them out of His sight. Zedekiah also rebelled against the king of Babylon.

(Jeremiah 52:4) 
In the ninth year of Zedekiah's reign, in the tenth month on the tenth day of that month, Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem with all his army. They surrounded the city and built siege works all around it.

(Jeremiah 52:5) 
The city remained under siege until the eleventh year of King Zedekiah's reign.

(Jeremiah 52:6) 
In the fourth month, on the ninth day of that month, the famine in the city became severe, and there was no bread left for the people of the land.

(Jeremiah 52:7) 
The city wall was breached, and all the soldiers fled. They went out of the city by night through the gate between the two walls, which led to the king's garden. The Chaldeans were besieging the city all around. Zedekiah proceeded along the road through the desert plain.

(Jeremiah 52:8) 
The Chaldean army pursued the king and captured Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho. All the soldiers who were with him were scattered from him.

(Jeremiah 52:9) 
So they brought the captured king to the king of Babylon at Riblah, which is in the land of Hamath. There, the king of Babylon passed judgment on him.

(Jeremiah 52:10) 
The king of Babylon slaughtered Zedekiah's sons before his very eyes. He also slaughtered all the officials of Judah at Riblah.

(Jeremiah 52:11) 
Then he put out Zedekiah's eyes and bound him with bronze chains. The king of Babylon brought him to Babylon and put him in prison until the day of his death.

(Jeremiah 52:12) 
In the fifth month, on the tenth day of that month (which was the nineteenth year of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon), Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, who served the king of Babylon, came to Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 52:13) 
And he burned the Lord's Temple, the king's palace, all the houses in Jerusalem, and every great house, burning them all with fire.

(Jeremiah 52:14) 
The entire Chaldean army, who were with the commander of the imperial guard, tore down all the walls around Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 52:15) 
Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, carried away into exile some of the poorest people, the remaining common people who were left in the city, the deserters who had gone over to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the multitude.

(Jeremiah 52:16) 
But Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, left some of the poorest people of the land to be vinedressers and farmers.

(Jeremiah 52:17) 
The Chaldeans broke into pieces the bronze pillars that were in the Lord's Temple, along with the bronze stands and the great bronze basin called 'the Sea' that was in the Lord's Temple. They carried all that bronze to Babylon.

(Jeremiah 52:18) 
They also took away the pots, shovels, snuffers, bowls, dishes, and all the bronze articles used in the Temple service.

(Jeremiah 52:19) 
Furthermore, the commander of the imperial guard took away the basins, incense burners, pitchers, bowls, lampstands, dishes, and cups—whatever was gold, he took as gold; and whatever was silver, he took as silver.

(Jeremiah 52:20) 
There were two pillars, one great basin, and twelve bronze stands that King Solomon had made for the Lord's Temple. The weight of the bronze of all these articles was beyond measure.

(Jeremiah 52:21) 
As for the pillars, the height of one pillar was eighteen cubits (about twenty-seven feet), and a cord of twelve cubits (about eighteen feet) went around it. Its thickness was four fingers (about three inches), and it was hollow inside.

(Jeremiah 52:22) 
There were bronze capitals on top of each pillar. The height of one capital was five cubits (about seven and a half feet), with a network of bronze pomegranates all around the capitals—all made of bronze. The second pillar was similar, also with pomegranates.

(Jeremiah 52:23) 
There were ninety-six pomegranates hanging down, and all the pomegranates on the network amounted to one hundred, surrounding it on all sides.

(Jeremiah 52:24) 
The commander of the imperial guard took Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the second priest, and the three doorkeepers.

(Jeremiah 52:25) 
From the city, he took one eunuch who was in charge of the soldiers. He also took seven men from those who stood near the king, who were found in the city. He took the commander of the army's scribe, who was responsible for conscripting the people of the land, and sixty men from the people of the land who were found in the midst of the city.

(Jeremiah 52:26) 
Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, took them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah.

(Jeremiah 52:27) 
The king of Babylon struck them down and put them to death at Riblah, in the land of Hamath. So Judah was carried away into exile from their own land.

(Jeremiah 52:28) 
These are the people whom Nebuchadnezzar carried into exile: in the seventh year, three thousand twenty-three Jews.

(Jeremiah 52:29) 
In the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar, eight thousand three hundred thirty-two people from Jerusalem.

(Jeremiah 52:30) 
In the twenty-third year of Nebuchadnezzar, Nebuzaradan, the commander of the imperial guard, carried away seven hundred forty-five Jews. All the people carried into exile totaled four thousand six hundred.

(Jeremiah 52:31) 
It came to pass in the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Jehoiachin, king of Judah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-fifth day of that month, that Evil-merodach, king of Babylon, in the first year of his reign, lifted up the head of Jehoiachin, king of Judah, and brought him out of prison.

(Jeremiah 52:32) 
He spoke kindly to Jehoiachin and gave him a seat of honor higher than the seats of the other kings who were with him in Babylon.

(Jeremiah 52:33) 
Jehoiachin changed his prison clothes, and he ate regularly in the king's presence for all the days of his life.

(Jeremiah 52:34) 
And as for his allowance, a regular allowance was given to him by the king of Babylon, a set amount each day, until the day of his death.

(Lamentations 1:1) 
How lonely she now sits, the city that was once full of so many people!
She has become like a widow, she who was the sovereign lady over many nations.
She who ruled among the provinces is now forced to pay tribute.

(Lamentations 1:2) 
She weeps bitterly throughout the night, and her tears stream down her cheeks.
Among all those who once loved her, there is no one to comfort her.
All her former friends have scorned her and have now become her enemies.

(Lamentations 1:3) 
Judah has been forced to go into exile because of her great affliction and her overwhelming servitude.
She now lives among foreign nations, but she finds no rest there.
All of her persecutors have overtaken her in these times of great distress.

(Lamentations 1:4) 
The roads leading to Sion are in mourning because there is no one coming to her solemn feasts anymore.
All of her city gates are destroyed, and her priests are groaning.
Her young women are in squalor, and Sion herself is oppressed with utter bitterness.

(Lamentations 1:5) 
Her enemies have become her masters, and her foes have become rich.
This has happened because the Lord Himself has brought judgment upon her due to the multitude of her sins.
Her little children have been led away into captivity before the very eyes of their tormentors.

(Lamentations 1:6) 
From the Daughter of Sion, all her beauty has now departed.
Her princes have become like rams who cannot find any pasture.
They have gone away, utterly without strength, before the face of their pursuers.

(Lamentations 1:7) 
Jerusalem now remembers the days of her affliction and her transgressions against God.
She remembers all the precious things she had from ancient times.
She remembers when her people fell into the hand of the enemy, and there was no one to help them.
Her enemies saw her and openly mocked her Sabbaths, which she could no longer keep.

(Lamentations 1:8) 
Jerusalem has sinned terribly, which is why she has become unstable and wandering.
All those who used to glorify her now scorn her, because they have seen her disgrace.
She herself is groaning and has turned away in shame.

(Lamentations 1:9) 
Her defilement is on her very feet, and she did not remember what her end would be.
She has been violently cast down, having no one to comfort her.
O Lord, look upon my affliction, for the enemy has risen up against me.

(Lamentations 1:10) 
The enemy has stretched out his hand to seize all of her most precious things.
For she has seen the Gentiles enter her sanctuary,
—those very nations whom You had commanded should never enter into Your holy assembly.

(Lamentations 1:11) 
All of her people are now groaning as they search for bread.
They have given up all their precious possessions in exchange for food, just to keep themselves alive.
O Lord, look and consider this, for I have become worthless.

(Lamentations 1:12) 
O, all you who pass by on this road, pay attention and see if there is any sorrow like my sorrow!
For the Lord has afflicted me, as He promised, on the very day of His fierce and burning anger.

(Lamentations 1:13) 
From His exalted dwelling, God sent fire down into my very bones, and He chastised me.
He spread a net for my feet and made me stumble backward.
He has made me desolate, utterly consumed with sorrow all the day long.

(Lamentations 1:14) 
The heavy yoke of my sins has been fastened upon me; they have been intertwined by His hand and placed upon my neck.
My strength has completely failed.
The Lord has delivered me into a hand from which I will never be able to rise.

(Lamentations 1:15) 
The Lord has taken away all my mighty men from among me.
He has called for a specific time to come against me, so that He might crush my valiant men.
The Lord has trodden the winepress upon the virgin daughter of Judah, crushing her utterly.

(Lamentations 1:16) 
Therefore, I weep continuously, and my eyes pour out tears.
For the Comforter, who could restore my soul, has gone far from me.
My children have become desolate because the enemy has utterly prevailed.

(Lamentations 1:17) 
Sion stretches out her hands for help, but there is no one to comfort her.
The Lord has commanded her enemies to surround Jacob, so they are all around her.
Jerusalem has become like an unclean woman among them, utterly despised.

(Lamentations 1:18) 
The Lord is truly just in His judgment, for I have provoked His divine will to anger.
Listen, I beg you, all peoples, and see my great sorrow!
My young women and my young men have been led away into captivity.

(Lamentations 1:19) 
I called upon my friends, but they themselves deceived me.
My priests and my elders perished within the city,
because they were desperately searching for food to keep themselves alive.

(Lamentations 1:20) 
O Lord, look upon me, for I am in severe distress.
My innermost being is in turmoil; my heart is utterly overturned within me, for I am filled with overwhelming bitterness.
Outside the city, the sword has brought death, and inside my home, it feels just like death.

(Lamentations 1:21) 
They have heard that I am groaning, and there is no one to comfort me.
All my enemies have heard of my misfortune, and they rejoiced that You, O God, have done this.
You have brought their day of reckoning, and they will become just like me in their suffering.

(Lamentations 1:22) 
Let all their wickedness come before Your sight, O God.
And punish them just as You have punished me, because of all my many sins.
For my groans are many, and my heart is filled with sorrow.

(Lamentations 2:1) 
How the Lord, in His fury, has covered the Daughter of Zion with darkness, casting down from its exalted position to the ground the renown of Israel! In the day of His anger, He did not even remember His holy footstool, the Temple.

(Lamentations 2:2) 
The Lord has cast down and shown no mercy to all the glorious places of Jacob. In His fury, He destroyed the strongholds of the Daughter of Judah, leveling them to the ground. He has defiled both the kingdom and its leaders.

(Lamentations 2:3) 
In the blazing anger of His fury, He broke every source of Israel's strength. He withdrew His powerful right hand from the sight of the enemy, and He set Jacob ablaze like a devouring fire that consumed everything around it.

(Lamentations 2:4) 
Like an enemy, He drew His bow. He stood firm with His right hand like an adversary, and He killed everything beautiful to behold in the dwellings of Zion. He poured out His indignation like a raging fire.

(Lamentations 2:5) 
The Lord acted like an enemy; He utterly destroyed Israel. He destroyed all its walls and demolished its strongholds. And in Zion, He brought a time of mourning for both its outer walls and its inner ramparts.

(Lamentations 2:6) 
He has torn down His protective hedge as one would a garden wall. He has demolished His own dwelling place, the Temple. The Lord has made all the feast days and Sabbaths in Zion to cease. And in His fierce indignation, He has rejected both king and priest.

(Lamentations 2:7) 
The Lord has rejected His own altar. He has cursed His sanctuary, delivering the walls of its towers into the hands of the enemy. The enemies now shout in the House of the Lord, as if it were a feast day of their own celebration.

(Lamentations 2:8) 
The Lord planned to tear down the wall of the Daughter of Zion. He stretched out His measuring line for destruction and did not withdraw His hand from the task until it was complete. The outer wall mourned, and the city wall was utterly destroyed with it.

(Lamentations 2:9) 
Its gates are buried deep in the ground. He broke and shattered all its defensive bars. Its king and its princes are now exiled among the foreign nations. There is no Law of God observed, and its prophets no longer receive a vision from the Lord.

(Lamentations 2:10) 
The elders of the Daughter of Zion sit silently on the ground. They have sprinkled ashes on their heads and clothed themselves in sackcloth. The virgins of Jerusalem have bowed their heads to the ground in despair.

(Lamentations 2:11) 
My eyes are consumed with weeping, and my inner being is deeply troubled. My life essence feels poured out onto the ground because of the utter destruction of the Daughter of my people, as I see little children and infants fainting in the streets of the city.

(Lamentations 2:12) 
The children cried to their mothers, 'Where is bread and wine?' as they fainted like wounded soldiers in the city streets, and breathed their last breath in their mothers' arms.

(Lamentations 2:13) 
To what can I compare you, O Daughter of Jerusalem? To what can I liken you, or how can I comfort you, O Virgin Daughter of Zion? For your destruction is as vast as the sea; who can possibly heal you?

(Lamentations 2:14) 
Your prophets saw for you false and foolish visions. They did not expose your iniquity to provoke you to repentance. Instead, they saw for you false burdens and misleading delusions.

(Lamentations 2:15) 
All who pass by the way clap their hands in scorn over you. They hiss and shake their heads at the Daughter of Jerusalem, saying, 'Is this the city that was called the perfection of beauty, the joy of the whole earth?'

(Lamentations 2:16) 
All your enemies open their mouths wide against you. They hiss and gnash their teeth, saying, 'We have utterly devoured her! Behold, this is the day we have waited for; we have found it, we have seen it with our own eyes!'

(Lamentations 2:17) 
The Lord has done what He purposed; He has fulfilled the word He spoke from ancient days. He has destroyed without sparing, and He has made your enemy rejoice over you. He has exalted the strength of your adversaries.

(Lamentations 2:18) 
Their hearts cry out to the Lord over the walls of the Daughter of Zion: 'Let your tears flow like a torrent day and night. Do not give yourself any rest, and let the stream of your tears never cease!'

(Lamentations 2:19) 
Arise! Cry out in the night, at the beginning of the night watches. Pour out your heart like water before the presence of the Lord. Lift up your hands to Him for the lives of your little children, who are fainting from hunger at every street corner.

(Lamentations 2:20) 
Look, O Lord, and consider how You have utterly ravaged us. Shall women really eat their own children, the fruit of their own bodies? Shall priest and prophet be put to death in the very sanctuary of the Lord?

(Lamentations 2:21) 
The young child and the old man lie on the ground, lifeless. My virgins and my young men have fallen by the sword. You have killed them in the day of Your fury; You struck them down without any mercy.

(Lamentations 2:22) 
As if for a solemn feast day, You called forth my terrors from every side. In the day of the Lord's fury, no one escaped or was left alive. Those children whom I had lovingly raised and nourished, my enemy has utterly consumed them all.

(Lamentations 3:1) 
I am the man who has seen my own utter misery, inflicted by the rod of God's righteous anger.

(Lamentations 3:2) 
God has led me and brought me into spiritual darkness, and not into His light.

(Lamentations 3:3) 
God has continually turned His hand against me, all day long.

(Lamentations 3:4) 
He has stripped away my skin and my flesh, and broken my bones, leaving me utterly vulnerable.

(Lamentations 3:5) 
He has built a wall around me, and surrounded me with bitter affliction and great suffering.

(Lamentations 3:6) 
He has placed me in the deepest darkness, like those who have been dead for a long time.

(Lamentations 3:7) 
He has walled me in completely so that I cannot escape; He has made my chains heavy and unbreakable.

(Lamentations 3:8) 
And even when I cry out and pray for help, God has shut out my prayers.

(Lamentations 3:9) 
He has blocked my paths with massive, squared stones, and made my ways impossible to navigate.

(Lamentations 3:10) 
God has become to me like a bear lying in ambush, or a lion hidden in wait.

(Lamentations 3:11) 
He has completely overturned my life's paths and broken me; He has left me utterly desolate and alone.

(Lamentations 3:12) 
He has drawn His bow and set me up as a target for His arrow.

(Lamentations 3:13) 
He has shot the arrows from His quiver deep into my vital organs.

(Lamentations 3:14) 
I have become the object of mockery for all my own people, and their song of scorn all day long.

(Lamentations 3:15) 
God has filled me with bitter experiences; He has made me drunk with the bitter poison of suffering.

(Lamentations 3:16) 
He has broken my teeth on gravel; He has made me eat ashes.

(Lamentations 3:17) 
My soul has been driven far away from any peace, and I have forgotten what good things feel like.

(Lamentations 3:18) 
And I said to myself, "My strength is completely gone, and all my hope from the Lord has vanished."

(Lamentations 3:19) 
Remember my profound suffering and my homeless wandering, the bitter poison and the gall of it all.

(Lamentations 3:20) 
I will always remember these things, and my soul will waste away within me because of it.

(Lamentations 3:21) 
But when I bring this to my mind, I then find strength.

(Lamentations 3:22) 
It is because of the Lord’s mercies that we are not completely destroyed; His compassions never fail.

(Lamentations 3:23) 
They are new every morning, constantly renewed; indeed, Your faithfulness is great.

(Lamentations 3:24) 
My soul proclaims, "The Lord is my portion and inheritance, therefore I will wait in hope for Him."

(Lamentations 3:25) 
The Lord is truly good to those who wait for Him, to the soul that earnestly seeks Him.

(Lamentations 3:26) 
It is good to quietly wait and hope for the saving help of God.

(Lamentations 3:27) 
It is good for a person to bear the burden of suffering from their youth.

(Lamentations 3:28) 
The one who bears suffering will sit alone and remain silent, because he has accepted this burden upon himself.

(Lamentations 3:29) 
He will put his mouth in the dust, prostrating himself in utter humility, if by chance there is still hope.

(Lamentations 3:30) 
He will offer his cheek to the one who strikes him; he will allow himself to be filled with insults and shame.

(Lamentations 3:31) 
For the Lord will not cast off His people forever.

(Lamentations 3:32) 
For even if He has cast them away, He will show mercy according to the abundance of His compassion.

(Lamentations 3:33) 
For God does not willingly humble or cast away the children of mankind from His heart.

(Lamentations 3:34) 
He takes no pleasure in seeing those bound on earth crushed underfoot by oppressors.

(Lamentations 3:35) 
Nor does He approve when a person's justice is subverted in the presence of the Most High God.

(Lamentations 3:36) 
Nor does the Lord approve when a man is defrauded in his legal judgment.

(Lamentations 3:37) 
Who is it that has spoken a command and it came to be, when the Lord Himself had not commanded it?

(Lamentations 3:38) 
Does not both evil and good proceed from the mouth of the Most High God?

(Lamentations 3:39) 
Why then should any living person murmur or complain, especially a man who suffers for his own sins?

(Lamentations 3:40) 
Let us carefully examine our ways, and search our consciences, and then turn back to the Lord.

(Lamentations 3:41) 
Let us lift up our hearts, not just our hands, in prayer to the Lord who dwells in the spiritual heavens.

(Lamentations 3:42) 
We have acted wickedly and defiantly, and provoked You to anger; because of this, You have not spared us.

(Lamentations 3:43) 
You have covered Yourself with fury and pursued us; You have slain us without mercy.

(Lamentations 3:44) 
You have covered Yourself with a thick cloud so that no prayer can pass through to You.

(Lamentations 3:45) 
You have made us an object of scorn and contempt in the midst of the nations.

(Lamentations 3:46) 
All of our enemies have opened their mouths against us in derision.

(Lamentations 3:47) 
A terrifying report and destruction have come upon us; calamity and utter ruin.

(Lamentations 3:48) 
My eyes pour out rivers of tears because of the utter destruction of the daughter of my people.

(Lamentations 3:49) 
My eyes will continue to pour out tears and will not stop, because there is no rest or relief from this suffering.

(Lamentations 3:50) 
Until the Lord looks down and sees from His dwelling in the spiritual heavens.

(Lamentations 3:51) 
The sight of my city's suffering has deeply grieved my soul, because of all the people, the daughters of my city.

(Lamentations 3:52) 
My enemies have hunted me down like a bird, without any cause or reason.

(Lamentations 3:53) 
They trapped me alive in a pit, and placed a large stone over me.

(Lamentations 3:54) 
The waters closed over my head, and I said, "We are utterly lost and destroyed!"

(Lamentations 3:55) 
I called upon Your Holy Name, O Lord, from the lowest, most desperate pit.

(Lamentations 3:56) 
You heard my voice calling out; do not turn away Your ear from my groaning and my cries.

(Lamentations 3:57) 
You came near to me on the very day I called upon You; You said, "Do not be afraid."

(Lamentations 3:58) 
You have defended the cause of my soul, O Lord; You have redeemed my very life.

(Lamentations 3:59) 
You have seen, O Lord, the injustice done to me; now, give judgment on my behalf.

(Lamentations 3:60) 
You have seen all their acts of vengeance, and all their evil thoughts against me.

(Lamentations 3:61) 
You have heard their insults, O Lord, and all their malicious plots against me.

(Lamentations 3:62) 
You know the hostile words of those who rise up against me, and their wicked thoughts against me all day long.

(Lamentations 3:63) 
Observe their every action, whether they are sitting or rising; I am the constant subject of their mocking songs.

(Lamentations 3:64) 
You will repay them, O Lord, according to the evil works of their own hands.

(Lamentations 3:65) 
You will give them hardness of heart as a punishment, and Your curse will be upon them.

(Lamentations 3:66) 
You will pursue them in Your wrath and utterly destroy them under Your created universe, O Lord.

(Lamentations 4:1) 
How the gold has grown dim! How the finest color has changed! The precious stones of the sanctuary are scattered at the head of every street, desecrated and lost.

(Lamentations 4:2) 
The glorious sons of Sion, once adorned in the finest gold, how they are now esteemed as mere earthen vessels, like common pottery made by a potter's hands!

(Lamentations 4:3) 
Even the wild animals, like jackals, bare their breasts and nurse their young. But the daughter of my people, out of desperation, has become cruel, like an ostrich in the desert that abandons its eggs.

(Lamentations 4:4) 
The tongue of the nursing child clings to the roof of its mouth from unbearable thirst. Little children beg for bread, but there is no one to break it and give it to them.

(Lamentations 4:5) 
Those who used to eat luxuriously have perished in the streets from hunger. Those who were brought up in scarlet robes now embrace dung heaps out of sheer starvation.

(Lamentations 4:6) 
The punishment for the iniquity of the daughter of my people has become greater and more prolonged than the sin of Sodom. Sodom was overthrown in a moment, its destruction was swift and complete, with no human hands laying hold of it for further torment.

(Lamentations 4:7) 
Her Nazirites, who once were purer than snow and whiter than milk, more ruddy than ancient ivory, and more beautiful than sapphires,

(Lamentations 4:8) 
now have faces darker than charcoal. They are not recognized in their own streets. Their skin clings to their bones, shriveled and become dry like wood.

(Lamentations 4:9) 
Those killed by the sword were better off than those killed by famine, for the latter wasted away, consumed by the utter barrenness of the land.

(Lamentations 4:10) 
The hands of even compassionate women have cooked their own children. These children became their food during the destruction and heartbreak of the daughter of my people.

(Lamentations 4:11) 
The Lord has fully accomplished His fury; He has poured out the wrath of His indignation. He kindled a devastating fire in Zion, and it devoured even her very foundations.

(Lamentations 4:12) 
The kings of the earth and all the inhabitants of the world could not believe that an enemy and an adversary would ever enter through the gates of Jerusalem, a city thought to be impregnable.

(Lamentations 4:13) 
This disaster came because of the sins of her prophets and the iniquities of her priests, who shed the blood of the righteous in her midst.

(Lamentations 4:14) 
They, the defiled priests and prophets, wandered like blind men in the streets, so stained with blood that they became ritually impure. And when they could not avoid it, they defiled others even by touching them with their garments.

(Lamentations 4:15) 
'Depart, you who are defiled!' people cried out to them. 'Depart, depart, do not touch!' Indeed, they were consumed by wrath and wasted away. The nations said among themselves: 'They, the people of God, will no longer dwell among them here.'

(Lamentations 4:16) 
The very presence of the Lord has scattered them; He will no longer look upon them with favor. He showed no regard for the priests, nor did He pity the elders, no matter their former status.

(Lamentations 4:17) 
While we still had a little life left, our eyes failed, constantly looking for our vain help. We watched intently for a foreign nation that could not possibly save us.

(Lamentations 4:18) 
Our enemies hunted our steps so that we could not walk in our own streets. Our end drew near, our days were fulfilled, for our ultimate destruction had come.

(Lamentations 4:19) 
Our persecutors were swifter than the eagles of the sky. They pursued us relentlessly over the mountains, and they lay in wait for us in the barren desert.

(Lamentations 4:20) 
Our very breath of life, the Lord's Anointed King, was captured because of our sins. He, in whom we had placed our hope, to whom we had said: 'Under your shadow, we shall live safely among the nations.'

(Lamentations 4:21) 
Rejoice and be glad for now, O daughter of Edom, you who dwell in the land of Uz. But beware, to you also the cup of God's wrath shall pass; you shall be made drunk with judgment and stripped bare in humiliation.

(Lamentations 4:22) 
Your punishment is now complete, O daughter of Zion; the Lord will no longer cause you to go into exile. But He will visit your iniquity, O daughter of Edom, and He will fully uncover your sins.

(Lamentations 5:1) 
Remember, Lord, what has happened to us. Look upon us and truly see our deep disgrace.

(Lamentations 5:2) 
Our inheritance, the land God gave us, has been given to strangers. Our homes have been taken by foreigners.

(Lamentations 5:3) 
We have become like orphans, completely abandoned by our father. Our mothers are like widows, left alone and unprotected.

(Lamentations 5:4) 
We have to buy even our own water to drink. We must pay a high price for our own wood to burn.

(Lamentations 5:5) 
We are constantly under threat, with the enemy's yoke on our necks. Even when we are exhausted, there is no rest for us.

(Lamentations 5:6) 
We were forced to seek help and make alliances with Egypt and Assyria, just so we could get enough bread to eat.

(Lamentations 5:7) 
Our fathers sinned greatly, and now they are gone from this earth. But we, their children, are left to carry the heavy burden of their wickedness.

(Lamentations 5:8) 
We are ruled by mere servants, who have no right to govern us. There was no one who could rescue us from their cruel grasp.

(Lamentations 5:9) 
We had to go out into the desolate wilderness, risking our very lives to find bread, facing the constant threat of the enemy's sword.

(Lamentations 5:10) 
Our skin has become as dark and cracked as a baking oven, scorched by the ravaging heat of famine and disease.

(Lamentations 5:11) 
They violated the women in Jerusalem, the holy city. They violently dishonored the virgins in the towns throughout the land of Judah.

(Lamentations 5:12)
