He will not regard the God of his fathers, nor will he look upon the desires of women, nor will he regard any god; for he will magnify himself against all things.

(Daniel 11:38) 
But in his place he will honor the god of fortresses; and a god whom his fathers did not know, he will honor with gold, and silver, and precious stones, and most precious things.

(Daniel 11:39) 
And he will act to fortify the fortresses of the mighty with a foreign god; and he will increase glory, and give them power over many, and divide the land for a price.

(Daniel 11:40) 
And at the appointed time, the king of the south will fight against him; and like a tempest, the king of the north will come against him with chariots, and horsemen, and many ships; and he will enter into the lands, and will subvert, and pass through.

(Daniel 11:41) 
And he will enter into the glorious land, and many will fall; but those who escape his hand will be saved, Edom, and Moab, and the chiefs of the children of Ammon.

(Daniel 11:42) 
And he will stretch out his hand against the lands, and the land of Egypt will not escape.

(Daniel 11:43) 
And he will have dominion over the treasures of gold, and silver, and over all the precious things of Egypt; and the Libyans and the Ethiopians will follow his steps.

(Daniel 11:44) 
But messengers from the east and from the north will trouble him; and he will come with a great multitude to destroy and kill many.

(Daniel 11:45) 
And he will set his tabernacle between the seas, in the glorious and holy mountain; and he will come to its summit; but there will be no one to help him.

(Daniel 12:1) 
And at that time, the great Michael, a prince of the angels, will rise to defend your people. Then there will be a time of tribulation the likes of which the world has never seen before. But your people will be delivered, everyone written in the book of life.

(Daniel 12:2) 
And many who are sleeping in the dust of the earth will awaken: some to eternal life, but others will awaken to eternal punishment and disgrace.

(Daniel 12:3) 
Those who are wise will shine like the glory of the universe. And those who lead many to righteousness will shine like the stars forever.

(Daniel 12:4) 
But you, Daniel, keep the words secret, and seal the book until the appointed time. Many will travel the earth, and knowledge will increase.

(Daniel 12:5) 
Then I, Daniel, looked, and there stood two others: one on this side of the bank of the river, and the other on the other side of the bank of the river.

(Daniel 12:6) 
And I said to the man clothed in linen, who was standing above the waters of the river, "How long will it be until the end of these wonders?"

(Daniel 12:7) 
I heard the man clothed in linen, who was standing above the waters of the river, raise his right hand toward the sky. He swore by Him who lives forever, that it would be a time, times, and half a time. And when the persecution of the holy people ends, all these things will be fulfilled.

(Daniel 12:8) 
And I heard, but I did not understand. So I said, "My Lord, what will be the end of these things?"

(Daniel 12:9) 
He answered, "Go your way, Daniel, because the words are closed up and sealed until the appointed time.

(Daniel 12:10) 
Purify yourselves, and make yourselves clean. Many will be refined, and tested, and purified. The wicked will continue to do wrong, and none of the wicked will understand. But those who are wise will understand.

(Daniel 12:11) 
From the time that the daily sacrifice is taken away, and the abomination that causes desolation is set up, there will be 1,290 days.

(Daniel 12:12) 
Blessed is the one who waits and reaches the end of the 1,335 days.

(Daniel 12:13) 
As for you, go your way till the end. You will rest, and then you will rise to receive your allotted inheritance at the end of days.

(Daniel 13:1) 
A man named Joachim lived in Babylon.

(Daniel 13:2) 
He took a wife named Susanna, the very beautiful daughter of Helcias, who was also a woman of deep faith.

(Daniel 13:3) 
Her parents were upright people and taught Susanna the law of Moses.

(Daniel 13:4) 
Now Joachim was wealthy, and his garden was next to his house. The Jews went to him because he was more respected than the others.

(Daniel 13:5) 
Two elders from the people were appointed as judges that year, of whom the Lord said: "Wickedness has come forth from Babylon from the elders who seemed to be ruling the people."

(Daniel 13:6) 
These elders were in Joachim's house, and all who had business came to them.

(Daniel 13:7) 
When Susanna left to walk in her husband's garden at midday,

(Daniel 13:8) 
the elders saw her enter and walk there. Driven by lust, their hearts burned for her.

(Daniel 13:9) 
They turned their gaze away.

(Daniel 13:10) 
After they withdrew, she entered the garden and walked there. It was hot, so she wanted to bathe in the garden.

(Daniel 13:11) 
There was a large container there. She opened it, wanting to bathe.

(Daniel 13:12) 
The two elders were hiding, watching her.

(Daniel 13:13) 
Susanna said, "Bring us oil and ointments, and close the doors of the garden so we can bathe."

(Daniel 13:14) 
They shouted, closed the doors of the garden, sent their servants away, and shut the doors.

(Daniel 13:15) 
When the servants had left, the two elders rose and rushed toward her.

(Daniel 13:16) 
They said to her, "The doors of the garden are closed, and no one sees us. We desire you; therefore, yield to us and be with us."

(Daniel 13:17) 
She said to them, "I will not do this. It is better for me to fall into your hands than to sin in the sight of the Lord."

(Daniel 13:18) 
So Susanna cried out in a loud voice, and the elders cried out against her.

(Daniel 13:19) 
Each of them ran off in his own direction.

(Daniel 13:20) 
One said to the other, "What is this that has happened?"

(Daniel 13:21) 
The elders returned and gathered against her, saying, "We caught Susanna, the daughter of Helcias and the wife of Joachim, walking in the garden with a young man, and we apprehended him. Since he refused to confess, we killed him."

(Daniel 13:22) 
They immediately said they had seen her with the young man, and this was their testimony.

(Daniel 13:23) 
In the morning, the assembly of the people was gathered, and the elders of the judges came with Susanna.

(Daniel 13:24) 
She was sent by her husband, her parents, and her servants. Susanna wept.

(Daniel 13:25) 
When she was in the sight of everyone, the elders said, "Send her away, and let us render judgment."

(Daniel 13:26) 
They said to her, "Tell us under what tree you caught them together."

(Daniel 13:27) 
She replied, "Under a mastic tree." And she said, "You have lied to your own detriment."

(Daniel 13:28) 
As they looked at each other, they said, "Tell us under what tree you caught them in conversation."

(Daniel 13:29) 
She said, "Under an holm oak." And she said, "You have lied, and you will not cease lying."

(Daniel 13:30) 
When all was said, everyone cried out and said, "Let her be killed!" Susanna cried out in a loud voice and wept because she was innocent.

(Daniel 13:31) 
Then Daniel stood up and said, "You sons of Israel are wicked, and you have rendered a false judgment against the daughter of Israel!"

(Daniel 13:32) 
All the people returned to him. He said, "You are foolish sons of Israel! Without judgment and without knowledge, have you condemned the daughter of Israel?"

(Daniel 13:33) 
Return to the judgment, for they have given false testimony against her."

(Daniel 13:34) 
Daniel, hastening, said, "Separate them, and let them not approach each other."

(Daniel 13:35) 
When they were separated, he called one of them and said to him, "O elder of wicked days, now your sins, which you committed before, have come to light,

(Daniel 13:36) 
judging false judgments, condemning the innocent, and acquitting the guilty, even though the Lord says, 'You shall not kill the innocent and the just.'"

(Daniel 13:37) 
Now then, if you saw her, tell us under what tree you saw them conversing together."

(Daniel 13:38) 
He replied, "Under an holm oak."

(Daniel 13:39) 
Then Daniel said, "You have lied to your own detriment! For behold, the angel of God, holding a sword, awaits you to destroy you."

(Daniel 13:40) 
And when he had removed him, he ordered the other to come. He said to him, "Seed of Canaan, not of Judah, a deceptive appearance, and let not error deceive you."

(Daniel 13:41) 
Why did you say you saw her walking with a young man, when you had lust for her?"

(Daniel 13:42) 
He replied, "Under a mastic tree."

(Daniel 13:43) 
Then Daniel said to him, "And you also have lied to your own detriment, for the angel of God awaits with a sword to cut you to pieces."

(Daniel 13:44) 
And the whole assembly cried out with a loud voice and blessed God, who saves those who hope in Him.

(Daniel 13:45) 
They rose against the two elders (because Daniel had convicted them of false testimony), and they did to them as they had wickedly planned.

(Daniel 13:46) 
They put them to death, and the innocent life was saved that day.

(Daniel 13:47) 
And Helcias and his wife praised God for their daughter Susanna, along with her husband Joachim, because no shameful thing had been found in her.

(Daniel 13:48) 
And Daniel became great in the sight of the people from that day forward.

(Daniel 14:1) 
And in the land was the prophet Habakkuk, and he took a meal of stew and a loaf of bread and carried it in a container to the harvesters in the field.

(Daniel 14:2) 
Now the dragon of Bel, as we were together, consumed all of the offerings that were given to him.

(Daniel 14:3) 
Therefore, Habakkuk said, “Lord, give me the stew and the bread, so I may give it to the harvesters.”

(Daniel 14:4) 
And an angel of the Lord grabbed Habakkuk by the hair of his head and carried him to Babylon, to the lion’s den, and with the force of his spirit, he placed him above the den.

(Daniel 14:5) 
Then Habakkuk spoke, “Habakkuk, give the meal to Habakkuk, whom you sent to Babylon.”

(Daniel 14:6) 
And Habakkuk gave Habakkuk the meal.

(Daniel 14:7) 
Bel and his priests, along with all the people, ate the offerings that were there.

(Daniel 14:8) 
But when they saw this, they cried out with a loud voice, “Great is Bel!”

(Daniel 14:9) 
But Daniel laughed and seized Bel, killing him and handing his priests over to Daniel’s power.

(Daniel 14:10) 
And he said, “Look, who is this? Do you see, Lord?”

(Daniel 14:11) 
And the king said: “Let them be brought before me, and I will determine who among them has done this.”

(Daniel 14:12) 
And when they were gathered and tested by the king, three hundred lying priests were found. He ordered them to be killed and gave Bel to Daniel’s power. And he destroyed him, and destroyed his temple.

(Daniel 14:13) 
In the same place was a great serpent, which the Babylonians worshipped.

(Daniel 14:14) 
And the king said to Daniel: “Do not say that this serpent is made of bronze? Look, it is alive; it eats and drinks; you cannot say that it is not a living god; therefore, adore him.”

(Daniel 14:15) 
And Daniel said, “I will worship my Lord God; because He is the living God; but this serpent is not a living God.”

(Daniel 14:16) 
Then Daniel took pitch, fat, and hair and cooked these things together; he made them into masses, and gave them to the serpent. The serpent burst.

(Daniel 14:17) 
And the Babylonians said, “King, because the serpent ate the offerings, Daniel killed the serpent.”

(Daniel 14:18) 
And when the king heard this, he was angry and handed Daniel over, and they gave him to the lions, and he remained there for six days.

(Daniel 14:19) 
And there were two prophets in Judea: one was Habakkuk, the other Daniel.

(Daniel 14:20) 
And the angel of the Lord took Habakkuk from Judea to Babylon and sent him into the lion’s den.

(Daniel 14:21) 
On the seventh day, the king came and saw Daniel sitting in the middle of the lions, and he worshiped and said, “You are great, Lord, the God of Daniel, and there is no other besides you.”

(Daniel 14:22) 
And he brought him out of the lion’s den.

(Daniel 14:23) 
Now those who wanted to kill Daniel were given to the lions and were consumed immediately before them.

(Daniel 14:24) 
Then the king said, “Let all those who dwell in the entire land fear the God of Daniel, because He is the savior, performing signs and wonders on the earth.”

(Hosea 1:1) 
The Son's message was given to Hosea son of Beeri, during the reigns of kings of Judah, Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah. It was also during the time of Jeroboam son of Joash, king of Israel.

(Hosea 1:2) 
This is the beginning of the Lord's message to Hosea. The Lord told Hosea: “Go, and take for yourself a wife who is a prostitute, and children born from her promiscuity. Because the land itself will become unfaithful, committing sins, abandoning its duties to the Lord.”

(Hosea 1:3) 
So Hosea went and married Gomer, daughter of Diblaim. She conceived and bore him a son.

(Hosea 1:4) 
And the Lord said, “Name him Jezreel, because soon I will punish the house of Jehu for the bloodshed in Jezreel. I will end the kingdom of the house of Israel.”

(Hosea 1:5) 
And in that day, I will break the bow of Israel in the valley of Jezreel.

(Hosea 1:6) 
She conceived again and gave birth to a daughter. And the Lord said to Hosea, “Name her Lo-ruchamah, which means 'not pitied', because I will no longer show mercy to the house of Israel. I will utterly forget them.”

(Hosea 1:7) 
But I will show mercy to the house of Judah, and I will save them by the Lord their God. I will not save them by means of bows, swords, warfare, horses, or riders.

(Hosea 1:8) 
After she had weaned Lo-ruchamah, she conceived and gave birth to a son.

(Hosea 1:9) 
And the Lord said, “Name him Lo-ammi, which means 'not my people', because you are not my people, and I am not your God.”

(Hosea 1:10) 
Yet the number of the Israelites will be like the sand of the sea, which cannot be measured or counted. And in the place where they were told, 'You are not my people,' they will be called 'sons of the living God.'

(Hosea 1:11) 
The people of Judah and the people of Israel will be gathered together, and they will appoint one leader and then leave the land. For a great day will come to Jezreel.

(Hosea 2:1) 
Hear the Word of the Lord, children of Israel! The Lord has a case against those who inhabit the land because there is no truth, there is no mercy, and there is no knowledge of God in the land.

(Hosea 2:2) 
They swear falsely, they lie, murder, steal, and commit adultery. Violence and bloodshed are everywhere.

(Hosea 2:3) 
For these sins, the land will mourn, and everyone who lives there will grow weak. Even the beasts of the field, and the birds of the sky, and the fish in the sea will be affected.

(Hosea 2:4) 
Nevertheless, let no one judge or accuse anyone, for my people are like those who are not judged.

(Hosea 2:5) 
My people will fall because they lack knowledge. Because you have rejected knowledge, I will reject you from serving me as a priest. Since you have forgotten the law of your God, I will forget your children.

(Hosea 2:6) 
The more they multiplied, the more they sinned against me; I will turn their glory into shame.

(Hosea 2:7) 
They eat the sin of my people and raise their souls to iniquity.

(Hosea 2:8) 
The priest will be like the people. I will punish them for their ways and repay them for their deeds.

(Hosea 2:9) 
They will eat, but not be satisfied. They have committed whoredom, but they have not increased, because they have abandoned the Lord.

(Hosea 2:10) 
Whoredom, wine, and drunkenness take away the heart.

(Hosea 2:11) 
My people consult their wood, and their staff gives them oracles. For the spirit of whoredom has led them astray, and they have departed from their God to commit whoredom.

(Hosea 2:12) 
They sacrifice on the tops of the mountains and burn incense on the hills, under oak, poplar, and terebinth trees because their shade is good. Therefore, your daughters will commit whoredom, and your brides will commit adultery.

(Hosea 2:13) 
I will not punish your daughters when they commit whoredom, nor your brides when they commit adultery, for the men themselves consort with prostitutes and sacrifice with cult prostitutes. A people without understanding will fall.

(Hosea 2:14) 
Though you, Israel, commit whoredom, let not Judah offend, nor enter Gilgal, nor go up to Beth-aven, nor swear, 'As the Lord lives.'

(Hosea 2:15) 
For Israel is like a stubborn heifer; now the Lord will pasture them like a lamb in an open place.

(Hosea 2:16) 
Ephraim is joined to idols; let him alone.

(Hosea 2:17) 
Their drink is gone; they have committed whoredom. Their rulers dearly love shame.

(Hosea 2:18) 
The wind has wrapped her in its wings, and they will be ashamed of their sacrifices.

(Hosea 2:19) 
A wind has wrapped her in its wings, and they will be ashamed of their sacrifices.

(Hosea 2:20) 
Say this to the house of Jacob, and to all the remnants of the house of Israel, who swear by the name of the Lord, and invoke the God of Israel, but not in truth or righteousness.

(Hosea 2:21) 
For they call themselves after the holy city, and glory in the God of Israel, but not in truth.

(Hosea 2:22) 
Therefore, I will be like a harlot to you, Israel. Don't go to Gilgal, don't go up to Beth-aven, and don't swear, 'As the Lord lives.'

(Hosea 2:23) 
For like a stubborn heifer, you have turned away from the Lord. Now he will pasture you like a lamb in an open place.

(Hosea 2:24) 
When their drinking is over, they commit whoredom, and their rulers dearly love shame. The shield of her protectors is shame.

(Hosea 2:25) 
The wind has wrapped her in its wings, and she will be ashamed of her sacrifices.

(Hosea 3:1) 
And the Lord said to me: “Go again, and love a woman who is loved by a neighbor and is an adulteress. This is how the Lord loves the children of Israel, even though they are looking to other gods, and are fond of raisin cakes.”

(Hosea 3:2) 
So I bought her for fifteen pieces of silver, a measure of barley, and a container of wine.

(Hosea 3:3) 
I said to her: “You will wait for me for many days. You will not be unfaithful, nor will you belong to any other man, and I will also wait for you.”

(Hosea 3:4) 
For the children of Israel will remain for many days without a king, and without a leader, and without sacrifices, and without an altar, and without the priestly vestments, and without household gods.

(Hosea 3:5) 
After this, the children of Israel will return and seek the Lord their God, and David their king. They will fear the Lord, and His goodness at the end of days.

(Hosea 4:1) 
Hear the word of the Lord, children of Israel, because the Lord has a case against those who live on the earth, because there is no truth, no mercy, and no knowledge of God in the land.

(Hosea 4:2) 
Lying, and deceit, and murder, and theft, and adultery have come to light, and bloodshed follows more bloodshed.

(Hosea 4:3) 
That is why the land will mourn, and everyone who lives in it will be weakened, with the wild animals of the field and the birds of the sky, and even the fish of the sea will disappear.

(Hosea 4:4) 
But let no one bring a charge, or accuse anyone: for my people are like those who have no knowledge.

(Hosea 4:5) 
Israel does not understand this: they have their implements made of wood. In their divination there is an arrow, and in their part they have a shield.

(Hosea 4:6) 
That is why my people will fail, because they have no knowledge: because you have rejected knowledge, I will reject you, so that you will not function as a priest for me; and because you have forgotten the law of your God, I will also forget your children.

(Hosea 4:7) 
The more they have multiplied, the more they have sinned against me: I will change their glory into disgrace.

(Hosea 4:8) 
They will eat the sins of my people, and they will lift up their souls towards their iniquity.

(Hosea 4:9) 
It will be: like people, so also the priest: and I will visit upon him his ways, and I will give to him according to his works.

(Hosea 4:10) 
They will eat, and not be satisfied: they have committed fornication, and have not increased, because they have abandoned the Lord for wantonness.

(Hosea 4:11) 
Fornication, wine, and drunkenness take away the heart.

(Hosea 4:12) 
My people seek counsel from their wood, and their staff declares to them: for a spirit of fornication has seduced them, and they have committed fornication against their God.

(Hosea 4:13) 
They sacrifice on the tops of the mountains, and they offer incense on the hills: under the oak, and the poplar, and the elm, because its shade is good: that is why your daughters commit fornication, and your brides commit adultery.

(Hosea 4:14) 
I will not punish your daughters when they commit fornication, or your brides when they commit adultery: because they themselves are involved with prostitutes, and with effeminate men, the undisciplined people sacrifice.

(Hosea 4:15) 
If you, Israel, commit fornication, let not Judah trespass; and let them not enter into Gilgal, and let them not go up to Beth-aven, nor swear “As the Lord lives.”

(Hosea 4:16) 
Because Israel is wanton, like a heifer: now the Lord will feed them as a lamb in the open space.

(Hosea 4:17) 
Ephraim has been associated with idols: let her be.

(Hosea 4:18) 
Their drinking is polluted, they are exhausted: they have committed fornication, they have loved it, they have despised their shield.

(Hosea 4:19) 
The wind has wrapped her in its wings, and they will be ashamed because of their sacrifices.

(Hosea 5:1) 
Listen to this, priests. Pay attention, house of Israel! Give ear, you in the royal household! The judgment is against you. You are caught in a trap at Mizpah, and a net spread over Tabor.

(Hosea 5:2) 
The rebels of Israel have gone deep into sin. But I know them all.

(Hosea 5:3) 
I know Ephraim. Israel is not hidden from Me. Now, Ephraim, you have committed spiritual adultery. Israel is corrupted.

(Hosea 5:4) 
They will not turn from their ways, to turn back to their God, because the spirit of spiritual adultery is within them, and they do not know the Lord.

(Hosea 5:5) 
The pride of Israel condemns them. Israel and Ephraim will fall because of their sin. Judah will also fall.

(Hosea 5:6) 
They will go to seek the Lord with their flocks and herds, but they will not find Him, because He has departed from them.

(Hosea 5:7) 
They have acted against the Lord, because they have had children with other gods. Now, the new moon with their feasts will consume them.

(Hosea 5:8) 
Blow the horn in Gibeah, and the trumpet in Ramah! Cry out in Beth-Aven! Fear the coming judgment, O Benjamin!

(Hosea 5:9) 
Ephraim will be made desolate in the day of rebuke. I have made known the truth among the tribes of Israel, like a root is their corruption.

(Hosea 5:10) 
The leaders of Judah have become like those who move boundary stones, so I will pour out My wrath on them like water.

(Hosea 5:11) 
Ephraim is oppressed and crushed by judgment, because they have begun to walk after idols.

(Hosea 5:12) 
I will be like a moth to Ephraim and like decay to the house of Judah.

(Hosea 5:13) 
Ephraim sees its sickness, and Judah sees its wounds. Then Ephraim goes to Assyria and sends to King Jareb, but he cannot heal you nor cure your wounds.

(Hosea 5:14) 
I will be like a lion to Ephraim and like a young lion to the house of Judah. I, yes I, will tear them to pieces and then I will depart. There is no one to save them.

(Hosea 5:15) 
They will go back to their own place, and will not return until they acknowledge their sin and failure. In their suffering, they will seek My face.

(Hosea 6:1) 
Come, and let’s return to the Lord, because He wounds us, and He will heal us. He strikes, and He will cure us.

(Hosea 6:2) 
After two days, He will give us life. On the third day, He will raise us up, and we will live in His presence.

(Hosea 6:3) 
Let us strive to know the Lord. As surely as the dawn appears, so will He come forth. He will come to us like the rain—the early and the late rain to the earth.

(Hosea 6:4) 
What can I do with you, Ephraim? What can I do with you, Judah? Your love for Me is like the morning clouds, and like the morning dew that disappears.

(Hosea 6:5) 
Therefore, I hacked them to pieces by the prophets; I killed them with the words of My mouth, and the judgment of God is like the light that goes forth.

(Hosea 6:6) 
For I desire mercy and not sacrifice, and the knowledge of God more than burnt offerings.

(Hosea 6:7) 
But they, like Adam, have transgressed the covenant. There, they despised Me.

(Hosea 6:8) 
Gilead is a city of evildoers, stained with blood.

(Hosea 6:9) 
They act like a band of robbers, lying in wait on the road. They strike.

(Hosea 6:10) 
In the house of Israel, I saw a horrible thing. There are adulteries with Ephraim; Israel is defiled.

(Hosea 6:11) 
Also, Judah, a harvest is appointed for you when I return the captivity of My people.

(Hosea 7:1) 
When I, the Lord, wanted to heal Israel, I found the sins of Ephraim—the northern kingdom—and the wickedness of Samaria—its capital city. For they have lied to me and turned away from me, and a thief breaks into a house to steal.

(Hosea 7:2) 
They don’t realize that I know all their evil actions. They think their wicked deeds have hidden them from me. These actions of theirs are right in front of my face.

(Hosea 7:3) 
They make their king happy with their wicked deeds, and their leaders happy with their schemes and lies.

(Hosea 7:4) 
All of them are unfaithful, like a baker’s oven that is heated. The baker stops stirring the dough after he mixes in the ingredients, and then he waits for the dough to rise.

(Hosea 7:5) 
In the day of our king, the leaders became drunk with wine and made a mess.

(Hosea 7:6) 
Their hearts are like a heated oven, and they plan all night long. In the morning, it is as if the oven is on fire.

(Hosea 7:7) 
All of them are hot like an oven, and they have consumed their judges and their kings. None of them call on me.

(Hosea 7:8) 
Ephraim has mingled himself among the nations. Ephraim is now like a cake that is not flipped on the griddle.

(Hosea 7:9) 
Foreigners have drained his strength. He does not know it. Gray hairs are sprinkled on him, but he does not know it.

(Hosea 7:10) 
Israel’s pride testifies against him. Yet they have not returned to the Lord their God. They have not sought him in all these things.

(Hosea 7:11) 
Ephraim has become like a silly dove, without a heart. They call to Egypt, and they go to Assyria.

(Hosea 7:12) 
When they go there, I will spread my net over them. I will bring them down like birds of the sky. I will punish them as their community has heard.

(Hosea 7:13) 
Woe to them, for they have fled from me! Destruction to them, because they have transgressed against me. Although I have redeemed them, they have spoken lies against me.

(Hosea 7:14) 
They did not cry out to me with their hearts, but they wailed on their beds. They have separated themselves from me, but they will gather grain and wine.

(Hosea 7:15) 
Though I have trained and strengthened their arms, they plot evil against me.

(Hosea 7:16) 
They turned, but not to the Most High. They have become like a faulty bow. They will fall by the sword because of the rage of their tongues. They will become a joke in the land of Egypt.

(Hosea 8:1) 
Sound the trumpet! Like an eagle over the house of the Lord, because they have broken my covenant and defied my law.

(Hosea 8:2) 
They will cry out to me: 'My God, we know you, Israel.'

(Hosea 8:3) 
Israel has rejected what is good; now, an enemy will chase after him.

(Hosea 8:4) 
They set up their own rulers, not those I chose. They made idols from their silver and gold, which will destroy them.

(Hosea 8:5) 
Cast out your calf, Samaria. My anger burns against them. How long will they be unable to be cleansed?

(Hosea 8:6) 
Because it is from Israel, this calf. A craftsman made it, but it is not God. It will be broken.

(Hosea 8:7) 
They sow the wind, and they will reap the whirlwind. It has no stalk and it will not produce grain. If it did, strangers would devour it.

(Hosea 8:8) 
Israel is being destroyed. Now he is among the nations like a vessel with no purpose.

(Hosea 8:9) 
For they have gone up to Assyria, like a wild donkey by himself. Ephraim has hired lovers.

(Hosea 8:10) 
Indeed, they have hired lovers among the nations. Now, I will gather them, and they will rest a little from the burden of the king and the princes.

(Hosea 8:11) 
Because Ephraim has multiplied altars for sinning, altars have become for him as a way to sin.

(Hosea 8:12) 
I wrote many things from my law for him, but they were considered as foreign.

(Hosea 8:13) 
They offer sacrifices, and eat the flesh, but it is not pleasing to the Lord. Now, He will remember their iniquity, and visit their sins. They will return to Egypt.

(Hosea 8:14) 
And Israel will forget his maker, and will build palaces. And he will multiply altars for sinning.

(Hosea 8:15) 
I will send fire into his cities, and it will devour his palaces.

(Hosea 9:1) 
Do not be like the pagans, O Israel. Because you committed fornication from God. You loved the gifts that came from others more than God, who provides everything.

(Hosea 9:2) 
Neither the harvest fields nor the wine will give what you think. The wine will deceive you.

(Hosea 9:3) 
They will not live in the land of the Lord. Ephraim will return to Egypt, and in Assyria they will eat impure food.

(Hosea 9:4) 
They will not offer wine to the Lord, and it will not please Him. Like the bread of mourning, all those who eat it will be defiled, because their bread is for themselves.

(Hosea 9:5) 
What will you do on the feast day, and on the day of the festival of the Lord?

(Hosea 9:6) 
Look, because they have left, they will be ravaged. Egypt will gather them, Memphis will bury them. The most prized of their possessions, will become nettles. Thorns will be in their tabernacles.

(Hosea 9:7) 
The days of visitation have come, the days of retribution have come. Israel will know this. The prophet is a fool, and is crazy in his own spirit, because of the multitude of your iniquities, and the great turning away from God.

(Hosea 9:8) 
The watchman of Ephraim was with my God: a prophet is a snare for a bird-catcher in all his ways, and there is a turning away from the house of God.

(Hosea 9:9) 
They have sinned even more deeply than in the days of Gibeah: He will remember their iniquity and visit their sins.

(Hosea 9:10) 
I found Israel as the grapes in the desert. I saw your fathers like the first fruits of the fig tree in their early season: They went in to Baal-phegor, and were separated in him, and became abominable as they loved.

(Hosea 9:11) 
Ephraim will fly away like a bird: from glory, from offspring, from the womb, and from conception.

(Hosea 9:12) 
And even if they raise their sons, I will take them away without a man. Woe to them when I depart from them.

(Hosea 9:13) 
Ephraim, like I see, is planted in Tyre in beauty: and Ephraim will bring forth his sons to be killed.

(Hosea 9:14) 
Give them, O Lord: what will you give? Give them a womb without conception.

(Hosea 9:15) 
All their wickedness is at Gilgal, because I hate them there: because of the evil of their works I will cast them from my house. I will not continue to love them, all their princes are rebellious.

(Hosea 9:16) 
Ephraim is struck, their root has withered, they will not bear fruit. And if they conceive, I will kill their most desired children.

(Hosea 9:17) 
My God will cast them away, because they did not hear Him: and they will wander among the gentiles.

(Hosea 10:1) 
Israel was like a special vineyard, producing valuable grain for itself. Because of its abundance of crops, it multiplied altars. Because of the fertility of its land, it made statues to pagan gods.

(Hosea 10:2) 
Their hearts are divided and weakened. They will soon be destroyed. God Himself will smash their idols to pieces; their idol-statues will be shattered.

(Hosea 10:3) 
For now they are saying: "We have no king, because we have no fear of the Lord." And what can a king do for us now?

(Hosea 10:4) 
They speak wickedness, making false promises, and entering into treaties with oaths. Therefore, judgment will spring up like poisonous weeds in the furrows of a field.

(Hosea 10:5) 
The people of Israel will be terrified by the false idols of Beth-aven. The people and their priests will mourn and wail because the glory of Israel has been exiled.

(Hosea 10:6) 
Israel and its priests will also be carried away as tribute to the king of Assyria. Israel and Ephraim will be ashamed of their own plans.

(Hosea 10:7) 
Samaria will be destroyed because it has rebelled against its God. The people will fall by the sword; their little children will be crushed, and the pregnant women will be ripped open.

(Hosea 10:8) 
Return, Israel, to the Lord your God, for you have fallen because of your sin.

(Hosea 10:9) 
Prepare your words, and return to the Lord. Say to Him, "Forgive all our wickedness, and receive us in Your goodness, and we will give You our own thanks."

(Hosea 10:10) 
Assyria will not save us. We will not ride on horses. We will no longer say to the works of our hands, "You are our gods," because in You, O Lord, the orphan finds mercy.

(Hosea 10:11) 
I will heal their wounds. I will love them freely, for My anger has turned away from them.

(Hosea 10:12) 
I will be like the morning dew. Israel will sprout like a lily and send out its roots like the trees of Lebanon.

(Hosea 10:13) 
Its branches will spread out, and its glory will be like the olive tree. It will have a pleasant aroma like the cedars of Lebanon.

(Hosea 10:14) 
Those who dwell in its shadow will return; they will revive and flourish like the grain; they will grow like a vine. Their remembrance will be like the wine of Lebanon.

(Hosea 10:15) 
Ephraim, what more have I to do with idols? I will answer him and watch over him. I am like a flourishing cypress tree; your fruit comes from Me.

(Hosea 11:1) 
When Israel was a child, I loved him: and I called my son out of Egypt.

(Hosea 11:2) 
The more I called them, the more they went away from me: they sacrificed to the Baals, and offered incense to carved images.

(Hosea 11:3) 
Yet I myself was like a father to Ephraim: I carried them on my arm, and they did not realize that I would be there for them.

(Hosea 11:4) 
I drew them with ties of men, with bonds of love: and I was to them as one who lifts the yoke from their jaws: and I cared for them.

(Hosea 11:5) 
They shall not return to the land of Egypt: and Assur himself shall be their master, because they would not turn back to Me.

(Hosea 11:6) 
The sword will rage in his cities, and will consume his bars, and devour them because of their wickedness.

(Hosea 11:7) 
And my people shall hang in suspense as they return to Me: and if he calls upon Me, I will not exalt them at the same time.

(Hosea 11:8) 
How shall I give you up, Ephraim? How shall I protect you, Israel? How shall I give you up as Adama? Shall I make you like Zeboim? My heart is turned within me, and my repentance is disturbed at once.

(Hosea 11:9) 
I will not execute the wrath of my anger: I will not return to destroy Ephraim, for I am God and not man: the Holy One in your midst, and I will not enter the city.

(Hosea 11:10) 
The Lord will walk after him: he shall roar like a lion, he shall roar: and the children of the sea shall tremble.

(Hosea 11:11) 
And they shall fly away like a bird out of Egypt: and like a dove out of the land of the Assyrians: and I will place them in their houses, says the Lord.

(Hosea 11:12) 
Ephraim has surrounded Me with falsehood, and the house of Israel with deceit: but Judah is still walking with God, and is faithful with the Holy One.

(Hosea 12:1) 
Ephraim surrounds Me with lies, and the house of Israel surrounds Me with deceit. But now, Judah still trusts God, and remains faithful to the Holy Ones.

(Hosea 12:2) 
Ephraim seeks emptiness, and follows the desert wind: all day long he multiplies lies and violence. He has also made a covenant with the Assyrians, and carries oil to Egypt.

(Hosea 12:3) 
Therefore, the Lord will contend with Israel in Judah, and will visit Jacob, and will repay him according to his ways and deeds.

(Hosea 12:4) 
In the womb, he supplanted his brother, and he had power with God.

(Hosea 12:5) 
He had power over the angel, and prevailed: he wept, and made supplication to him. At Bethel, he found Him, and there He spoke with us.

(Hosea 12:6) 
The Lord God of hosts, the Lord is His memorial.

(Hosea 12:7) 
So you, return to your God: keep mercy and judgment, and hope in your God always.

(Hosea 12:8) 
Canaan has a fraudulent balance in his hand, and desires to defraud.

(Hosea 12:9) 
And Ephraim said: "Surely I have become rich, I have found for myself rest: all my works will not discover in me the iniquity which I have done."

(Hosea 12:10) 
But I am the Lord your God, from the land of Egypt: I will yet make you dwell in tents, as in the days of the feast.

(Hosea 12:11) 
And I have spoken by the prophets, and I have multiplied visions, and I have been likened by the hands of the prophets.

(Hosea 12:12) 
If Gilead is iniquity, truly they were in vain: in Gilgal they sacrificed to bulls: their altars also are as heaps in the furrows of the field.

(Hosea 12:13) 
And Jacob fled into the country of Syria, and Israel served for a wife, and he was nourished for a wife.

(Hosea 12:14) 
And the Lord brought Israel out of Egypt by a prophet, and by a prophet he was kept.

(Hosea 12:15) 
Ephraim provoked in bitterness: his blood will be left behind, and his ignominy will be restored to him.

(Hosea 13:1) 
Ephraim was feared when he spoke, a leader in Israel, but he was already dead to God, and addicted to the sin of Baal.

(Hosea 13:2) 
And now they make their sins even worse, manufacturing idols of silver, works of craftsmen. They tell these idols: “Sacrifice people!”—men who kiss the idols.

(Hosea 13:3) 
Therefore, they will become like morning mist, like passing morning dew, like dust blown from the threshing floor, and like smoke from a chimney.

(Hosea 13:4) 
Yet I am the Lord, your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt. You shall acknowledge no other gods besides Me, for there is no savior except Me.

(Hosea 13:5) 
I knew you in the desert, in the land of solitude.

(Hosea 13:6) 
When they had fed, their hearts grew proud, and they forgot Me.

(Hosea 13:7) 
So I became like a lion to them, like a leopard on the road of the Assyrians.

(Hosea 13:8) 
I will meet them like a bear robbed of her cubs, and I will tear open their hearts. There I will devour them like a lion; wild beasts will tear them apart.

(Hosea 13:9) 
Israel, you are destroyed because you are against Me, against your help.

(Hosea 13:10) 
Where is your king, that he may save you in all your cities? And where are your judges, of whom you said, “Give me a king and princes”?

(Hosea 13:11) 
I gave you a king in My anger, and I took him away in My wrath.

(Hosea 13:12) 
The iniquity of Ephraim is bound, his sin is stored up.

(Hosea 13:13) 
The pangs of childbirth will come to him, but he is a foolish son. For it is not yet time to open the womb.

(Hosea 13:14) 
I will rescue them from the power of the grave. I will redeem them from death. Where, O death, are your plagues? Where, O hell, is your destruction? Compassion is hidden from My eyes.

(Hosea 13:15) 
Though he flourishes among the brothers, an east wind will come, the wind of the Lord, rising from the desert. It will come like a whirlwind from His ways.

(Hosea 13:16) 
The land will become desolate. All of its fruit will dry up. All the precious vessels will be destroyed.

(Hosea 14:1) 
Israel, come back to the Lord your God, because you fell into sin.

(Hosea 14:2) 
Take these words to pray with, and come back to the Lord. Say to Him: “Take away all iniquity, and receive what is good, and we will give you the sacrifices of our lips.”

(Hosea 14:3) 
Assyria will not save us. We will not depend on horses. We will no longer say, ‘These idols are our gods, made by our hands,’ because in You, the orphan is shown mercy.

(Hosea 14:4) 
I will heal their wounds and I will love them of my own accord, because my anger is turned away from them.

(Hosea 14:5) 
I will be like the morning dew to Israel. They will flourish like the lily, and they will send down their roots like the cedars of Lebanon.

(Hosea 14:6) 
His branches will spread out, and his glory will be like an olive tree, and his scent will be like the cedars of Lebanon.

(Hosea 14:7) 
Those who live in the shadow of the righteous will return. They will live by the wheat, and they will flourish like the vine. Their fame will be like the wine of Lebanon.

(Hosea 14:8) 
Ephraim, what do I have to do with idols anymore? I will answer them and look after them. I will be like a green cypress tree, and from me, your fruit will be found.

(Hosea 14:9) 
Who is wise and will understand these things? Who is prudent and will know these things? The ways of the Lord are just, and the righteous will walk in them. But the wicked will stumble and fall.

(Joel 1:1) 
The following is the word of the Lord, which came to Joel, the son of Fathuël.

(Joel 1:2) 
Listen to this, you elders, and hear with your ears, all inhabitants of the earth: Has anything like this happened in your time, or in the time of your ancestors?

(Joel 1:3) 
Tell your children this, and let your children tell their children, and their children tell the next generation.

(Joel 1:4) 
What the locusts left, the swarming locusts ate. What the swarming locusts left, the grasshoppers ate, and what the grasshoppers left, the mildew ate.

(Joel 1:5) 
Wake up, you drunkards, and weep! And wail, all you who drink wine in sweetness, because it is taken away from your mouth.

(Joel 1:6) 
For a nation has come up upon my land, strong and without number; its teeth are the teeth of a lion, and its molar teeth are those of a lioness.

(Joel 1:7) 
It has made my vineyard a desolation, and my fig tree a ruin. It has stripped it bare, and cast it away; its branches are despised.

(Joel 1:8) 
Lament like a virgin, girded with sackcloth, for the husband of her youth.

(Joel 1:9) 
The sacrifice and the libation are cut off from the house of the Lord; the priests, the ministers of the Lord, are in mourning.

(Joel 1:10) 
The fields are wasted, the ground is in mourning, because the wheat is ruined, the wine is dried up, the oil is gone.

(Joel 1:11) 
The farmers are ashamed; the vinedressers wail over the wheat and the barley, for the harvest of the field has perished.

(Joel 1:12) 
The vine has dried up, and the fig tree is broken. The pomegranate, the palm, the apple, and all the trees of the field have withered; because joy has failed from the sons of men.

(Joel 1:13) 
Gird yourselves and lament, priests; wail, ministers of the altar. Go in, lie in sackcloth, ministers of my God, because the sacrifice and the libation are cut off from the house of your God.

(Joel 1:14) 
Sanctify a fast, call a solemn assembly; gather the elders, all the inhabitants of the land, into the house of your God, and cry out to the Lord.

(Joel 1:15) 
Alas for the day, because the day of the Lord is near, and it will come like a desolation from the Almighty.

(Joel 1:16) 
Isn’t the food cut off before our eyes, joy and exultation from the house of our God?

(Joel 1:17) 
The seeds have withered under the clods; the barns have been laid waste; because there is no grain.

(Joel 1:18) 
How the animals groan! The herds of cattle are moaning, because they have no pasture; even the flocks of sheep are scattered.

(Joel 1:19) 
To you, Lord, I will cry out, because fire has devoured the beauty of the wilderness, and the flame has burned all the trees of the region.

(Joel 1:20) 
Even the beasts of the field long for you, because the torrent of waters is dried up, and fire has devoured the beauty of the wilderness.

(Joel 2:1) 
Sound the trumpet in Zion! Give a warning cry on My holy mountain! Let all who live on earth tremble, because the day of the Lord is coming soon.

(Joel 2:2) 
The day of darkness, of storm, of clouds, and of shadows is approaching! Like the dawn expanding on the mountains, there comes a great and mighty people the likes of which has never been, nor will there be again for generations to come.

(Joel 2:3) 
Ahead of them is a devouring fire, and behind them is a blazing flame. The land before them is as the Garden of Eden, and behind them, a desolate wasteland. Nothing escapes them.

(Joel 2:4) 
They look like horses, and they run like warriors on horseback.

(Joel 2:5) 
Like the sound of chariots, they rush over the mountaintops. Like the crackling of a fire devouring the stubble, they are a mighty people prepared for battle.

(Joel 2:6) 
Nations tremble at their approach; their faces are black like those of a boiling pot.

(Joel 2:7) 
They charge like warriors. Each goes straight ahead. They don’t get in each other’s way.

(Joel 2:8) 
They don't jostle one another; each marches straight ahead. They burst through windows like thieves.

(Joel 2:9) 
They storm the city; they run along the wall; they climb into the houses, entering like a thief through the windows.

(Joel 2:10) 
The earth quakes before them, and the sky trembles. The sun and moon are darkened, and the stars no longer shine.

(Joel 2:11) 
The Lord is giving his voice to His great army. The Lord's day is very great and exceedingly terrible. Who can endure it?

(Joel 2:12) 
So now, says the Lord, “Turn back to Me with all your heart, and fast, and weep, and mourn.

(Joel 2:13) 
Tear your hearts, not your clothes; return to the Lord your God, for He is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, abounding in steadfast love; and He relents over disaster.

(Joel 2:14) 
Who knows whether He will relent and leave behind Him a blessing, a grain offering and a drink offering for the Lord your God?

(Joel 2:15) 
Sound the trumpet in Zion! Declare a holy fast; call a sacred assembly.

(Joel 2:16) 
Gather the people, consecrate the congregation; assemble the elders; gather the children, even nursing infants. Let the bridegroom leave his room, and the bride her chamber.

(Joel 2:17) 
Between the porch and the altar, let the priests, the ministers of the Lord, weep. Let them say, “Spare Your people, O Lord, and give not Your heritage to reproach, that the nations may rule over them. Why should they say among the peoples, ‘Where is their God?’”

(Joel 2:18) 
Then the Lord became jealous for His land and had pity on His people.

(Joel 2:19) 
The Lord answered His people: “Behold, I will send you grain, wine, and oil, and you will be satisfied; and I will no longer make you a reproach among the nations.

(Joel 2:20) 
I will remove the northern army far from you, and drive it into a barren and desolate land, its front to the eastern sea and its rear to the western sea. And its stench will rise, and its foul odor will go up, for it has done great things.”

(Joel 2:21) 
Fear not, O land; be glad and rejoice, for the Lord has done great things!

(Joel 2:22) 
Fear not, you beasts of the field, for the pastures of the wilderness are green; the tree bears its fruit; the fig tree and vine give their strength.

(Joel 2:23) 
And children of Zion, be glad and rejoice in the Lord your God! For He has given you the early rain for your vindication; and He will pour down for you the rain, both the early and the late.

(Joel 2:24) 
The threshing floors shall be full of grain; the vats shall overflow with wine and oil.

(Joel 2:25) 
“I will restore the years that the locust has eaten—the hopper, the destroyer, and the cutter, My great army, which I sent among you.

(Joel 2:26) 
You shall eat in plenty and be satisfied, and praise the name of the Lord your God, who has dealt wondrously with you. And My people shall never again be put to shame.

(Joel 2:27) 
You shall know that I am in the midst of Israel, and that I am the Lord your God and there is no other. And My people shall never again be put to shame.

(Joel 2:28) 
“And it shall come to pass afterward, that I will pour out My Spirit on all flesh; your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, and your young men shall see visions.

(Joel 2:29) 
Even on the male and female servants in those days I will pour out My Spirit.

(Joel 2:30) 
“And I will show wonders in the heavens and on the earth, blood and fire and columns of smoke.

(Joel 2:31) 
The sun shall be turned to darkness, and the moon to blood, before the great and awesome day of the Lord comes.

(Joel 2:32) 
And it shall come to pass that everyone who calls on the name of the Lord shall be saved. For in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem there shall be those who escape, as the Lord has said, and among the survivors shall be those whom the Lord calls.

(Joel 3:1) 
For, in those days, and at that time, I will restore the prosperity of Judah and Jerusalem,

(Joel 3:2) 
I will gather all nations and bring them down to the valley of Josaphat. There I will judge them for what they did to My people and My inheritance, Israel, whom they scattered among the nations, and for dividing My land.

(Joel 3:3) 
They cast lots for My people, and gave a boy for a prostitute, and a girl for wine, so that they might drink.

(Joel 3:4) 
And what are you doing, Tyre, and Sidon, and all the territories of the Philistines? Are you trying to take My works from Me? Or what are you doing to Me?

(Joel 3:5) 
If you do these things, I will quickly and swiftly bring your actions down upon your own heads.

(Joel 3:6) 
You have taken My silver and gold, and have brought My precious and beautiful things into your temples.

(Joel 3:7) 
You have sold the sons of Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks, so that you might remove them far from their territory.

(Joel 3:8) 
Behold, I will stir them up from the place where you have sold them, and I will return your retribution on your own heads.

(Joel 3:9) 
I will sell your sons and daughters into the hands of the sons of Judah, and they will sell them to the Sabeans, a distant nation, because the Lord has spoken.

(Joel 3:10) 
Proclaim this among the nations: Prepare for war! Rouse the warriors! Let all the soldiers advance and come forward!

(Joel 3:11) 
Beat your plowshares into swords and your spears into sickles. Let the weak say, “I am strong.”

(Joel 3:12) 
Hurry and come, all you nations from every side, and gather there; there the Lord will gather His mighty ones.

(Joel 3:13) 
Let the nations go down to the valley of Josaphat, because there I will sit to judge all the nations from every side.

(Joel 3:14) 
Put in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe. Come, tread the winepress, for it is full; the vats overflow, for their wickedness is great.

(Joel 3:15) 
Multitudes, multitudes, in the valley of judgment! For the day of the Lord is near in the valley of judgment.

(Joel 3:16) 
The sun and moon are darkened, and the stars withdraw their brilliance.

(Joel 3:17) 
The Lord will roar from Zion, and give His voice from Jerusalem; and the heavens and the earth will shake, and the Lord will be the hope of His people and the strength of the children of Israel.

(Joel 3:18) 
And you will know that I am the Lord your God, dwelling in Zion, My holy mountain. Jerusalem will be holy, and strangers will no longer pass through it.

(Joel 3:19) 
And in that day, the mountains will drip with sweetness, and the hills will flow with milk and honey, and all the streams of Judah will flow with water. A fountain will come out from the house of the Lord, and will water the torrent of thorns.

(Joel 3:20) 
Egypt will become a desolation, and Edom a desert wasteland, because they did evil to the sons of Judah and shed innocent blood in their land.

(Joel 3:21) 
But I will avenge their blood, and will not hold them guiltless, and the Lord will dwell in Zion.

(Amos 1:1) 
These are the words of Amos, who was a shepherd from Tekoa. He saw visions about Jerusalem during the reign of King Uzziah of Judah and during the reign of Jeroboam, son of Joash, king of Israel. This happened two years before the earthquake.

(Amos 1:2) 
Amos said: “The Lord will roar from Zion, and He will make His voice heard from Jerusalem, so the beautiful pastures will mourn, and the top of Mount Carmel will dry up.”

(Amos 1:3) 
The Lord says: “For the three transgressions of Damascus and for the four, I will not relent; because they have threshed Gilead with iron sledges.

(Amos 1:4) 
“So I will send a fire upon the house of Hazael, and it shall devour the strongholds of Ben-hadad.

(Amos 1:5) 
“I will break the gate of Damascus. And I will destroy the one who rules from the valley of Aven, the one who holds the scepter from the house of Eden. The people of Aram will be exiled, along with the remnant of the Israelites,” says the Lord.

(Amos 1:6) 
The Lord says: “For the three transgressions of Gaza and for the four, I will not relent; because they took captives and deported them to Edom.”

(Amos 1:7) 
“So I will send a fire upon the wall of Gaza, and it will consume its fortresses.

(Amos 1:8) 
“I will destroy the one who rules from Ashdod, and the one who holds the scepter from Ashkelon. I will turn my hand against Ekron, and the remnant of the Philistines will perish,” says the Lord God.

(Amos 1:9) 
The Lord says: “For the three transgressions of Tyre and for the four, I will not relent; because they delivered up an entire population of captives to Edom.

(Amos 1:10) 
“So I will send a fire upon the wall of Tyre, and it shall devour its fortresses.

(Amos 1:11) 
The Lord says: “For the three transgressions of Edom and for the four, I will not relent; because he pursued his brother with the sword and cast off all pity, and his anger tore at all that was good, and he kept his wrath forever.

(Amos 1:12) 
“So I will send a fire upon Teman, and it shall devour the fortresses of Bozrah.

(Amos 1:13) 
The Lord says: “For the three transgressions of the Ammonites and for the four, I will not relent; because they have ripped open the pregnant women of Gilead, that they might enlarge their border.

(Amos 1:14) 
“So I will kindle a fire upon the wall of Rabbah, and it shall devour its fortresses, with shouting on the day of battle, with a storm on the day of the tempest.

(Amos 1:15) 
“And their king will go into exile, along with his princes,” says the Lord.

(Amos 2:1) 
The Lord says this: "Moab has committed three crimes, and I will not turn away from punishing them, for they have desecrated the bones of the king of Edom by burning them to ashes.

(Amos 2:2) 
So, I will send fire against Moab that will consume its fortresses, and Moab will die in battle, with the shouts and blare of the war horn.

(Amos 2:3) 
I will destroy their leaders, and I will kill their rulers with them, says the Lord.

(Amos 2:4) 
The Lord says: "Judah has committed three crimes, and I will not turn away from punishing them, because they have rejected the law of the Lord, and have not kept His commandments. Their idols have deceived them, and they followed the same sinful paths as their ancestors.

(Amos 2:5) 
So I will send fire against Judah, and it will consume the fortresses of Jerusalem.

(Amos 2:6) 
The Lord says: "Israel has committed three crimes, and I will not turn away from punishing them, for they have sold the innocent for silver, and the poor for a pair of shoes. They trample the heads of the poor into the dust of the earth.

(Amos 2:7) 
They oppress the poor, and they turn away from the needs of the humble. Fathers and sons exploit young women, which desecrates My holy Name.

(Amos 2:8) 
They take pledges of clothing, and they drink the wine of the condemned in the house of their God.

(Amos 2:9) 
I destroyed the Amorites before them, although they were as tall as the cedars and as strong as the oaks.

(Amos 2:10) 
I destroyed their fruit above, and their roots below.

(Amos 2:11) 
I brought you out of the land of Egypt, and I led you through the desert for forty years, so that you might possess the land of the Amorites.

(Amos 2:12) 
I raised up prophets from among your own sons, and I raised up Nazarites from among your young men. Isn't that the truth, children of Israel? says the Lord.

(Amos 2:13) 
But you made the Nazarites drink wine, and you commanded your prophets, saying, "Do not prophesy."

(Amos 2:14) 
I will press you down, as a cart presses down the sheaves of grain after the harvest. No swift runner will escape, the strong will not retain their strength, and the brave will not save their lives.

(Amos 2:15) 
The archer will not stand his ground, the swift of foot will not escape, and the horseman will not save his life.

(Amos 2:16) 
On that day, even the bravest of warriors will flee in terror, says the Lord. I will multiply those who are wicked.

(Amos 3:1) 
Hear this word which I speak against you, children of Israel, against the entire family I brought out of the land of Egypt, saying:

(Amos 3:2) 
“I have known only you of all the families of the earth. Therefore, I will visit against you all your iniquities.”

(Amos 3:3) 
If two walk together, unless they have agreed?

(Amos 3:4) 
Will a lion roar in the forest if it doesn't have prey? Will a young lion give its cry in its den if it has captured nothing?

(Amos 3:5) 
Does a bird fall into a snare on the earth without cause? Is the snare taken up from the earth before it has caught something?

(Amos 3:6) 
If a trumpet sounds in a city, will the people not be afraid? If there is evil in a city, hasn't the Lord done it?

(Amos 3:7) 
Indeed, the Lord God does nothing unless He reveals His secret to His servants, the prophets.

(Amos 3:8) 
A lion roars, who will not fear? The Lord God has spoken; who will not prophesy?

(Amos 3:9) 
Proclaim this against the house of Jacob and to all the remaining members of the house of Israel: You who carry on, you who are like the high places, and you who practice iniquity.

(Amos 3:10) 
You hate the one who reproves in the gate, and you detest the one who speaks perfectly.

(Amos 3:11) 
Therefore, because you trample on the poor, and take a tribute of grain from them, you have built houses of squared stones, but you will not live in them; you have planted precious vineyards, but you will not drink wine from them.

(Amos 3:12) 
For I know your many crimes and your strong sins: hating the just, taking a bribe, and oppressing the poor in the gate.

(Amos 3:13) 
Therefore, the wise man will keep silent at that time, because it is a bad time.

(Amos 3:14) 
Seek good and not evil, that you may live; and so the Lord God of hosts will be with you, as you have said.

(Amos 3:15) 
Hate evil and love good, and establish judgment in the gate; perhaps the Lord God of hosts will have mercy on the remnant of Joseph.

(Amos 3:16) 
Therefore, the Lord God of hosts, the Lord, says this: There will be wailing in the streets, and in all the roads they will say, “Woe, woe!” They will call the farmer to mourning, and those who know how to wail to lament.

(Amos 3:17) 
And there will be wailing in all the vineyards, because I will pass through the midst of you, says the Lord.

(Amos 3:18) 
Woe to you who desire the day of the Lord! Why is this to you? The day of the Lord is darkness and not light.

(Amos 3:19) 
It is like a man who flees from a lion, and a bear meets him; and he goes into a house and rests his hand on the wall, and a serpent strikes him.

(Amos 3:20) 
Surely the day of the Lord will be darkness and not light? It will be gloom and not splendor in it?

(Amos 3:21) 
I hate and I have rejected your festivals; and I will not smell your assemblies.

(Amos 3:22) 
Because if you offer me holocausts and your gifts, I will not receive them, and I will not look upon the peace offerings of your fat beasts.

(Amos 3:23) 
Take away from me the sound of your songs; I will not hear the song of your psaltery.

(Amos 3:24) 
But let judgment flow like water, and justice like a mighty torrent.

(Amos 3:25) 
Did you offer victims and sacrifices to me in the desert for forty years, house of Israel?

(Amos 3:26) 
And you carried the tabernacle of your Moloch and the star of your god, which you made for yourselves.

(Amos 3:27) 
And I will make you go into exile beyond Damascus, says the Lord, whose name is the God of hosts.

(Amos 4:1) 
Listen to this, you wealthy women of Samaria, who oppress the poor, and crush the needy, who say to your husbands, “Bring us wine!”

(Amos 4:2) 
The Lord swears by His holiness, “Behold, the days are coming upon you, when they shall take you away with hooks, and what is left of you with fishhooks.”

(Amos 4:3) 
You shall go out through breaches in the walls, each one straight ahead, and you will be cast into the Hermon mountain,” says the Lord.

(Amos 4:4) 
Go to Bethel and sin; go to Gilgal and multiply transgression! Offer your sacrifices every morning, and your tithes every three days.

(Amos 4:5) 
Offer a sacrifice of thanksgiving, and proclaim it, and announce the offerings of freewill. For this is what you love, children of Israel!” says the Lord God.

(Amos 4:6) 
I gave you also cleanness of teeth in all your cities, and lack of bread in all your places, and yet you have not returned to Me,” says the Lord.

(Amos 4:7) 
And I also withheld the rain from you when there were still three months to the harvest. I caused it to rain on one city, and caused it not to rain on another city. One part was rained upon, and the part on which it did not rain withered.

(Amos 4:8) 
So two or three cities wandered to one city to drink water, and were not satisfied, and yet you have not returned to Me,” says the Lord.

(Amos 4:9) 
I smote you with a burning wind and blight. Your gardens and your vineyards and your olive orchards the locust consumed, and yet you have not returned to Me,” says the Lord.

(Amos 4:10) 
I sent among you pestilence after the manner of Egypt. I slew your young men with the sword, along with your captured horses, and I made the stench of your camps come up to your nostrils, and yet you have not returned to Me,” says the Lord.

(Amos 4:11) 
I overthrew some of you, as God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah, and you were like a brand plucked from the burning, and yet you have not returned to Me,” says the Lord.

(Amos 4:12) 
Therefore, I will do this to you, O Israel; and because I will do this to you, prepare to meet your God, O Israel.

(Amos 4:13) 
For behold, He who forms the mountains, and creates the wind, and declares to man what his thoughts are, who makes the morning darkness, and treads on the heights of the earth—the Lord, the God of hosts, is His name.

(Amos 5:1) 
Hear this word, because I am mourning over you, people of Israel.

(Amos 5:2) 
Israel has fallen and will not rise again.

(Amos 5:3) 
Because of this, God says, “The city that once provided a thousand soldiers will have only a hundred left. And the city that had a hundred soldiers will have only ten left, O people of Israel.”

(Amos 5:4) 
For God says to the people of Israel, “Seek Me, and you will live.

(Amos 5:5) 
Don’t go to Bethel. Don’t enter Gilgal, nor travel to Beersheba. Gilgal will become a ruin, and Bethel will be stripped of glory.

(Amos 5:6) 
Seek God so that you may live, or else He will strike the house of Joseph like a fire, and it will consume everything, and there will be no one to extinguish it in Bethel.

(Amos 5:7) 
You change the meaning of justice, making it bitter like wormwood, and you throw righteousness to the ground,

(Amos 5:8) 
You make the stars and the constellations, and you turn the shadow of death into morning, and the day into a dark night. You call for the waters of the sea, and pour them out over the surface of the earth.

(Amos 5:9) 
You bring ruin on the strong, and ruin will come upon the mighty.

(Amos 5:10) 
You hate those who rebuke evil at the gate, and you despise those who speak the truth.

(Amos 5:11) 
Because you trample the poor, and collect grain from them, you have built houses of stone, but you will not live in them; you have planted vineyards, but you will not drink their wine.

(Amos 5:12) 
For I know your many sins and the strength of your transgressions: you are enemies of the righteous, taking bribes, and oppressing the poor at the gate.

(Amos 5:13) 
So at this time, the wise will be silent because it is an evil time.

(Amos 5:14) 
Seek good, not evil, so that you may live. Then God will be with you, just as you say He is.

(Amos 5:15) 
I hate and reject your feasts. I will not receive the scent of your solemn assemblies.

(Amos 5:16) 
Even if you offer Me burnt offerings and gifts, I will not accept them; nor will I look at the peace offerings of your fattened animals.

(Amos 5:17) 
Take away from Me the noise of your songs; I will not listen to the music of your harps.

(Amos 5:18) 
But let judgment flow like water, and justice like a mighty river.

(Amos 5:19) 
O people of Israel, did you offer sacrifices and offerings to Me in the desert for forty years?

(Amos 5:20) 
You carried the tent of your god Moloch and the image of your idols, the star of your god, which you made for yourselves.

(Amos 5:21) 
So I will send you into exile beyond Damascus, God says. God of Hosts is His name.

(Amos 5:22) 
Woe to those who are so confident in the mountain of Samaria, the strength of the head of the nations, to whom the people of Israel come.

(Amos 5:23) 
Go to Calneh and see it, and then go to Hamath the great, and then descend to Gath of the Philistines. Are these kingdoms better than yours? Is their territory wider than yours?

(Amos 5:24) 
You separate yourselves for the day of evil, and you come to the throne on the Sabbath days.

(Amos 5:25) 
You sleep on beds of ivory and lounge on your couches. You eat the lambs from the flock and the calves from the midst of the herd.

(Amos 5:26) 
You sing along with the sound of the instruments, and you think of yourselves as one great nation, eating the best parts of the calves.

(Amos 5:27) 
Therefore, now you will be the first to be led away as captives, and the gatherings of revelers will be taken away.

(Amos 6:1) 
Woe to those who live carelessly in Zion and think they are safe on the mountain of Samaria! You are the leaders of the most important families and clans, the men of renown, and you consider yourselves to be the leaders of Israel.

(Amos 6:2) 
Go to Calneh and see. Then go on from there to Hamath the great, and go down to Gath of the Philistines. See if these kingdoms are better than yours; see if their territory is greater than yours!

(Amos 6:3) 
You postpone the day of misfortune and cling to the ways of wickedness!

(Amos 6:4) 
You sleep on ivory beds and sprawl on your couches, you eat the best lambs from the flock and the finest calves from the stall;

(Amos 6:5) 
You sing idle songs to the music of the harp. You are conceited, as if you are David, inventing musical instruments.

(Amos 6:6) 
You drink wine by the bowlful, and you anoint yourselves with the finest oils, but you are not grieved over the destruction of Israel.

(Amos 6:7) 
Therefore, you will now be the first to be taken into exile. The revelry of the arrogant will end.

(Amos 6:8) 
The Lord God has sworn by his own power: “I detest the pride of Jacob and hate their palaces. I will deliver this city and all that is in it to the enemy.”

(Amos 6:9) 
Will not the land tremble for this? Will not everyone who lives there mourn? The land will be flooded like the Nile, rising and falling again like the river of Egypt.

(Amos 6:10) 
And in that day, says the Lord God: “Your songs of praise will be turned to lamentation. And the music will be silenced.

(Amos 6:11) 
Your loud and frivolous partying will become weeping.

(Amos 6:12) 
Do horses run on the rocky terrain? Does one plow there with oxen? You have turned justice into bitter poison, and the fruit of righteousness into wormwood.

(Amos 6:13) 
You are proud of what is worthless and you say, “Did we not seize power through our own strength?”

(Amos 6:14) 
But I am about to raise up against you, house of Israel, says the Lord, the God of hosts, and I will oppress you as a cart is crushed when it is overloaded with grain.

(Amos 6:15) 
The swift will lose their means of escape, the strong will lose their strength, and the mighty will not save themselves.

(Amos 6:16) 
Those who are skilled with a bow will not stand their ground, and the swift runner will not get away, and the horseman will not save himself.

(Amos 6:17) 
Even the most courageous soldier will flee naked on that day, says the Lord.

(Amos 7:1) 
These are the visions that Amos, a shepherd from Tekoa, saw about Israel, which he saw during the reigns of King Uzziah of Judah and King Jeroboam son of Joash of Israel, two years before the earthquake.

(Amos 7:2) 
And he said: "The Lord will roar from Zion, and He will give His voice from Jerusalem. The best pastures of the desert will mourn, and the field will wither because the whole earth is cursed, along with everyone who lives in it."

(Amos 7:3) 
This is what the Lord says: "For three crimes of Damascus, and for four, I will not relent, because they threshed Gilead with saws, threshing them with iron saws."

(Amos 7:4) 
I will send a fire into the house of Hazael, which will consume the foundations of Ben-hadad.

(Amos 7:5) 
I will break the bar of Damascus, and I will destroy the one who dwells in the field of pleasure, and the remnant of Syria will be exiled," says the Lord.

(Amos 7:6) 
This is what the Lord says: "For three crimes of Gaza, and for four, I will not relent, because they took captives and sold them completely to Edom."

(Amos 7:7) 
I will send fire into the walls of Gaza, and it will consume its foundations.

(Amos 7:8) 
I will destroy the one who lives in Ashdod, and the one who lives in Ashkelon, and I will turn My hand against Ekron. The remnant of the Philistines will perish," says the Lord God.

(Amos 7:9) 
This is what the Lord says: "For three crimes of Tyre, and for four, I will not relent, because they handed over captives completely to Edom."

(Amos 7:10) 
I will send fire into the walls of Tyre, and it will consume its foundations.

(Amos 7:11) 
This is what the Lord says: "For three crimes of Edom, and for four, I will not relent, because he pursued his brother with the sword, and broke every mercy, and in his fury he always tore him apart, and his anger kept itself forever."

(Amos 7:12) 
I will send fire into Teman, and it will consume the foundations of Bozrah.

(Amos 7:13) 
This is what the Lord says: "For three crimes of the Ammonites, and for four, I will not relent, because they ripped open the pregnant women of Gilead, in order to expand their territory."

(Amos 7:14) 
I will set fire to the walls of Rabbah, and it will consume its foundations, with a shout on the day of battle, and with a whirlwind on the day of destruction.

(Amos 7:15) 
Their king will go into captivity, along with his princes," says the Lord.

(Amos 8:1) 
This is what the Lord God showed to me, and behold, a basket of ripe fruits.

(Amos 8:2) 
And He said, “What do you see, Amos?” And I said, “A basket of ripe fruits.” Then the Lord said to me, “The end has come for My people Israel. I will not spare them any further.

(Amos 8:3) 
In that day, the songs of the Temple will turn to wailing, says the Lord God. Many corpses will be cast out, in the place where they are buried.

(Amos 8:4) 
Hear this, you who oppress the poor and destroy the needy of the land.

(Amos 8:5) 
You say, “When will the new moon be over, so that we may sell our grain? When will the Sabbath be over, so that we may open our storehouses? We want to make the measure smaller, and increase the price, and falsify the scales.

(Amos 8:6) 
We want to buy the poor with silver and the needy for a pair of sandals. We want to sell even the discarded wheat.

(Amos 8:7) 
The Lord has sworn by the pride of Jacob: I will never forget all their deeds.

(Amos 8:8) 
Will not the land tremble for this, and will not all who dwell in it mourn? The land will rise like the Nile, and it will surge up and then sink like the river of Egypt.

(Amos 8:9) 
And in that day, says the Lord God, I will make the sun go down at noon, and I will darken the land in broad daylight.

(Amos 8:10) 
I will turn your feasts into mourning, and all your songs into lamentation. I will bring sackcloth upon every back, and baldness upon every head. I will make it like mourning for an only son, and its end as a bitter day.

(Amos 8:11) 
Behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, when I will send a famine on the land—not a famine of bread or a thirst for water, but of hearing the words of the Lord.

(Amos 8:12) 
They will wander from sea to sea, and from the north to the east; they will run to and fro, seeking the word of the Lord, but they will not find it.

(Amos 8:13) 
In that day the beautiful virgins and the young men will faint from thirst.

(Amos 8:14) 
Those who swear by the sin of Samaria, who say, “As your god lives, O Dan,” and, “As the way of Beersheba lives,” they will fall, and never rise again.

(Amos 9:1) 
I saw the Lord standing near the altar and He said, “Strike at the top of the temple! Shake the threshold of the doors. The temple will collapse above their heads, and I will kill the rest of them by the sword. No one will escape, and no one will survive who runs away.”

(Amos 9:2) 
“Even if they dig their way into hell, I will bring them out. If they climb all the way up to the sky, I will bring them down.

(Amos 9:3) 
“If they hide in the highest place on Mount Carmel, I will search for them and bring them out. If they hide from me on the ocean floor, I will command the sea serpent to bite them.

(Amos 9:4) 
“If they are led away into captivity by their enemies, I will command the sword and kill them. I will fix my eyes on them for bad, and not for good.”

(Amos 9:5) 
The Lord God of hosts touches the earth and makes it melt, and all who live on the earth mourn. The earth will rise up like the Nile River, and then it will recede like the Nile.

(Amos 9:6) 
God has built His high place in the sky, and He has set the foundation of the Temple on the earth. He calls up the waters of the sea and pours them over the face of the earth. The Lord is His name.

(Amos 9:7) 
“Are you not like the children of Ethiopia to me, children of Israel?” says the Lord. “Did I not bring Israel out of the land of Egypt, and the Philistines from Caphtor, and the Arameans from Kir?

(Amos 9:8) 
“I am the Lord. I see the sin in this kingdom, and I will destroy it from the face of the earth. But I will not destroy them completely,” says the Lord.

(Amos 9:9) 
“I will give the command, and I will shake them among all the nations, like you shake wheat in the barn. Not a grain will fall to the ground.

(Amos 9:10) 
“The sinners of my people will die by the sword, those who say, ‘Evil will not come near us.’”

(Amos 9:11) 
“On that day, I will reestablish the fallen kingdom of David. I will repair its breaks, rebuild its ruins, and restore it as it was in the ancient days,

(Amos 9:12) 
so they may take possession of what remains of Edom and of all the nations. These are the people who are called by my name,” says the Lord, who does these things.

(Amos 9:13) 
“The days are coming,” says the Lord, “when the one plowing will catch the reaper, and the one who treads grapes will catch the one who is scattering the seeds. The mountains will drip with sweetness, and all the hills will be filled with fruits.

(Amos 9:14) 
“I will restore the captivity of my people Israel. They will rebuild the ruined cities and live there. They will plant vineyards and drink their wine. They will make gardens and eat their fruit.

(Amos 9:15) 
“I will plant them on their own land. They will never again be uprooted from the land that I have given them,” says the Lord your God.

(Obadiah 1:1) 
The vision of Abdias. God the Lord says this about Edom: I, God, have a message to deliver to the nations. Rise up, let us fight against Edom!

(Obadiah 1:2) 
Behold, I have made you a small nation among the nations. You are held in contempt.

(Obadiah 1:3) 
Your pride of heart has deceived you, O Edom, who dwell in the high, stony places. You say in your heart: “Who can bring me down to the earth?”

(Obadiah 1:4) 
Even if you soar like an eagle, even if you make your nest among the stars, I will bring you down, says the Lord.

(Obadiah 1:5) 
If thieves were to come to you, if robbers by night, how would you hide? Would they not steal until they had enough? If grape-gatherers came to you, surely they would leave some grapes behind!

(Obadiah 1:6) 
How have the descendants of Esau been plundered! How have their hidden treasures been sought out! Even to the end of the nation they have expelled you.

(Obadiah 1:7) 
All your allies have deceived you, and have prevailed against you, those who eat with you have set a trap for you: there is no understanding in him.

(Obadiah 1:8) 
On that day, says the Lord, I will destroy the wise men from Edom and all understanding from the mountain of Esau.

(Obadiah 1:9) 
And your mighty men, Teman, will be struck with fear, and I will destroy all understanding from the mountain of Esau.

(Obadiah 1:10) 
Because of the violence done to your brother Jacob, shame will cover you, and you will be destroyed forever.

(Obadiah 1:11) 
On the day that you stood by, when strangers carried off Jacob’s wealth, when foreigners entered his gates, and cast lots for Jerusalem, you were like one of them.

(Obadiah 1:12) 
You should not have looked on the day of your brother’s misfortune, nor rejoiced over the children of Judah on the day of their destruction; nor should you have spoken proudly in the day of distress.

(Obadiah 1:13) 
You should not have entered the gate of my people on the day of their disaster, nor gloated over his misfortune on the day of his affliction, nor laid hands on his wealth on the day of his desolation.

(Obadiah 1:14) 
You should not have stood at the crossroads to cut off those who escaped, nor delivered over his survivors on the day of distress.

(Obadiah 1:15) 
For the day of the Lord is near against all the nations. As you have done, so shall it be done to you. Your actions will return upon your own head.

(Obadiah 1:16) 
For just as you have drunk on my holy mountain, so all the nations shall drink continually, and they shall drink and swallow, and be as though they had never been.

(Obadiah 1:17) 
But on Mount Zion there will be deliverance, and it will be holy; and the house of Jacob will possess those who possessed them.

(Obadiah 1:18) 
And the house of Jacob will be a fire, and the house of Joseph a flame, and the house of Esau like stubble, and they will burn them and consume them. There will be no survivor of the house of Esau, because the Lord has spoken.

(Obadiah 1:19) 
Those of the south will possess the mountain of Esau, and those of the plain, the Philistines. They will possess the territories of Ephraim and Samaria, and Benjamin will possess Gilead.

(Obadiah 1:20) 
And the exiles of this army of the children of Israel will possess what is in Canaan as far as Zarephath; and the exiles of Jerusalem, who are in Sepharad, will possess the cities of the south.

(Obadiah 1:21) 
And saviors will go up to Mount Zion to judge the mountain of Esau, and the kingdom will be the Lord’s.

(Jonah 1:1) 
The word of the Lord came to Jonah, the son of Amittai, saying:

(Jonah 1:2)
