“Go to the great city of Nineveh, and preach to it: because its wickedness has come up before me.”

(Jonah 1:3) 
But Jonah rose up to flee to Tarshish, away from the Lord. He went down to Joppa and found a ship going to Tarshish. He paid his fare and went down into it, to go with them to Tarshish, away from the Lord.

(Jonah 1:4) 
The Lord then sent a great wind on the sea, and there was a great storm on the sea, and the ship was in danger of breaking up.

(Jonah 1:5) 
The sailors were afraid, and each man cried to his god. They threw the cargo which was in the ship into the sea, to lighten the ship. But Jonah had gone down into the lowest parts of the ship, and was fast asleep.

(Jonah 1:6) 
The shipmaster came to him and said, “What are you doing sleeping? Get up, call upon your God, so that God may think of us and we do not die.”

(Jonah 1:7) 
Each of them said to his companion: “Come, let’s cast lots, to find out why this evil has come upon us.” So they cast lots, and the lot fell on Jonah.

(Jonah 1:8) 
Then they said to him, “Tell us why this evil has come upon us. What is your job, and where do you come from? What is your nation?”

(Jonah 1:9) 
He said to them, “I am a Hebrew, and I fear the God of the universe who made the sea and the dry land.”

(Jonah 1:10) 
Then the men were exceedingly afraid, and they said to him, “Why have you done this?” For the men knew that he was fleeing from the Lord, because he had told them.

(Jonah 1:11) 
They said to him, “What should we do to you, that the sea may cease from us?” For the sea was getting rougher and rougher.

(Jonah 1:12) 
He said to them, “Take me up and throw me into the sea, and the sea will be calm for you. For I know that because of me this great storm has come upon you.”

(Jonah 1:13) 
The men rowed to get back to dry land, but they couldn’t. For the sea continued to rage more and more.

(Jonah 1:14) 
Then they called upon the Lord and said, “We beseech you, Lord, do not let us perish for the life of this man, and do not put innocent blood upon us. For you, Lord, have done as you have willed.”

(Jonah 1:15) 
So they took Jonah and threw him into the sea. And the sea stopped its raging.

(Jonah 1:16) 
Then the men feared the Lord exceedingly, and they offered a sacrifice to the Lord and made vows.

(Jonah 1:17) 
Now the Lord prepared a great fish to swallow Jonah. And Jonah was in the belly of the fish for three days and three nights.

(Jonah 2:1) 
And Jonah prayed to the Lord his God from the belly of the fish.

(Jonah 2:2) 
And he said: "In my suffering, I called out to the Lord, and he heard me:

(Jonah 2:3) 
From the depths of Sheol (the grave), I cried out, and you heard my voice.

(Jonah 2:4) 
You cast me into the deep sea, and the waves were all around me;

(Jonah 2:5) 
all of your great waves and surging seas passed over me.

(Jonah 2:6) 
And I said: 'I am cast out from before your eyes';

(Jonah 2:7) 
yet I will look upon your holy temple again.

(Jonah 2:8) 
The waters closed in around me, threatening my life;

(Jonah 2:9) 
the deep sea engulfed me; the ocean covered my head.

(Jonah 2:10) 
I sank to the foundations of the mountains; the earth's bars closed upon me forever.

(Jonah 2:11) 
But you brought my life back from corruption, O Lord my God.

(Jonah 2:12) 
When my soul was fainting within me, Lord, I remembered you:

(Jonah 2:13) 
and my prayer came to you, into your holy temple.

(Jonah 2:14) 
Those who cling to worthless things abandon their own mercy.

(Jonah 2:15) 
But I, with a voice of thanksgiving, will offer sacrifice to you. I will pay what I have vowed for salvation.

(Jonah 2:16) 
And the Lord spoke to the fish, and it vomited Jonah out onto dry land.

(Jonah 3:1) 
The word of the Lord then came to Jonah a second time, saying:

(Jonah 3:2) 
“Go to the great city of Nineveh, and preach the message that I give to you there.”

(Jonah 3:3) 
So Jonah arose, and went to Nineveh according to the word of the Lord. Now Nineveh was an exceedingly great city before God, a journey of three days.

(Jonah 3:4) 
Jonah began to enter the city, going the distance of one day’s walk. And he cried out, and said, “Forty days more, and Nineveh shall be overthrown!”

(Jonah 3:5) 
And the men of Nineveh believed in God. They proclaimed a fast and put on sackcloth, from the greatest to the least.

(Jonah 3:6) 
For word reached the king of Nineveh: and he arose from his throne, and laid aside his robe, and was covered with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.

(Jonah 3:7) 
And he proclaimed and said in Nineveh: “By the decree of the king and his nobles, saying: Let neither men nor beasts, oxen nor sheep, taste anything; let them not feed, nor drink water.

(Jonah 3:8) 
And let men and beasts be covered with sackcloth, and cry to God with all their might. Let each one turn from their evil way and from the wickedness that is in their hands.

(Jonah 3:9) 
Who knows if God will turn and repent, and turn away from the wrath of His fury, so that we may not perish?”

(Jonah 3:10) 
And God saw their works, that they had turned from their evil way. And God had mercy on the evil that He said He would do to them, and He did not do it.

(Jonah 4:1) 
And Jonas was very displeased, and he became angry.

(Jonah 4:2) 
And he prayed to the Lord, and said, "I beseech Thee, Lord, was not this my word when I was still in my own land? Therefore, I fled to Tharsis, for I knew that Thou art a gracious God, and merciful, patient, and of great compassion, and easy to forgive evil."

(Jonah 4:3) 
And now, Lord, take my life from me, for it is better for me to die than to live."

(Jonah 4:4) 
And the Lord said, "Do you think it is right to be angry?"

(Jonah 4:5) 
And Jonas went out of the city, and sat down on the east side of it, and he made himself a booth there, and sat under it, to see what would happen to the city.

(Jonah 4:6) 
And the Lord God caused a gourd vine to grow up over the head of Jonas, to make a shade over his head, and to protect him; for he had toiled.

(Jonah 4:7) 
And Jonas was exceedingly glad because of the gourd vine.

(Jonah 4:8) 
But God prepared a worm when the dawn came up, and it struck the gourd vine, and it withered.

(Jonah 4:9) 
And it came to pass when the sun rose, that a burning wind blew, and the sun struck the head of Jonas, and he fainted, and he desired his own death, and said, "It is better for me to die than to live."

(Jonah 4:10) 
And God said to Jonas, "Do you think it is right to be angry about the gourd vine?" And he said, "I am right to be angry, even unto death."

(Jonah 4:11) 
And the Lord said, "You are sorry for the gourd vine, which you did not labor on, nor did you make it grow, which came up in a night, and perished in a night:

(Jonah 4:12) 
and should not I spare Ninive, that great city, in which there are more than one hundred and twenty thousand people who do not know how to distinguish between their right hand and their left, and also many animals?"

(Micah 1:1) 
The Word of the Lord, which came to Micah of Moresheth, in the days of Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah, that he saw concerning Samaria and Jerusalem.

(Micah 1:2) 
Listen, all you peoples: let the earth give ear and the world around it: and let the Lord God be your witness, the Lord from his holy temple.

(Micah 1:3) 
Because, behold, the Lord will leave His place, and will come down, and will tread upon the high places of the earth.

(Micah 1:4) 
And the mountains will melt under Him, and the valleys will be split open as wax before the fire, and as waters that rush down a precipice.

(Micah 1:5) 
All of this is because of the sin of Jacob, and because of the sins of the house of Israel. What is the sin of Jacob? Is it not Samaria? And what are the high places of Judah? Is it not Jerusalem?

(Micah 1:6) 
I will make Samaria like a heap of stones in the field, in the planting of a vineyard: and I will cast down the stones thereof into the valley, and I will discover the foundations thereof.

(Micah 1:7) 
And all her graven images will be broken to pieces, and all her wages will be burned with fire, and I will make all her idols desolate: for she gathered them from the wages of a harlot, and she will return to the wages of a harlot.

(Micah 1:8) 
Therefore will I wail and howl: I will go stripped and naked: I will make a lamentation as for the dragons, and a mourning as for the daughters of ostriches.

(Micah 1:9) 
Because her wound is desperate: for it is come even to Judah, it has touched the gate of my people Jerusalem.

(Micah 1:10) 
Tell it not in Gath, weep not at all: in the house of dust, you shall sprinkle yourselves with dust.

(Micah 1:11) 
Pass over, you that dwell in Saphir, naked with shame: she that dwells in Sanan will not go forth. The mourning of Joath: he will take away from you his hope.

(Micah 1:12) 
For the inhabitant of Maroth is become weak for good: because evil is come down from the Lord to the gate of Jerusalem.

(Micah 1:13) 
Harness the chariot to the chariot, inhabitant of Lachis: the beginning of sin is to the daughter of Sion: for in you are found the wicked deeds of Israel.

(Micah 1:14) 
Therefore she will give a parting gift to Moresheth Gath: the houses of Achzib will be a lie to the kings of Israel.

(Micah 1:15) 
I will bring to you again the heir, inhabitant of Maresa: even to Odollam will come the glory of Israel.

(Micah 1:16) 
Make yourself bald, and shave off the hair of your head for your delicate sons: enlarge your baldness as the eagle: because they are gone from you.

(Micah 2:1) 
Woe to those who plan wickedness, and work evil in your beds! You will bring it to completion in the morning light, because it is in your power.

(Micah 2:2) 
And they covet fields, and seize them by force, and houses, and take them away: they have calumniated the man and his house, the man and his inheritance.

(Micah 2:3) 
Therefore, the Lord says this: Behold, I am planning evil against this generation, from which you will not remove your necks, and you will not walk proudly, for it is an evil time.

(Micah 2:4) 
In that day, a parable will be taken up against you, and sung in a song, saying:

(Micah 2:5) 
“We are utterly destroyed! He has taken my portion of the land. He has parceled out my fields.”

(Micah 2:6) 
Therefore, there will be no one for you to cast a lot in the assembly of the Lord.

(Micah 2:7) 
“Do not preach,” they say, “do not prophesy.” They will not prophesy to these, and they will not suffer reproaches.

(Micah 2:8) 
But I say: What will you speak? For an evil time will come.

(Micah 2:9) 
And he said: “Listen to what I speak: Do not hope. Do not hope,” he said, “in the sons of iniquity.”

(Micah 2:10) 
Because you suddenly drive away my people: from their garments you take away the robe, from those passing by confidently, turning them away.

(Micah 2:11) 
The women of my people you cast out from the houses of their delights, taking away their glory forever from their children.

(Micah 2:12) 
Arise, and go, because there is no rest here because of the uncleanness that ruins, a most grievous ruin.

(Micah 2:13) 
If I were to walk in the spirit and go falsely, I would say to you, “Prophesy,” and I would prophesy to you of wine and drunkenness, and this would be the people I would speak to.

(Micah 3:1) 
And I said: “Listen, rulers of Israel! You leaders of the house of Jacob, shouldn’t you know what’s right?

(Micah 3:2) 
You hate good and you love evil. You tear the skin off the poor and take away their flesh from their bones.

(Micah 3:3) 
You eat the flesh of my people, you rip the skin off them, you break their bones, you chop them up like meat in a pot, like flesh in a cauldron.

(Micah 3:4) 
Then they will cry to the Lord, but He will not answer them. He will hide His face from them in that time, because of the evil they have done.

(Micah 3:5) 
Thus says the Lord about the false prophets who lead my people astray: “They bite with their teeth and cry out, ‘Peace!’ If anyone does not give them something to eat, they prepare war against him.”

(Micah 3:6) 
Therefore, the night will be for you instead of vision, and darkness will be for you instead of divination. The sun will set upon the prophets, and the day will be darkened for them.

(Micah 3:7) 
Then the seers will be ashamed, and the diviners will blush. They will all cover their mouths, for there will be no answer from God.

(Micah 3:8) 
But as for me, I am filled with the power of the Spirit of the Lord, and with justice and strength, to declare to Jacob his crimes and to Israel his sins.

(Micah 3:9) 
Hear this, you leaders of the house of Jacob, and rulers of the house of Israel, you who hate justice, and who pervert all that is right:

(Micah 3:10) 
You build Zion with bloodshed, and Jerusalem with iniquity.

(Micah 3:11) 
Its leaders judge for a bribe, its priests teach for pay, and its prophets divine for money. And they lean on the Lord, saying, “Is the Lord not among us? No evil will come upon us.”

(Micah 3:12) 
Therefore, because of you, Zion will be plowed like a field, and Jerusalem will be a heap of stones, and the mountain of the temple will be like the high places of the forest.

(Micah 4:1) 
In the last days, the mountain of the Lord's house will be made ready. This mountain will be the highest of all mountains, and more important than the hills. And people will come to it.

(Micah 4:2) 
Many nations will hasten to it, and they will say, “Come! Let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob. He will teach us His ways, and we will walk in His paths. For the Law will go out from Zion, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.”

(Micah 4:3) 
He will judge among many peoples, and will rebuke strong nations from afar. And they will turn their swords into plowshares, and their spears into sickles. Nation shall not take up the sword against nation, nor will they learn war anymore.

(Micah 4:4) 
Everyone will sit under their own vine, and under their own fig tree, and no one will make them afraid. For the mouth of the Lord of Hosts has spoken.

(Micah 4:5) 
For all peoples will walk, each in the name of their own god, and we will walk in the name of the Lord our God, forever and ever.

(Micah 4:6) 
“In that day,” says the Lord, “I will gather the lame, and the one who was cast out, and the one whom I afflicted.”

(Micah 4:7) 
I will make the lame a remnant, and the one who was weary, a strong nation. And the Lord will reign over them in Mount Zion, from now and forever.

(Micah 4:8) 
And you, O tower of the flock, O fortified hill of the daughter of Zion, the former dominion will come to you, and the kingdom will come to the daughter of Jerusalem.

(Micah 4:9) 
Now, why do you cry aloud? Is there no king in you? Has your counselor perished, that pain has seized you like a woman in labor?

(Micah 4:10) 
Be in pain, and labor, daughter of Zion, like a woman in labor. For now you will go out of the city, and you will live in the countryside, and you will come to the field; and there you will be saved.

(Micah 4:11) 
Now many nations are gathered against you, saying, “Let her be profaned, and let our eye see in Zion.”

(Micah 4:12) 
But they do not know the thoughts of the Lord, and they have not understood His plan, for He has gathered them like sheaves to the threshing floor.

(Micah 4:13) 
Arise, and thresh, daughter of Zion, for I will make your horn iron, and I will make your hooves bronze, and you will crush many peoples, and you will consecrate the Lord of the earth, and their plunder to the Lord.

(Micah 5:1) 
Now you must gather your troops. A siege will be set against us. With a rod, the judge of Israel will strike on the cheek.

(Micah 5:2) 
And you, Bethlehem Ephrata, are small among the clans of Judah, but from you, the ruler of Israel will come forth for me, whose origins are from old, even from eternity itself.

(Micah 5:3) 
Therefore, God will let them be defeated until the one who will give birth has given birth, and then the rest of his brothers will return to the Israelites.

(Micah 5:4) 
He will stand and lead them in the strength of the Lord, in the glorious name of the Lord his God. And they will be converted and be with him, because his kingdom will be made great until the ends of the earth.

(Micah 5:5) 
And He will be peace, and when the Assyrians invade our land, and tread on our houses, we will raise up against them seven shepherds, and eight leaders from among mankind.

(Micah 5:6) 
They will shepherd the land of the Assyrians with the sword, and the land of Nimrod with his spears. And they will save us from the Assyrian, when he invades our land, and when he steps inside our borders.

(Micah 5:7) 
And the remnant of Jacob will be among many peoples, like dew from the Lord, like showers on the grass, not waiting on man, nor expecting the sons of men.

(Micah 5:8) 
The remnant of Jacob will be among the Gentiles, in the midst of many peoples, like a lion among the beasts of the forest, like a young lion among flocks of sheep, when he passes through, tramples, and seizes, and there is none to rescue.

(Micah 5:9) 
Let your hand be raised against your enemies, and may all your enemies perish.

(Micah 5:10) 
And in that day, says the Lord, I will take away your horses from among you, and I will destroy your chariots.

(Micah 5:11) 
I will remove the cities of your land, and I will tear down all your fortresses.

(Micah 5:12) 
I will take away your sorceries, and there will be no divination practiced by you.

(Micah 5:13) 
I will take away your carved images, and your idols, and you shall no longer worship the works of your hands.

(Micah 5:14) 
I will tear out your groves from your midst, and I will destroy your cities.

(Micah 5:15) 
And I will execute vengeance in wrath and indignation on the nations who have not obeyed.

(Micah 6:1) 
Hear what the Lord is saying: “Rise up. Make your case before the mountains, and let the hills hear your voice.”

(Micah 6:2) 
Mountains, hear the Lord’s legal case. You solid foundations of the earth, listen to the judgment. For the Lord is in judgment with His people, and He will contend with Israel.

(Micah 6:3) 
My people, what have I done to you? How have I wearied you? Answer Me.

(Micah 6:4) 
Because I brought you out of the land of Egypt. I freed you from slavery. I sent before you Moses, Aaron, and Miriam.

(Micah 6:5) 
My people, remember what Balak, king of Moab, planned, and what Balaam son of Beor answered him, and the journey from Shittim to Gilgal, so that you may know the righteous acts of the Lord.

(Micah 6:6) 
With what shall I come before the Lord, and bow down to God on high? Shall I come before Him with burnt offerings, with calves of a year old?

(Micah 6:7) 
Will the Lord be pleased with thousands of rams, or with ten thousand rivers of oil? Shall I give my firstborn son for my wickedness, the fruit of my body for the sin of my soul?

(Micah 6:8) 
He has shown you, O man, what is good, and what the Lord requires of you. Surely, to do justice, to love mercy, and to walk carefully with your God.

(Micah 6:9) 
The Lord's voice cries out to the city: Fear will call, and the wise will see your name. Listen, you tribes, and all who are gathered.

(Micah 6:10) 
Are there still treasures of wickedness in the house of the wicked? And a diminished measure, full of curse?

(Micah 6:11) 
Shall I justify the wicked balance, and the deceitful purse in my hand?

(Micah 6:12) 
Because the rich of the city are filled with wickedness, and its inhabitants have spoken lies, and their tongues are deceitful in their mouth.

(Micah 6:13) 
So now I have struck you, making you barren because of your sins.

(Micah 6:14) 
You will eat, but not be satisfied. Your despair will be in your midst. You will take in, but not save. And those you save, I will deliver to the sword.

(Micah 6:15) 
You will sow, but not reap. You will tread the olive, but you will not anoint yourself with oil. You will crush the grapes, but will not drink the wine.

(Micah 6:16) 
You have kept the statutes of Omri and all the works of the house of Ahab. You have walked in their ways, so that I would make you a ruin. I will make your inhabitants a hissing, and you will bear the reproach of My people.

(Micah 7:1) 
Woe is me, for I am become as a man who gathers the remnants of the harvest. There is no ripe cluster of grapes to eat, and the first fruits that I desired have passed away.

(Micah 7:2) 
The holy ones have vanished from the land, and there is no one who acts uprightly among men. They all lie in wait for the blood of their neighbors, each one hunts his brother unto death.

(Micah 7:3) 
Their hands are ready to do evil. The prince demands a bribe, and the judge is influenced by money. The great man expresses the desire of his soul, and they thus conspire together.

(Micah 7:4) 
The best of them is like a thornbush, and the most upright is like a thorny hedge. The day of their punishment is coming, the day that they have been warned about.

(Micah 7:5) 
Do not trust your neighbor, and do not rely on a friend. Be on guard against the one who lies in your bosom; keep the doors of your mouth.

(Micah 7:6) 
For the son dishonors the father, the daughter rises up against her mother, the daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law. A man’s enemies are the men of his own house.

(Micah 7:7) 
But I will look to the Lord; I will wait for God my Savior; my God will hear me.

(Micah 7:8) 
Do not rejoice over me, O my enemy, for though I have fallen, I will arise. When I sit in darkness, the Lord will be my light.

(Micah 7:9) 
I will bear the wrath of the Lord, because I have sinned against Him, until He judges my cause and executes my judgment. He will bring me out into the light; I will see His justice.

(Micah 7:10) 
Then my enemy will see, and she will be covered with shame, she who said to me, “Where is the Lord your God?” My eyes will gaze upon her; now she will be for trampling, like the mud in the streets.

(Micah 7:11) 
In the day that your walls are to be rebuilt, in that day the boundary will be extended. In that day the Assyrian will come to you, and to the fortified cities.

(Micah 7:12) 
In that day, they will come to you from Assyria, and from the fortified cities, and from the fortresses to the river, and from sea to sea, and from mountain to mountain.

(Micah 7:13) 
And the land will be desolate because of its inhabitants, as a result of their deeds.

(Micah 7:14) 
Shepherd Your people with Your staff, the flock of Your inheritance, those who dwell alone in the forest, in the midst of Carmel. Let them feed in Bashan and Gilead, as in the days of old.

(Micah 7:15) 
As in the days of your coming out of the land of Egypt, I will show them wonders.

(Micah 7:16) 
The nations will see and be ashamed of all their power; they will put their hand over their mouth, their ears will be deaf.

(Micah 7:17) 
They will lick the dust like a serpent, like the reptiles of the earth. They will come trembling out of their fortresses, and they will fear the Lord our God and be afraid.

(Micah 7:18) 
Who is a God like You, who removes iniquity and passes over the transgression of the remnant of His inheritance? He does not hold onto anger forever because He delights in mercy.

(Micah 7:19) 
He will turn again and have mercy on us. He will tread our iniquities underfoot, and will cast all our sins into the depths of the sea.

(Micah 7:20) 
You will give truth to Jacob, and mercy to Abraham, which You swore to our fathers from days of old.

(Nahum 1:1) 
A prophecy about Nineveh. The record of Nahum of Elkosh.

(Nahum 1:2) 
The Lord is a jealous and avenging God; the Lord is avenging and full of wrath. The Lord takes vengeance on His adversaries and is angry with His enemies.

(Nahum 1:3) 
The Lord is slow to anger, but great in power; He will not acquit the guilty. His way is in the tempest and the storm is under His feet.

(Nahum 1:4) 
He rebukes the sea and dries it up; He dries up all the rivers. Bashan and Carmel wither, and the bloom of Lebanon fades.

(Nahum 1:5) 
The mountains quake because of Him, and the hills melt away. The earth trembles before Him, the world and all who dwell in it.

(Nahum 1:6) 
Who can stand before His indignation? Who can endure the heat of His anger? His wrath is poured out like fire, and the rocks are shattered by Him.

(Nahum 1:7) 
The Lord is good, a refuge in the day of distress; He knows those who trust in Him.

(Nahum 1:8) 
But with an overflowing flood He will make an end of its place, and will pursue His enemies into darkness.

(Nahum 1:9) 
What do you plot against the Lord? He will make an end; He will not take vengeance twice.

(Nahum 1:10) 
For though they are like tangled thorns, though they are drunkards as they drink, they shall be consumed like dry stubble.

(Nahum 1:11) 
From you came one who devised evil against the Lord, a wicked counselor.

(Nahum 1:12) 
Thus says the Lord: “Though they are at full strength and many, they will be cut down and pass away. Though I have afflicted you, I will afflict you no more.

(Nahum 1:13) 
And now I will break his yoke from your neck, and I will burst your bonds.

(Nahum 1:14) 
The Lord has given a command concerning you: Your name shall be perpetuated no longer. From the house of your gods I will cut off the carved image and the cast image. I will make your grave, for you are worthless.

(Nahum 1:15) 
Behold, on the mountains, the feet of him who brings good tidings, who proclaims peace! Celebrate your festivals, O Judah, fulfill your vows, for never again shall the wicked pass through you; he is utterly cut off.

(Nahum 2:1) 
The army is coming! Prepare yourself. Guard your city. Strengthen your defenses.

(Nahum 2:2) 
The Lord will destroy the pride of Jacob, as He destroyed Israel. Because the destroyers will destroy them and break their branches.

(Nahum 2:3) 
The shields of their soldiers are red. Their soldiers are dressed in scarlet. The fire of destruction is ready. The chariots are like lightning!

(Nahum 2:4) 
The chariots will rush through the streets, colliding in the city squares. The appearance of the soldiers is like torches, as flashes of lightning.

(Nahum 2:5) 
The best soldiers will be called forward, but they will stumble in their haste. The city's protective wall will be prepared.

(Nahum 2:6) 
The river gates will be opened, and the palace will be captured.

(Nahum 2:7) 
The captives will be taken away, and the captive women will mourn like doves.

(Nahum 2:8) 
Nineveh is like a pool of water, but its people are fleeing. “Stop! Stop!” they cry, but no one turns back.

(Nahum 2:9) 
Take the silver! Take the gold! There is no end to the valuable treasures.

(Nahum 2:10) 
Nineveh is now wasted, plundered, and destroyed. The heart is broken, the knees are shaking, the body trembles, and the faces are blackened.

(Nahum 2:11) 
Where is the den of the lions? Where is the feeding ground for the young lions, where the lion and the lioness walked? No one will scare them now.

(Nahum 2:12) 
The lion tore apart enough for its cubs, and strangled enough for the lionesses. He filled his caves with prey and his dens with spoils.

(Nahum 2:13) 
“I am against you,” says the Lord of Hosts. “I will burn your chariots in smoke. The sword will consume your young lions. I will not let your spoils echo your boasts.”

(Nahum 2:14) 
The voices of your messengers will no longer be heard. Your city will never again be destroyed.

(Nahum 3:1) 
Woe to that bloody city! That city of constant lies and endless robbery! The pillaging will never end.

(Nahum 3:2) 
Listen to the cracking whip! Hear the noise of the wheels! See the galloping horses and the bouncing chariots,

(Nahum 3:3) 
Watch the horsemen charging, the flashing swords and the glittering spears! There are so many dead. Corpses pile up. There is no end to the dead! They stumble over the bodies.

(Nahum 3:4) 
This is because of the countless sins of the prostitute, the beautiful harlot! She seduced the nations with her prostitution and the families with her spells.

(Nahum 3:5) 
“Look,” says the Lord of Hosts, “I am against you! I will lift your skirts and expose your shame before the nations, and show the kingdoms your disgrace.

(Nahum 3:6) 
I will cast abominations upon you and disgrace you. I will make you a spectacle.

(Nahum 3:7) 
Then everyone who sees you will flee from you, saying, 'Nineveh is devastated! Who will mourn for her?' Where shall I seek someone to comfort you?

(Nahum 3:8) 
Are you better than Thebes, which was situated on the Nile, surrounded by water? Her ramparts were the sea; the water was her wall.

(Nahum 3:9) 
Ethiopia and Egypt were her strength. There was no limit to her power. Put and Libya were among her allies.

(Nahum 3:10) 
Yet she was captured and carried away. Her little children were dashed to pieces at the head of every street. They cast lots for her nobles, and all her great men were put in chains.

(Nahum 3:11) 
So you also will become drunk and hidden. You will seek refuge from the enemy.

(Nahum 3:12) 
All your fortresses are like fig trees with their first ripe figs; if they are shaken, they fall straight into the mouth of the eater.

(Nahum 3:13) 
Look, your people within you are like women. The gates of your land are wide open to your enemies; fire has consumed your bars.

(Nahum 3:14) 
Draw water for the siege. Strengthen your fortresses. Go into the mud and trample it. Repair your brick molds.

(Nahum 3:15) 
There the fire will consume you; the sword will cut you down. It will devour you like the locust. Multiply yourselves like the locust; increase like the grasshopper.

(Nahum 3:16) 
You have increased your merchants more than the stars of the sky. Like the locust, they swarm and fly away.

(Nahum 3:17) 
Your princes are like grasshoppers, your officials like swarms of locusts that settle on the walls in the cold. When the sun comes up, they fly away, and no one knows where they have gone.

(Nahum 3:18) 
Your shepherds are sleeping, O king of Assyria. Your nobles lie in the dust; your people are scattered on the mountains, and there is no one to gather them.

(Nahum 3:19) 
There is no healing for your wound. Your injury is severe. All who hear the news of you clap their hands over you, for who has not felt your endless cruelty?

(Habakkuk 1:1) 
This is the burden of prophecy that Habakkuk saw.

(Habakkuk 1:2) 
How much longer, Lord, will I cry out to you, and will you not hear? How much longer will I complain of violence to you, and will you not save?

(Habakkuk 1:3) 
Why do you show me wickedness and toil, that I may see injustice and the destruction of those who do wrong to me? Because of this, judgment will come, and strife will come upon all.

(Habakkuk 1:4) 
Because of this, the law is weakened, and the judgment never succeeds: because the wicked are stronger than the righteous. Therefore, perverse judgment comes forth.

(Habakkuk 1:5) 
Look among the nations and see, and be astonished, and be astounded: because you will do a work in your days that you will not believe when it is told.

(Habakkuk 1:6) 
Because behold, I will raise up the Chaldeans, a bitter and swift nation that marches across the breadth of the earth to take possession of dwelling places that are not their own.

(Habakkuk 1:7) 
They are terrifying and fearsome; their judgment and their power will come forth from themselves.

(Habakkuk 1:8) 
Their horses are swifter than leopards, and they are more fierce than wolves at evening; their horsemen are proud.

(Habakkuk 1:9) 
They will all come to plunder; their faces will be as a burning wind, and they will gather captives like sand.

(Habakkuk 1:10) 
They themselves will mock kings, and they will scoff at princes; they will laugh at every fortress and they will build a ramp to capture it.

(Habakkuk 1:11) 
Then his spirit will change, and he will pass through; and he will consider this power to be his own wickedness.

(Habakkuk 1:12) 
Are you not from the beginning, Lord my God, my Holy One? We will not die. Lord, you have appointed him for judgment, and you have set him as a rebuke.

(Habakkuk 1:13) 
You whose eyes are pure and cannot look upon evil, who cannot look upon wickedness, why do you look on those who act unjustly, and are silent when the wicked devour one more just than themselves?

(Habakkuk 1:14) 
You make humans like the fish of the sea, and like the creeping things that have no ruler.

(Habakkuk 1:15) 
He takes them all up with a hook and drags them into his net and gathers them into his dragnet; over this, he rejoices and exults.

(Habakkuk 1:16) 
For this reason, he will sacrifice to his net, and he will offer sacrifices to his dragnet: because for this reason, his portion is fattened, and his food is rich.

(Habakkuk 1:17) 
Therefore, will he empty his sword, and will he not have mercy on the nations?

(Habakkuk 2:1) 
I will stand guard over my watch. I will go on. I will stand on my watchtower to see what He might say to me in response to my prayers.

(Habakkuk 2:2) 
The Lord will answer me. He will say, “Write down the vision. Make it clear on tablets, so that everyone who reads it can run with it.”

(Habakkuk 2:3) 
For the vision is not of immediate fulfillment. It looks ahead to the end, and it will not lie. If it seems to tarry, wait for it. It will surely come; it will not delay.

(Habakkuk 2:4) 
Behold, the arrogant one is not upright within himself. But the just man will live by his faith.

(Habakkuk 2:5) 
Truly, because of wine, the proud man is arrogant and restless; he does not remain at peace. His soul is as vast as Sheol, like death, and he gathers all nations to himself, like death.

(Habakkuk 2:6) 
Will not all of these take up a parable against him? Will they not utter a riddle concerning him and say, “Woe to him who amasses what is not his own! How long will he keep gathering debts against himself?”

(Habakkuk 2:7) 
Will they not suddenly arise who will bite you, those who will agitate you so fiercely? And you will become their plunder.

(Habakkuk 2:8) 
Because you have plundered many nations, the remnant of the peoples will plunder you for the blood of man and the iniquity of the land, of the city, and of all who live in it.

(Habakkuk 2:9) 
Woe to him who gathers evil gain for his house, setting his nest on high to be delivered from the reach of evil!

(Habakkuk 2:10) 
You have devised shame for your house by cutting off many peoples, and you have sinned against your own soul.

(Habakkuk 2:11) 
For the stone will cry out from the wall, and the beam from the woodwork will answer.

(Habakkuk 2:12) 
Woe to him who builds a city with blood, and prepares a town with iniquity!

(Habakkuk 2:13) 
Is this not from the Lord of hosts? The peoples labor only for fire, and the nations weary themselves only for nothing.

(Habakkuk 2:14) 
For the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the Lord, as the waters cover the sea.

(Habakkuk 2:15) 
Woe to him who gives drink to his neighbor, pouring out his venom to make him drunk, so that he may look on his nakedness!

(Habakkuk 2:16) 
You will be filled with disgrace instead of glory. Drink yourself and be uncircumcised! The cup in the Lord’s right hand will come around to you, and utter shame will come upon your glory.

(Habakkuk 2:17) 
For the violence done to Lebanon will overwhelm you, and the destruction of the beasts will terrify you because of the blood of man and the iniquity of the land, of the city, and of all who live in it.

(Habakkuk 2:18) 
Of what use is an idol, since its maker has crafted it? It is an image, a teacher of lies! For the maker trusts in his own work, though he has produced mute idols.

(Habakkuk 2:19) 
Woe to him who says to wood, “Awake!” and to a mute stone, “Arise!” Can it teach? Behold, it is covered with gold and silver, and there is no breath at all in it.

(Habakkuk 2:20) 
But the Lord is in His holy temple; let all the earth keep silence before Him.

(Habakkuk 3:1) 
This is the prayer of the prophet Habakkuk, who had difficulty understanding God.

(Habakkuk 3:2) 
Lord, I heard Your fame, and I was afraid.

(Habakkuk 3:3) 
I considered Your works, and I was filled with awe.

(Habakkuk 3:4) 
Lord, revive Your work as the years pass.

(Habakkuk 3:5) 
As the years pass, make Your power known.

(Habakkuk 3:6) 
Even when my soul is troubled, remember Your mercy.

(Habakkuk 3:7) 
God will come from the south, and the Holy One from Mount Pharan.

(Habakkuk 3:8) 
His glory covered the skies, and the earth is filled with praise of Him.

(Habakkuk 3:9) 
His splendor will be like light: He has all power in His hands.

(Habakkuk 3:10) 
In Him is all strength hidden.

(Habakkuk 3:11) 
Before Him will go pestilence, and the devil will walk before His feet.

(Habakkuk 3:12) 
He stood, and measured the land.

(Habakkuk 3:13) 
He looked, and the nations were terrified.

(Habakkuk 3:14) 
The ancient mountains were crushed, the hills of the world were bowed down, from His eternal paths.

(Habakkuk 3:15) 
Because of iniquity, I saw the tents of Ethiopia; the coverings of the land of Midian were troubled.

(Habakkuk 3:16) 
Were You angry with the rivers, Lord?

(Habakkuk 3:17) 
Was Your fury against the sea?

(Habakkuk 3:18) 
You rode on Your horses, and Your chariots brought salvation.

(Habakkuk 3:19) 
You roused Your bow, and prepared it for battle.

(Habakkuk 3:20) 
You spoke oaths to the tribes.

(Habakkuk 3:21) 
You divided the rivers of the land.

(Habakkuk 3:22) 
The mountains saw You, and were in pain: the torrents of waters passed by.

(Habakkuk 3:23) 
The deep gave forth a sound; the depths sent out their voice.

(Habakkuk 3:24) 
He lifted up His hands to the heights.

(Habakkuk 3:25) 
The sun and moon stood still in their dwelling, at the light of Your arrows they shall go, in the splendor of Your flashing spear.

(Habakkuk 3:26) 
In anger, You trampled the earth; in fury, You destroyed the nations.

(Habakkuk 3:27) 
You went out to save Your people, to save Your people with Your anointed ones.

(Habakkuk 3:28) 
You struck the head from the house of the wicked; You laid bare the foundation even to the neck.

(Habakkuk 3:29) 
You cursed their scepters, the heads of their warriors.

(Habakkuk 3:30) 
You invaded the sea with Your horses, in the tumult of many waters.

(Habakkuk 3:31) 
I heard, and my belly was troubled.

(Habakkuk 3:32) 
At the voice of my lips, trembling entered into my bones, and I trembled.

(Habakkuk 3:33) 
I waited for the day of tribulation, that I may ascend to the people who are girded for battle.

(Habakkuk 3:34) 
For the fig tree will not blossom, and there will be no fruit on the vines.

(Habakkuk 3:35) 
The labor of the olive trees will be in vain, and the vineyards will not give fruit.

(Habakkuk 3:36) 
All the food in the field will fail, and there will be no cattle in the stalls.

(Habakkuk 3:37) 
Yet I will rejoice in the Lord, and I will be joyful in God, my Savior.

(Habakkuk 3:38) 
The Lord God is my strength, and He will make my feet like those of the hinds.

(Habakkuk 3:39) 
He will bring me to the heights, where I can sing a song of victory.

(Zephaniah 1:1) 
The Word of the Lord, which was delivered to Zephaniah, son of Cushi, son of Gedaliah, son of Amariah, son of Hezekiah, in the days of Josiah, son of Amon, king of Judah:

(Zephaniah 1:2) 
The Lord says, “I will completely sweep away the land.”

(Zephaniah 1:3) 
“I will take away men and the animals; I will take away the birds of the sky, and the fish of the sea. And the wicked will collapse along with their sins. I will destroy all mankind from the face of the land,” says the Lord.

(Zephaniah 1:4) 
“I will stretch out my hand against Judah and against all those who live in Jerusalem. I will destroy from this place the remnants of Baal, and the names of the false priests, along with the true priests.

(Zephaniah 1:5) 
“Also, I will destroy those who worship the armies of the sky on the rooftops, and who worship, and swear by the Lord, and swear by Milcom.

(Zephaniah 1:6) 
“I will also destroy those who have turned away from the Lord, those who have not sought after the Lord, nor inquired after Him.”

(Zephaniah 1:7) 
Be silent before the face of the Lord God, because the day of the Lord is near; for the Lord has prepared his sacrifice, he has sanctified those whom he has called.

(Zephaniah 1:8) 
“And on the day of the Lord’s sacrifice, I will visit the princes and the sons of the king, and all those who are clothed in foreign garments.

(Zephaniah 1:9) 
“On that day I will visit everyone who leaps over the threshold, who fills the house with violence and deceit.

(Zephaniah 1:10) 
“On that day,” says the Lord, “there will be a cry of wailing from the Fish Gate, and a lamentation from the second quarter, and a great destruction from the hills.

(Zephaniah 1:11) 
Wail, you inhabitants of the Mortar, because all the people of Canaan have become silent; all those who were merchants have been destroyed.

(Zephaniah 1:12) 
“At that time I will thoroughly search Jerusalem with lamps, and I will visit the men of renown who say in their hearts, ‘The Lord does not act for good, nor does he act for evil.’

(Zephaniah 1:13) 
“And their wealth will be for plunder, and their houses for desolation; they will build houses, but not inhabit them, and they will plant vineyards, but not drink their wine.”

(Zephaniah 1:14) 
The great day of the Lord is near; it is near, and hastens quickly; the voice of the day of the Lord is bitter; there the strong man will cry out.

(Zephaniah 1:15) 
That day is a day of wrath, a day of trouble and distress, a day of calamity and misery, a day of darkness and gloom, a day of clouds and thick darkness,

(Zephaniah 1:16) 
a day of the trumpet and the battle cry against the fortified cities and against the high corners.

(Zephaniah 1:17) 
“I will bring distress upon men, and they will walk like the blind, because they have sinned against the Lord; and their blood will be poured out like dust, and their bodies like dung.

(Zephaniah 1:18) 
“Neither their silver nor their gold will be able to save them on the day of the Lord's wrath; but the whole land will be consumed in the fire of his jealousy, for he will make a speedy end of all the inhabitants of the land.”

(Zephaniah 2:1) 
Gather yourselves together, you nations that don't care about God,

(Zephaniah 2:2) 
Before the time to act comes like the wind blows the dust away, before the anger of the Lord's fury comes on you, before the Lord's day of wrath descends on you.

(Zephaniah 2:3) 
Seek the Lord, all you humble ones of the earth, you who work to do His will. Seek righteousness, seek meekness, so that perhaps you may be protected on the day of the Lord's fury.

(Zephaniah 2:4) 
For Gaza will be forsaken, and Ascalon will become a wasteland. They will cast out the people of Ashdod at noon, and Ekron will be uprooted.

(Zephaniah 2:5) 
Woe to you who live on the coast, you nation of the lost! The Lord's word is against you, Canaan, land of the Philistines. I will destroy you so that no one will live there.

(Zephaniah 2:6) 
The coast will become pastures and folds for flocks, for those who rest in the middle of their herds.

(Zephaniah 2:7) 
And those who remain of the house of Judah will be saved, and they will graze in the houses of Ascalon, when they sit at evening.

(Zephaniah 2:8) 
I have heard the taunts of Moab and the insults of the children of Ammon, who have reproached My people and have magnified themselves against their borders.

(Zephaniah 2:9) 
Therefore, as I live, says the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, surely Moab will be like Sodom, and the children of Ammon like Gomorrah: a possession of thorns, and salt pits, and a desolation forever: the remnants of My people will plunder them, and the remnants of My nation will possess them.

(Zephaniah 2:10) 
This will happen to them for their pride, because they have reproached and have magnified themselves against the people of the Lord of hosts.

(Zephaniah 2:11) 
The Lord will be terrible against them: He will destroy all the gods of the earth; and all the islands of the nations, each in its own place, will worship Him.

(Zephaniah 2:12) 
You Ethiopians, you also will be slain by My sword.

(Zephaniah 2:13) 
And He will stretch out His hand against the north and destroy Assyria; He will make Nineveh a desolation, as dry as the desert.

(Zephaniah 2:14) 
Herds will lie down in its midst, all the beasts of the nations; both the pelican and the hedgehog will lodge in its thresholds; the owl will hoot in the windows; the raven will be in the roof beams; for their strength has been crushed.

(Zephaniah 2:15) 
This is the joyful city that dwelt securely, that said in her heart: 'I am, and there is no more.' How has she become a desolation, a den for beasts! Everyone who passes by her will hiss and shake their hand.

(Zephaniah 3:1) 
What misery awaits the rebellious, polluted, oppressing city!

(Zephaniah 3:2) 
It has not obeyed God. It has rejected all guidance. It did not trust in the Lord. It would not approach its God.

(Zephaniah 3:3) 
Its leaders are roaring lions in the city. Its judges are wolves at dusk, devouring until dawn.

(Zephaniah 3:4) 
Its prophets are brash and untrustworthy men. Its priests defile holy things, and they disrespect the law.

(Zephaniah 3:5) 
The Lord, who is just, is within it. He will do no injustice. Every morning, He brings His judgment to light, and it never fails.

(Zephaniah 3:6) 
He has destroyed nations. Their towers are desolate. He has made their roads deserted so no one can pass. Their cities are desolate, without inhabitants.

(Zephaniah 3:7) 
I said: Surely you will fear Me and accept guidance. You will not be destroyed before My eyes, nor lose all of My decrees. But instead, rising up every morning, they corrupt all their thoughts.

(Zephaniah 3:8) 
Therefore, be patient and wait for Me, says the Lord, until the day I arise to judge. Because My judgment will come upon the nations so I can gather kings and gather kingdoms, pouring out upon them all My indignation, all the heat of My anger. For in the fire of My zeal, all the earth will be consumed.

(Zephaniah 3:9) 
Then I will give to the peoples a pure tongue so that all will call on the name of the Lord, and they will serve Him with one accord.

(Zephaniah 3:10) 
From beyond the rivers of Ethiopia, My supplicants, the remnant of My scattered, will bring offerings to Me.

(Zephaniah 3:11) 
In that day, you will not be ashamed because of all your deeds, by which you have transgressed against Me. Then I will remove from your midst those who boast of their pride. You will never again be exalted on My holy mountain.

(Zephaniah 3:12) 
I will leave within you a poor and humble people, and they will trust in the name of the Lord.

(Zephaniah 3:13) 
The remnant of Israel will do no wrong, nor will they speak lies, nor will a deceitful tongue be found in their mouth. For they will feed and rest, and no one will frighten them.

(Zephaniah 3:14) 
Sing, daughter of Zion; shout with joy, Israel; rejoice and exult, daughter of Jerusalem, with all your heart.

(Zephaniah 3:15) 
The Lord has removed your judgment; He has turned away your enemies. The Lord, the King of Israel, is in your midst; you shall no longer fear evil.

(Zephaniah 3:16) 
In that day, it will be said to Jerusalem: “Do not be afraid, Zion; let not your hands be slack.”

(Zephaniah 3:17) 
The Lord your God is in your midst, a warrior, He will save. He will rejoice over you with gladness; He will be silent in His love for you; He will rejoice over you with singing.

(Zephaniah 3:18) 
I will gather those who mourn for the feasts, who are of you, and I will take away your disgrace.

(Zephaniah 3:19) 
Behold, I will deal with all those who afflict you at that time; and I will save the lame and gather the outcast; and I will make them a praise and a name in all the earth.

(Zephaniah 3:20) 
At that time, I will bring you in, and at the time I gather you together; for I will give you renown and praise among all the peoples of the earth, when I restore your fortunes before your eyes, says the Lord.

(Haggai 1:1) 
In the second year that Darius was king, in the sixth month, on the first day of the month, the Lord spoke to Haggai the prophet, to Zorobabel son of Shealtiel, the governor of Judah, and to Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest, saying:

(Haggai 1:2) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘This people says: ‘The time to build the Lord’s house has not yet come.’”

(Haggai 1:3) 
Then the Lord spoke through Haggai the prophet, saying:

(Haggai 1:4) 
“Is it right for you to be living in your paneled homes while this house remains in ruins?”

(Haggai 1:5) 
“Now, this is what the Lord of Hosts says: ‘Consider your ways!’

(Haggai 1:6) 
“You have planted much, but harvested little. You eat, but you are not satisfied. You drink, but you are not drunk. You put on clothes, but you are not warm. The one who earns wages puts them in a bag full of holes.’”

(Haggai 1:7) 
“This is what the Lord of Hosts says: ‘Consider your ways!’

(Haggai 1:8) 
“Go up into the hills, bring timber, and build the house. I will take pleasure in it, and I will be glorified,’ says the Lord.”

(Haggai 1:9) 
“You expected much, but it came to little. When you brought it home, I blew it away. Why?” says the Lord of Hosts. “Because my house is ruined, while each of you is busy with your own home.”

(Haggai 1:10) 
“Therefore, the sky has withheld the dew over you, and the earth has withheld its produce.

(Haggai 1:11) 
“I have called for a drought on the land, on the mountains, on the grain, on the wine, on the oil, on everything that the ground produces, and on men, on animals, and on all the work of your hands.”

(Haggai 1:12) 
Then Zorobabel son of Shealtiel, Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest, and all the rest of the people listened to the voice of the Lord their God, and the words of Haggai the prophet because the Lord their God had sent him. And the people feared the Lord.

(Haggai 1:13) 
Then Haggai, the Lord’s messenger, gave the Lord’s message to the people, saying: “I am with you, says the Lord.”

(Haggai 1:14) 
So the Lord stirred up the spirit of Zorobabel son of Shealtiel, governor of Judah, and the spirit of Joshua son of Jehozadak, the high priest, and the spirit of the rest of the people. They came and began to work on the house of the Lord of Hosts on the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month, in the second year of Darius the king.

(Haggai 2:1) 
In the second year of King Darius, in the sixth month, on the first day of the month, the Son revealed himself to the prophet Haggai, and through Haggai spoke the Lord to Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, who was the governor of Judah, and to Joshua, the son of Jehozadak, the high priest, saying:

(Haggai 2:2) 
The Lord of Hosts says this: “This people says that the time has not yet come to rebuild the Lord’s house. But now is the time—the house of the Lord must be rebuilt.”

(Haggai 2:3) 
Then the Son spoke through the prophet Haggai, saying:

(Haggai 2:4) 
“Who among you is left who saw this house in its former glory? And how do you see it now? Isn’t it as nothing in your eyes?

(Haggai 2:5) 
“But now, be strong, Zerubbabel,” says the Lord. “And be strong, Joshua, son of Jehozadak, the high priest. Be strong, all you people of the land,” says the Lord, “and work, because I am with you,” says the Lord of Hosts.

(Haggai 2:6) 
“This is what I promised when you came out of Egypt: My Spirit shall remain among you. Fear not.”

(Haggai 2:7) 
“For the Lord of Hosts says this: 'Once more, I will shake the universe and the earth, the sea and the dry land.'

(Haggai 2:8) 
“'I will shake all the nations, and the desired one of all nations will come, and I will fill this house with glory,’ says the Lord of Hosts.

(Haggai 2:9) 
“'The silver is mine, and the gold is mine,’ says the Lord of Hosts.

(Haggai 2:10) 
“The glory of this new house will be greater than the glory of the former house,” says the Lord of Hosts, “and in this place, I will give peace,” says the Lord of Hosts.

(Haggai 2:11) 
On the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month, in the second year of Darius, the Son spoke through Haggai the prophet, saying:

(Haggai 2:12) 
The Lord of Hosts says this: “Ask the priests about the law, saying:

(Haggai 2:13) 
“‘If a man carries consecrated meat in his garment, and the edge of his garment touches bread, or cooked food, or wine, or oil, or any other food, will it be consecrated?’”

(Haggai 2:14) 
The priests answered, “No.”

(Haggai 2:15) 
Then Haggai said, “If someone unclean by contact with a dead body touches any of these things, will they be defiled?” The priests answered, “They will be defiled.”

(Haggai 2:16) 
Then Haggai said, “Such is this people, and such is this nation before Me,” says the Lord, “and such is every work of their hands, and everything they offer there is defiled.”

(Haggai 2:17) 
“But now, consider this from this day forward, before the stones were laid in the temple of the Lord.

(Haggai 2:18) 
“When you went to the winepress to get twenty measures, there were only ten. And when you went to the pool to draw water, you could not, because I had brought a curse on all the works of your hands.”

(Haggai 2:19) 
“I struck you with blight and mildew in all the work of your hands; yet you did not turn to Me,” says the Lord.

(Haggai 2:20) 
“Consider this, from this day forward, from the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month, from the day the Lord’s temple was founded; consider this:

(Haggai 2:21) 
“Is any seed still in the barn? From this day on, I will bless you.”

(Haggai 2:22) 
The Son spoke to Haggai the second time on the twenty-fourth day of the month, saying:

(Haggai 2:23) 
“Speak to Zerubbabel, the governor of Judah, saying: ‘I will shake the universe and the earth.

(Haggai 2:24) 
“‘I will overthrow the thrones of kingdoms and destroy the strength of the kingdoms of the nations. I will overthrow the chariots and their riders; the horses and their riders will fall, each by the sword of his brother.

(Haggai 2:25) 
“‘On that day,’ says the Lord of Hosts, ‘I will take you, Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel, my servant,’ says the Lord, ‘and I will make you like a signet ring, for I have chosen you,’ says the Lord of Hosts.”

(Zechariah 1:1) 
In the second year of the reign of Darius, in the eighth month, the word of the Lord came to Zechariah, the son of Berechiah, the son of Iddo, the prophet, saying:

(Zechariah 1:2) 
The Lord was angry with your fathers.

(Zechariah 1:3) 
And you shall say to them, ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts: “Return to me,” says the Lord of hosts, “and I will return to you,” says the Lord of hosts.’

(Zechariah 1:4) 
Do not be like your fathers, to whom the former prophets cried out, saying, ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts: “Turn now from your evil ways and from your evil deeds.”’ But they did not listen, nor did they pay attention to me, says the Lord.

(Zechariah 1:5) 
Your fathers, where are they? And the prophets, do they live forever?

(Zechariah 1:6) 
But my words and my decrees, which I commanded my servants the prophets, did they not reach your fathers? So they turned and said, ‘As the Lord of hosts purposed to do to us according to our ways and according to our deeds, so he has done to us.’

(Zechariah 1:7) 
On the twenty-fourth day of the eleventh month, which is the month of Shebat, the word of the Lord came to Zechariah, the son of Berechiah, the son of Iddo, the prophet, saying:

(Zechariah 1:8) 
I saw by night, and behold, a man riding on a red horse, and he was standing among the myrtle trees, which were in the deep; and behind him were red, dappled, and white horses.

(Zechariah 1:9) 
And I said, “What are these, my lord?”

(Zechariah 1:10) 
And the angel who spoke with me said to me, “I will show you what these are.”

(Zechariah 1:11) 
And the man who was standing among the myrtle trees replied, “These are they whom the Lord has sent to patrol the earth.”

(Zechariah 1:12) 
And they answered the angel of the Lord who spoke to them, “We have patrolled the earth, and behold, all the earth is inhabited and at rest.”

(Zechariah 1:13) 
Then the angel of the Lord answered and said, “O Lord of hosts, how long will you not have compassion on Jerusalem and on the cities of Judah, against which you have been angry these seventy years?”

(Zechariah 1:14) 
And the Lord answered the angel who spoke with me, good words, words of consolation.

(Zechariah 1:15) 
And the angel who spoke with me said to me, “Cry out, saying, ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts: “I am jealous for Jerusalem and for Zion with a great jealousy.”’

(Zechariah 1:16) 
And I am exceedingly angry with the nations that are at ease; for I was only a little angry, and they have helped to bring about the evil.”

(Zechariah 1:17) 
Therefore, thus says the Lord: “I have returned to Jerusalem with compassion. My house shall be built in it,” says the Lord of hosts, “and the measuring line shall be stretched out over Jerusalem.”

(Zechariah 1:18) 
Cry out again, saying, ‘Thus says the Lord of hosts: “My cities shall yet again abound with prosperity, and the Lord will again comfort Zion and again choose Jerusalem.”’

(Zechariah 1:19) 
And I lifted up my eyes and saw, and behold, four horns.

(Zechariah 1:20) 
And I said to the angel who spoke with me, “What are these?”

(Zechariah 1:21) 
And he answered me, “These are the horns which have scattered Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem.”

(Zechariah 1:22) 
Then the Lord showed me four smiths.

(Zechariah 1:23) 
And I said, “What are these coming to do?” And he said, “These are the horns that scattered Judah, so that no one could lift up his head; and these have come to terrify them, to cast down the horns of the nations, which lifted up their horn against the land of Judah to scatter it.”

(Zechariah 2:1) 
And I lifted up my eyes and looked, and behold, a man holding a measuring line in his hand.

(Zechariah 2:2) 
So I asked him, “Where are you going?” And he said to me, “To measure Jerusalem, to see how wide it is and how long it is.”

(Zechariah 2:3) 
Then the angel who was speaking to me went out, and another angel went out to meet him.

(Zechariah 2:4) 
He said to him, “Run, speak to that young man, saying: ‘Jerusalem will be inhabited without walls, because of the multitude of men and animals in it.’

(Zechariah 2:5) 
And I, says the Lord, will be a wall of fire all around her, and I will be glory in the midst of her.”

(Zechariah 2:6) 
O, oh, flee from the land of the north, says the Lord: “For I have scattered you to the four winds, says the Lord.”

(Zechariah 2:7) 
Arise, Zion, you who live with the daughter of Babylon.

(Zechariah 2:8) 
For thus says the Lord of hosts: “After glory He sent me to the nations who plundered you: for he who touches you touches the pupil of My eye.”

(Zechariah 2:9) 
For behold, I will raise My hand against them, and they will be plunder for those who served them: and you will know that the Lord of hosts has sent me.”

(Zechariah 2:10) 
Sing and rejoice, daughter of Zion, for behold, I come, and I will dwell in your midst, says the Lord.

(Zechariah 2:11) 
And many nations will be joined to the Lord in that day, and they will be My people: and I will dwell in your midst. And you will know that the Lord of hosts has sent me to you.

(Zechariah 2:12) 
And the Lord will take possession of Judah, His portion, in the holy land: and He will yet choose Jerusalem.

(Zechariah 2:13) 
Let all flesh be silent before the Lord: for He is roused from His holy dwelling.”

(Zechariah 3:1) 
The Lord showed me Joshua, the High Priest, standing before the angel of the Lord; and Satan stood at his right hand to accuse him.

(Zechariah 3:2) 
And the Lord said to Satan: "May the Lord rebuke you, Satan! May the Lord rebuke you, Satan, who has chosen Jerusalem. Isn't this man like a brand pulled from the fire?"

(Zechariah 3:3) 
Now, Joshua was dressed in filthy garments. He stood before the angel.

(Zechariah 3:4) 
The angel spoke to those standing before him, saying: "Take off his filthy garments." And he said to Joshua, "Behold, I have removed your iniquity, and I will clothe you in clean garments."

(Zechariah 3:5) 
Then I said, "Let them put a clean turban on his head." So they put a clean turban on his head, and they clothed him with garments. And the angel of the Lord stood by.

(Zechariah 3:6) 
And the angel of the Lord testified to Joshua, saying:

(Zechariah 3:7) 
"Thus says the Lord of hosts: 'If you walk in my ways, and keep my commandments, you shall judge my house, and you shall also walk in my courts. And I will give you access among those who are standing here.'

(Zechariah 3:8) 
“Hear, Joshua the High Priest, you and your friends who sit before you, for these men are a sign. Behold, I am bringing my servant, the Branch.

(Zechariah 3:9) 
For behold, the stone that I have laid before Joshua, upon one stone are seven eyes. Behold, I will engrave its inscription," says the Lord of hosts, "and I will remove the iniquity of the land in one day.

(Zechariah 3:10) 
“In that day,” says the Lord of hosts, “every one will invite his neighbor to come under his vine and under his fig tree.”

(Zechariah 4:1) 
And the angel who was speaking with me came back and roused me, as if he were waking a man from sleep.

(Zechariah 4:2) 
He asked me, “What do you see?” I said, “I see a solid gold lampstand, with a bowl at the top. There are seven lamps on the lampstand, each with its own little tube.

(Zechariah 4:3) 
And on each side of the lampstand stand two olive trees, one on the right side of the bowl and one on the left.

(Zechariah 4:4) 
I answered, speaking to the angel who was talking with me, and I said, “What are these, my lord?”

(Zechariah 4:5) 
The angel who was talking with me answered and said to me, “Don’t you know what these are?” I said, “No, my lord.”

(Zechariah 4:6) 
He answered and spoke to me, saying: “This is the Lord's message to Zerubbabel: ‘It is not by army or by strength, but by My Spirit,’ says the Lord of hosts.

(Zechariah 4:7) 
Who are you, great mountain, before Zerubbabel? It will be made level ground; and he will bring forth the cornerstone with shouts of “Grace, grace to it!”

(Zechariah 4:8) 
Then the Lord's word came to me, saying:

(Zechariah 4:9) 
“The hands of Zerubbabel have laid the foundation of this temple; his hands will also complete it.’ Then you will know that the Lord of hosts has sent me to you.

(Zechariah 4:10) 
For whoever has despised the day of small things will rejoice and see the plumb line in the hand of Zerubbabel. These seven are the eyes of the Lord that range throughout the earth.

(Zechariah 4:11) 
Then I said, “What are these two olive trees on the right and the left of the lampstand?”

(Zechariah 4:12) 
And for the second time I said, “What are these two olive branches beside the two golden spouts that are pouring out golden oil?”

(Zechariah 4:13) 
He asked me, “Don’t you know what these are?” I said, “No, my lord.”

(Zechariah 4:14) 
Then he said, “These are the two anointed ones who stand before the Lord of all the earth.”

(Zechariah 5:1) 
I turned, and looked up, and saw: and behold a flying scroll.

(Zechariah 5:2) 
He said to me: “What do you see?” And I said: “I see a flying scroll; its length is twenty cubits, and its width ten cubits.”

(Zechariah 5:3) 
Then he said to me: “This is the curse that goes out over the face of the whole earth; because every thief, as it is written, is judged, and everyone who swears falsely, as it is written, will be held as innocent.”

(Zechariah 5:4) 
“I will send it out,” says the Lord of hosts, “and it will enter the house of the thief, and the house of those who swear falsely in my name; and it will stay inside of that house, and consume it, with its timbers and its stones.”

(Zechariah 5:5) 
Then the angel who was speaking with me came forward, and said to me: “Raise your eyes and see what this is going out.”

(Zechariah 5:6) 
I said: “What is it?” And he said: “It is an ephah measure going out.” And he said: “This is their iniquity throughout the whole earth.”

(Zechariah 5:7) 
And behold, a talent of lead was being carried, and behold, a woman was sitting inside of the ephah.

(Zechariah 5:8) 
And he said: “This is wickedness.” And he cast her into the middle of the ephah, and cast the lead weight over its mouth.

(Zechariah 5:9) 
Then I raised my eyes, and saw: and behold, two women were going out, and the wind was in their wings; and they had wings like the wings of a stork: and they carried the ephah between the land and the sky.

(Zechariah 5:10) 
Then I said to the angel who was speaking with me: “Where are these taking the ephah?”

(Zechariah 5:11) 
And he said to me: “So that a house may be built for it in the land of Shinar, and it may be established, and put there upon its base.”

(Zechariah 6:1) 
Then I turned and looked up, and saw four cosmic powers, rising from between two mountains. These mountains were made of bronze.

(Zechariah 6:2) 
The first chariot had red horses, and the second chariot had black horses,

(Zechariah 6:3) 
the third chariot had white horses, and the fourth chariot had dappled, strong horses.

(Zechariah 6:4) 
Then I answered, and said to the angel who was speaking with me: “What are these, my Lord?”

(Zechariah 6:5) 
The angel answered, and said to me: “These are the four cosmic powers sent from the heavens. They serve the Lord of all Creation.”

(Zechariah 6:6) 
The black horses went towards the southern land, and the white horses followed them. The dappled horses went towards the sunrise.

(Zechariah 6:7) 
Then they went out, and sought to travel through the land. The angel said: “Go and travel the Earth,” and they went around the earth.

(Zechariah 6:8) 
Then he called to me, and spoke to me, saying: “See those who are going to the northern land? They have calmed my spirit in the north.”

(Zechariah 6:9) 
Then the word of the Lord came to me, saying:

(Zechariah 6:10) 
“Receive gifts from those who were in captivity from Heldai, and from Tobias, and from Jedaiah, who came from Babylon. You will come on that day, and enter the house of Josiah, son of Zephaniah.

(Zechariah 6:11) 
Take gold and silver, and make crowns, and place them on the head of Joshua, son of Jehozadak, the high priest.

(Zechariah 6:12) 
Say to him: ‘Thus says the Lord of Hosts: “Behold, the man whose name is the Rising Sun. He will arise where he is, and He will rebuild the Temple of the Lord.

(Zechariah 6:13) 
He will rebuild the Temple of the Lord; He will take glory and sit and rule on His throne, and He will be a priest on His throne, and there will be peace between the two of them.”

(Zechariah 6:14) 
The crowns will be for Heldai, and Tobias, and Jedaiah, and for the son of Zephaniah, as a memorial in the Temple of the Lord.

(Zechariah 6:15) 
Then those who are far away will come and rebuild in the Temple of the Lord; and you will know that the Lord of Hosts has sent me to you. This will happen if you listen to the voice of the Lord your God.”

(Zechariah 7:1) 
In the fourth year of King Darius's reign, the Word of the Lord came to Zechariah, on the fourth day of the ninth month, the month of Casleu.

(Zechariah 7:2) 
And the people of Bethel sent Sarasar and Regemmelech, and the men who were with them, to pray to the Lord.

(Zechariah 7:3) 
They asked the priests who were in the house of the Lord of hosts, and the prophets, saying: “Should I continue to mourn in the fifth month, as I have done for so many years?”

(Zechariah 7:4) 
Then the Word of the Lord came to me, saying:

(Zechariah 7:5) 
“Speak to all the people of the land, and to the priests, saying: ‘When you fasted and wept in the fifth and seventh months for these seventy years, was it really for Me that you were fasting?’

(Zechariah 7:6) 
And when you ate, and when you drank, weren’t you eating and drinking for your own sakes?

(Zechariah 7:7) 
Did the Lord not give you the same message that He delivered through the prophets who came before, when Jerusalem was inhabited, and prosperous, and when its cities were spread out all around, and the south and the plain were inhabited?”

(Zechariah 7:8) 
And the Word of the Lord came to Zechariah, saying:

(Zechariah 7:9) 
“The Lord of hosts has spoken, saying: ‘Administer true justice, and show mercy and compassion, each one to his brother.’”

(Zechariah 7:10) 
“Do not oppress the widow, nor the orphan, nor the stranger, nor the poor; and let no man devise evil in his heart against his brother.”

(Zechariah 7:11) 
But they refused to listen, and they turned a stubborn shoulder, and their ears were stopped so they would not hear.

(Zechariah 7:12) 
They made their hearts as hard as a diamond, so that they would not listen to the Law, and the words that the Lord sent by the hand of the former prophets. Therefore, there came great wrath from the Lord of hosts.

(Zechariah 7:13) 
And it came to pass that just as He called out, and they would not listen, so they will cry out, and I will not listen, says the Lord of hosts.

(Zechariah 7:14) 
And I scattered them among all the nations which they did not know, and the land behind them was desolate as they passed through, and there was no return, and they made the desirable land a desolation.”

(Zechariah 8:1) 
The Word of the Lord came to Zachariah, saying:

(Zechariah 8:2) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘I am passionately concerned for Zion, and I love her very much.’”

(Zechariah 8:3) 
“The Lord says this: ‘I will return to Zion. I will live in the middle of Jerusalem. Jerusalem will be called “the city of truth,” and the mountain of the Lord of Hosts will be called “the holy mountain.”’

(Zechariah 8:4) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘Old men and old women will sit in the streets of Jerusalem, each with a staff in their hand because of old age.’

(Zechariah 8:5) 
‘And the streets of the city will be full of boys and girls playing in its streets.’

(Zechariah 8:6) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘It may seem difficult to the remnant of this people at that time, but do you think it will be difficult for me too?’ says the Lord of Hosts?

(Zechariah 8:7) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘I will save my people from the east and the west.’

(Zechariah 8:8) 
‘I will bring them back. They will live in Jerusalem. They will be my people, and I will be their God, with truth and justice.’

(Zechariah 8:9) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘Be strong, all of you who hear these words in these days, the days when the foundation of the Lord’s house was laid so that the temple might be built.’

(Zechariah 8:10) 
‘Before those days, there was no pay for people or animals, and there was no peace because of the trouble. I will let every person turn against their neighbor.’

(Zechariah 8:11) 
‘But now, unlike those former days, I will plant the seeds of peace. The vineyard will produce its fruit. The earth will give its harvest, and the sky will give its dew. I will give all these things to the remnant of my people.’

(Zechariah 8:12) 
‘Then it will be: just as you, the house of Judah and the house of Israel, were a curse among the nations, so I will save you, and you will be a blessing. Do not be afraid. Be strong!’

(Zechariah 8:13) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘Just as I decided to bring disaster upon you, when your ancestors angered me,’ says the Lord, ‘I did not change my mind,’

(Zechariah 8:14) 
‘so now I have decided to bring good to Jerusalem and to the house of Judah. Do not be afraid.’

(Zechariah 8:15) 
“These are the things you must do: Speak the truth to each other. Judge fairly and justly in your courts.

(Zechariah 8:16) 
Do not plan evil against each other. Do not love to swear falsely. I hate all these things,” says the Lord.

(Zechariah 8:17) 
The Word of the Lord of Hosts came to me, saying:

(Zechariah 8:18) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘The fasts of the fourth, fifth, seventh, and tenth months will become times of joy, gladness, and cheerful festivals for the house of Judah. But love truth and peace.’

(Zechariah 8:19) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘People from many cities will come again,’

(Zechariah 8:20) 
and the inhabitants of one city will go to another, saying, ‘Let us go and seek the favor of the Lord and search for the Lord of Hosts. I am going, too.’

(Zechariah 8:21) 
‘Many peoples and powerful nations will come to Jerusalem to seek the Lord of Hosts and to implore the favor of the Lord.’

(Zechariah 8:22) 
“The Lord of Hosts says this: ‘In those days, ten men from every language of the nations will grasp the cloak of a Jew, saying, ‘Let us go with you, for we have heard that God is with you.’

(Zechariah 9:1) 
This is the prophecy of the Lord about the land of Hadrach. The Lord's protection will fall on Damascus; the eyes of mankind and of all the tribes of Israel are turned to Him.

(Zechariah 9:2) 
So too will Hadrach and Hamath; and Tyre and Sidon, because those cities have developed great skill.

(Zechariah 9:3) 
Tyre built itself strongholds and amassed wealth as great as dust, and gold as common as the mud of the streets.

(Zechariah 9:4) 
But the Lord will take away her power. He will cast her strength into the sea, and the city will be consumed by fire.

(Zechariah 9:5) 
Ashkelon will see it and fear, and Gaza will be in great pain; Ekron will be terrified, for her hope will be gone. The king will perish from Gaza, and Ashkelon will be deserted.

(Zechariah 9:6) 
Foreigners will occupy Ashdod, and I will cut off the pride of the Philistines.

(Zechariah 9:7) 
I will take away the blood from their mouths and the abominations from between their teeth. Those who remain will belong to the Lord and will become a part of Judah, and Ekron will join as one of the Israelites.

(Zechariah 9:8) 
I will keep my people safe from their enemies, who pass through and return. I will watch over them with my own eyes, and no oppressor will ever come against them again.

(Zechariah 9:9) 
Rejoice greatly, daughter Zion! Shout, daughter Jerusalem! Look, your king is coming to you! He is righteous and brings salvation! He is humble, riding on a donkey, on a colt, the foal of a donkey.

(Zechariah 9:10) 
I will cut off the chariots of Ephraim and the horses of Jerusalem, and the bows of war will be broken. He will proclaim peace to the nations; his dominion will extend from sea to sea and from the Euphrates to the ends of the earth.

(Zechariah 9:11) 
Because of the blood of my covenant with you, I will set your prisoners free from the waterless pit. Return to your stronghold, you prisoners of hope; today I declare that I will restore twice as much to you.

(Zechariah 9:12) 
Return to your stronghold, you prisoners of hope; today I declare that I will restore twice as much to you.

(Zechariah 9:13) 
I will bend Judah as my bow, and I will fit the arrow of Ephraim. I will rouse your sons, Zion, against the sons of Greece; I will make you like a warrior’s sword.

(Zechariah 9:14) 
Then the Lord will appear over them; his arrow will be like lightning. The Lord God will sound the trumpet and will march in the storms of the south.

(Zechariah 9:15) 
The Lord of Hosts will protect them. They will eat and will trample the sling stones; they will drink and roar as if drunk with wine; they will be filled with blood like bowls, like the corners of the altar.

(Zechariah 9:16) 
On that day the Lord their God will save them, like the flock of his people. For they will be like the jewels of a crown, gleaming over his land.

(Zechariah 9:17) 
How beautiful and good they are, the grain of the elect, and the new wine that makes virgins flourish!

(Zechariah 10:1) 
Beseech the Lord, and He will give rain at the appointed time: then the Lord will make the clouds gather, and He will give them food in the field.

(Zechariah 10:2) 
False gods speak empty words; the soothsayers have seen lies and spoken in vain; they console in vain. Therefore, they have wandered away like sheep, and are afflicted because there is no shepherd.

(Zechariah 10:3) 
My wrath is kindled against the shepherds, and I will punish the leaders. For the Lord of hosts will visit His flock, the house of Judah, and will make them as a glorious horse in battle.

(Zechariah 10:4) 
From Judah will come the cornerstone, from him the peg, from him the bow of war. From him, will the strength of all of them come forth.

(Zechariah 10:5) 
And they shall be as mighty men, trampling the mire of the streets in battle, and they shall fight, because the Lord is with them.

(Zechariah 10:6) 
And I will strengthen the house of Judah, and I will save the house of Joseph, and I will restore them, because I will have mercy on them, and they shall be as they were before I had cast them off. For I am the Lord their God, and I will hear them.

(Zechariah 10:7) 
And Ephraim shall be as a mighty man, and their heart shall rejoice as if with wine, and their children shall see it, and shall rejoice, and their heart shall be glad in the Lord.

(Zechariah 10:8) 
I will whistle for them, and I will gather them, because I have redeemed them, and I will multiply them as before.

(Zechariah 10:9) 
And I will disperse them among the peoples, and in distant lands they will remember Me, and they shall live with their children, and shall turn back to Me.

(Zechariah 10:10) 
And I will bring them back from the land of Egypt, and I will gather them from Assyria, and I will bring them to the land of Gilead and Lebanon, and there will be no room for them.

(Zechariah 10:11) 
And they shall pass through the sea of tribulation, and He shall strike down the waves in the sea, and all the depths of the river shall be dried up, and the pride of Assyria shall be taken away, and the scepter of Egypt.

(Zechariah 10:12) 
And I will strengthen them in the Lord, and in His name they shall rejoice, says the Lord.

(Zechariah 11:1) 
Open your gates, Lebanon, so the fire will devour your cedars.

(Zechariah 11:2) 
Howl, fir tree, because the cedar has fallen. The mighty are ruined. Howl, oaks of Bashan, because the impenetrable forest has been cut down.

(Zechariah 11:3) 
Listen to the shepherds' cries of grief, because their glory is ruined. Listen to the lions' roaring, because the pride of the Jordan is ruined.

(Zechariah 11:4) 
Thus says the Lord, my God: "Shepherd the flock that is being slaughtered.

(Zechariah 11:5) 
Those who possessed them killed them without regret. Those who sold them said, 'Blessed is the Lord, for we have become rich!' and their shepherds show them no pity.

(Zechariah 11:6) 
Because I will no longer pity the inhabitants of the land, behold, I will cause men to fall into the hands of their neighbors and into the hands of their kings. They will crush the land, and I will not deliver it from their hands."

(Zechariah 11:7) 
So I shepherded the flock that was being slaughtered, that is, the poor of the flock. And I took for myself two staffs: one I named Favor, and the other I named Union. And I tended the flock.

(Zechariah 11:8) 
I dismissed the three shepherds in one month. My soul became impatient with them, and their souls also detested me.

(Zechariah 11:9) 
Then I said, "I will not be your shepherd. Let the dying die, and those who are perishing, perish. Let those who are left devour each other's flesh!"

(Zechariah 11:10) 
Then I took my staff, Favor, and I broke it, because I was breaking the covenant that I had made with all the peoples.

(Zechariah 11:11) 
So it was broken on that day, and the poor of the flock, who were watching me, knew that it was the word of the Lord.

(Zechariah 11:12)
