Then King Ptolemy answered, "I am the king of Egypt. I have come to my own land, and I have given them help, and I have restored the land to the city, and you shall not depart from me."

(1 Maccabees 11:3) 
And a war was fought against Alexander, because the Romans were in everything with Ptolemy, and Ptolemy prevailed and they departed from the land.

(1 Maccabees 11:4) 
And Ptolemy gathered all his forces and came into Syria and took many cities and killed them.

(1 Maccabees 11:5) 
And he sent a great letter to Simon and made an appointment with him in Ammathunte, which is near the mountain, that he should come to him.

(1 Maccabees 11:6) 
And he went to him and saw his glory, his army, and his equipment and was afraid, and he acted against him and did not want to do him harm.

(1 Maccabees 11:7) 
And they said to him that they would do whatever they wished against Simon, and make him king, and whoever was their friend or enemy.

(1 Maccabees 11:8) 
And because Simon saw that he was angry, he was afraid and laid his hands on him, and did him violence, for he was an old man.

(1 Maccabees 11:9) 
And they killed him and his sons and his brothers. And he sent and sent his army and killed them and inflicted violence on them.

(1 Maccabees 11:10) 
And war was made, and the children of Israel went out of the field and came to the place of battles, and he was angry and prevailed.

(1 Maccabees 11:11) 
And Alexander, the king of Syria, hearing of this, gathered all his forces together and came into Syria.

(1 Maccabees 11:12) 
And he gathered a very large army and prevailed against Ptolemy and drove him from his land.

(1 Maccabees 11:13) 
And Alexander fought a war in the land, and those from the strongest cities came to him.

(1 Maccabees 11:14) 
And he gave him a very strong city, and he made him the leader of all who were around him.

(1 Maccabees 11:15) 
And Jonathan, hearing of this, sent ambassadors to him, asking him to make friendship with him.

(1 Maccabees 11:16) 
And he was accepted by him and sent letters to him saying:

(1 Maccabees 11:17) 
King Alexander to his brother Jonathan, greetings.

(1 Maccabees 11:18) 
We have heard of you that you are a man powerful in virtue and that you deserve to be our friend.

(1 Maccabees 11:19) 
Therefore, we have appointed you today to be a high priest and one of the king's friends.

(1 Maccabees 11:20) 
And he sent him a purple cloak and a golden crown, and he gave them to him.

(1 Maccabees 11:21) 
And Jonathan put them on, and was in the day of the feast of the seventh month, and began to go out to the people and sacrifice.

(1 Maccabees 11:22) 
And King Alexander, hearing this, made him a friend, even before he was with him.

(1 Maccabees 11:23) 
And he wrote to him, saying: "Why have you given your people the law, and made a covenant with the Romans?"

(1 Maccabees 11:24) 
And he was very angry and acted against him, and Alexander, hearing this, gathered great forces.

(1 Maccabees 11:25) 
And he commanded Jonathan and brought him before the king in Ptolemais. And the king came and met him and fought.

(1 Maccabees 11:26) 
And they fled from Ptolemais and pursued them to the gates, and about three thousand men fell from Ptolemais.

(1 Maccabees 11:27) 
And Jonathan took Alexander's sword, and they went out of the city and fled.

(1 Maccabees 11:28) 
And Jonathan fought in Bethsura, and they came together in battle.

(1 Maccabees 11:29) 
And Alexander sent letters to Jonathan in peace. And Jonathan sent to him, for he was acting in peace and to him, in peace.

(1 Maccabees 11:30) 
And King Alexander put Jonathan in honor and gave him possessions and divisions.

(1 Maccabees 11:31) 
And Jonathan went out to Ptolemais, and King Alexander met him, and he honored him greatly.

(1 Maccabees 11:32) 
And he took him and they met and slept together.

(1 Maccabees 11:33) 
And Alexander went out and went into Egypt and reigned.

(1 Maccabees 11:34) 
And Ptolemy, the king of Egypt, died, and he made his son Philip reign, who was in Egypt for eighteen years.

(1 Maccabees 11:35) 
And Philip died, and Demetrius reigned.

(1 Maccabees 12:1) 
In the year one hundred and forty-four, those who were in Rome sent greetings to the people of Macedonia and to the Jews.

(1 Maccabees 12:2) 
The Jews in Judea received this message.

(1 Maccabees 12:3) 
They also sent to the Romans, Athenians, Chaldeans, and all the nations gathered in the same place in the land of Judea.

(1 Maccabees 12:4) 
This is a copy of the letter: "The Jewish brothers send greetings and prosperity to the people of Rome.

(1 Maccabees 12:5) 
If you are well, we are well.

(1 Maccabees 12:6) 
Because of the war we had with Philip and those who were with him, we have had to deal with various events, which concerned both you and us.

(1 Maccabees 12:7) 
You sent us a letter and we sent you one also, asking that we might confirm our treaty with you.

(1 Maccabees 12:8) 
So, at the time we wrote to you, we wrote to our Jewish brothers and your priests. We asked them not to ignore but to observe these things.

(1 Maccabees 12:9) 
We are hoping what we have agreed upon is what you agree upon also.

(1 Maccabees 12:10) 
Therefore, we are sending you Antiochus and Jason, the sons of Jason, and the Romans sent them to you to confirm what we have written, and for you to confirm what we have written.

(1 Maccabees 12:11) 
And now, farewell.""

(1 Maccabees 12:12) 
This letter was written in Rome on the first days of the month of Spartius.

(1 Maccabees 12:13) 
They wrote to those who were in Judea, and to the Jews who were in the land.

(1 Maccabees 12:14) 
"Jewish brothers, greetings and prosperity.

(1 Maccabees 12:15) 
The people of Rome and the Jews wish you peace and prosperity forever. May God grant you grace, both now and in the future.

(1 Maccabees 12:16) 
The Romans sent envoys to us to confirm friendship and a treaty with you.

(1 Maccabees 12:17) 
They established decrees so that we, our people, you, and your land would not wage war.

(1 Maccabees 12:18) 
Therefore, if war is first waged against you by the Romans or any of their allies, we will defend you to the best of our ability.

(1 Maccabees 12:19) 
Likewise, if war is first waged against the Romans, we will join with you.

(1 Maccabees 12:20) 
We have confirmed these things just as they decreed.

(1 Maccabees 12:21) 
These words were written in Rome on the first days of the month of Spartius.

(1 Maccabees 12:22) 
Then they sent letters to King Demetrius and to every nation in Asia, and to those in Judea, and to those at peace.

(1 Maccabees 12:23) 
Jewish brothers, greetings, prosperity, and health.

(1 Maccabees 12:24) 
Demetrius and his ancestors have made peace with you and the Jewish people.

(1 Maccabees 12:25) 
We have confirmed these words we wrote to you.

(1 Maccabees 12:26) 
So, if you want to make a treaty with us, write to us, and we will write to you.

(1 Maccabees 12:27) 
The people confirmed that Demetrius had granted us peace.

(1 Maccabees 12:28) 
For King Demetrius saw that the Jewish people belonged to God, and that they fought against those who opposed them.

(1 Maccabees 12:29) 
He included them among his friends and sent them honors.

(1 Maccabees 12:30) 
This was during the days when they wrote to those in Judea.

(1 Maccabees 12:31) 
At the command of the Romans, letters were sent to the Jews, saying, "Greetings and prosperity to the Jews.

(1 Maccabees 12:32) 
The people of Rome and their allies send peace, strength, and prosperity to the Jewish nation forever.

(1 Maccabees 12:33) 
If war is first waged against you by the Romans or any of their allies, we will defend you to the best of our ability.

(1 Maccabees 12:34) 
Again, if war is first waged against the Romans, we will join with you.

(1 Maccabees 12:35) 
These words, written, we sent them to those in Judea.

(1 Maccabees 13:1) 
In the one hundred and forty-ninth year, King Demetrius wrote letters to Simon the high priest and leader of the people, and to his friends, and to the Jewish people, both those in Judea and those in other lands, offering greetings of peace.

(1 Maccabees 13:2) 
The letters read: “King Demetrius to Simon the high priest, his friends, and the Jewish people, greetings.

(1 Maccabees 13:3) 
“Because of the troubles the Jews had caused, we have decided, though with much pain, to acknowledge their strength, courage, and honor. So we will do as the Jews wish.”

(1 Maccabees 13:4) 
“Therefore, we decree to them and their friends, and to the land of Judea, freedom and release: and we let go and forgive them all things which the Jews have taken until this day, and all the crimes they committed.”

(1 Maccabees 13:5) 
“Let all that they did through ignorance or in secret be forgiven.”

(1 Maccabees 13:6) 
“We will provide for the construction of the Temple and the repair of its walls, as well as the other expenses that were required.”

(1 Maccabees 13:7) 
“Furthermore, the Jews will be free to do whatever they want.”

(1 Maccabees 13:8)

(2 Maccabees 2:1) 
The books of Nehemiah and the Acts of the Kings contain these same accounts, along with the writings about the kings and the prophets, and the accounts of David.

(2 Maccabees 2:2) 
The first book, that is, the book of Nehemiah, contains the history and the accounts of the kings, as well as the writings of the prophets.

(2 Maccabees 2:3) 
I collected the accounts of the kings, the writings of the prophets, and the accounts of David, and the sacred gifts of the kings.

(2 Maccabees 2:4) 
The books of those who wrote about David and the acts of Solomon are available.

(2 Maccabees 2:5) 
Thus, a history was compiled to instruct those who want to learn and those who are abroad.

(2 Maccabees 2:6) 
Both the author and those who carefully researched it, took great care.

(2 Maccabees 2:7) 
For not all writings, as in these, should be presented in this way, especially the historical accounts, because of the events described.

(2 Maccabees 2:8) 
The author then sent a short treatise, and he included those things that were relevant to the matter in order to be brief.

(2 Maccabees 2:9) 
Diligence must be given to those who read, but to those who write, the ability to speak and the diligence of investigation into the subject itself.

(2 Maccabees 2:10) 
Therefore, we will now discuss what should be done with these things, and having made this preface, we will begin the present discourse.

(2 Maccabees 2:11) 
When Judas Maccabeus waged war, he chose to honor his fallen soldiers, and he secretly sent some of his friends to retrieve the bones of those who had fallen.

(2 Maccabees 2:12) 
They were brought under their tunics, and they carried them to Jerusalem.

(2 Maccabees 2:13) 
And they placed them in the tombs of their fathers, in a place that was revealed to them.

(2 Maccabees 2:14) 
On the day of the feast, when the children of Israel were rejoicing, they prayed and implored that the sins which had been committed would be forgiven.

(2 Maccabees 2:15) 
Judas and the leaders, along with the people, prayed and implored that sin would be blotted out completely.

(2 Maccabees 2:16) 
For the glorious deeds and the valiant actions in war, the Jews and their brothers, did not seek honor, but faith.

(2 Maccabees 2:17) 
For they saw it as good and honorable to fight to the death and to give their lives for those things that pertain to God.

(2 Maccabees 2:18) 
Therefore, as we were writing the remaining works from Jason of Cyrene, and from those things that especially pertain to Judas, we ourselves, for the sake of brevity, have made this preface.

(2 Maccabees 2:19) 
Jason of Cyrene wrote five books about Judas Maccabeus and his brothers, about the purification of the great temple, the consecration of the altar, the wars against King Antiochus Epiphanes, and the cause for liberty.

(2 Maccabees 2:20) 
And about those things that were done against him and those who were with him, and about the things that were accomplished.

(2 Maccabees 2:21) 
And about the battles against the Greeks in Persia, and in the place called Garisa, and other such events, he includes all of these things individually.

(2 Maccabees 2:22) 
Therefore, we attempt to summarize these events in a short form, and we give our attention to those who wrote and those who read.

(2 Maccabees 2:23) 
And I say this to the reader, and to those who read, so that they may be able to understand more easily.

(2 Maccabees 2:24) 
And we will say these things at the end, as in the beginning, and in the middle, and in the end.

(2 Maccabees 3:1) 
While the holy city was living in peace, and the laws were being observed in the best way possible due to piety, there was hatred because of evil.

(2 Maccabees 3:2) 
It happened that some of the citizens, specifically Philip, a man from the region of Syria, and the same man put in charge of the city, became very angry; but also Jason with his followers, who wickedly corrupted the just law and a holy life,

(2 Maccabees 3:3) 
were commanding that the holy temple in Jerusalem be moved, and that the sacred offerings, money, and revenues, which had been given by holy men, and which were provided by good men, be taken away.

(2 Maccabees 3:4) 
The one who was in charge, Onias, who was placed in charge as the High Priest, and a good and gentle man, and who hated evil, said

(2 Maccabees 3:5) 
to King Ptolemy, who was in Alexandria, that he would rebuke these men for the illegal things they had done.

(2 Maccabees 3:6) 
But when they arrived, and remained in the same city, by the providence of God, men were sent from the people, to handle the business of money.

(2 Maccabees 3:7) 
When they came to Philip and his associates, they were asked to give money for the business, and they immediately begged them not to do anything unjust.

(2 Maccabees 3:8) 
But because they insisted on this, and spoke against all the requests, then Onias, who was in charge as the High Priest, shouted, saying, "These are the ones who were insulting the temples in Jerusalem, and stealing the money of the poor"

(2 Maccabees 3:9) 
for which reason, they and their children, who were righteous according to the holy law, and with Onias, the High Priest, and others who were of the priesthood.

(2 Maccabees 3:10) 
Then Philip and his associates, because they were not able to achieve anything concerning this matter, struck them with anger, and sent all of them, who had spoken against the evil, to Ptolemy.

(2 Maccabees 3:11) 
When the king was angry with them, and ordered the wicked to be tortured, and that they should be scourged in Jerusalem, and he gave them all those things, except for what they had wickedly done in the city,

(2 Maccabees 3:12) 
But Onias, when he heard that they were suffering unjustly, begged and pleaded for them, because they were from the people, and he pleaded for them.

(2 Maccabees 3:13) 
This is the very same thing that happened in Jerusalem, it came to pass, while Heliodorus, appointed by King Seleucus, and placed in charge of the treasury, was entering the city in order to receive the money.

(2 Maccabees 3:14) 
And when he approached, with the whole army, and with the intent of the city, Heliodorus was seen, who was appointed by the king, and with the power to do evil.

(2 Maccabees 3:15) 
However, the priests and the whole multitude were present at prayer, and they were calling upon Him, who gave the law, and for those who preserved holy things.

(2 Maccabees 3:16) 
Then the High Priest, and all the multitude, with tears, and with prayer, begged that he who was appointed, should be saved, and that he who had been sent to do the work, would be preserved.

(2 Maccabees 3:17) 
But Heliodorus was already at the entrance to the treasuries, with the guard, and the custodians, who were around him.

(2 Maccabees 3:18) 
Then a man appeared to him in a frightening way, with terrible glory, and with weapons, he commanded that he rush into battle, and they struck him very severely.

(2 Maccabees 3:19) 
And when he thought he would enter more boldly, the treasuries, they came to him with scourges, and struck him, and threw him on the ground, with great fear.

(2 Maccabees 3:20) 
Those who were around him, then, and his limbs were bound, and he was tied up, so that he should do completely what he was ordered to do by the king.

(2 Maccabees 3:21) 
However, while he was lying on the ground, and enduring the most harsh torments, it happened that he himself was being forced to do all things.

(2 Maccabees 3:22) 
Meanwhile, while those in the temple were rejoicing, the whole multitude, and they were worshipping the all-powerful God, who saved the glory, who works miracles for everything.

(2 Maccabees 3:23) 
Heliodorus, however, when he had fallen, and was not able to rise, was sent with his companions, and they carried him, as if he were already dead.

(2 Maccabees 3:24) 
When they were in the place, and Heliodorus with his companions were at the king's garrison, then, those who had done this, asked him about those who had done this, and about the things he had done, and about the things he had carried out.

(2 Maccabees 3:25) 
However, he himself answered in their sight, that he seemed to be through the force of violence, and that it was as had been spoken by God.

(2 Maccabees 3:26) 
For when he was with the soldiers, who were around him, two very excellent young men appeared to him, and of great glory, who stood over him, and struck him very severely.

(2 Maccabees 3:27) 
And they who are in sight came to him, and in his eyes, and who then struck him.

(2 Maccabees 3:28) 
Therefore, when they were in the place, and in these things, all of those who were there, glorified the Lord, because he did wonderful things.

(2 Maccabees 3:29) 
However, those who were in the place, glorified God, and gave the gifts of thanks, in the temple, and to those who had been saved, for Heliodorus, who was dead.

(2 Maccabees 3:30) 
Heliodorus, however, promised to God, who was life, and saved him, and all those things that had come, and all those things that had been done, and had now perished, gave his hand to them.

(2 Maccabees 3:31) 
Onias, however, when he was no longer in life, and congratulated him on what God had saved him, and what he had given to him.

(2 Maccabees 3:32) 
Then the king, when he arrived at him, and at the Hebrews, who were from Jerusalem, and who were with great glory, and with great glory in peace, and gave them gifts of every kind, and blessed God.

(2 Maccabees 3:33) 
But also Onias, who was in charge as High Priest, who had been saved, prayed for all the people, and gave them peace, and gave them peace.

(2 Maccabees 4:1) 
It happened that when Antiochus, also called Epiphanes, entered the city, he wanted to quickly expel Heliodorus from his position. Heliodorus had returned without fulfilling his orders.

(2 Maccabees 4:2) 
Therefore, he sent Lysias, the commander of his army and the administrator of his affairs, to remove Heliodorus from his position.

(2 Maccabees 4:3) 
Upon hearing this, Heliodorus went to Ptolemais, gathered a large crowd there, and prepared to use deceit.

(2 Maccabees 4:4) 
For he brought forth accusations before the king against those of the city who were wicked.

(2 Maccabees 4:5) 
These were Jason and those with him who practiced impiety and drove out their fellow citizens.

(2 Maccabees 4:6) 
Nor was there innocent blood which did not cry out to God for vengeance.

(2 Maccabees 4:7) 
Therefore, immediately Lysias, encouraging the people, accused Ptolemais of the evils committed against the city.

(2 Maccabees 4:8) 
And he accused the king of all these things.

(2 Maccabees 4:9) 
Then Antiochus, enraged, immediately heeded the advice of Lysias.

(2 Maccabees 4:10) 
And he appointed Jason, without delay, to punish those who had attacked and to inflict punishment on the citizens.

(2 Maccabees 4:11) 
When Jason arrived, as soon as he appeared, he struck his own brothers and drove his enemies into exile.

(2 Maccabees 4:12) 
And he did not have power in the kingdom, nor great honor.

(2 Maccabees 4:13) 
Then Menelaus, as mentioned before, the brother of Jason, sold himself to the prince, through much money, and swore to be the king's friend.

(2 Maccabees 4:14) 
He sent Jason into the city with three men from the city.

(2 Maccabees 4:15) 
When they received the king's letters, they went to the king and explained the matter to him.

(2 Maccabees 4:16) 
Then Menelaus, in the absence of Jason, promised three hundred talents of silver, and seventy talents from other gifts, from every promise that was given.

(2 Maccabees 4:17) 
And he sought to obtain the priestly office.

(2 Maccabees 4:18) 
Therefore, the king gave it to Menelaus, and he took on the priestly office, ordering that Jason be brought to trial from the city.

(2 Maccabees 4:19) 
And he sent Jason to the city, sending him letters concerning what he had done and what he had accomplished.

(2 Maccabees 4:20) 
When he arrived, he was brought in by Menelaus, and when the people heard this, they immediately became angry at Jason and killed him.

(2 Maccabees 4:21) 
And Menelaus succeeded to the priesthood, yet he did not fulfill any priestly duties, nor did he care for the laws, nor did he consider judgments, but he did everything according to the will and pleasure of the king.

(2 Maccabees 4:22) 
Then Menelaus went with those who were wicked from the city, and they sent to the king and put them to death in the city.

(2 Maccabees 4:23) 
And when they came, many from the city were delivered to punishment, and the blood of many was shed because of the anger that had come from Jason's impiety.

(2 Maccabees 4:24) 
Antiochus, while preparing for an expedition into Egypt, heard that a disturbance had occurred in the city of Jerusalem.

(2 Maccabees 4:25) 
And that those who were with Jason had fled the city and had acted injuriously in the holy temple.

(2 Maccabees 4:26) 
When he heard this, he thought Egypt had been conquered, and he went up in a rage and seized the city, and ordered his soldiers not to spare anyone in the city and to kill those who were encountered.

(2 Maccabees 4:27) 
And entering the temple, he stole the gold and silver vessels, the utensils, and all the treasures he found there.

(2 Maccabees 4:28) 
And taking everything, he went back to his own land and committed a great slaughter.

(2 Maccabees 4:29) 
And there was great mourning and lamentation in Israel.

(2 Maccabees 4:30) 
And there were the leaders and elders who mourned and were grieved in spirit, and who sat at the gates of the city, who were distressed and filled with sorrow.

(2 Maccabees 4:31) 
It happened that those in the city, and those in the mountains, who were also robbers, and who had taken plunder, and all those in the city who had gathered to fight, and who were impious, and who did every evil deed.

(2 Maccabees 4:32) 
And the king ordered them to be in the temple, to be struck and killed, and those who were over all, and those in the temple who had killed, were killed, and then they came to war.

(2 Maccabees 4:33) 
And there were many of the impious over them, who were also wounded, and those who were in the city, and those who were in the temple, who were also killed.

(2 Maccabees 4:34) 
And he ordered throughout all the cities that all those who were in the city should make sacrifices and offer to idols.

(2 Maccabees 4:35) 
And from the temple in Jerusalem, they took away the altar and burned it, and they made seats, statues, and idols in it.

(2 Maccabees 4:36) 
And they sacrificed pigs on the altar and poured out blood, and there was no one to bury the dead.

(2 Maccabees 4:37) 
And great disgrace was cast upon them, and a great abomination was committed against Israel.

(2 Maccabees 4:38) 
And many fled from the city and left their wives, children, brothers, and parents, and went into the mountains, to hiding places, to caves, and to other solitary places.

(2 Maccabees 4:39) 
Then there were many who were dying and lying in the city and in the mountains.

(2 Maccabees 4:40) 
And great wrath was poured out upon them, and a great judgment took place.

(2 Maccabees 4:41) 
And Judas Maccabeus and those who were with him, on the mountain, and those who were with him, to fight against the impious, and to fight, and to strike, and to kill.

(2 Maccabees 4:42) 
And they gathered together and placed each one in his place, and they took up arms and said, "It is better for us to die than to see the wickedness of the wicked and the holy things defiled."

(2 Maccabees 4:43) 
And they went to war with the impious and killed them.

(2 Maccabees 4:44) 
And quickly the impious fled from their presence.

(2 Maccabees 4:45) 
And they pursued them and killed and destroyed the impious, and they took vengeance from their hands, and they purified the holy things.

(2 Maccabees 4:46) 
And they purified the temple, the altar, and all the vessels, and they hung up in it those things that were defiled.

(2 Maccabees 4:47) 
And they offered in it the burnt offering, praise, and glory, and they said, "Lord, Lord God, who made the universe and the earth, and who is the Lord of all things."

(2 Maccabees 4:48) 
Send now your spirit and sanctify us, and send your light and strike those who are impious and their deeds.

(2 Maccabees 4:49) 
And after these things, they pursued and established, and they took vengeance on all the nations, and they killed the impious.

(2 Maccabees 4:50) 
And after this, they had peace, and they did all things according to the law of God.

(2 Maccabees 5:1) 
Around this time, Antiochus came back from Persia and arrived in the city of Antioch.

(2 Maccabees 5:2) 
And when he entered, he wanted to go into the temple, and his enemies attacked him, causing a disturbance.

(2 Maccabees 5:3) 
Because he was forbidden to enter, he became angry and departed.

(2 Maccabees 5:4) 
Upon his return, his fury flared, and he ordered the Jewish temple to be struck without pause.

(2 Maccabees 5:5) 
Then, many people came out and gathered around him.

(2 Maccabees 5:6) 
He commanded the men to be prepared. Quickly they entered and struck the city, killing many.

(2 Maccabees 5:7) 
They seized many spoils and set the city on fire.

(2 Maccabees 5:8) 
They demolished homes and tore down the surrounding walls.

(2 Maccabees 5:9) 
They took women and children captive and seized livestock.

(2 Maccabees 5:10) 
In the Holy Temple, they plundered the gold, silver, and valuable vessels they found there.

(2 Maccabees 5:11) 
They took everything and went back to their own land, causing great slaughter.

(2 Maccabees 5:12) 
There was great mourning in Israel.

(2 Maccabees 5:13) 
The leaders and elders groaned; young men and girls mourned; and the women lost their beauty.

(2 Maccabees 5:14) 
Every groom assumed the lament, and the bride was as if in mourning.

(2 Maccabees 5:15) 
The lands trembled because of their inhabitants, and the whole house of Jacob was confounded.

(2 Maccabees 5:16) 
After two years, the king sent a tax collector to the cities of Judea, and he came to Jerusalem with a large multitude.

(2 Maccabees 5:17) 
He spoke words of peace, but he deceived them. He struck the city with a great plague.

(2 Maccabees 5:18) 
He killed many of the people and scattered their spoils.

(2 Maccabees 5:19) 
He took away the ornaments of Jerusalem and put them in his own cities, and he destroyed Jerusalem.

(2 Maccabees 5:20) 
He led women and children into captivity and took possession of the livestock.

(2 Maccabees 5:21) 
They built a city of David with a large, strong wall, solid towers, and it became a citadel for them.

(2 Maccabees 5:22) 
They placed a sinful people there, wicked men; and they established themselves within it.

(2 Maccabees 5:23) 
They put weapons there, gathered food, stored arms there, and they uttered blasphemies, making it a snare for them.

(2 Maccabees 5:24) 
They spread out before the temple, surrounded it on all sides, and it became a wicked enemy to them.

(2 Maccabees 5:25) 
They poured out the blood of the innocent around the sanctuary, and the sanctuary was defiled, and the sons of strangers were around the temple, and the gentiles lived with the prostitutes and worked with them.

(2 Maccabees 5:26) 
The Jews were not allowed to enter, nor to observe the law or the commandments of God, because of their wickedness.

(2 Maccabees 5:27) 
Also, all of its honor was taken away, and all its glory was turned into disgrace.

(2 Maccabees 5:28) 
And the temple of the gentiles was full of luxury, banquets, and fornications. Women were with the gentiles in the temple, and things were done both around and within the sacred things that were forbidden.

(2 Maccabees 5:29) 
And the heart of Judah was troubled, and as he departed from the temple, the whole city was full of confusion.

(2 Maccabees 5:30) 
And all the streets resounded with the voice of those crying out, and everyone groaned together.

(2 Maccabees 6:1) 
Not long after, the king sent elders from Athens to force the Jews to abandon their ancestral laws and to cease living according to God’s laws:

(2 Maccabees 6:2) 
They were to defile the Temple in Jerusalem, dedicating it to foreign gods, setting up altars and temples for those gods, and offering unclean pigs as sacrifices.

(2 Maccabees 6:3) 
When this happened, many in the Jewish population agreed with them, offering sacrifices to idols and violating the Sabbath.

(2 Maccabees 6:4) 
The king sent written commands by messengers to Jerusalem and the cities of Judea, ordering them to follow practices that were foreign to their ancestral laws.

(2 Maccabees 6:5) 
They forced the people and gave them the commands to offer sacrifices to idols, defiling themselves through the sacrifices.

(2 Maccabees 6:6) 
But those who remained in Judea, and who were left behind, faced great tribulations because no one had the ability to escape from a given place.

(2 Maccabees 6:7) 
When this happened, many Jews agreed with them and sacrificed to idols in every way, profaning the Sabbath.

(2 Maccabees 6:8) 
Afterward, he brought about the deaths of many who did not agree, but persevered in Judaism and forbade such practices.

(2 Maccabees 6:9) 
On the fifteenth day of the month of Casleu, in the one hundred and forty-fifth year, they built the abominable idol in the Temple and in the cities of Judea all around.

(2 Maccabees 6:10) 
They sacrificed on the day of the idol’s birth and on the first day of each month, according to the king's command, at the altar.

(2 Maccabees 6:11) 
Those in Jerusalem were forced to pretend and to offer sacrifices, crowning themselves for Bacchus.

(2 Maccabees 6:12) 
But there was great sorrow over Israel.

(2 Maccabees 6:13) 
For those who pretended did not refuse to eat the unclean things.

(2 Maccabees 6:14) 
Therefore, many Jews fled to hide themselves and to attack those who were doing those things.

(2 Maccabees 6:15) 
And on the ninth day of the month of Casleu, in the one hundred and forty-fifth year, they rose up to offer sacrifices, sacrificing at the altar that was above the altar and they killed according to the king's command.

(2 Maccabees 6:16) 
The women who had circumcised their sons made themselves known, and they were hung by the neck throughout the city.

(2 Maccabees 6:17) 
And they destroyed others along with their families and those who were with them, and they killed them on every day.

(2 Maccabees 6:18) 
So, many Israelites decided in their hearts not to eat unclean things.

(2 Maccabees 6:19) 
They chose to die rather than to be defiled by food and to violate the holy law and so they died.

(2 Maccabees 6:20) 
And great wrath came upon them.

(2 Maccabees 6:21) 
Two women were also brought forth because they had circumcised their sons.

(2 Maccabees 6:22) 
When they seized their sons, they hung the women from their breasts, ripped them open, and killed their sons at the same time.

(2 Maccabees 6:23) 
But others, along with their sons, gave themselves up, and they died frequently.

(2 Maccabees 6:24) 
Then, the Lord was angry with them, because their sins were the cause.

(2 Maccabees 6:25) 
But Machabeus gathered those who were with him, hiding in the mountains and forests, and he struck those who were in Judea, attacking those who were against them.

(2 Maccabees 7:1) 
This also happened: Seven brothers and their mother were arrested. The king tortured them with whips and cords to force them to eat pork, which the Law forbade.

(2 Maccabees 7:2) 
But the first brother said: "What do you want to know from us? We are ready to die rather than disobey the laws of our fathers."

(2 Maccabees 7:3) 
The enraged king commanded the fires and frying pans to be heated. He then ordered the brothers to be tortured by their tongues, hands, and feet.

(2 Maccabees 7:4) 
While they were enduring this torture, the other brothers said: "What are you looking for? What do you want to know? We are ready to die."

(2 Maccabees 7:5) 
The second brother, at the point of death by torture, said: "You wicked man, you may end our present life, but the King of the universe will raise us up again to eternal life because we die for His laws."

(2 Maccabees 7:6) 
After him, the third brother, who was mocked, quickly extended his tongue, and his hands with a courageous boldness, saying: "I received these from God, and because of His laws I despise them; and I hope to receive them again."

(2 Maccabees 7:7) 
Even the king and those with him were amazed at the youths' resolve. They despised the tortures and threw away their present life.

(2 Maccabees 7:8) 
When the third brother died, the fourth was tortured in the same way. As he was at the point of death, he said: "It is good to die at the hands of men, but we have hope of being raised again by God. But for you, there will be no resurrection to life."

(2 Maccabees 7:9) 
Then they brought the fifth brother and tortured him. But he, looking at the king, said: "Although you have the power of men, you are corruptible and you do what you will. Do not think that our race has been abandoned by God:"

(2 Maccabees 7:10) 
Hold on and see His great works, and how He will test them and punish you."

(2 Maccabees 7:11) 
Then the sixth brother said, as he was dying: "Do not be mistaken: for we suffer these things for ourselves because we have sinned against God, for which reason these wonders have happened to us."

(2 Maccabees 7:12) 
The mother was even more marvelous and worthy of memory. For she, when she saw one day in the presence of her seven sons dying, endured this courageously, and with a good spirit, she had hope in the Lord.

(2 Maccabees 7:13) 
Exhorting each of them in their native language, with wisdom, she united the youths’ understanding in piety. Saying: "I do not know how you appeared in my womb: for I did not give you spirit, soul, and sense, nor did I form each of you."

(2 Maccabees 7:14) 
But the Creator of the universe, who formed the birth of man, and who is the inventor of all things, He will restore spirit and life to you in mercy, just as you now despise your souls because of His laws."

(2 Maccabees 7:15) 
Antiochus, however, thought that he was being scorned, and suspected words of reproach. He tried to persuade the remaining son not only with words, but also with an oath, and with friendship, kindness, riches, and authority, and by making him renounce the laws.

(2 Maccabees 7:16) 
But since he did not care about anything, he summoned the mother and exhorted her to follow the youth’s advice and persuade him for his safety.

(2 Maccabees 7:17) 
But the mother, as he was persuading him much, and he was not obeying her, said: "My son, have mercy on me, who carried you for nine months in my womb, and nursed and raised you up to this age, and provided for you."

(2 Maccabees 7:18) 
I beg you, son, look at the universe and the earth, and everything in them, and consider: and know that God made them from nothing, and the race of men."

(2 Maccabees 7:19) 
So, do not fear this executioner, but, being worthy of your brothers, accept death so that I may receive you in mercy."

(2 Maccabees 7:20) 
While she was speaking these things, the youth said: "What are you waiting for? For I do these things, not obeying the commands of the fathers, but of God."

(2 Maccabees 7:21) 
And immediately, he was tortured, so that he might also die. As he died, he said: "Dying at the hands of men, but through the hope of resurrection from God, I am going to eternal life. But as for you, may you never rise again."

(2 Maccabees 7:22) 
After the brothers and the mother, he said: "But I, through the power of Him, am with you, and with the seed of my brothers, and with their souls."

(2 Maccabees 7:23) 
After these words, they and the mother received death in various ways.

(2 Maccabees 8:1) 
Judas Maccabaeus and his soldiers secretly entered the fortresses and called together their relatives. They gathered about six thousand men, including those who remained loyal in Judea and those who had deserted to join them.

(2 Maccabees 8:2) 
They prayed to the Lord to look with favor on the people and to see the injury they were suffering.

(2 Maccabees 8:3) 
They said to Maccabaeus: “What shall we do, now that God has given our enemies such power, to attack us?”

(2 Maccabees 8:4) 
Maccabaeus said in response: “Let us pray and call on the Lord. He may, perhaps, relent. He will do whatever He wishes, and if He doesn't, then He does as He wills.”

(2 Maccabees 8:5) 
After gathering the army and preparing for battle, he said: “It is better to die in battle than to see the evils of our people and our holy places.”

(2 Maccabees 8:6) 
This was the will of heaven.

(2 Maccabees 8:7) 
Then, exhorting them and giving them the watchword, he placed the most valiant men, fifty to a company, and put them in charge.

(2 Maccabees 8:8) 
He told them, “Don’t be afraid in this battle. Let us fight for our souls and avenge ourselves.”

(2 Maccabees 8:9) 
He gave the signal, and they attacked Nicanor in the center, who immediately fell in battle.

(2 Maccabees 8:10) 
They fell together with the majority of the Syrian army, and the rest fled.

(2 Maccabees 8:11) 
They captured their spoils. They cut off Nicanor's head and his hand, which he had so proudly raised. They brought them and hung them near the fortress of Jerusalem.

(2 Maccabees 8:12) 
The Jews greatly rejoiced and glorified this day, and they decreed that this day should be celebrated annually.

(2 Maccabees 8:13) 
Then, gathering together, they said, “May God be praised, for He saves His people.”

(2 Maccabees 8:14) 
They attacked and struck down those who were with Timothy and Bacchides, who were besieging them. They inflicted a great defeat, and the enemy were wounded and fled.

(2 Maccabees 8:15) 
Judas Maccabaeus stationed men in Jerusalem, who were besieging the fortress. He also stationed men in Gazara, Beth-zur, and the fortress. And he put others in charge of other locations.

(2 Maccabees 8:16) 
Timothy and Bacchides then sent their troops to fight against the Jews and they met in battle.

(2 Maccabees 8:17) 
In the battle that followed, about twenty thousand men of Timothy’s army were killed.

(2 Maccabees 8:18) 
But Timothy himself escaped with a few men, and they came to a certain fortress called Gazara, where Chereas was.

(2 Maccabees 8:19) 
Then the Jewish leaders with Maccabaeus laid siege to the fortress for twenty days, with a great assault.

(2 Maccabees 8:20) 
They set up siege towers, war machines, and catapults and they assaulted the place.

(2 Maccabees 8:21) 
Those inside fell into their hands. They set fire to the fortress and burned those inside, and they fell.

(2 Maccabees 8:22) 
Then they went to another fortress and fought against Timothy, who was there.

(2 Maccabees 8:23) 
He gathered about one hundred and twenty thousand men from his army and put him and the others with him in battle.

(2 Maccabees 8:24) 
They fought against Maccabaeus, and as they were about to begin, about twenty thousand men of Timothy’s army were killed. Timothy fled to a fortress where his brother Chereas was.

(2 Maccabees 8:25) 
Then Maccabaeus and those with him besieged the fortress and struck it.

(2 Maccabees 8:26) 
Fearing them, Timothy immediately sent to them, promising to release them and all their possessions, and he swore he would never harm them in any way.

(2 Maccabees 8:27) 
Maccabaeus let them go, but not according to the promise. He killed Chereas, his brother, and Timothy, and he gave the fortress to the citizens.

(2 Maccabees 8:28) 
After this victory they went to Caraca and Charecensi, and to the Jews who were in that place. They thought they were not loyal, and they tried to attack them.

(2 Maccabees 8:29) 
But those inside, seeing their enemies fighting against them, cried out to Maccabaeus, begging him, and saying, “We are righteous, and we are not your enemies.”

(2 Maccabees 8:30) 
Crying out they gave testimony, saying, “We call God as our witness, and we are faithful to you and not to your enemies.”

(2 Maccabees 8:31) 
Maccabaeus received them in friendship and did not cease to harm them, but gathered their people, up to thirty thousand.

(2 Maccabees 8:32) 
He put them to work in the service of the Jews, and he returned with them to Jerusalem and freed the city.

(2 Maccabees 8:33) 
In Jerusalem, he killed those among them who had gone out, because they were in sins and had done evil.

(2 Maccabees 8:34) 
He placed a fortress in Jerusalem with men and fortified it, and they and others guarded it.

(2 Maccabees 8:35) 
And they sent troops to Beth-zur against them and attacked them, and they killed about five thousand men.

(2 Maccabees 8:36) 
Judas, seeing their deeds and their attack, gathered the people to praise the Lord, who saves Israel.

(2 Maccabees 8:37) 
He gathered them and went out against them and struck them.

(2 Maccabees 8:38) 
In the battle, he killed Ptolemy, the son of Dori, and those with him.

(2 Maccabees 8:39) 
He stationed troops in the fortress, and with all of Israel they praised him daily, who is their savior.

(2 Maccabees 9:1) 
So, King Antiochus then departed for the regions of Persia with a great army, because he heard that there was an army in Persia that was resisting him.

(2 Maccabees 9:2) 
For a great problem, which was being handled by the Greeks there, and because there were those in that region who opposed him.

(2 Maccabees 9:3) 
So he departed to Persia with those who were with him, and he heard that there was great wealth in the temple of Nanaea, in Persia.

(2 Maccabees 9:4) 
And he came, and he hoped to take the city, and to obtain the wealth. Because he sent to the city and he obtained it.

(2 Maccabees 9:5) 
So when Antiochus came, and those who were with him, the temple priests immediately came there, and they showed him the reason why they had come.

(2 Maccabees 9:6) 
And they said: “Behold, there is much wealth, which has been entrusted to us. But take it immediately, and do what has been commanded to you.”

(2 Maccabees 9:7) 
And he said, “Immediately, and with haste.” And he arranged it. But when Antiochus entered the temple, and those who were with him, the priests, carrying it, entered.

(2 Maccabees 9:8) 
And when Antiochus, and those who were with him, entered, immediately the temple priests, shouting, and at once in the ashes and on the ground, made a fire.

(2 Maccabees 9:9) 
And when this had been done, and this that was done, they perished, not moderately, and those who were with him, and he was struck by swords, and without fear.

(2 Maccabees 9:10) 
And the whole city, with great exultation, and all who were in it, did it to him.

(2 Maccabees 9:11) 
On the fourth day, he was in great pain, and those who were with him were saddened.

(2 Maccabees 9:12) 
And when this was done, those who were with him, who were his enemies, said: “How powerful and terrifying was this man!”

(2 Maccabees 9:13) 
And Antiochus died, in great pain, and he cried out.

(2 Maccabees 9:14) 
And it happened that many of those who were with him fell, and were killed, and those who were with him. And Philip, who was educated with Antiochus, spoke about his son, and brought him, and he reigned.

(2 Maccabees 9:15) 
And Philip reigned. And he was sick, and troubled, and all who were with him were saddened.

(2 Maccabees 10:1) 
Judas, who was called Maccabeus, and his companions went into the villages secretly, and then arrested those who were there. They gathered those who had not deserted from Judea until they met the forces opposing them.

(2 Maccabees 10:2) 
They called upon the Lord, terrified the surrounding nations, and attacked them. They burned down their fortress and captured it.

(2 Maccabees 10:3) 
When it was time for battle, Judas, forming his company, chose 3,000 men and sent them into battle against Bacchides and his army.

(2 Maccabees 10:4) 
Fearing Bacchides, they withdrew from the camp. Of the 3,000, only 2,680 men remained.

(2 Maccabees 10:5) 
When Judas saw those who had withdrawn, he pursued them.

(2 Maccabees 10:6) 
He turned them to fight, and killed 3,000 men. He then advanced to Bacchides' camp and fought.

(2 Maccabees 10:7) 
Bacchides, fearing his strength, crossed over to the place called Azotus, and then they went with him to fight Judas.

(2 Maccabees 10:8) 
A large crowd gathered and formed a council. They told those with Judas that Judas and his brothers had been killed.

(2 Maccabees 10:9) 
When Judas heard these words, as they were on their way, he said: "There shall be no mercy for me, but we shall break into them."

(2 Maccabees 10:10) 
He fought against them in the city and killed about 20,000 men. The rest they forced to flee into a castle in Azotus.

(2 Maccabees 10:11) 
Taking the spoils, they burned Azotus and everything in it. Then they returned to Judea.

(2 Maccabees 10:12) 
Bacchides and Judas met in the field called Bersa, with Judas having few men.

(2 Maccabees 10:13) 
The men with Judas were exhausted, and when they saw the large crowd, they were afraid and could not stand. Judas and his companions fought to the death.

(2 Maccabees 10:14) 
The men with Judas saw that his brothers and all who were with him had died. They followed them.

(2 Maccabees 10:15) 
They fled into the land.

(2 Maccabees 10:16) 
On the other side, Bacchides and his leaders set up camp and encamped in the land of Judea.

(2 Maccabees 10:17) 
The Jews mourned and said, "How have the strong ones perished, who saved Israel!"

(2 Maccabees 10:18) 
The rest of Judas’ deeds, his wars, and the acts of valor he performed are not written in this book, because they were too great.

(2 Maccabees 10:19) 
After the death of Judas, those who were not pious arose and stirred up all sorts of evil throughout all the borders of Israel.

(2 Maccabees 10:20) 
All wickedness gathered against them. Then those who committed sins arose, and evil conspiracies followed.

(2 Maccabees 10:21) 
A great famine occurred, and the land failed, and all the multitude gathered together. Then Simon rose up, fought for his people, and offered his life for his nation.

(2 Maccabees 10:22) 
He gathered his friends and sent them forth. He gathered those of his own family and strengthened them in justice.

(2 Maccabees 10:23) 
He multiplied the works of the people, and the land was glorified, and all evil was driven out of the land.

(2 Maccabees 10:24) 
He arose in the sight of his people and avenged his nation. He gathered the works of the people and avenged it.

(2 Maccabees 10:25) 
In his days, he prospered in his works and extended his borders.

(2 Maccabees 11:1) 
After this, Judas Maccabaeus and his men entered the villages in secret, and they summoned those in Judea who had not deserted to Philip. And they observed the Sabbath day.

(2 Maccabees 11:2) 
Later, they gathered and made war against Philip. After Philip was defeated and killed with great valor, and the rest who were with him...

(2 Maccabees 11:3) 
Judas and his brothers, along with the best of the Israelites, resolved on that day and followed this course:

(2 Maccabees 11:4) 
They said: “Behold, our enemies are defeated! Let us go up to cleanse the sanctuary and dedicate it.”

(2 Maccabees 11:5) 
Then, the whole multitude gathered and went up to Mount Zion.

(2 Maccabees 11:6) 
They saw the sanctuary deserted, the altar defiled, the gates burned, and plants growing in the courtyards as in a forest or a mountain, and the chambers destroyed.

(2 Maccabees 11:7) 
They tore their garments and mourned with a great lamentation; they put on sackcloth and placed ashes on their heads.

(2 Maccabees 11:8) 
And they fell to the ground and cried out with a loud voice to the universe.

(2 Maccabees 11:9) 
Then Judas ordered the men to fight against those in the fortress until they had cleansed the sanctuary.

(2 Maccabees 11:10) 
He chose priests without blemish and of good will, and they cleansed the sanctuary and removed the stones of defilement to an unclean place.

(2 Maccabees 11:11) 
They considered what to do with the altar of burnt offerings, which had been defiled.

(2 Maccabees 11:12) 
They gave good counsel to tear it down, lest it be reproached to them that the Gentiles had defiled it, and they demolished the altar.

(2 Maccabees 11:13) 
They placed the stones in a fitting place on the mountain of the house until, that is, a prophet should come and give an answer about them.

(2 Maccabees 11:14) 
Then they took whole stones according to the law and built an altar like the former one.

(2 Maccabees 11:15) 
And they built the sanctuary and the interior of the house, and they sanctified the courts.

(2 Maccabees 11:16) 
They made new sacred vessels and brought in the lampstand, the altar of incense, and the table in the temple.

(2 Maccabees 11:17) 
And they burned incense on the altar, and they lit the lamps that were on the lampstand, and they gave light in the temple.

(2 Maccabees 11:18) 
They placed the bread on the table and hung the veils, and they finished the work they had done.

(2 Maccabees 11:19) 
On the twenty-fifth day of the ninth month was the dedication of the temple.

(2 Maccabees 11:20) 
And they offered sacrifices with song, with harps, cymbals, and drums.

(2 Maccabees 11:21) 
And the priests fell on their faces before the temple during the dedication of the temple, and the Levites sang with harps and songs in a great chant.

(2 Maccabees 11:22) 
And all the people adored.

(2 Maccabees 11:23) 
And they sacrificed burnt offerings and offered sacrifices and peace offerings.

(2 Maccabees 11:24) 
And Judas celebrated the dedication of the altar for eight days, and he offered burnt offerings and libations with joy and gladness.

(2 Maccabees 11:25) 
They also renewed the ornaments of the temple itself, both inside and out.

(2 Maccabees 11:26) 
On the twenty-fifth day of the ninth month, in the one hundred and forty-eighth year, they rose early.

(2 Maccabees 11:27) 
And they sacrificed according to the law on the altar of burnt offerings, which they had built.

(2 Maccabees 11:28) 
And according to the time and day when the Gentiles had defiled it, it was dedicated with songs, harps, cymbals, and drums.

(2 Maccabees 11:29) 
And all the people fell on their faces, and adored, and they blessed the one in the universe who had given them success.

(2 Maccabees 11:30) 
And they celebrated the dedication of the altar for eight days in joy, just as they were reminded of the feast of the tabernacles; because recently, they had lived in the tabernacles of the forests and endured wild beasts.

(2 Maccabees 11:31) 
Because of this, they cried out with firm shouts, and they implored the one who had given them success to preserve them to the end.

(2 Maccabees 11:32) 
And Judas and his brothers established for the whole community of the Jews that the days of the dedication of the altar should be celebrated annually with joy and gladness for eight days, at their appointed times.

(2 Maccabees 11:33) 
Moreover, this time, in which they were in Persia, and with King Artaxerxes, and in the time of Maccabaeus...

(2 Maccabees 11:34) 
And they sent letters to the Jews who were in Egypt, to all the provinces of the Jews, greetings from the Jewish brothers—to the Jews who were in Judea, and those who were, greetings.

(2 Maccabees 11:35) 
On the dedication of the altar, and on the twenty-fifth day of the month of Chislev, in the one hundred and forty-eighth year...

(2 Maccabees 11:36) 
We declare all the events that occurred in Maccabees and with his companions, and of their strength and great endurance.

(2 Maccabees 11:37) 
How they affected the Jews in war, and how they fought with courage for the Jewish law, how, for that reason, they were enemies, and how they purified the holy temple and the sanctuary, and they dedicated the altar.

(2 Maccabees 11:38) 
And we will narrate what was done about the others, and about these, in those same times.

(2 Maccabees 11:39) 
And let these things have been said in words; now, therefore, we will bring the speech to an end.

(2 Maccabees 12:1)

(2 Maccabees 12:2)

(2 Maccabees 12:3)

(2 Maccabees 12:4) 
He prepared a path for his men, anticipating the enemy, and rushed upon them.

(2 Maccabees 12:5)

(2 Maccabees 13:1) 
In the one hundred and forty-ninth year, Judas learned that Antiochus Eupator was coming with an army into Judea,

(2 Maccabees 13:2) 
and he brought with him a great force. With him was Alcimus, whom the king had made high priest.

(2 Maccabees 13:3) 
He had been disgraced in his own time because of his betrayal, and he began to strike the people and to kill those who were doing his work.

(2 Maccabees 13:4) 
All the wicked men gathered together and gathered wicked men to themselves, and they became strong, and they controlled the land, and they inflicted a severe plague upon Israel.

(2 Maccabees 13:5) 
And Judas, seeing that the evils had increased, and that the army was in the camps against them, and that the time was approaching for them to advance,

(2 Maccabees 13:6) 
commanded the rest of the people, saying: Do not be afraid of the face of the multitude, nor be terrified by the onslaught of the army.

(2 Maccabees 13:7) 
Remember the great salvation that was made for our fathers in the sea, when Pharaoh pursued them with his army.

(2 Maccabees 13:8) 
And now, if we cry out to the sky, God will have mercy on us and will remember His covenant, and He will crush this army before our faces today.

(2 Maccabees 13:9) 
So they terrified them, and they charged, and the adversaries were thrown into confusion.

(2 Maccabees 13:10) 
And they struck down of them on that day about five thousand men, and the horsemen and foot soldiers were wounded.

(2 Maccabees 13:11) 
And seeing that they had begun to resist, and had become bold, they boldly engaged against them.

(2 Maccabees 13:12) 
And they were confused, and many wounded fell from the rest; others fled into the camp.

(2 Maccabees 13:13) 
And in the camp was Nicanor, who had come from Judea and had been sent by the king.

(2 Maccabees 13:14) 
Hearing that the men of the Jews were stronger, he was terrified and no longer dared to strike.

(2 Maccabees 13:15) 
And on the Sabbath day, Judas went out with his men, and the war flared up.

(2 Maccabees 13:16) 
And they said among themselves, “What shall we do, since these Jews do not cease, but go to fight?”

(2 Maccabees 13:17) 
Then Nicanor commanded on the Sabbath day that they should lay down their arms and go out.

(2 Maccabees 13:18) 
And they went around to the Jews and fought against them, and about three hundred men fell from them on that day.

(2 Maccabees 13:19) 
Judas and his men went to bury the dead, and they began to place them with their fathers.

(2 Maccabees 13:20) 
And they found under the tunics of the slain men the vessels of the idols of Jamnia, which the Jews were forbidden to use according to the law.

(2 Maccabees 13:21) 
And it became clear to everyone that they had fallen for this reason.

(2 Maccabees 13:22) 
Therefore, all blessed the Lord, the just judge, who reveals hidden things.

(2 Maccabees 13:23) 
And Judas, turning back, exhorted the people to guard themselves from sins, because they had seen with their own eyes what had happened on account of the sin of those who had been killed.

(2 Maccabees 13:24) 
Then, gathering them individually, he sent twelve men to Rome to make friendship with them, and to receive help from them.

(2 Maccabees 13:25) 
And he read in them letters, in which they were commanded to receive the Jewish people into friendship and to give them aid if there was any need.

(2 Maccabees 13:26) 
Then the Macedonians went out to war, and Judas and his men besieged Casphin, and they fought.

(2 Maccabees 13:27) 
And those in the camp fled within the walls, and the Jews captured the city.

(2 Maccabees 13:28) 
And when day came, Judas gathered two thousand men from them, and divided them into two divisions for battle.

(2 Maccabees 13:29) 
And they engaged in battle, and they killed about eight thousand of them, and all the rest fled into the land of Galathi.

(2 Maccabees 13:30) 
On that day, Timothy, who was over the camps, was captured by them and was greatly tormented.

(2 Maccabees 13:31) 
And his brothers gathered around him, and they beseeched him and let him go, for they were afraid.

(2 Maccabees 14:1) 
In the one hundred forty-ninth year of the Seleucid era, Demetrius learned that the Romans and those in Asia were fearful of the Jews and were alarmed by them.

(2 Maccabees 14:2) 
So he gathered his wicked men and went out on a military campaign.

(2 Maccabees 14:3) 
He came to the land of Judea and marched toward the city of Jerusalem. He then fought against a large army.

(2 Maccabees 14:4) 
And Macabeus (Judas Maccabaeus) set up camp against him and against his army. Seeing his army coming, he prayed to the Lord and said:

(2 Maccabees 14:5) 
“O Lord, you have always gone before our fathers in battle, throwing down their enemies and giving them into our hands.

(2 Maccabees 14:6) 
Give our army the strength to fight and send a good angel before us to encourage us.

(2 Maccabees 14:7) 
May they be struck with fear and terror by the power of your arm, and let those who blaspheme your holy name perish.”

(2 Maccabees 14:8) 
The battle began, and many soldiers of Demetrius fell and were routed. Judas pursued them from the camp as far as Gaza and the surrounding territories.

(2 Maccabees 14:9) 
The battle brought great defeat on that day.

(2 Maccabees 14:10) 
Now, Jason, who had transported the Jews to his own city, and who had treated them badly and unjustly, betrayed his own people.

(2 Maccabees 14:11) 
Those who were persecuting the Jews along all the roads, and the citizens as well, killed them all and seized their silver and gold.

(2 Maccabees 14:12) 
They took the silver to the city and the rest to Jerusalem. Jason fled from Jerusalem to the city.

(2 Maccabees 14:13) 
The one who was defeated fled to the city of the Arabs and was routed and driven out by Aretas, the prince of the Arabs.

(2 Maccabees 14:14) 
Jason was pursued into the city, where he behaved wickedly, and was driven out into exile.

(2 Maccabees 14:15) 
Then, about three hundred Jews who had gone on the road to the city were captured and handed over to their enemies.

(2 Maccabees 14:16) 
Meanwhile, Menelaus became so wicked and was a most cruel tyrant. He gave orders for the killing of his own citizens.

(2 Maccabees 14:17) 
He entered Jerusalem with the wicked Antiochus, committing all of his evil deeds.

(2 Maccabees 14:18) 
He fell upon the city as if he were an enemy. He came with a scheme to do wrong and acted unjustly.

(2 Maccabees 14:19) 
He struck down many of the people and seized great spoils.

(2 Maccabees 14:20) 
Hearing this, Judas, who was fighting against Demetrius with his army, returned to the land of Judea and immediately went out to Berse and fought against Menelaus.

(2 Maccabees 14:21) 
He hid himself in Jerusalem and near the walls.

(2 Maccabees 14:22) 
While Judas was pressing the battle, the king sent soldiers to him.

(2 Maccabees 14:23) 
Menelaus was struck down and fell in battle, and Judas defeated him.

(2 Maccabees 14:24) 
When Judas went to the king, he pointed out the wickedness of those in the city.

(2 Maccabees 14:25) 
But when the king judged him, he ordered him to go to his death.

(2 Maccabees 14:26) 
For he had committed wickedness in the city, inflicting tortures and all kinds of crimes. Therefore, he was punished.

(2 Maccabees 14:27) 
And a crowd gathered around him and on his side, and they stoned him in the place where he had done wrong.

(2 Maccabees 14:28) 
Of those who were with Menelaus, many perished. He was now alone in Jerusalem, acting unjustly.

(2 Maccabees 14:29) 
When Jason came to trial and was sent to the Lacedaemonians, he was found guilty of acting unjustly.

(2 Maccabees 14:30) 
And those who sent him were punished, since he betrayed both himself and the one whom he had sent.

(2 Maccabees 14:31) 
When the king heard this, he was angry and punished them. Because they were from the city, he judged them and killed them.

(2 Maccabees 14:32) 
He killed many of the citizens and gave others to the soldiers to plunder. He cast out Jason, the wicked man, and the one who acted unjustly towards all, and he drove them into exile.

(2 Maccabees 14:33) 
He returned to Arabia and died in exile, and there was no one to bury him.

(2 Maccabees 14:34) 
And all those who acted against the law, against the holy things, and committed iniquities did not escape punishment.

(2 Maccabees 14:35) 
For even Demetrius, while fighting with his army, surrounded them. He was defeated by Macabeus and those with him and fled into the city.

(2 Maccabees 15:1) 
After this happened, Judas and his brothers were told that Antiochus Eupator had arrived in Judea with a large army,

(2 Maccabees 15:2) 
and with him was Lysias, his regent, commanding the most powerful part of the army: 110,000 infantry, 5,000 cavalry, 22 elephants, and 300 scythed chariots.

(2 Maccabees 15:3) 
Some Jews also came to him, requesting peace and hoping to avoid danger, and Lysias urged them forward.

(2 Maccabees 15:4) 
But he, acting with bad intentions and cruel desire, was invading Judea and the brothers who were mentioned previously.

(2 Maccabees 15:5) 
As he was approaching Jerusalem, a horseman, armed with golden armor, appeared in a vision from the sky, riding in front of him.

(2 Maccabees 15:6) 
Showing the mounted troop to Lysias, the horseman said, "Judas and his brothers were walking in this way, without fear."

(2 Maccabees 15:7) 
When Lysias saw this, they all fell from their horses, terrified, and were scattered.

(2 Maccabees 15:8) 
The Jews, however, were giving thanks to God, rejoicing in what He had done for them. Those who had been sent from the sky to them, were equipped with weapons, ready to fight.

(2 Maccabees 15:9) 
When they were close, they fought fiercely, and the enemies were wounded and scattered, and the rest fled.

(2 Maccabees 15:10) 
As Judas and his brothers were gaining glory and strength, he said, "Do not fight against your enemies, but remain in your place and worship the Lord together."

(2 Maccabees 15:11) 
Then, singing hymns in their presence and giving thanks to the Lord, who had acted wonderfully for them, brave and strong men arose and fought the battle, wounding more than 5,000 of the enemy.

(2 Maccabees 15:12) 
Seeing his armies defeated and the strongest soldiers fleeing, Antiochus Eupator became afraid and, against his will, agreed to peace with the Jews.

(2 Maccabees 15:13) 
The Jews, after agreeing to peace, handed over the weapons to their citizens and returned the garrisons, provisions, and everything they had taken to the camp.

(2 Maccabees 15:14) 
Antiochus and Lysias, after receiving everything, returned to the king through Judea with praise.

(2 Maccabees 15:15) 
After this, as they were returning to King Antiochus, a certain Philip, who was one of the king's advisors and was troubled, said to the king, "We don't control the kingdom; it's being governed with a garrison and wealth."

(2 Maccabees 15:16) 
But also, the Jews who fled from Judea are disturbing us and are adopting their customs."

(2 Maccabees 15:17) 
Therefore, I say, it is necessary for us to depart and make peace with the Jews. Otherwise, they and those who have helped them will harm us."

(2 Maccabees 15:18) 
After saying these things, Antiochus immediately became enraged and ordered Philip to be seized and killed, and he died many days later.

(2 Maccabees 15:19) 
After a great sacrifice, the Jews, and his sons, gathered to the destruction of the temple, and for this cause, they all came together.

(2 Maccabees 15:20) 
The gathering was made so that they would be seen, and the Jews, in their place, fought for the law and their homeland.

(2 Maccabees 15:21) 
Philip and those with him withdrew and fought, coming to the aid of those who were with the Jews.

(2 Maccabees 15:22) 
Then Judas, gathered with the other Jews in the appointed place, fought.

(2 Maccabees 15:23) 
And he shouted in their hearing: "God is just and strong! God is just and strong!"

(2 Maccabees 15:24) 
And he set up a banner, upon which there was a golden sign. Everyone who came forward in strength and danger, perished.

(2 Maccabees 15:25) 
The enemies were thrown down, but Judas, the son of Matthias, especially, waged war with his men.

(2 Maccabees 15:26) 
When the Jews heard of Judas's fame and what he had done, fearing him, they remained in his hands, as they were.

(2 Maccabees 15:27) 
And they praised the Lord, who had given them victory.

(Matthew 1:1) 
This is the book of the ancestry of Jesus Christ, the Son of David, son of Abraham.

(Matthew 1:2) 
Abraham was the father of Isaac. Isaac was the father of Jacob. Jacob was the father of Judah and his brothers:

(Matthew 1:3) 
Judah was the father of Phares and Zaram. Their mother was Thamar. Phares was the father of Esrom. Esrom was the father of Aram:

(Matthew 1:4) 
Aram was the father of Aminadab. Aminadab was the father of Naasson. Naasson was the father of Salmon:

(Matthew 1:5) 
Salmon was the father of Booz, whose mother was Rahab. Booz was the father of Obed, whose mother was Ruth. Obed was the father of Jesse:

(Matthew 1:6) 
Jesse was the father of King David. King David was the father of Solomon, whose mother was the wife of Uriah:

(Matthew 1:7) 
Solomon was the father of Rehoboam. Rehoboam was the father of Abijah. Abijah was the father of Asa:

(Matthew 1:8) 
Asa was the father of Jehoshaphat. Jehoshaphat was the father of Joram. Joram was the father of Uzziah:

(Matthew 1:9) 
Uzziah was the father of Jotham. Jotham was the father of Ahaz. Ahaz was the father of Hezekiah:

(Matthew 1:10) 
Hezekiah was the father of Manasseh. Manasseh was the father of Amos. Amos was the father of Josiah:

(Matthew 1:11) 
Josiah was the father of Jechoniah and his brothers, at the time of the exile to Babylon.

(Matthew 1:12) 
After the exile to Babylon, Jechoniah was the father of Shealtiel. Shealtiel was the father of Zerubbabel:

(Matthew 1:13) 
Zerubbabel was the father of Abiud. Abiud was the father of Eliakim. Eliakim was the father of Azor:

(Matthew 1:14) 
Azor was the father of Zadok. Zadok was the father of Achim. Achim was the father of Eliud:

(Matthew 1:15) 
Eliud was the father of Eleazar. Eleazar was the father of Matthan. Matthan was the father of Jacob:

(Matthew 1:16) 
Jacob was the father of Joseph, the husband of Mary, and Mary was the mother of Jesus, who is called Christ.

(Matthew 1:17) 
Thus there were fourteen generations from Abraham to David, fourteen generations from David to the exile to Babylon, and fourteen generations from the exile to Christ.

(Matthew 1:18) 
This is how Jesus Christ was born. His mother Mary was engaged to Joseph, but before they were married, she became pregnant through the power of the Holy Spirit.

(Matthew 1:19) 
Because Joseph was a righteous man and did not want to publicly disgrace her, he decided to quietly divorce her.

(Matthew 1:20) 
But as he considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, “Joseph, son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary as your wife, for what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit.

(Matthew 1:21) 
She will give birth to a son, and you are to name him Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.”

(Matthew 1:22) 
All of this took place to fulfill what the Lord had said through the prophet:

(Matthew 1:23) 
“Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel,” which means, “God with us.”

(Matthew 1:24) 
When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him. He took Mary as his wife.

(Matthew 1:25) 
But he did not know her as a husband until she gave birth to a son, and he named him Jesus.

(Matthew 2:1) 
When Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judea during the reign of King Herod, behold, wise men from the east came to Jerusalem,

(Matthew 2:2) 
saying, “Where is he who has been born king of the Jews? For we saw his star in the east and have come to worship him.”

(Matthew 2:3) 
King Herod heard this, he was troubled, and all Jerusalem with him.

(Matthew 2:4) 
He assembled all the chief priests and scribes of the people, and inquired of them where the Christ was to be born.

(Matthew 2:5) 
They said to him, “In Bethlehem of Judea.” For so it is written by the prophet:

(Matthew 2:6) 
“And you, Bethlehem, land of Judah, are by no means least among the rulers of Judah; for from you shall come a ruler who will shepherd my people Israel.”

(Matthew 2:7) 
Then Herod secretly called the wise men and learned from them the time when the star had appeared.

(Matthew 2:8) 
And he sent them to Bethlehem, saying, “Go and search diligently for the child; and when you have found him, bring me word, that I too may come and worship him.”

(Matthew 2:9) 
When they had heard the king, they went their way; and lo, the star which they had seen in the east went before them, till it came to rest over the place where the child was.

(Matthew 2:10) 
When they saw the star, they rejoiced exceedingly with great joy.

(Matthew 2:11) 
And going into the house, they saw the child with Mary his mother, and they fell down and worshiped him. Then, opening their treasures, they offered him gifts, gold, frankincense, and myrrh.

(Matthew 2:12) 
And being warned in a dream not to return to Herod, they departed to their own country by another way.

(Matthew 2:13) 
Now when they had departed, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream, saying, “Get up, take the child and his mother, and flee to Egypt, and stay there until I tell you; for Herod is going to search for the child to destroy him.”

(Matthew 2:14) 
So he got up, took the child and his mother by night, and went to Egypt,

(Matthew 2:15) 
and remained there until the death of Herod. This was to fulfill what the Lord had spoken by the prophet, saying, “Out of Egypt I called my son.”

(Matthew 2:16) 
Then when Herod saw that he had been tricked by the wise men, he became very enraged, and sent and slew all the male children who were in Bethlehem and in all its vicinity, from two years old and under, according to the time which he had determined from the wise men.

(Matthew 2:17) 
Then was fulfilled what was spoken by the prophet Jeremiah, saying,

(Matthew 2:18) 
“A voice was heard in Ramah, weeping and loud lamentation, Rachel weeping for her children; and she refused to be comforted, because they are no more.”

(Matthew 2:19) 
But when Herod was dead, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph in Egypt,

(Matthew 2:20) 
saying, “Get up, take the child and his mother, and go into the land of Israel, for those who sought the child’s life are dead.”

(Matthew 2:21) 
So he got up, took the child and his mother, and came into the land of Israel.

(Matthew 2:22) 
But when he heard that Archelaus was reigning over Judea in place of his father Herod, he was afraid to go there; and being warned in a dream, he withdrew to the region of Galilee,

(Matthew 2:23) 
and came and lived in a city called Nazareth, that what was spoken by the prophets might be fulfilled, that he would be called a Nazarene.

(Matthew 3:1) 
At that time, John the Baptist came, preaching in the desert of Judea,

(Matthew 3:2) 
and saying, "Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand!"

(Matthew 3:3) 
For this is the one about whom the prophet Isaiah spoke, saying: 'The voice of one crying in the desert, prepare the way of the Lord, make straight His paths.'

(Matthew 3:4) 
Now John himself wore a garment made of camel's hair, and a leather belt around his waist, and his food was locusts and wild honey.

(Matthew 3:5) 
Then Jerusalem, all of Judea, and all the region around the Jordan River went out to him,

(Matthew 3:6) 
and were baptized by him in the Jordan River, confessing their sins.

(Matthew 3:7) 
But when he saw many Pharisees and Sadducees coming to his baptism, he said to them, "You brood of vipers! Who warned you to flee from the wrath to come?

(Matthew 3:8) 
Therefore produce fruit worthy of repentance.

(Matthew 3:9) 
And do not presume to say to yourselves, 'We have Abraham as our father.' For I say to you that God is able to raise up children for Abraham from these stones.

(Matthew 3:10) 
And now the axe is laid to the root of the trees. Therefore every tree that does not bear good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire.

(Matthew 3:11) 
I baptize you with water for repentance, but He who is coming after me is mightier than I, whose sandals I am not worthy to carry. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.

(Matthew 3:12) 
His winnowing fork is in His hand, and He will thoroughly cleanse His threshing floor, and gather His wheat into the barn; but He will burn the chaff with unquenchable fire."

(Matthew 3:13) 
Then Jesus came from Galilee to the Jordan to John, to be baptized by him.

(Matthew 3:14) 
But John tried to prevent Him, saying, "I need to be baptized by You, and do You come to me?"

(Matthew 3:15) 
But Jesus answered and said to him, "Permit it now, for thus it is fitting for us to fulfill all righteousness." Then he allowed Him.

(Matthew 3:16) 
When He had been baptized, Jesus came up immediately from the water; and behold, the heavens were opened to Him, and He saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and alighting upon Him.

(Matthew 3:17) 
And suddenly a voice came from heaven, saying, "This is My beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased."

(Matthew 4:1) 
Then the Holy Spirit sent Jesus to the desert to be tested by the devil.

(Matthew 4:2) 
After fasting for forty days and forty nights, He became hungry.

(Matthew 4:3) 
The tempter then came to Him, and said, "If You are the Son of God, tell these stones to become bread."

(Matthew 4:4) 
But Jesus responded: "The Scriptures say, 'Man does not live by bread alone, but by every word that comes from the mouth of God.'"

(Matthew 4:5) 
Then the devil took Him to the holy city, and set Him on the pinnacle of the temple,

(Matthew 4:6) 
saying, "If You are the Son of God, throw Yourself down, because it is written, 'He will command His angels concerning you.' And 'On their hands they will bear you up, lest at any time you dash your foot against a stone.'

(Matthew 4:7) 
Jesus said to him, "Again, it is written, 'You shall not tempt the Lord your God.'

(Matthew 4:8) 
Again, the devil took Him to a very high mountain, and showed Him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory,

(Matthew 4:9) 
and said to Him, "All these things I will give You if You fall down and worship me."

(Matthew 4:10) 
Then Jesus said to him, "Go away, Satan! For it is written, 'You shall worship the Lord your God, and Him only you shall serve.'

(Matthew 4:11) 
Then the devil left Him, and angels came and ministered to Him.

(Matthew 4:12) 
But when Jesus heard that John had been put in prison, He departed to Galilee.

(Matthew 4:13) 
And leaving Nazareth, He came and dwelt in Capernaum, which is by the sea, in the borders of Zebulun and Naphtali,

(Matthew 4:14) 
that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet Isaiah, saying:

(Matthew 4:15) 
'The land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, the way of the sea beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles,

(Matthew 4:16) 
the people who sat in darkness have seen a great light, and upon those who sat in the region and shadow of death, light has dawned.'

(Matthew 4:17) 
From that time, Jesus began to preach and to say, "Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand."

(Matthew 4:18) 
And walking by the Sea of Galilee, He saw two brothers, Simon, who is called Peter, and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.

(Matthew 4:19) 
And He said to them, "Follow Me, and I will make you fishers of men."

(Matthew 4:20) 
And immediately they left their nets and followed Him.

(Matthew 4:21) 
And going on from there, He saw two other brothers, James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, in the boat with Zebedee their father, mending their nets. And He called them.

(Matthew 4:22) 
And immediately they left the nets and their father, and followed Him.

(Matthew 4:23) 
And Jesus went about all Galilee, teaching in their synagogues, preaching the gospel of the kingdom, and healing all kinds of sickness and all kinds of disease among the people.

(Matthew 4:24) 
Then His fame went throughout all Syria; and they brought to Him all sick people who were afflicted with various diseases and torments, and those who were demon-possessed, epileptics, and paralytics; and He healed them.

(Matthew 4:25) 
And great multitudes followed Him from Galilee, and from Decapolis, and from Jerusalem, and from Judea, and from beyond the Jordan.

(Matthew 5:1) 
Seeing the crowds, He went up onto the mountain, and when He sat down, His disciples gathered around Him.

(Matthew 5:2) 
Opening His mouth, He taught them, saying:

(Matthew 5:3) 
Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

(Matthew 5:4) 
Blessed are the meek: for they shall possess the earth.

(Matthew 5:5) 
Blessed are they who mourn: for they shall be comforted.

(Matthew 5:6) 
Blessed are they who hunger and thirst for righteousness: for they shall have their fill.

(Matthew 5:7) 
Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.

(Matthew 5:8) 
Blessed are the clean of heart: for they shall see God.

(Matthew 5:9) 
Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God.

(Matthew 5:10) 
Blessed are they who suffer persecution for justice's sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

(Matthew 5:11) 
Blessed are you when they shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you, falsely, for My sake:

(Matthew 5:12) 
Be glad and rejoice, for your reward is very great in heaven. For so they persecuted the prophets who were before you.

(Matthew 5:13) 
You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its savor, with what shall it be salted? It is good for nothing anymore but to be cast out and trodden under the feet of men.

(Matthew 5:14) 
You are the light of the world. A city set on a mountain cannot be hidden.

(Matthew 5:15) 
Neither do they light a lamp and put it under a basket, but upon a lampstand, that it may shine to all who are in the house.

(Matthew 5:16)
