they were angry that Peter and John were teaching the people and proclaiming in Jesus the resurrection from the dead,

(Acts 4:3) 
and they seized them and put them in prison until the next day, because it was already evening.

(Acts 4:4) 
However, many of those who heard the message believed, and the number of men came to about five thousand.

(Acts 4:5) 
On the next day, the rulers, elders, and scribes gathered in Jerusalem:

(Acts 4:6) 
Annas the high priest, Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and all those who were of the priestly race.

(Acts 4:7) 
And putting Peter and John in the middle, they questioned them: “By what power or by what name did you do this?”

(Acts 4:8) 
Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them: “Leaders of the people and elders,

(Acts 4:9) 
if we are being examined today about a good deed done to a weak man, and by what means he was healed,

(Acts 4:10) 
then know this, you and all the people of Israel: It is by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified and whom God raised from the dead, that this man is standing before you healed.

(Acts 4:11) 
This is the stone that was rejected by you, the builders, and has become the cornerstone:

(Acts 4:12) 
And there is salvation in no one else, because there is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved.”

(Acts 4:13) 
Now when they saw the boldness of Peter and John, and realized that they were uneducated men, they were astonished, and they recognized that they had been with Jesus.

(Acts 4:14) 
And seeing the man who had been healed standing with them, they had nothing to say against it.

(Acts 4:15) 
But when they had ordered them to leave the council, they conferred with one another, saying:

(Acts 4:16) 
“What are we going to do with these men? For a notable sign has been done through them, which is obvious to all who dwell in Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.

(Acts 4:17) 
But so that it may spread no further among the people, let us warn them that they speak no more to anyone in this name.”

(Acts 4:18) 
So they called them and commanded them not to speak or teach at all in the name of Jesus.

(Acts 4:19) 
But Peter and John answered them, “Judge for yourselves whether it is right in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to God.

(Acts 4:20) 
For we cannot help but speak about what we have seen and heard.”

(Acts 4:21) 
So when they had further threatened them, they let them go, because they could not find any way to punish them, on account of the people, because all were glorifying God for what had been done.

(Acts 4:22) 
For the man on whom this miracle of healing had been performed was over forty years old.

(Acts 4:23) 
When they were released, they went to their own people and reported everything that the chief priests and the elders had said to them.

(Acts 4:24) 
And when they heard it, with one accord they raised their voices to God and said: “Lord, you are the one who made the universe, the earth, the sea, and everything in them.

(Acts 4:25) 
By the Holy Spirit you said through the mouth of our father David, your servant: ‘Why did the nations rage, and the peoples devise empty things?

(Acts 4:26) 
The kings of the earth rose up, and the rulers gathered together against the Lord and against His Christ.’

(Acts 4:27) 
For truly in this city there were gathered together against your holy servant Jesus, whom you anointed, both Herod and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles and the peoples of Israel,

(Acts 4:28) 
to do whatever your hand and your plan had predestined to happen.

(Acts 4:29) 
And now, Lord, look upon their threats and grant to your servants to speak your word with all boldness,

(Acts 4:30) 
while you stretch out your hand to heal, and signs and wonders are performed through the name of your holy servant Jesus.”

(Acts 4:31) 
And when they had prayed, the place in which they were gathered was shaken, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and spoke the word of God with boldness.

(Acts 4:32) 
Now the multitude of those who believed were of one heart and soul, and no one claimed that anything of what he possessed was his own, but they held everything in common.

(Acts 4:33) 
And with great power the apostles gave testimony to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and great grace was upon them all.

(Acts 4:34) 
For there was not anyone needy among them, because all who owned land or houses sold them and brought the proceeds of what was sold,

(Acts 4:35) 
and laid it at the apostles’ feet. And distribution was made to each as any had need.

(Acts 4:36) 
Now Joseph, whom the apostles called Barnabas (which means, Son of encouragement), a Levite, a native of Cyprus,

(Acts 4:37) 
having a field, sold it and brought the money and laid it at the apostles’ feet.

(Acts 5:1) 
Then Peter rose up and said, “Brothers, listen. God chose me to preach the Gospel to the Gentiles, so they could hear and believe.”

(Acts 5:2) 
And God, who knows the mind and heart of every man, also gave the Holy Spirit to them, just as He did to us,

(Acts 5:3) 
making no distinction between us, since He purified their hearts through faith.

(Acts 5:4) 
So, why do you now put God to the test, placing a burden on the necks of these disciples which neither we nor our fathers have been able to carry?

(Acts 5:5) 
But we believe it is by the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ that we are saved, as they are.”

(Acts 5:6) 
And all the assembly of the apostles remained silent. They were listening to Barnabas and Paul as they told of the wonders and signs God had worked through them among the Gentiles.

(Acts 5:7) 
After they were done speaking, James addressed the assembly, saying, “Brothers, listen to me.

(Acts 5:8) 
Simeon has related how God first showed His concern by gathering a people for his own name out of the Gentiles.

(Acts 5:9) 
And the words of the prophets agree with this, as it is written:

(Acts 5:10) 
“After this I will return and rebuild the fallen house of David; I will rebuild its ruins and restore it,

(Acts 5:11) 
so that the rest of humanity may seek the Lord, including all the Gentiles over whom my name has been proclaimed.”

(Acts 5:12) 
God has shown us this from the beginning of the world.

(Acts 5:13) 
Therefore, it is my judgment that we should not make it difficult for those Gentiles who are turning to God,

(Acts 5:14) 
but we should instead write to them to abstain from things polluted by idols, from unlawful marriage, from the meat of strangled animals, and from blood.

(Acts 5:15) 
For from ancient times Moses has had those who proclaim him in every town, as he is read every Sabbath in the synagogues.”

(Acts 5:16) 
Then the apostles and the elders, with the whole church, decided to send men chosen from among them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Judas, called Barsabbas, and Silas, leading men among the brothers.

(Acts 5:17) 
They sent the following letter by their hand: “The apostles and the elders, your brothers, to the brothers in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia, who are Gentiles: Greetings.

(Acts 5:18) 
We have heard that some of us went out from us without our authorization. They troubled your souls with what they said and upset you, telling you that you must be circumcised and keep the law. We gave them no such instructions.

(Acts 5:19) 
So we all agreed to choose men to send to you, along with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,

(Acts 5:20) 
men who have risked their lives for the sake of our Lord Jesus Christ.

(Acts 5:21) 
We have therefore sent Judas and Silas, who will also tell you the same things by word of mouth.

(Acts 5:22) 
For it has seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to place no further burden on you than these essential things:

(Acts 5:23) 
that you abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, from blood, from the meat of strangled animals, and from unlawful marriage. If you keep yourselves from these things, you will do well. Farewell.”

(Acts 5:24) 
So they left, went down to Antioch, and gathered the whole assembly. Then they delivered the letter.

(Acts 5:25) 
When they read it, they rejoiced over the encouragement it provided.

(Acts 5:26) 
Judas and Silas, being prophets themselves, encouraged the brothers with many words and strengthened them.

(Acts 5:27) 
After they spent some time there, they were sent off with peace by the brothers to those who had sent them.

(Acts 5:28) 
But Silas decided to remain there.

(Acts 5:29) 
Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord, along with many others.

(Acts 5:30) 
After some time, Paul said to Barnabas, “Let us go back and visit the brothers in every town where we have preached the word of the Lord, and see how they are doing.”

(Acts 5:31) 
Barnabas wanted to take John, called Mark, along with them.

(Acts 5:32) 
But Paul didn’t think it was right to take him, because he had deserted them in Pamphylia and hadn’t accompanied them in their work.

(Acts 5:33) 
There was a sharp disagreement, so that they separated from each other, and Barnabas took Mark with him and sailed to Cyprus.

(Acts 5:34) 
Paul chose Silas and left, commended by the brothers to the grace of God.

(Acts 5:35) 
He traveled through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.

(Acts 6:1) 
Now, in those days, as the number of disciples grew, a complaint arose among the Hellenists against the Hebrews, because their widows were being neglected in the daily distribution.

(Acts 6:2) 
The Twelve summoned the whole group of disciples and said: “It is not right for us to neglect the word of God in order to serve tables.

(Acts 6:3) 
Therefore, brothers, select seven men from among you, of good repute, full of the Holy Spirit and wisdom, whom we may appoint for this task.

(Acts 6:4) 
But we will devote ourselves to prayer and to the ministry of the word.”

(Acts 6:5) 
This proposal pleased the whole group, and they chose Stephen, a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit, along with Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolaus, a proselyte from Antioch.

(Acts 6:6) 
These they presented to the apostles, and after they prayed, they laid their hands on them.

(Acts 6:7) 
And the word of God continued to spread. The number of the disciples in Jerusalem increased greatly, and a great many of the priests were becoming obedient to the faith.

(Acts 6:8) 
Now Stephen, full of grace and power, was working great wonders and signs among the people.

(Acts 6:9) 
But some of those who belonged to the Synagogue of the Freedmen (as it was called), and of the Cyrenians, and of the Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and Asia, rose up and disputed with Stephen.

(Acts 6:10) 
And they could not withstand the wisdom and the Spirit with which he was speaking.

(Acts 6:11) 
Then they secretly instigated men to say, “We have heard him speak blasphemous words against Moses and God.”

(Acts 6:12) 
And they stirred up the people, the elders, and the scribes; and they came upon him and seized him and brought him before the council.

(Acts 6:13) 
They set up false witnesses who said, “This man never stops speaking against this holy place and the law.

(Acts 6:14) 
For we have heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place and will change the customs that Moses delivered to us.”

(Acts 6:15) 
And gazing at him, all who sat in the council saw that his face was like the face of an angel.

(Acts 7:1) 
The high priest then said: “Are these things so?”

(Acts 7:2) 
And Stephen said: "Brothers and fathers, listen. The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham while he was in Mesopotamia, before he went to live in Charran.

(Acts 7:3) 
And God said to him: 'Leave your land and your family, and come to the land that I will show you.'

(Acts 7:4) 
Then Abraham went out from the land of the Chaldeans, and lived in Charran. And from there, after his father died, God brought him into this land, where you now live.

(Acts 7:5) 
And God gave him no inheritance in it, not even a foot of land. But God promised to give it to him as a possession, and to his descendants after him, even though Abraham had no son then.

(Acts 7:6) 
And God spoke: 'His descendants will be strangers in a foreign land, and they will be enslaved and mistreated for four hundred years.'

(Acts 7:7) 
'But I will judge the nation that they will serve,' God said. 'And after that, they will come out and serve Me in this place.'

(Acts 7:8) 
And God gave Abraham the covenant of circumcision. And so Abraham fathered Isaac, and Abraham circumcised Isaac on the eighth day. And Isaac fathered Jacob, and Jacob fathered the twelve patriarchs.

(Acts 7:9) 
And the patriarchs, jealous of Joseph, sold him into Egypt, but God was with him,

(Acts 7:10) 
and rescued him from all his tribulations. And God gave Joseph favor and wisdom in the sight of Pharaoh, king of Egypt. And Pharaoh made Joseph governor over Egypt and over all his household.

(Acts 7:11) 
Now a famine came upon all of Egypt and Canaan, and there was great hardship, and our fathers could not find food.

(Acts 7:12) 
But when Jacob heard that there was grain in Egypt, he sent our fathers there first.

(Acts 7:13) 
And on the second trip, Joseph was recognized by his brothers, and Joseph's family was revealed to Pharaoh.

(Acts 7:14) 
So Joseph sent for his father Jacob, and for his whole family, seventy-five people in all.

(Acts 7:15) 
So Jacob went down to Egypt, and he died there, as did our fathers.

(Acts 7:16) 
And they were brought back to Shechem, and placed in the tomb that Abraham had bought for a sum of silver from the sons of Hamor, the son of Shechem.

(Acts 7:17) 
But as the time drew near for the fulfillment of the promise that God had made to Abraham, the people grew and multiplied in Egypt,

(Acts 7:18) 
until another king arose in Egypt, who did not know Joseph.

(Acts 7:19) 
This king, scheming against our race, mistreated our fathers, and forced them to abandon their infants, so that they would not be kept alive.

(Acts 7:20) 
It was at this time that Moses was born, and he was pleasing to God. And Moses was nourished for three months in his father's house.

(Acts 7:21) 
But when Moses was abandoned, Pharaoh's daughter took him up and raised him as her own son.

(Acts 7:22) 
And Moses was educated in all the wisdom of the Egyptians, and he was powerful in his words and in his deeds.

(Acts 7:23) 
Now when Moses was forty years old, he decided to visit his brothers, the sons of Israel.

(Acts 7:24) 
And when he saw one of them being wronged, Moses defended him, and avenged the one who was being oppressed by striking down the Egyptian.

(Acts 7:25) 
Moses thought that his brothers would understand that God was giving them salvation by his hand, but they did not understand.

(Acts 7:26) 
And on the next day Moses appeared to them as they were fighting, and he tried to reconcile them in peace, saying: 'Men, you are brothers! Why do you wrong each other?'

(Acts 7:27) 
But the one who was wronging his neighbor pushed him away, saying: 'Who made you a ruler and a judge over us?'

(Acts 7:28) 
'Do you want to kill me as you killed the Egyptian yesterday?'

(Acts 7:29) 
Then Moses fled at this word, and became a stranger in the land of Midian, where he fathered two sons.

(Acts 7:30) 
And when forty years were completed, an Angel appeared to him in the wilderness of Mount Sinai, in a flame of fire from a bush.

(Acts 7:31) 
When Moses saw the vision, he marveled at it. And as he approached to examine it, the voice of the Lord came to him,

(Acts 7:32) 
'I am the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.' But Moses, trembling, did not dare to consider it.

(Acts 7:33) 
And the Lord said to him: 'Take off the sandals from your feet, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.'

(Acts 7:34) 
'I have surely seen the affliction of My people who are in Egypt, and I have heard their groaning, and I have come down to deliver them. And now come, I will send you to Egypt.'

(Acts 7:35) 
This Moses, whom they rejected, saying: 'Who made you a ruler and a judge?' God sent Moses as both a ruler and a redeemer by the hand of the Angel who appeared to him in the bush.

(Acts 7:36) 
Moses led them out, doing wonders and signs in the land of Egypt, and in the Red Sea, and in the wilderness for forty years.

(Acts 7:37) 
This is that Moses who said to the sons of Israel: 'God will raise up for you a prophet from among your brothers, just like me.'

(Acts 7:38) 
This is the Moses who was in the assembly in the wilderness with the Angel who spoke to him on Mount Sinai, and with our fathers; Moses received living words to give to us.

(Acts 7:39) 
But our fathers would not obey Moses. They rejected him, and in their hearts they turned back to Egypt,

(Acts 7:40) 
saying to Aaron: 'Make us gods to go before us, for as for this Moses, who led us out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has become of him.'

(Acts 7:41) 
And they made a calf in those days, and offered a sacrifice to the idol, and were rejoicing in the works of their own hands.

(Acts 7:42) 
But God turned away from them and gave them over to serve the host of heaven, as it is written in the book of the prophets: 'Did you offer Me sacrifices and offerings during the forty years in the wilderness, O house of Israel?'

(Acts 7:43) 
'And you took up the tent of Moloch and the star of your god Remphan, the images that you made to worship. So I will send you into exile beyond Babylon.'

(Acts 7:44) 
Our fathers had the tabernacle of testimony in the wilderness, as He who spoke to Moses directed, so that Moses should make it according to the pattern he had seen.

(Acts 7:45) 
Our fathers, in turn, brought it in with Joshua when they took possession of the land of the Gentiles, whom God drove out before our fathers, until the days of David.

(Acts 7:46) 
David found favor in the sight of God, and he asked to find a dwelling place for the God of Jacob.

(Acts 7:47) 
But it was Solomon who built a house for God.

(Acts 7:48) 
However, the Most High does not dwell in buildings made by hands, as the prophet says:

(Acts 7:49) 
'Heaven is My throne, and earth is the footstool of My feet. What house will you build for Me?' says the Lord, 'or what is the place of My rest?'

(Acts 7:50) 
'Has not My hand made all these things?'

(Acts 7:51) 
You stiff-necked people, uncircumcised in heart and ears, you always resist the Holy Spirit; as your fathers did, so do you.

(Acts 7:52) 
Which of the prophets did your fathers not persecute? And they killed those who foretold the coming of the Righteous One, of whom you have now become the betrayers and murderers.

(Acts 7:53) 
You received the law as delivered by angels, and you did not keep it.

(Acts 7:54) 
Now when they heard these things, they were cut to the heart, and they gnashed their teeth at him.

(Acts 7:55) 
But Stephen, full of the Holy Spirit, looked intently into the universe, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing at the right hand of God.

(Acts 7:56) 
And Stephen said: "Behold, I see the sky opened, and the Son of man standing at the right hand of God."

(Acts 7:57) 
Then they cried out with a loud voice, and stopped their ears, and rushed at him together,

(Acts 7:58) 
and they cast him out of the city and began to stone him. And the witnesses laid down their garments at the feet of a young man named Saul.

(Acts 7:59) 
And they were stoning Stephen as he called out, saying, "Lord Jesus, receive my spirit."

(Acts 7:60) 
And he knelt down and cried out with a loud voice, saying, "Lord, do not hold this sin against them." And when he had said this, he fell asleep in the Lord.

(Acts 8:1) 
Saul approved of the killing of Stephen. A great persecution began against the Church in Jerusalem that very day, and all the Christians were scattered throughout Judea and Samaria—except for the apostles, who stayed in Jerusalem.

(Acts 8:2) 
Some devout men buried Stephen, and they mourned for him.

(Acts 8:3) 
Saul ravaged the Church, entering house after house, dragging off both men and women, and putting them in prison.

(Acts 8:4) 
So those who had been scattered went about preaching the good news of God.

(Acts 8:5) 
Philip went down to the city of Samaria and preached Christ to them.

(Acts 8:6) 
The crowds paid close attention to what Philip said, because they were united in listening to him and seeing the miracles that he was performing.

(Acts 8:7) 
For unclean spirits, crying out loudly, came out of many who were possessed by them, and many who were paralyzed or lame were cured.

(Acts 8:8) 
So there was great joy in that city.

(Acts 8:9) 
Now a certain man named Simon had previously practiced magic in the city of Samaria and had amazed the Samaritan people. He claimed to be someone great,

(Acts 8:10) 
and all the people, from the least to the greatest, listened to him, saying, “This man is the power of God, which is called ‘the Great Power.’”

(Acts 8:11) 
They were devoted to him because for a long time he had amazed them with his magic.

(Acts 8:12) 
But when they believed Philip as he proclaimed the good news about the Kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.

(Acts 8:13) 
Even Simon himself believed. And after he was baptized, he stayed close to Philip. When he saw the signs and great miracles that were being performed, he was amazed.

(Acts 8:14) 
Now when the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent Peter and John to them.

(Acts 8:15) 
When they arrived, they prayed that the Samaritans might receive the Holy Spirit.

(Acts 8:16) 
The Spirit had not yet come down on any of them, they had only been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.

(Acts 8:17) 
Then Peter and John placed their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.

(Acts 8:18) 
When Simon saw that the Spirit was given through the laying on of the apostles’ hands, he offered them money,

(Acts 8:19) 
saying, “Give me this power also, so that anyone on whom I lay my hands may receive the Holy Spirit.”

(Acts 8:20) 
But Peter replied, “May your money perish with you, because you thought you could buy the gift of God with money!

(Acts 8:21) 
You have no part or share in this matter, because your heart is not right before God.

(Acts 8:22) 
Repent of this wickedness of yours, and pray to the Lord that, if possible, your heart’s intent may be forgiven.

(Acts 8:23) 
For I see that you are in the gall of bitterness and in the bondage of iniquity.”

(Acts 8:24) 
Then Simon answered, “Pray to the Lord for me, that nothing of what you have said may happen to me.”

(Acts 8:25) 
So when they had testified and proclaimed the word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem, preaching the good news in many villages of the Samaritans.

(Acts 8:26) 
Then an angel of the Lord said to Philip, “Get up and go south to the road that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza.” (This road is desolate.)

(Acts 8:27) 
So he got up and went. There he met an Ethiopian eunuch, a high official of Candace, the queen of the Ethiopians, who was in charge of her entire treasury. This man had come to Jerusalem to worship,

(Acts 8:28) 
and he was returning home; he was sitting in his chariot and reading the prophet Isaiah.

(Acts 8:29) 
Then the Spirit said to Philip, “Go over and join this chariot.”

(Acts 8:30) 
So Philip ran up to him and heard him reading the prophet Isaiah. He asked, “Do you understand what you are reading?”

(Acts 8:31) 
He replied, “How can I, unless someone guides me?” And he invited Philip to come up and sit with him.

(Acts 8:32) 
Now the passage of Scripture that he was reading was this: “He was led like a sheep to the slaughter, and as a lamb before its shearer is silent, so he did not open his mouth.

(Acts 8:33) 
In his humiliation justice was denied him. Who will tell of his generation? For his life is taken away from the earth.”

(Acts 8:34) 
The eunuch replied to Philip, “Please tell me, who is the prophet talking about? Is it about himself or about someone else?”

(Acts 8:35) 
Then Philip opened his mouth, and beginning with this passage, he preached the good news about Jesus to him.

(Acts 8:36) 
And as they were going along the road, they came to some water; and the eunuch said, “Look, here is water! What prevents me from being baptized?”

(Acts 8:37) 
And Philip said, “If you believe with all your heart, you may.” And he replied, “I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.”

(Acts 8:38) 
Then he ordered the chariot to stop, and both of them, Philip and the eunuch, went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.

(Acts 8:39) 
When they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord suddenly took Philip away, and the eunuch did not see him again, but went on his way rejoicing.

(Acts 8:40) 
But Philip found himself at Azotus, and as he passed through the region, he proclaimed the good news in all the cities until he came to Caesarea.

(Acts 9:1) 
Meanwhile, Saul was still threatening the Lord’s disciples. He wanted to kill them, so he went to the high priest,

(Acts 9:2) 
and asked for letters to the synagogues in Damascus. He wanted to arrest any men or women who followed the Way of Jesus, so that he could bring them to Jerusalem in chains.

(Acts 9:3) 
As he was traveling and nearing Damascus, suddenly a light shone from the sky all around him.

(Acts 9:4) 
He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him, “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?”

(Acts 9:5) 
Saul asked, “Who are you, Lord?” The voice replied, “I am Jesus, the one you are persecuting.

(Acts 9:6) 
Now get up and go into the city, where you will be told what you must do.”

(Acts 9:7) 
The men traveling with him stood speechless. They heard the voice, but they could not see anyone.

(Acts 9:8) 
Saul got up from the ground, and when he opened his eyes, he could see nothing. So they took him by the hand and led him into Damascus.

(Acts 9:9) 
He could not see for three days, and he neither ate nor drank.

(Acts 9:10) 
In Damascus there was a disciple named Ananias. The Lord spoke to him in a vision, saying, “Ananias.” Ananias answered, “Here I am, Lord.”

(Acts 9:11) 
The Lord said to him, “Get up and go to the street called Straight. Ask at the house of Judas for a man from Tarsus named Saul. He is praying,

(Acts 9:12) 
and he has seen a man named Ananias coming in and laying his hands on him so that he can see again.”

(Acts 9:13) 
Ananias answered, “Lord, I have heard many reports about this man and all the harm he has done to your holy people in Jerusalem.

(Acts 9:14) 
He has received authority from the chief priests to arrest everyone who calls on your name.”

(Acts 9:15) 
But the Lord said to him, “Go, for this man is my chosen instrument to proclaim my name to the Gentiles and their kings and to the people of Israel.

(Acts 9:16) 
I will show him how much he must suffer for my name.”

(Acts 9:17) 
Then Ananias went to the house and entered it. He placed his hands on Saul and said, “Brother Saul, the Lord Jesus, who appeared to you on the road as you were coming here, has sent me so that you may see again and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”

(Acts 9:18) 
Immediately something like scales fell from Saul’s eyes, and he could see again. He got up and was baptized,

(Acts 9:19) 
and after taking some food, he regained his strength. Saul stayed with the disciples in Damascus for some days.

(Acts 9:20) 
Immediately he began to preach in the synagogues that Jesus is the Son of God.

(Acts 9:21) 
All those who heard him were astonished and asked, “Isn’t this the man who raised havoc in Jerusalem among those who call on this name? And hasn’t he come here to take them as prisoners to the chief priests?”

(Acts 9:22) 
Yet Saul grew more and more powerful and baffled the Jews living in Damascus by proving that Jesus is the Messiah.

(Acts 9:23) 
After many days had passed, the Jews plotted to kill him,

(Acts 9:24) 
but Saul learned of their plan. They were watching the city gates day and night in order to kill him.

(Acts 9:25) 
But his followers helped him escape during the night by lowering him in a basket through an opening in the wall.

(Acts 9:26) 
When Saul came to Jerusalem, he tried to join the disciples, but they were all afraid of him, not believing that he really was a disciple.

(Acts 9:27) 
But Barnabas took him and brought him to the apostles. He told them how Saul on his journey had seen the Lord and that the Lord had spoken to him, and how in Damascus he had preached fearlessly in the name of Jesus.

(Acts 9:28) 
So Saul stayed with them and moved about freely in Jerusalem, speaking boldly in the name of the Lord.

(Acts 9:29) 
He talked and debated with the Hellenists, but they tried to kill him.

(Acts 9:30) 
When the believers learned of this, they took him down to Caesarea and sent him off to Tarsus.

(Acts 9:31) 
Then the church throughout Judea, Galilee and Samaria enjoyed a time of peace and was strengthened. Living in the fear of the Lord and encouraged by the Holy Spirit, it increased in numbers.

(Acts 9:32) 
As Peter traveled about the country, he went to visit the Lord’s people who lived in Lydda.

(Acts 9:33) 
There he found a man named Aeneas, who was paralyzed and had been bedridden for eight years.

(Acts 9:34) 
Peter said to him, “Aeneas, Jesus Christ heals you. Get up and roll up your mat.” Immediately Aeneas got up,

(Acts 9:35) 
and all those who lived in Lydda and Sharon saw him. And many turned to the Lord.

(Acts 9:36) 
In Joppa there was a disciple named Tabitha (which, when translated, is Dorcas), who was always doing good and helping the poor.

(Acts 9:37) 
About that time she became sick and died, and her body was washed and placed in an upstairs room.

(Acts 9:38) 
Lydda was near Joppa; so when the disciples heard that Peter was in Lydda, they sent two men to him and urged him, “Please come at once!”

(Acts 9:39) 
Peter went with them, and when he arrived, he was taken upstairs to the room. All the widows stood around him, crying and showing him the robes and other clothing that Dorcas had made while she was still with them.

(Acts 9:40) 
Peter sent them all out of the room; then he got down on his knees and prayed. Turning toward the dead woman, he said, “Tabitha, get up.” She opened her eyes, and seeing Peter, she sat up.

(Acts 9:41) 
He gave her his hand and helped her to her feet. Then he called the believers and the widows and presented her to them alive.

(Acts 9:42) 
This became known all over Joppa, and many people believed in the Lord.

(Acts 9:43) 
Peter stayed in Joppa for some time with a tanner named Simon.

(Acts 10:1) 
There was a certain man in Caesarea, whose name was Cornelius, a centurion of the cohort which is called the Italian,

(Acts 10:2) 
a religious man, and one that feared God with all his house, giving much alms to the people, and always praying to God.

(Acts 10:3) 
This man saw in a vision manifestly, about the ninth hour of the day, an angel of God coming in to him, and saying to him: Cornelius.

(Acts 10:4) 
And he, beholding him, being seized with fear, said: What is it, Lord?

(Acts 10:5) 
And he said to him: Thy prayers and thy alms are ascended for a memorial in the sight of God.

(Acts 10:6) 
And now send men to Joppe, and call for one Simon who is surnamed Peter:

(Acts 10:7) 
He lodgeth with one Simon a tanner, whose house is by the sea side. He will tell thee what thou must do.

(Acts 10:8) 
And when the angel who spoke to Cornelius was departed, he called two of his servants, and a soldier that was religious, of them that were with him,

(Acts 10:9) 
To whom when he had related all, he sent them to Joppe.

(Acts 10:10) 
And on the next day, whilst they were going on their journey, and drawing nigh to the city, Peter went up to the higher parts of the house to pray, about the sixth hour.

(Acts 10:11) 
And being hungry, he was desirous to taste something. And whilst they were preparing, there came upon him an ecstasy of mind:

(Acts 10:12) 
And he saw the heaven opened, and a certain vessel descending, as it were a great sheet, let down from heaven by four corners to the earth,

(Acts 10:13) 
Wherein were all manner of fourfooted beasts, and creeping things of the earth, and fowls of the air.

(Acts 10:14) 
And there came a voice to him: Arise, Peter; kill and eat.

(Acts 10:15) 
But Peter said: Far be it from me; for I have never eaten any thing that is common and unclean.

(Acts 10:16) 
And the voice came again to him the second time: That which God hath made clean, do not thou call common.

(Acts 10:17) 
And this was done thrice: and incontinently the vessel was taken up into heaven.

(Acts 10:18) 
And as Peter was doubting within himself, what the vision that he had seen might mean, behold, the men that were sent from Cornelius, inquiring for Simon's house, stood at the gate.

(Acts 10:19) 
And when they had called, they asked if Simon, who is surnamed Peter, were lodged there.

(Acts 10:20) 
And as Peter was thinking of the vision, the Spirit said to him: Behold, three men seek thee.

(Acts 10:21) 
Arise, therefore, and go down, and do not hesitate to go with them: for I have sent them.

(Acts 10:22) 
Then Peter, going down to the men, said: Behold, I am he whom you seek. What is the cause for which you are come?

(Acts 10:23) 
Who said: Cornelius, the centurion, a just man, and one that feareth God, and that hath good testimony from all the nation of the Jews, received an answer from God by a holy angel, to send for thee into his house, and to hear words from thee.

(Acts 10:24) 
Then bringing them in, he lodged them. And the day following, he arose and went with them: and some of the brethren from Joppe accompanied him.

(Acts 10:25) 
And the next day they entered into Cesarea. And Cornelius was waiting for them, having called together his kinsmen and special friends.

(Acts 10:26) 
And it came to pass that when Peter was come in, Cornelius came to meet him, and fell down and worshipped him.

(Acts 10:27) 
But Peter lifted him up, saying: Arise, I myself also am a man.

(Acts 10:28) 
And as he was talking with him, he went in, and found many that were come together:

(Acts 10:29) 
And he said to them: You know how unlawful it is for a man that is a Jew, to keep company or to come unto one of another nation: but God hath shewed to me, not to call any man common or unclean.

(Acts 10:30) 
Therefore I came without any doubt, being sent for. I ask, therefore, for what cause have you sent for me?

(Acts 10:31) 
And Cornelius said: Four days ago, I was fasting until this hour, and I prayed in my house at the ninth hour, and behold a man stood before me in white clothing, and said:

(Acts 10:32) 
Cornelius, thy prayer is heard, and thy alms are in remembrance in the sight of God.

(Acts 10:33) 
Send therefore to Joppe, and call hither Simon, who is surnamed Peter: he lodgeth in the house of Simon a tanner, by the sea side. He will tell thee what thou must do.

(Acts 10:34) 
Immediately therefore I sent to thee: and thou hast done well in coming. Now therefore are we all here present in thy sight, to hear all things whatsoever are commanded thee by God.

(Acts 10:35) 
And Peter opening his mouth, said: In very deed I perceive that God is not a respecter of persons:

(Acts 10:36) 
But in every nation, he that feareth him, and worketh justice, is acceptable to him.

(Acts 10:37) 
God sent the Son to the children of Israel, to announce peace through Jesus Christ: (he is the Lord of all things).

(Acts 10:38) 
You know what happened, the Word spoken throughout all Judea. It all started in Galilee, after the baptism that John proclaimed.

(Acts 10:39) 
The mission of Jesus from Nazareth: How God anointed Him with the Holy Spirit and with power, and he passed by doing good and healing all that were oppressed by the devil, for God was with Him.

(Acts 10:40) 
And we are witnesses of all things that he did in the land of the Jews and in Jerusalem: whom they killed, hanging him upon a tree.

(Acts 10:41) 
Him God raised up the third day, and gave him to be made manifest,

(Acts 10:42) 
Not to all the people, but to witnesses preordained by God, even to us, who did eat and drink with him after he rose again from the dead:

(Acts 10:43) 
And he commanded us to preach to the people, and to testify that it is he who was appointed by God to be judge of the living and of the dead.

(Acts 10:44) 
To him all the prophets give testimony, that through his name all receive remission of sins, who believe in him.

(Acts 10:45) 
While Peter was yet speaking these words, the Holy Ghost fell on all them that heard the word.

(Acts 10:46) 
And they of the circumcision, who believed, were astonished at them that were come with Peter, because that the grace of the Holy Ghost was also poured out upon the Gentiles.

(Acts 10:47) 
For they heard them speaking with tongues, and magnifying God. Then Peter answered:

(Acts 10:48) 
Can any man forbid water, that these should not be baptized, who have received the Holy Ghost as well as we?

(Acts 10:49) 
And he commanded them to be baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ. Then they besought him to tarry with them some days.

(Acts 11:1) 
The apostles and the brothers and sisters throughout Judea then heard that the Gentiles had received the word of God.

(Acts 11:2) 
When Peter went up to Jerusalem, those of the circumcision began to argue with him,

(Acts 11:3) 
saying, "Why did you go in to uncircumcised men and eat with them?"

(Acts 11:4) 
Peter then began to explain the matter to them in order.

(Acts 11:5) 
He said, "I was in the city of Joppa, praying; and in a trance I saw a vision: a certain vessel descended, as it were a great sheet, let down from heaven by four corners, and it came even to me.

(Acts 11:6) 
In this vision I looked and saw the four-footed beasts of the earth, and wild animals, and creeping things, and the birds of the sky.

(Acts 11:7) 
And I heard a voice saying to me, 'Rise, Peter; kill and eat.'

(Acts 11:8) 
But I said, 'Not so, Lord; for nothing common or unclean has ever entered my mouth.'

(Acts 11:9) 
But the voice answered again from heaven, 'What God has cleansed, do not you call common.'

(Acts 11:10) 
Now this was done three times, and all were drawn up again into heaven.

(Acts 11:11) 
And behold, immediately three men stood before the house in which I was, sent from Caesarea to me.

(Acts 11:12) 
And the Spirit told me to go with them, making no distinction. And these six brothers went with me also, and we entered into the man's house.

(Acts 11:13) 
And he told us how he had seen an angel in his house, standing and saying to him, 'Send to Joppa and get Simon, who is called Peter,'

(Acts 11:14) 
who will speak words to you by which you will be saved, you and all your household.'

(Acts 11:15) 
And as I began to speak, the Holy Spirit fell on them, just as on us in the beginning.

(Acts 11:16) 
Then I remembered the word of the Lord, how He said, 'John indeed baptized with water, but you shall be baptized with the Holy Spirit.'

(Acts 11:17) 
If then God gave the same gift to them as to us when we believed in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I that I could withstand God?

(Acts 11:18) 
When they heard these things, they held their peace and glorified God, saying, "Then God has also granted to the Gentiles repentance to life."

(Acts 11:19) 
Now they who were scattered by the persecution that arose over Stephen traveled as far as Phoenicia, and Cyprus, and Antioch, speaking the word to no one except the Jews only.

(Acts 11:20) 
But there were some of them, men of Cyprus and Cyrene, who, when they had come to Antioch, spoke also to the Greeks, preaching the Lord Jesus.

(Acts 11:21) 
And the hand of the Lord was with them, and a great number believed and turned to the Lord.

(Acts 11:22) 
Then tidings of these things came to the ears of the church in Jerusalem, and they sent Barnabas to Antioch.

(Acts 11:23) 
When he had come and seen the grace of God, he was glad, and he exhorted them all that with purpose of heart they should continue with the Lord.

(Acts 11:24) 
For he was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and of faith. And a great number of people were added to the Lord.

(Acts 11:25) 
Then Barnabas went to Tarsus to seek Saul.

(Acts 11:26) 
And when he had found him, he brought him to Antioch. So it was that for a whole year they assembled with the church and taught a great number of people. And the disciples were first called Christians in Antioch.

(Acts 11:27) 
And in these days prophets came from Jerusalem to Antioch.

(Acts 11:28) 
Then one of them, named Agabus, stood up and showed by the Spirit that there would be a great famine throughout all the world, which also happened in the days of Claudius Caesar.

(Acts 11:29) 
Then the disciples, each according to his ability, determined to send relief to the brethren dwelling in Judea.

(Acts 11:30) 
This they also did, and sent it to the elders by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.

(Acts 12:1) 
At that same time, Herod the king had some members of the Church arrested.

(Acts 12:2) 
He killed James, the brother of John, with a sword.

(Acts 12:3) 
When he saw that this pleased the Jews, he had Peter arrested as well. This happened during the days of Unleavened Bread.

(Acts 12:4) 
Having arrested him, he put him in prison, entrusting him to four squads of soldiers to guard him, intending to bring him before the people after the Passover.

(Acts 12:5) 
So Peter was kept in prison, but the Church was praying to God for him, constantly.

(Acts 12:6) 
The night before Herod was going to bring him out, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains, and guards were in front of the door, guarding the prison.

(Acts 12:7) 
Suddenly, an angel of the Lord appeared, and light shone in the cell. He struck Peter on the side and woke him up, saying, "Get up quickly!" And the chains fell from his hands.

(Acts 12:8) 
The angel said to him, "Put on your belt and put on your sandals." And he did so. The angel said to him, "Wrap your cloak around you and follow me."

(Acts 12:9) 
Peter went out and followed him, though he didn't know that what the angel was doing was real; he thought he was seeing a vision.

(Acts 12:10) 
They passed the first and second guards and came to the iron gate leading to the city. It opened for them on its own. They went out and walked along one street, and then the angel left him.

(Acts 12:11) 
Then Peter came to himself and said, "Now I know for certain that the Lord has sent His angel and rescued me from Herod and from everything the Jewish people were hoping for."

(Acts 12:12) 
When he realized this, he went to the house of Mary, the mother of John, also called Mark, where many people were gathered and praying.

(Acts 12:13) 
Peter knocked at the door, and a servant girl named Rhoda came to answer it.

(Acts 12:14) 
Recognizing Peter's voice, she was so overjoyed that she didn't open the door, but ran in and announced that Peter was standing at the door.

(Acts 12:15) 
They said to her, "You're out of your mind." But she insisted that it was true. They said, "It must be his angel."

(Acts 12:16) 
But Peter kept knocking. When they opened the door and saw him, they were astonished.

(Acts 12:17) 
He motioned to them with his hand to be quiet and then told them how the Lord had brought him out of prison. "Tell James and the other brothers about this," he said, and then he left and went to another place.

(Acts 12:18) 
In the morning, there was a great commotion among the soldiers about what had happened to Peter.

(Acts 12:19) 
After Herod had a thorough search for him and did not find him, he interrogated the guards and ordered that they be executed. Then Herod went down from Judea to Caesarea and stayed there.

(Acts 12:20) 
Herod was furious with the people of Tyre and Sidon, but they came to him in a body. After getting Blastus, the king's personal aide, on their side, they asked for peace, because their country depended on Herod's country for its food supply.

(Acts 12:21) 
On the appointed day, Herod, wearing royal robes, sat on his throne and delivered a speech to them.

(Acts 12:22) 
The crowd began to shout, "This is the voice of a god, not of a man."

(Acts 12:23) 
Immediately, because Herod did not give praise to God, the angel of the Lord struck him down, and he was eaten by worms and died.

(Acts 12:24) 
But the Word of the Lord continued to spread and flourish.

(Acts 12:25) 
Then Barnabas and Saul returned to Jerusalem after completing their mission, taking John, also called Mark, with them.

(Acts 13:1) 
Now in the Church that was in Antioch there were prophets and teachers: Barnabas, and Simon who was called Niger, and Lucius of Cyrene, and Manaen, who was brought up with Herod the tetrarch, and Saul.

(Acts 13:2) 
As they were ministering to the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said: “Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them.”

(Acts 13:3) 
Then, after they had fasted and prayed and laid hands on them, they sent them away.

(Acts 13:4) 
So they, being sent on a mission by the Holy Spirit, went down to Seleucia; and from there they sailed to Cyprus.

(Acts 13:5) 
And when they came to Salamis, they preached the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews. And they had John in their ministry.

(Acts 13:6) 
And when they had gone through the whole island as far as Paphos, they found a certain sorcerer, a false prophet, a Jew whose name was Bar-Jesus,

(Acts 13:7) 
who was with the proconsul Sergius Paulus, a man of intelligence. This man called for Barnabas and Saul and was eager to hear the word of God.

(Acts 13:8) 
But Elymas the sorcerer (for so is the meaning of his name) was resisting them, seeking to turn the proconsul away from the faith.

(Acts 13:9) 
But Saul, who is also called Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, looking intently at him,

(Acts 13:10) 
said: “O full of all deceit and all fraud, you son of the devil, enemy of all righteousness, will you not cease to pervert the straight ways of the Lord?

(Acts 13:11) 
And now, behold, the hand of the Lord is upon you, and you will be blind, not seeing the sun for a time.” And immediately a mist and darkness fell upon him, and he went about seeking someone to lead him by the hand.

(Acts 13:12) 
Then the proconsul, when he saw what had happened, believed, being astonished at the teaching of the Lord.

(Acts 13:13) 
Now when Paul and his companions set sail from Paphos, they came to Pamphylia, to Perga. And John, departing from them, returned to Jerusalem.

(Acts 13:14) 
But they, passing on from Perga, came to Antioch in Pisidia; and on the Sabbath they went into the synagogue and sat down.

(Acts 13:15) 
After the reading of the Law and the Prophets, the rulers of the synagogue sent to them, saying, “Men, brothers, if there is any word of exhortation for the people, speak.”

(Acts 13:16) 
Then Paul stood up and, motioning with his hand, said: “Men of Israel, and you who fear God, listen.

(Acts 13:17) 
The God of the people of Israel chose our fathers and exalted the people when they were sojourners in the land of Egypt, and with a high arm he led them out of it,

(Acts 13:18) 
and for about forty years he put up with them in the wilderness.

(Acts 13:19) 
And when he had destroyed seven nations in the land of Canaan, he distributed their land to them by lot,

(Acts 13:20) 
as it were, for about four hundred and fifty years. And after that he gave them judges until Samuel the prophet.

(Acts 13:21) 
And then they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul the son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.

(Acts 13:22) 
And when he had removed him, he raised up David to be their king, of whom he bore witness and said, ‘I have found in David the son of Jesse, a man after my heart, who will do all my will.’

(Acts 13:23) 
From the offspring of this man, according to the promise, God brought to Israel a Savior, Jesus,

(Acts 13:24) 
before whose coming John had preached a baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.

(Acts 13:25) 
And as John was finishing his course, he said, ‘What do you suppose that I am? I am not the one. But behold, one comes after me, whose sandal I am not worthy to untie.’

(Acts 13:26) 
“Men, brothers, children of the family of Abraham, and those among you who fear God, to you the word of this salvation has been sent.

(Acts 13:27) 
For those who live in Jerusalem and their rulers, because they did not recognize him, nor understand the voices of the prophets which are read every Sabbath, fulfilled these prophecies by condemning him.

(Acts 13:28) 
And though they found in him no cause for death, they asked Pilate to have him executed.

(Acts 13:29) 
And when they had fulfilled all that was written of him, they took him down from the tree and laid him in a tomb.

(Acts 13:30) 
But God raised him from the dead on the third day.

(Acts 13:31) 
And for many days he appeared to those who had come up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are now his witnesses to the people.

(Acts 13:32) 
And we bring you good news of the promise that was made to the fathers, that God has fulfilled this promise to their children by raising up Jesus,

(Acts 13:33) 
as it is also written in the second Psalm, ‘You are my Son; today I have become your Father.’

(Acts 13:34) 
And that he raised him from the dead, no more to return to corruption, he has spoken in this way: ‘I will give you the holy and sure blessings of David.’

(Acts 13:35) 
Therefore he says also in another place, ‘You will not let your Holy One see corruption.’

(Acts 13:36) 
For David, after he had served the purpose of God in his own generation, fell asleep and was laid with his fathers and saw corruption,

(Acts 13:37) 
but he whom God raised up did not see corruption.

(Acts 13:38) 
Let it be known to you therefore, men, brothers, that through this man forgiveness of sins is proclaimed to you, and by him everyone who believes is freed from everything from which you could not be freed by the law of Moses.

(Acts 13:39) 
and by him everyone who believes is freed from everything from which you could not be freed by the law of Moses.

(Acts 13:40) 
Beware, therefore, lest what is said in the prophets should come about:

(Acts 13:41) 
“Look, you scoffers, and wonder and perish; for I am doing a work in your days, a work that you will not believe, even if one tells it to you.”

(Acts 13:42) 
As they went out, they begged that these words might be spoken to them the next Sabbath.

(Acts 13:43) 
And after the meeting of the synagogue broke up, many of the Jews and devout converts to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas, who, as they spoke with them, urged them to continue in the grace of God.

(Acts 13:44) 
The next Sabbath almost the whole city gathered to hear the word of God.

(Acts 13:45) 
But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with jealousy and began to contradict what was spoken by Paul, reviling him.

(Acts 13:46) 
And Paul and Barnabas spoke out boldly, saying, “It was necessary that the word of God be spoken first to you. But since you reject it and judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, behold, we are turning to the Gentiles.

(Acts 13:47) 
For so the Lord has commanded us, saying, ‘I have made you a light for the Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.’

(Acts 13:48) 
And when the Gentiles heard this, they began rejoicing and glorifying the word of the Lord, and as many as were appointed to eternal life believed.

(Acts 13:49) 
And the word of the Lord was spreading throughout the whole region.

(Acts 13:50) 
But the Jews incited the devout women of high standing and the leading men of the city, and stirred up persecution against Paul and Barnabas and drove them out of their district.

(Acts 13:51) 
But they shook off the dust from their feet against them and went to Iconium.

(Acts 13:52) 
And the disciples were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.

(Acts 14:1) 
In Iconium, Paul and Barnabas continued to enter into the synagogue. They preached, and a large multitude of both Jews and Greeks believed.

(Acts 14:2) 
But the Jews who refused to believe stirred up the Gentiles and poisoned their minds against the brothers.

(Acts 14:3) 
Paul and Barnabas remained there a long time, speaking boldly, trusting in the Lord. God’s grace caused them to speak in power and perform miracles.

(Acts 14:4) 
The city was divided. Some sided with the Jews, but others sided with the Apostles.

(Acts 14:5) 
When both the Gentiles and the Jews, along with their rulers, violently attacked the Apostles, intending to abuse them and stone them...

(Acts 14:6) 
...they fled to the cities of Lystra and Derbe in Lycaonia and all the surrounding region.

(Acts 14:7) 
They continued to preach there the Gospel.

(Acts 14:8) 
In Lystra, there was a man sitting who was crippled in his feet. He had been lame from birth, and had never walked.

(Acts 14:9) 
He listened to Paul speaking. Paul looked at him, and seeing that he had the faith to be healed,

(Acts 14:10) 
said in a loud voice, "Stand upright on your feet!" And he leaped up and began to walk.

(Acts 14:11) 
When the crowds saw what Paul had done, they shouted in the Lycaonian language, saying, “The gods have come down to us, in the likeness of men!”

(Acts 14:12) 
They called Barnabas “Jupiter,” and Paul “Mercury,” because Paul was the chief speaker.

(Acts 14:13) 
The priest of Jupiter, whose temple was in front of the city, brought bulls and garlands to the gates, and with the crowds, wanted to offer sacrifice.

(Acts 14:14) 
But when the Apostles, Barnabas and Paul, heard this, they tore their clothes and rushed into the crowd, shouting:

(Acts 14:15) 
“Men, why are you doing this? We are also mortals, like you. We are preaching so that you turn from these empty things and come to the living God, who created the universe and the earth and the sea and all that is in them.

(Acts 14:16) 
In generations past, he allowed all the Gentiles to follow their own ways.

(Acts 14:17) 
Yet he did not leave himself without a witness. He did good, giving you rain from the sky and fruitful seasons, filling your hearts with food and joy.

(Acts 14:18) 
Even saying these things, it was barely enough to restrain the crowds from sacrificing to them.

(Acts 14:19) 
Then some Jews arrived from Antioch and Iconium, and they persuaded the crowds. They stoned Paul and dragged him outside the city, thinking he was dead.

(Acts 14:20) 
But when the disciples gathered around him, he rose up and went back into the city. The next day, he went with Barnabas to Derbe.

(Acts 14:21) 
After preaching the Gospel to that city and making many disciples, they returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch,

(Acts 14:22) 
strengthening the souls of the disciples, encouraging them to remain in the faith, because we must endure many tribulations to enter into the Kingdom of God.

(Acts 14:23) 
Then they appointed presbyters for them in each church, with prayer and fasting, and commended them to the Lord in whom they had believed.

(Acts 14:24) 
Then, after passing through Pisidia, they came to Pamphylia.

(Acts 14:25) 
After they spoke the word of the Lord in Perga, they went down to Attalia,

(Acts 14:26) 
and from there they sailed to Antioch, where they had been commended to the grace of God for the work they had completed.

(Acts 14:27) 
When they arrived, and gathered the Church, they reported all the things God had done with them, and that He had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles.

(Acts 14:28) 
They stayed there with the disciples for a long time.

(Acts 15:1) 
Certain men came down from Judea, and taught the brothers: “Unless you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses, you cannot be saved.”

(Acts 15:2) 
When there was no small dissension and debate by Paul and Barnabas against them, they determined that Paul and Barnabas, and certain others of them, should go up to the apostles and priests in Jerusalem, about this question.

(Acts 15:3) 
They therefore, having been led forward by the Church, were passing through Phoenicia and Samaria, narrating the conversion of the Gentiles: and they were making great joy to all the brothers.

(Acts 15:4) 
When they came to Jerusalem, they were received by the Church and the apostles and priests, announcing how great a thing God had done with them.

(Acts 15:5) 
Certain ones of the sect of the Pharisees, who had believed, rose up, saying: “It is necessary to circumcise them and command them to keep the law of Moses.”

(Acts 15:6) 
The apostles and the elders assembled to consider the word about this.

(Acts 15:7) 
When there was much debate, Peter rose up and said to them: “Men, brothers, you know that from the ancient days God chose among us, that the Gentiles should hear the word of the Gospel by my mouth, and believe.”

(Acts 15:8) 
And God, who knows the hearts, bore witness, giving to them the Holy Spirit, just as to us:

(Acts 15:9) 
And He made no distinction between us and them, purifying their hearts by faith.

(Acts 15:10) 
Now therefore why are you tempting God, to put a yoke upon the necks of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we could bear?

(Acts 15:11) 
But through the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, we believe that we shall be saved, in the same way as they also [shall be saved].

(Acts 15:12) 
Then all the multitude fell silent: and they listened to Barnabas and Paul, relating how great signs and wonders God had done among the Gentiles by them.

(Acts 15:13) 
And after they were silent, James answered, saying: “Men, brothers, hear me.

(Acts 15:14) 
Simon has recounted how God first visited, taking from the Gentiles a holy people for His name.

(Acts 15:15) 
And with this agree the words of the prophets, as it is written:

(Acts 15:16) 
“After these things I will return, and I will rebuild the tabernacle of David that has fallen: and I will rebuild its ruins, and I will raise it up:

(Acts 15:17) 
so that the rest of men may seek the Lord, and all the Gentiles, upon whom My name is called, says the Lord, who does these things.”

(Acts 15:18) 
Known from the beginning is His work with God.

(Acts 15:19) 
Wherefore I judge that those who are converted to God from the Gentiles should not be disturbed,

(Acts 15:20) 
but that they should write to them that they abstain from the contaminations of idols, and from fornication, and from what is strangled, and from blood.

(Acts 15:21) 
For Moses, from the generations of old, has in every city those who preach him in the synagogues, where he is read every Sabbath.

(Acts 15:22) 
Then it pleased the apostles and the elders, with the whole Church, to choose men from among themselves, and to send to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas, Judas, who was called Barsabas, and Silas, leading men among the brothers.

(Acts 15:23) 
Writing by their hands: “The apostles and the elder brothers to those in Antioch, and Syria, and Cilicia, brothers from the Gentiles, greeting.”

(Acts 15:24) 
“Because we have heard that certain ones, who went out from among us, have disturbed you with words, subverting your souls, to whom we did not give any command:

(Acts 15:25) 
it has pleased us, gathered together in one place, to choose men and send them to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,

(Acts 15:26) 
men who have delivered their souls for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.

(Acts 15:27) 
We have sent therefore Judas and Silas, who also will tell you the same things.”

(Acts 15:28) 
“For it has seemed good to the Holy Spirit, and to us, to impose upon you no further burden than these necessary things:

(Acts 15:29) 
that you abstain from things sacrificed to idols, and from blood, and from what is strangled, and from fornication: from which keeping yourselves, you shall do well. Farewell.”

(Acts 15:30) 
So they, having been dismissed, went to Antioch: and gathering the multitude together, they delivered the letter.

(Acts 15:31) 
When they had read it, they rejoiced over the consolation.

(Acts 15:32) 
Judas and Silas, they also being prophets, with many words exhorted the brothers, and they strengthened them.

(Acts 15:33) 
And after they had spent some time there, they were dismissed with peace by the brothers to those who had sent them.

(Acts 15:34) 
But it seemed good to Silas to remain there.

(Acts 15:35) 
But Paul and Barnabas continued in Antioch, teaching and evangelizing with many others the word of the Lord.

(Acts 15:36) 
After some days, Paul said to Barnabas: “Let us return and visit the brothers through all the cities in which we have preached the word of the Lord, to see how they are doing.”

(Acts 15:37) 
And Barnabas wanted to take with them also John, who was called Mark.

(Acts 15:38) 
But Paul was asking him not to take this one with them, who had departed from them in Pamphylia, and had not gone with them to the work.

(Acts 15:39) 
There was a disagreement, so that they departed from each other, and Barnabas, taking Mark, sailed to Cyprus:

(Acts 15:40) 
But Paul, having chosen Silas, set out, having been delivered to the grace of God by the brothers.

(Acts 15:41) 
And he was going through Syria and Cilicia, confirming the churches, commanding them to keep the precepts of the Apostles and elders.

(Acts 16:1) 
Paul next traveled to Derbe and Lystra. There was a disciple named Timothy there, the son of a Jewish woman who was a believer, and his father was a Gentile.

(Acts 16:2) 
The brothers at Lystra and Iconium gave a good report of him.

(Acts 16:3) 
Paul wanted Timothy to go with him. He had Timothy circumcised because of the Jews who were in those places, for they all knew that his father was a Gentile.

(Acts 16:4) 
As they traveled from town to town, they passed along the decisions that had been made by the apostles and elders in Jerusalem, and the new churches obeyed these commands.

(Acts 16:5) 
So the churches were strengthened in the faith and grew daily in numbers.

(Acts 16:6) 
Then they traveled through the Phrygian and Galatian regions, being prevented by the Holy Spirit from speaking the word in Asia.

(Acts 16:7) 
When they came to Mysia, they tried to go to Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not allow them.

(Acts 16:8) 
So they passed by Mysia and went down to Troas.

(Acts 16:9) 
During the night, Paul had a vision. A man of Macedonia was standing and begging him, saying, “Come over to Macedonia and help us.”

(Acts 16:10) 
As soon as Paul had seen the vision, we immediately tried to go to Macedonia, concluding that God had called us to preach the gospel to them.

(Acts 16:11) 
Setting sail from Troas, we went straight to Samothrace, and the next day to Neapolis.

(Acts 16:12) 
From there we went to Philippi, a leading city of the district of Macedonia and a Roman colony. We remained in this city for some days.

(Acts 16:13) 
On the Sabbath, we went outside the gate to the riverside, where we thought there would be a place of prayer. We sat down and spoke to the women who had gathered there.

(Acts 16:14) 
A woman named Lydia, a seller of purple cloth from the city of Thyatira, was listening. She was a worshiper of God, and the Lord opened her heart to pay attention to what Paul said.

(Acts 16:15) 
After she and her household were baptized, she urged us, saying, “If you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come to my house and stay.” And she compelled us.

(Acts 16:16) 
One day as we were going to the place of prayer, we met a slave girl who had a spirit of divination and brought her owners a great profit by fortune-telling.

(Acts 16:17) 
Following Paul and us, she kept crying out, saying, “These men are servants of the Most High God, who proclaim to you the way of salvation.”

(Acts 16:18) 
And she kept doing this for many days. But Paul, becoming greatly annoyed, turned and said to the spirit, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her.” And it came out that very hour.

(Acts 16:19) 
But when her owners saw that their hope of profit was gone, they seized Paul and Silas and dragged them to the marketplace before the authorities.

(Acts 16:20) 
And when they had brought them to the magistrates, they said, “These men are disturbing our city. They are Jews,

(Acts 16:21) 
and are proclaiming customs that are not lawful for us Romans to accept or practice.”

(Acts 16:22) 
The crowd joined in attacking them, and the magistrates tore off their clothes and ordered them to be beaten with rods.

(Acts 16:23) 
And when they had inflicted many blows upon them, they threw them into prison, ordering the jailer to keep them safely.

(Acts 16:24) 
Having received this order, he put them into the inner prison and fastened their feet in the stocks.

(Acts 16:25) 
About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the other prisoners were listening to them.

(Acts 16:26) 
Suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken. And immediately all the doors were opened, and everyone’s bonds were unfastened.

(Acts 16:27) 
When the jailer woke up and saw that the prison doors were open, he drew his sword and was about to kill himself, supposing that the prisoners had escaped.

(Acts 16:28) 
But Paul cried with a loud voice, “Do not harm yourself, for we are all here.”

(Acts 16:29) 
And the jailer called for lights and rushed in, and trembling with fear, he fell down before Paul and Silas.

(Acts 16:30) 
Then he brought them out and said, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”

(Acts 16:31) 
And they said, “Believe in the Lord Jesus, and you will be saved, you and your household.”

(Acts 16:32) 
Then they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to all who were in his house.

(Acts 16:33) 
And he took them that very hour of the night and washed their wounds; and immediately he was baptized, he and all his household.

(Acts 16:34) 
Then he brought them up into his house and set food before them. And he rejoiced with all his household that he had believed in God.

(Acts 16:35) 
But when it was day, the magistrates sent the police to say, “Release those men.”

(Acts 16:36) 
And the jailer reported these words to Paul, saying, “The magistrates have sent to release you. Therefore, come out now and go in peace.”

(Acts 16:37) 
But Paul said to them, “They have beaten us publicly without a trial, men who are Roman citizens, and have thrown us into prison; and now they are secretly sending us away? No, let them come themselves and

(Acts 16:38) 
take us out.”

(Acts 16:39) 
The police reported these words to the magistrates, and they were afraid when they heard that they were Roman citizens.

(Acts 16:40) 
So they came and apologized to them. And they brought them out and asked them to leave the city.

(Acts 16:41) 
So they went out of the prison and entered the house of Lydia. And when they had seen the brothers, they encouraged them and departed.

(Acts 17:1) 
After Paul and Silas traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they arrived in Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.

(Acts 17:2) 
Paul then went into the synagogue, as was his custom. For three Sabbaths, he reasoned with them from the Scriptures,

(Acts 17:3) 
explaining and demonstrating that the Christ had to suffer, and to rise again from the dead. And he said, "This Jesus whom I announce to you is the Christ."

(Acts 17:4) 
Some of them were persuaded, and joined Paul and Silas, as did a large number of Gentile converts and many prominent women.

(Acts 17:5) 
But the Jews were jealous, and they gathered wicked men from the marketplace, and stirred up the city. They attacked the house of Jason, seeking to bring them out to the people.

(Acts 17:6) 
Not finding them, they dragged Jason and some of the brothers before the city authorities, shouting, "These men who have upset the world have come here too,

(Acts 17:7) 
and Jason has received them. They are all acting against the decrees of Caesar, saying that there is another king, Jesus."

(Acts 17:8) 
They stirred up the crowd and the city authorities who heard these things.

(Acts 17:9) 
After taking security from Jason and the others, they let them go.

(Acts 17:10) 
The brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas away by night to Beroea. When they arrived, they went into the Jewish synagogue.

(Acts 17:11) 
These Jews were more noble than those in Thessalonica, because they received the word with all eagerness, examining the Scriptures daily to see if these things were so.

(Acts 17:12) 
Many of them therefore believed, as did quite a few of the distinguished Greek women and many men.

(Acts 17:13) 
But when the Jews from Thessalonica learned that the word of God was preached by Paul in Beroea also, they came there too, stirring up and disturbing the crowds.

(Acts 17:14) 
Then the brothers immediately sent Paul away to go as far as the sea, but Silas and Timothy remained there.

(Acts 17:15) 
Those who escorted Paul brought him to Athens. After receiving a command for Silas and Timothy to come to him as soon as possible, they departed.

(Acts 17:16) 
Now while Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit was provoked within him as he saw that the city was full of idols.

(Acts 17:17) 
So he reasoned in the synagogue with the Jews and the devout persons, and in the marketplace every day with those who happened to be there.

(Acts 17:18) 
Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also debated with him. Some said, "What does this babbler want to say?" Others said, "He seems to be a preacher of foreign divinities," because he was preaching about Jesus and the resurrection.

(Acts 17:19) 
And they took him and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, "May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting?

(Acts 17:20) 
For you bring some strange things to our ears. We want to know therefore what these things mean."

(Acts 17:21) 
Now all the Athenians and the foreigners who lived there would spend their time in nothing except telling or hearing something new.

(Acts 17:22) 
So Paul, standing in the midst of the Areopagus, said, "Men of Athens, I perceive that in all things you are very religious.

(Acts 17:23) 
For as I passed along and observed the objects of your worship, I found also an altar with this inscription, 'To the unknown god.' What therefore you worship as unknown, this I proclaim to you.

(Acts 17:24) 
The God who made the world and everything in it, being Lord of the universe and the earth, does not live in temples made by hands,

(Acts 17:25) 
nor is he served by human hands, as though he needed anything, since he himself gives to all mankind life and breath and everything.

(Acts 17:26) 
And he made from one man every nation of mankind to live on all the face of the earth, having determined allotted periods and the boundaries of their dwelling place,

(Acts 17:27) 
that they should seek God, and perhaps feel their way toward him and find him. Yet he is actually not far from each one of us,

(Acts 17:28) 
for "'In him we live and move and have our being'; as even some of your own poets have said, 'For we are indeed his offspring.'

(Acts 17:29) 
Being then God's offspring, we ought not to think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone, an image formed by the art and imagination of man.

(Acts 17:30) 
The times of ignorance therefore God overlooked, but now he commands all people everywhere to repent,

(Acts 17:31) 
because he has fixed a day on which he will judge the world in righteousness by a man whom he has appointed; and of this he has given assurance to all by raising him from the dead."

(Acts 17:32) 
Now when they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some mocked. But others said, "We will hear you again about this."

(Acts 17:33) 
So Paul went out from their midst.

(Acts 17:34) 
But some men joined him and believed, among whom also were Dionysius the Areopagite and a woman named Damaris and others with them.

(Acts 18:1) 
After these things, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.

(Acts 18:2) 
And when he found a certain Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently come from Italy, and Priscilla his wife (because Claudius had ordered all Jews to depart from Rome), he went to them.

(Acts 18:3) 
And because he practiced the same trade, he stayed with them and worked; for they were tentmakers.

(Acts 18:4) 
And he reasoned in the synagogue every Sabbath, explaining the name of Jesus, and persuading Jews and Greeks.

(Acts 18:5) 
But when Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was pressed by the word, testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the Christ.

(Acts 18:6) 
But when they opposed and blasphemed, he shook his garments and said to them: “Your blood be upon your own heads; I am clean. From now on I will go to the Gentiles.”

(Acts 18:7) 
And he departed from there and went to the house of a certain man named Titus Justus, a worshiper of God, whose house was next door to the synagogue.

(Acts 18:8) 
And Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed in the Lord with all his house. And many of the Corinthians hearing, believed and were baptized.

(Acts 18:9) 
And the Lord said to Paul in the night by a vision: “Do not be afraid, but speak and do not keep silent;

(Acts 18:10) 
for I am with you, and no one will attack you to harm you, for I have many people in this city.”

(Acts 18:11) 
And he stayed there a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.

(Acts 18:12) 
But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews with one accord rose up against Paul and brought him to the judgment seat,

(Acts 18:13) 
saying: “This fellow persuades men to worship God contrary to the law.”

(Acts 18:14) 
And when Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews: “If there were any act of wrongdoing or a wicked crime, O Jews, I would have reason to hear you.

(Acts 18:15) 
But if there are questions of words and names and your law, you yourselves look to it. I will not be a judge of these things.”

(Acts 18:16) 
And he drove them from the judgment seat.

(Acts 18:17) 
Then all the Greeks seized Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and beat him before the judgment seat. But Gallio was not concerned about any of these things.

(Acts 18:18) 
Then Paul, after staying many more days, took leave of the brothers and sailed away to Syria, and with him Priscilla and Aquila, having cut his hair in Cenchreae; for he had a vow.

(Acts 18:19) 
And he came to Ephesus, and he left them there. But he himself entered the synagogue and reasoned with the Jews.

(Acts 18:20) 
When they asked him to stay longer, he did not consent,

(Acts 18:21) 
but took leave of them, saying: “I must by all means keep this coming feast in Jerusalem. But I will return again to you, God willing.” And he set out from Ephesus.

(Acts 18:22) 
And when he had come down to Caesarea, he went up and greeted the church, and then he went down to Antioch.

(Acts 18:23) 
And having spent some time there, he departed and went through the region of Galatia and Phrygia in order, strengthening all the disciples.

(Acts 18:24) 
Now a certain Jew named Apollos, an Alexandrian by birth, an eloquent man, came to Ephesus, mighty in the Scriptures.

(Acts 18:25) 
This man was instructed in the way of the Lord, and being fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately the things concerning Jesus, knowing only the baptism of John.

(Acts 18:26) 
And he began to speak boldly in the synagogue. But when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him and explained to him the way of God more accurately.

(Acts 18:27) 
And when he wanted to pass over to Achaia, the brothers wrote, exhorting the disciples to receive him. When he arrived, he greatly helped those who had believed,

(Acts 18:28) 
for he vigorously refuted the Jews publicly, showing by the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ.

(Acts 19:1) 
After Apollos had moved on to Corinth, Paul traveled through the upper regions and came to Ephesus. There, he found some disciples,

(Acts 19:2) 
and he said to them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?” They replied, “We haven’t even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”

(Acts 19:3) 
He asked them, “Then how were you baptized?” They answered, “With John's baptism.”

(Acts 19:4) 
Paul then said, “John baptized with a baptism of repentance, telling the people to believe in the one who was to come after him, that is, Jesus.”

(Acts 19:5) 
After hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.

(Acts 19:6) 
And when Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they began speaking in tongues and prophesying.

(Acts 19:7) 
There were about twelve men in all.

(Acts 19:8) 
He entered the synagogue, and for three months he spoke boldly, debating and persuading people about the kingdom of God.

(Acts 19:9) 
But when some of them hardened themselves and refused to believe, speaking evil of the Way before the crowd, he left them, and separated the disciples, arguing daily in the school of Tyrannus.

(Acts 19:10) 
This continued for two years, so that all the inhabitants of Asia heard the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Greeks.

(Acts 19:11) 
And God worked extraordinary miracles by the hands of Paul,

(Acts 19:12) 
so that when they placed handkerchiefs or aprons that had touched his body on the sick, their diseases left them, and the evil spirits came out of them.

(Acts 19:13) 
Then some itinerant Jewish exorcists tried to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits, saying, “I adjure you by the Jesus whom Paul preaches.”

(Acts 19:14) 
There were seven sons of a Jewish high priest named Sceva who were doing this.

(Acts 19:15) 
But the evil spirit answered them, “Jesus I know, and Paul I know, but who are you?”

(Acts 19:16) 
And the man with the evil spirit leaped on them, overpowered them all, and they ran out of the house naked and wounded.

(Acts 19:17) 
This became known to everyone in Ephesus, both Jews and Greeks. Fear fell on them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.

(Acts 19:18) 
Many of those who had believed came, confessing and divulging their practices.

(Acts 19:19) 
And a number of those who had practiced magic arts brought their books together and burned them in front of everyone. When they calculated the value of the books, they found that it came to fifty thousand pieces of silver.

(Acts 19:20) 
So the word of the Lord continued to grow and prevail.

(Acts 19:21) 
Now after these events, Paul decided in the Spirit to go through Macedonia and Achaia and then to go to Jerusalem, saying, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome.”

(Acts 19:22) 
So he sent two of his assistants, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, while he himself stayed in Asia for a while.

(Acts 19:23) 
About that time, there arose a considerable disturbance concerning the Way.

(Acts 19:24) 
For a man named Demetrius, a silversmith, who made silver shrines of Artemis, was bringing no little business to the artisans.

(Acts 19:25) 
He gathered them together with the workmen of similar trades and said, “Men, you know that our prosperity depends on this business.

(Acts 19:26) 
You also see and hear that not only in Ephesus but in almost the whole of Asia, this Paul has persuaded and turned away a great many people, saying that gods made with hands are not gods.

(Acts 19:27) 
And there is danger not only that this trade of ours may be discredited, but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis may be counted as nothing, and that she whom all of Asia and the world worship will be dethroned from her magnificence.”

(Acts 19:28)
